webTitle: Jordan rebuilds fragile Palace

fields.headline: Jordan rebuilds fragile Palace
fields.standfirst:
New owner has given the club heart and strength to take on Liverpool tonight

Fowler snubbed for Worthington Cup semi-final
fields.trailText: Preview Crystal Palace's new owner has given the club heart and strength to take on Liverpool tonight.
fields.body:
Beset with financial and managerial tribulations, Crystal Palace have recently seemed to possess a fragility resembling that of their namesake, the soaring, delicate greenhouse designed by Joe Paxton 150 years ago.

In recent months, however, with the arrival of their new, motormouth owner Simon Jordan, the south London club have taken on a more down-to-earth - not to say earthy - persona. Anyone in any doubt about that should consult the former manager Steve Coppell, sent packing in July after a series of pre-season defeats, and his replacement by Alan Smith.

The speedy departure of Coppell, who had a deep history with the club, disappointed many supporters, though they may have changed their minds when Palace started to reverse their dismal early-season form. They have beaten the Premiership sides Leicester and Sunderland and turned around their form in the First Division.

Jordan says: "Steve and I did not click. I paid £10m for this club when no one was lining up behind me to buy it. And Steve wanted to have 100% autonomy without any pressure or responsibility.

"I don't want to pick the team but I do want to know what's going on. And if the wrong decisions are being made I want to help. We lost three pre-seasons 5-1, 4-0 and 6-0. That's not right. That's atrocious.

"I told Steve so and he felt that my management style was going to be difficult to work with. He also said I wouldn't get on with Alan. Wrong. And he said I wouldn't spend £3m on players. I've spent £7m."

Jordan says he will spend the £15m he feels is required to win promotion next season and is looking for a top-10 finish this time. "Like me or loathe me but I'm not a bullshitter. I'm direct but I'm also a decent, honest guy who does what I say I'll do."

Coppell may have been the first to feel the weight of Jordan's personality but his replacement can be under few illusions either. "You need to be strong when you're dealing with someone like Alan Smith. He's a strong man too, arrogant in views. He will undermine me and usurp me. But he knows I won't pull any punches.

"I won't tell him what team to pick but I have talked to him about man management. It's no good giving a team a bollocking when they play badly and then getting carried away when they do well. There will be consistency here."

The 32-year-old self-made millionaire, who is reported to have accumulated £75m from the mobile phone business, has Palace in his roots. Born locally, he signed schoolboy forms with both Palace and Chelsea and was coached by Terry Venables.

"Let's face it," says the 32-year-old, "we've been a lairy club for 30 years, from Malcolm Allison and his fedora to Terry Venables and all his escapades, right up to [Mark] Goldberg and Venables again.

"We were the team of the 80s and bang, we imploded. We came up in the 90s, reached the Cup semi-final and were third in the league, and we imploded again. Then Goldberg came in with a lot of puff and stuff and we imploded again. My job is to ensure it doesn't happen again."

He feels that his direct, shoot-from-the-hip management style is one way to achieve this end. "Earlier on in the season, when we had all the vile and bile from the fans, I went into the changing room after the game and made it clear to the players that they would go before the coach or manager departed. Then I made it clear to Alan that he needed to do something that hadn't been done before. He needed to get the players' respect."

Wearing a pullover and toiling away in a Portakabin, Jordan does not look your everyday multi-millionaire. But he is young, strong-minded and ambitious for his club. "I know that Palace can be as big as Chelsea, who were in our position 10 years ago but who now are one of the biggest clubs in Europe. But I don't like this thing in football where people talk about what they're going to do. When I ran PocketPhone I waited four years before I did an interview explaining what I had done."

The first thing Jordan did at Palace was spend £250,000 on refurbishing the club bar. Then he cut beer prices from £3 to £2.

"Then there were people accusing me of being gimmicky and of trying to buy popularity. Well, I don't need to do that. I ran a successful business with a big staff and believe I have the ability to lead from the front. I can make decisions and also give others the confidence to make decisions. I eat, sleep and shit football, because that is what you have to do to be successful."

webTitle: Fowler left to lick his wounds

fields.headline: Fowler left to lick his wounds
fields.standfirst: Jordan rebuilds fragile Palace
fields.trailText: If Robbie Fowler was seeking confirmation that he is now Liverpool's fourth-choice striker it arrived yesterday in the form of an embarrassing snub, writes Ian Ross .
fields.body:
If Robbie Fowler was seeking confirmation that he is now Liverpool's fourth-choice striker it arrived yesterday in the form of an embarrassing snub, writes Ian Ross .

The troubled striker was left out of Liverpool's squad for tonight's Worthington Cup semi-final first-leg tie at Crystal Palace.

Fowler had barely time to digest the news when it was announced that the Merseyside club's latest recruit, the Finland forward Jari Litmanen, will almost certainly feature at some point in tonight's game.

Fowler, who was omitted on fitness grounds, will need no reminding that Litmanen has yet to play a senior game this season after the close-season change of coach at Barcelona, a saga which precipitated his free transfer to Anfield last week.

Fowler and Litmanen played in a reserve fixture on Monday night and though Fowler scored, it was not sufficient to convince the manager, Gérard Houllier, that he is worthy of a place this evening.

Last week Fowler was assaulted in the city centre for the second time in two years. However Houllier, who has turned down a £12m bid from Chelsea, remains adamant that he would like Fowler to stay.

"He is not being frozen out," Houllier said. "This is no punishment because what happened to him last week was a very nasty and unprovoked attack. He is not available for this game because I have decided he's not available. He will train for the rest of the week and then we will see how he is."

webTitle: News round-up

fields.headline: News round-up
fields.trailText: Coventry's manager Gordon Strachan hopes to complete the £5m signing of John Hartson from Wimbledon by the weekend as he attempts to cure his side's chronic scoring problems.
fields.body:
Coventry's manager Gordon Strachan hopes to complete the £5m signing of John Hartson from Wimbledon by the weekend as he attempts to cure his side's chronic scoring problems.

Hartson would form an all-Welsh strike partnership with Coventry's £6.5m record signing Craig Bellamy after the Sky Blues improved their offer for the former West Ham player.

City have shown improved form in recent weeks and are unbeaten in five league and cup matches, but a failure to find the net is undermining that revival and they have scored just 21 goals in 22 matches.

Strachan is understood to have originally offered the First Division club £2.5m plus the out-of-favour defender Richard Shaw in exchange for Hartson.

But Wimbledon would be happier with a straight cash deal, receiving £3m now and the rest in instalments.

Coventry hope to have Hartson, who has seen moves to Tottenham and Rangers fail on medical grounds over the past year, signed in time for Saturday's game at Newcastle.

A Wimbledon spokesman confirmed Coventry's offer for Hartson but would not comment further "until the fat lady sings".

Aston Villa's finance director Mark Ansell is adamant the long-term future of the club will not be jeopardised by a quick-fix attempt to secure a Champions League place.

So John Gregory will not be allowed to spend more than the budgeted £10m to sign the likes of Liverpool's £15m-rated striker Robbie Fowler.

Manchester City should complete the £100,000 signing of Stockport's goalkeeper Carlo Nash today.

Wolverhampton Wanderers' new manager Dave Jones made a late offer but he appears to have lost out. Nash said last night: "I haven't spoken to Wolves. I'm waiting to finalise things with City and that should hopefully happen tomorrow. My ambition has always been to play in the Premiership."

Southampton's defender Francis Benali is set to join injury-hit Nottingham Forest on a month's loan. The 32-year-old former Saints captain is set to make his debut in Sunday's league game against Crystal Palace at the City Ground.

Ryan Giggs is about to be rewarded for his service to Manchester United with a testimonial. Preliminary talks have already taken place with the 27-year-old Welsh international and an announcement is likely in the next few weeks.

webTitle: Udinese move for Carbone

fields.headline: Udinese move for Carbone
fields.trailText: Benito Carbone is to be offered the chance of a quick departure from Bradford City after Udinese opened talks about taking the striker back to Italy.
fields.body:
Benito Carbone is to be offered the chance of a quick departure from Bradford City after Udinese opened talks about taking the striker back to Italy.

Geoffrey Richmond, the Bradford chairman, disclosed last night that negotiations were being held with the Serie A club. Along with Stan Collymore and Dan Petrescu, Carbone has been told he has no future at Valley Parade, although Bradford will want at least £2m for the 29-year-old.

If they can reach an agreement, Udinese will become the 11th professional club on Carbone's curriculum vitae.

Talks have broken down about a possible loan deal for Petrescu to Preston, with the Romanian saying he wants to see out his Bradford contract.

webTitle: The Eriksson era starts at the double

fields.headline: The Eriksson era starts at the double
fields.standfirst:
David Lacey comment
Football Unlimited comment
Graphic: Sven's career in full
fields.trailText: Having stepped out of the frying pan, Sven-Goran Eriksson will jump straight into the fire. The Football Association announced last night that the Swede will start the England job this week after resigning as coach of Lazio yesterday.
fields.body:
Having stepped out of the frying pan, Sven-Goran Eriksson will jump straight into the fire. The Football Association announced last night that the Swede will start the England job this week after resigning as coach of Lazio yesterday.

Eriksson will begin his preparations for next month's friendly at home to Spain by watching two Premiership matches this weekend. Sunday's will be Ipswich v Leicester, whose manager Peter Taylor remains on the coaching team with Steve McClaren and Tord Grip.

A chat with the media comes first, most likely tomorrow, at the FA's Soho Square headquarters, where "delighted" and "excited" officials expressed "relief" yesterday, hardly surprising given that Eriksson was not expected to start full-time until July 1.

Now the 52-year-old has the Spain game at Villa Park on February 28 as preparation and plenty of time to plan for the crucial games against Finland and Albania in March. If there is concern at the FA that Eriksson will arrive smelling of failure after losing his way at Lazio, it was not apparent.

"He's one of the top three or four coaches in the world," said the chief executive Adam Crozier, pointing to the titles won in Italy, Portugal and Sweden. "What we are buying into is what he's achieved over the last 15 years. Anyone who looks just at the last nine weeks is being pretty daft.

"That's the sort of short-term thinking that has ended up with England having something like six managers in the last 10 years, and that's what we have to move away from."

Crozier received a telephone call from Eriksson informing him of the resignation as he drank a mid-morning cup of coffee. "He simply said, 'I've thought this through, I think this is right for everyone,'" said Crozier, who described the time since Eriksson was chosen as "like treading water".

That is what Lazio have been doing, slipping 11 points behind the Serie A leaders Roma, going out of the Italian Cup and sitting bottom of their Champions League group.

It was after a 2-1 home defeat by struggling Napoli on Sunday and two meetings with the club president Sergio Cragnotti the following day that Eriksson resigned. He went to bed on Monday night thinking over his future and decided to quit yesterday as he drove to Lazio's Formello training ground. His players were the first to be told.

"I analysed that [Napoli] match in my head and I thought it was better to resign for the team's future," Eriksson said. "I am really upset with what has happened. I would have done this even if I had not taken the England job."

Eriksson stayed in Rome last night to attend Lazio's friendly against China and received a welcome which reduced him to tears. On the pitch the team and Cragnotti presented him with the Scudetto trophy he won last season. He is succeeded by the former Italy coach Dino Zoff.

Crozier did not deny that the Swede's uncertain future had destabilised Lazio, and Taylor welcomed his arrival, despite losing control of the Spain match. "It would have been nice to have been in charge," he said, "but at least I've done the job for one game [November's 1-0 defeat in Italy] and what is in the best interests of England is what counts."

John Barnwell and Gordon Taylor, chief executives of the League Managers' Association and Professional Footballers' Association, offered their support, despite opposing the appointment of a foreign coach. But there were sober words of warning from Crozier.

"We are bottom of our World Cup qualifying group, we haven't looked like winning a major championship for quite some time and we have a long way to go," he said. "The first job is to try to qualify for this World Cup." Sven-Goran Eriksson, welcome to England.

Jun 6 v Greece (a)

webTitle: Eriksson's bad run is good news for England

fields.headline: Eriksson's bad run is good news for England
fields.trailText: Eriksson's portentous departure from Lazio can only mean light at the end of the tunnel for England.
fields.body:
Coming suddenly, coming soon, coming certainly night or noon... If Adam Crozier had led a Football Association choir around Soho Square yesterday in an impromptu rendition of the old Sunday school song few need have been surprised.

From England's point of view Sven-Goran Eriksson's resignation as Lazio coach, which has enabled him to take up his post as Kevin Keegan's successor six months early, could hardly have been better timed had the FA's chief executive planned it that way.

When Eriksson's appointment as England coach from July 1 was announced at the end of October all the signs were that the FA wanted its man in position sooner if at all possible. In this respect Crozier was always going to be a hostage to Lazio's fortunes.

The ransom which has had to be paid involves any doubts about Eriksson's suitability which may have arisen from Lazio's subsequent decline in the Italian league and the two defeats in the second round of the Champions League which have left them bottom of their group.

When Leeds United beat Eriksson's team 1-0 in Rome just over a month ago it was assumed that his arrival to take charge of England had been hurried along more than somewhat, but there was no escaping the fact that the coach appointed to succeed Kevin Keegan because he was a habitual winner had now become a loser. In the end Lazio did not sack Eriksson but left him alone in a room with a revolver handy.

Yet the 52-year-old Swede is no less the coach the FA considered him to be when it gave him the job. Lazio have lost six of their last nine matches but that alone does not amount to a case against Eriksson's tactical acumen or his ability to organise and reorganise a team during the course of a game.

Players, not managers or coaches, lose football matches and England's need for someone who can, in 2001, restore confidence and success to a side badly battered by the events of 2000 is paramount. Eriksson's early availability gives England a much better chance finally to clear up the mess of doubt and uncertainty left by Keegan's peremptory resignation following the 1-0 home defeat by Germany on October 7 in their opening World Cup qualifier.

The scoreless draw England forced in Finland four days later under Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director who was left temporarily in charge, may yet turn out to be a useful result. But Wilko's hypothesis that the next England coach might want to pass up qualifying for the 2002 World Cup to concentrate on 2006 was ill-received and in any case rejected by Eriksson at his first press conference.

Had Eriksson seen out his contract with Lazio until the end of June the FA would doubtless have left team matters to Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren, respectively manager of Leicester City and assistant manager of Manchester United. Taylor's commonsense approach delighted the media after Keegan's cheerleading but a part-time partnership for three World Cup games was never the ideal way to set about restoring the early damage to England's hopes of qualifying.

Although there were signs of improvement in the team's passing and movement when Taylor deliberately selected players of 30 or under for the friendly in Turin the performance was hardly conclusive and in any case England lost that game to a half-interested Italy.

The FA may still feel that the Leicester manager could be an England coach in waiting and want to keep him involved with the national squad, but the exercise is now essentially Swedish with English accoutrements - a bit like a Volvo with headlamp bulbs by Lucas.

Continuity in England teams is never achieved easily and the internationals in February and March - first the friendly with Spain at Villa Park, then the World Cup qualifiers against Finland at Anfield and Albania in Tirana - will be played against a busy club background in the Premiership and Champion League. Yet by the time England play in Greece on June 6 Eriksson will need to know his best side.

Doubtless he will use his extra half-season as England coach confirming the reports on players he has been receiving from Tord Grip, his Swedish scout. But the who and the how of England under Eriksson will only be revealed when his new charges first take the field against Spain in seven weeks' time.

Like every other manager or coach Eriksson will be judged on results, but anyone tempted to prejudge him on Lazio's present poor form should remember that the FA once appointed a man whose team had won the championship the previous season but came into the job on the back of an early departure from the European Cup and a slump in the league which had seen them lose at home the previous month 5-3 and 5-1.

The club was Ipswich, the manager Alf Ramsey.

If Adam Crozier had led a Football Association choir around Soho Square yesterday in an impromptu rendition of the old Sunday school song few need have been surprised. From England's point of view Sven-Goran Eriksson's resignation as Lazio coach, which has enabled him to take up his post as Kevin Keegan's successor six months early, could hardly have been better timed had the FA's chief executive planned it that way. When Eriksson's appointment as England coach from July 1 was announced at the end of October all the signs were that the FA wanted its man in position sooner if at all possible. In this respect Crozier was always going to be a hostage to Lazio's fortunes. The ransom which has had to be paid involves any doubts about Eriksson's suitability which may have arisen from Lazio's subsequent decline in the Italian league and the two defeats in the second round of the Champions League which have left them bottom of their group. When Leeds United beat Eriksson's team 1-0 in Rome just over a month ago it was assumed that his arrival to take charge of England had been hurried along more than somewhat, but there was no escaping the fact that the coach appointed to succeed Kevin Keegan because he was a habitual winner had now become a loser. In the end Lazio did not sack Eriksson but left him alone in a room with a revolver handy. Yet the 52-year-old Swede is no less the coach the FA considered him to be when it gave him the job. Lazio have lost six of their last nine matches but that alone does not amount to a case against Eriksson's tactical acumen or his ability to organise and reorganise a team during the course of a game. Players, not managers or coaches, lose football matches and England's need for someone who can, in 2001, restore confidence and success to a side badly battered by the events of 2000 is paramount. Eriksson's early availability gives England a much better chance finally to clear up the mess of doubt and uncertainty left by Keegan's peremptory resignation following the 1-0 home defeat by Germany on October 7 in their opening World Cup qualifier. The scoreless draw England forced in Finland four days later under Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director who was left temporarily in charge, may yet turn out to be a useful result. But Wilko's hypothesis that the next England coach might want to pass up qualifying for the 2002 World Cup to concentrate on 2006 was ill-received and in any case rejected by Eriksson at his first press conference. Had Eriksson seen out his contract with Lazio until the end of June the FA would doubtless have left team matters to Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren, respectively manager of Leicester City and assistant manager of Manchester United. Taylor's commonsense approach delighted the media after Keegan's cheerleading but a part-time partnership for three World Cup games was never the ideal way to set about restoring the early damage to England's hopes of qualifying. Although there were signs of improvement in the team's passing and movement when Taylor deliberately selected players of 30 or under for the friendly in Turin the performance was hardly conclusive and in any case England lost that game to a half-interested Italy. The FA may still feel that the Leicester manager could be an England coach in waiting and want to keep him involved with the national squad, but the exercise is now essentially Swedish with English accoutrements - a bit like a Volvo with headlamp bulbs by Lucas. Continuity in England teams is never achieved easily and the internationals in February and March - first the friendly with Spain at Villa Park, then the World Cup qualifiers against Finland at Anfield and Albania in Tirana - will be played against a busy club background in the Premiership and Champion League. Yet by the time England play in Greece on June 6 Eriksson will need to know his best side. Doubtless he will use his extra half-season as England coach confirming the reports on players he has been receiving from Tord Grip, his Swedish scout. But the who and the how of England under Eriksson will only be revealed when his new charges first take the field against Spain in seven weeks' time. Like every other manager or coach Eriksson will be judged on results, but anyone tempted to prejudge him on Lazio's present poor form should remember that the FA once appointed a man whose team had won the championship the previous season but came into the job on the back of an early departure from the European Cup and a slump in the league which had seen them lose at home the previous month 5-3 and 5-1. The club was Ipswich, the manager Alf Ramsey.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Crystal Palace 2 - 1 Liverpool

fields.headline: Crystal Palace 2 - 1 Liverpool
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Crystal Palace: Kolinko, Austin, Harrison, Zhiyi, Rubins, Rodger, Smith, Thomson, Morrison, Mullins, Forssell. Subs: Gregg, Gray, Carlisle, Frampton, Pollock.

Liverpool: Westerveld, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher, Biscan, Babbel, Gerrard, Murphy, Barmby, Heskey, Owen. Subs: Nielsen, Hamann, Litmanen, Smicer, McAllister.

Referee: U Rennie (Sheffield)

1 Liverpool kick off the first leg of this Worthington Cup semi-final. Palace are seeking to underline their recovering season by taking a step closer to Europe tonight, but they will have their work cut against a Liverpool side hoping to reach their eighth League Cup final.
2 A lot of early pressure from Liverpool. Zhiyi almost gets into trouble when Heskey mugs him in the box, allowing Owen to spurn an early chance at goal.
4 Liverpool running after everything; Palace finally win a throw but Morrison is unable to control the ball.
5 A good - but brief - spell for Palace after they break with Rodger through the middle to Morrison. Carragher clears, but gives the ball away. It finds its way back to Morrison deep on the right, but Forssell can't connect with the cross.
7 Heskey's cross from the right is cleared by Zhiyi before Biscan attempts to fire in a shot from distance. Rodger blocks.
10 Morrison cuts inside from the left but Hyppia clears well. Liverpool break with Heskey down the right. He crosses for Owen in space inside the area but the Liverpool striker snatches at the shot and puts it over. Ouch!
15 Heskey doing his best to chase everything, but turns provider when he slides a beautiful ball through to Owen from just outside the centre circle. Owen runs on, but ends up passing to keeper Kolinko as he tries to turn inside Zhiyi.
18 Palace living dangerously and giving the ball away far to much.
19 Heskey unlucky to be called offside when trying to meet an Owen flick-on from the half-way line.
21 Palace battle their way into the Liverpool half for a couple of throws down the right before a decision goes Liverpool's way and Houllier's men break again.
22 Another shocker as a second sitter goes begging for Liverpool. Gerard shrugs off Rubins on the half-way line and lobs the ball over the top to release Heskey. And guess what? Heskey puts it over. Palace's night maybe.
23 Indeed it could be as great work by Austin in the Liverpool area opens the game up for the home side.
26 The crowd crank it up as Forssell crosses from the left to Morrison. Morrison shoots with his right from just outside the area to force a flying save by Westerveld.
27 Forssell has a great chance to score but can only win a corner. Austin charges into the area to head just wide of the far post.
31 Great spell for Palace as they win a free-kick 30 yards out. Rodger takes but the ball is cleared after a brief spell of head tennis.
32 Smith tries to find Austin on the far post from deep on the right but Liverpool clear.
33 Heskey and Owen play a lovely double one-two on the edge of the Palace area, but the keeper comes out to claim as Owen turns goes for goal.
38 Palace win a free-kick - high and deep into the area. Liverpool clear as far as Thompson; he finds Mullins deep on the right, who crosses for Morrison to shoot early and high from the edge of the area when he should have waited for the ball come down.
43 Where everything was going Liverpool's way early in the half, every ball that bounces now appears to be going to Palace.
45 Liverpool work the ball around the Palace half. Murphy holds it up on the edge of the area before laying it back for Gerard to shoot wide of the left-hand upright. The half winds up with Owen breaking into the area shadowed by the ever-present Zhiyi, who forces the Liverpool striker to poke the ball wide of the near post. Half-time Palace have recovered well. The game is now evenly balanced and Liverpool have only themselves to blame for not having wrapped things up already.

46 Palace get the second half underway with a punt up to Westerveld in the Liverpool goal.
48 Palace corner from the left; played short and then centred for Austin to shoot - comes to nothing.
49 Carragher plays Owen into the Palace area but Zhiyi forces him out to the touchline.
50 Owen unlucky not to get on the end of Heskey's flick-on from the edge of the area before Zhiyi clears.
53 Liverpool break to the edge of the area for Gerard to shoot early; Kolinko saves.
54 Owen finally gets away from Zhiyi but can only hit Kolinko's legs as he tries to lift it over. Resulting corner comes to nothing.
56 GOAL: Crystal Palace 1 - 0 Liverpool Henchoz the culprit as he gives the ball away in his own area. Rubins charges away to the left and shoots early with his left to beat Westerveld at the far post. A blinder.
59 Free-kick to Palace after Morrison is hacked down by Henchoz 30 yards out. Comes to nothing.
61 Liverpool break, but Palace chase well to clear before Hyppia plays in an offside Barmby to shoot wide.
62 Forssell ducks and dives into the Liverpool area before shooting a yard wide of the far post.
64 Substitutions Litmanen and Smicer on for Murphy and Owen.
67 Free-kick to Liverpool just outside the Palace area but the home sdie clear with ease. Palace then wiin a free-kick deep on the right but it comes to nothing.
70 Liverpool miss two golden chances in a row. Barmby's the greatest clanger when he fails the score when one on one with Kolinko. Litmanen provided the pass but then makes a hash of his second attempt after Barmby's miss.
73 Liverpool now effectively playing four up front with Barmby coming straight through the middle. Not that it does much good as Palace dig themselves into the Liverpool half with Houllier's men unable to clear.
77 GOAL: Crystal Palace 2 - 0 Liverpool Palace pressure plays off as Forssell stops dead a cross just inside the area for Morrison to put Palace two up.
78 GOAL: Crystal Palace 2 - 1 Liverpool Litmanen the provider as he races to the by-line and pulls the ball back from just inside the area for Smicer to bring some respectability to Liverpool's visit to South London.
84 Liverpool belatedly get themselves together in search of a result and Palace are left chasing shadows as they try and hold out for the final whistle.
86 Dodgy moment for Liverpool as Henchoz clears a Morrison cross from the hands of Westerveld.
90 Palace refusing to give up as they attempt to keep the ball in the Liverpool half. Two minutes extra to play. Palace corner comes to nothing but the ball finds its way back into the area for Forssell to direct a weak header at Westerveld.
Full-time

webTitle: Prokas receives official warning

fields.headline: Prokas receives official warning
fields.trailText: The Football Association intends to visit the Carlisle United midfielder Richard Prokas tomorrow and warn him as to his future conduct following his two-footed tackle on Patrick Vieira.
fields.body:
The Football Association intends to visit the Carlisle United midfielder Richard Prokas tomorrow and warn him as to his future conduct following his two-footed tackle on Patrick Vieira.

Adrian Bevington, the FA spokesman, said: "We clearly do not condone such actions on the field of play and will be making it abundantly clear to Richard Prokas that we don't expect to see such action at any time in the future."

Prokas, meanwhile, has publicly apologised to Patrick Vieira for his two-footed lunge.

Prokas, who was not penalised for the challenge during Saturday's third round FA Cup tie, had kept a low profile since the incident and left Brunton Park without showering when the hot water failed in the visitors' dressing room and the two teams had to share the home facilities.

"Richard Prokas regrets the incident last Saturday and certainly did not intend to injure Patrick Vieira," read a statement issued on behalf of the 24-year-old. "He regards Vieira as the best midfield player in the Premiership and particularly admires his competitive qualities.

"However, Richard accepts that his challenge for the ball was mistimed and would like to apologise to Patrick. At the same time he will be seeking to speak privately with Patrick to offer him his personal apologies and best wishes for the future."

Arsenal fans may have to wait months for their first glimpse of the £6m Brazilian midfielder Edu in action even if his on-off move to Highbury is completed this week.

"Even if we do sign him it is unlikely he will play a real part in our plans for this season," said the manager Arsène Wenger. "It can take a Brazilian player as much as six months to adapt to life in England and the Premiership."

The former AC Milan and Italy coach Arrigo Sacchi was appointed as the new coach of Parma. Sacchi, who coached the club in the mid-80s, returns to Serie A on the same day as another former Italy coach, Dino Zoff, who takes over at Lazio, following Sven-Goran Eriksson's resignation.

"Of course I am worried about failing because it is difficult to take over in the middle of a season, but like Zoff I am addicted to football," Sacchi said. "We have got a good side here, but I'm not going to make any promises."

More than 15,000 Napoli fans filled one of the stands at the San Paolo stadium to welcome Brazilian new signing Edmundo - the first player to be presented at the club since Diego Maradona. Napoli have taken the controversial 29-year-old on loan from Vasco da Gama for the rest of the season with a £5m option to buy.

Charlton's leading scorer Jonatan Johansson needs an operation on his right knee which could keep him out for a month.

Liverpool's fourth round Uefa Cup tie against the current Serie A leaders Roma will be shown live on BBC1 at 8.15pm on Thursday, February 15.

webTitle: The truth is that voters will only get what they pay for

fields.headline: The truth is that voters will only get what they pay for
fields.standfirst: The major parties should come clean on taxation and spending
fields.trailText: The major parties should come clean on taxation and spending
fields.body:
Election time is upon us, season of lists of doubtful truthfulness. One thousand Tory posters went up all over the country bearing the message: "You paid the tax, so where's all the money gone?" William Hague's speech, using his usual quaintly dated slang, claimed the people have been "clobbered" by Labour taxes. Meanwhile down in Bristol Tony Blair opened fire with his own list of facts, enumerating all Labour's triumphs so far.

Here is the shape of the election to come, to be fought as a tug of war between lower tax and higher public spending. Or so it should be. But in these opening stages both sides are trying to tug on both ends of the rope, each pointing eagerly to the other's contradictions. The Tories chant that there is too little to show for all the high expectations and extra tax levied by Labour. They have a point, with so much still left undone. But every time they point to the famines and chasms in public services, they remind the voter of 18 years of private tax cuts and public neglect. Every time they promise "a Conservative government will reduce taxes", the ghost of Tory public services past looms.

But Labour's riposte is hamstrung by its own ambivalence on tax. Gordon Brown remains unable to admit in public or to the Treasury select committee that he has actually put up taxes, let alone that tax is a public good. Instead his people stick to his old mantra, the three Brownite objectives - low and stable interest rates, more public investment and then - yes, it's still there - "affordable tax cuts". What is an "affordable tax cut" when Labour's own slogan admits there is still so much to do? No tax cut is affordable in this under-taxed, under-spent land unless it is a redistribution of the current burden from the broadest shoulders of the highest earners to the lowest earners. (Why not consider the Lib Dem policy of taxing more from the over £100,000 bracket?) If Labour says "affordable" tax cuts are desirable, they concede too much ground to Tory ideology. Such fudging did for Al Gore. Politicians are now mistrusted for failing to tell simple truths: voters will only get what they pay for. Start saying it now, and Labour could earn back its lost trust.

On every issue this fundamental tax v spend question will dominate. In the cascade of facts and factoids, none of them outright lies, none the whole truth, all requiring adept deconstruction, yesterday's opening salvoes produced two choice ones on each side. Tories say Labour has taxed an extra £670 off the typical "hard-working" family. Labour replies: "On average the typical family with children will be £850 better off." Who is right? Both and neither. First, the Tory £670: if total taxes have risen some 2% under Labour, dividing the extra £20bn a year by the 28m national households produces roughly that sum, agrees the Institute for Fiscal Studies. But it gets more complicated: the Tories have added in a notional £400 a year that people would need to pay into their pensions to cover the devious stealth tax stolen from pension funds. Right? Not quite. Pension funds have boomed by 70% in the last three buoyant years and many are actually in surplus so need no topping up. On further inspection, the Tory figure gets worse. They have used a couple on £40,000 - in the top 10% of earners. They have failed to add in £500 arriving to a couple with children next April or the £83 cut in national insurance they've already had. They have added a notional £193 for smoking 20 cigarettes a day.

So is Labour's £850 figure right? No, not altogether. Labour adds up the extra income coming directly to all families with children. But they have left out indirect taxes on petrol, cigarettes or drink, claiming it is too difficult to guess what a "typical" family might consume. Does that mean families are worse off under Labour? No. National average earnings have risen by 10% over the last three boom years, a million more people are in work and large extra sums have been paid out directly to poorer families and pensioners. All average earners with children will also get a new £10 a week child tax credit in their pay packets in April. On top of that, lower interest rates mean mortgage payers have gained an average £1,000 a year. No one, including the IFS has yet attempted a total profit and loss calculation on all this, but there is no doubt that virtually all voters have been winners, and most by quite a lot, even if some hardship cases like poor tennant farmers or the unemployed without children did see their living standards drop.

Crooked figures will be rife. Take Mr Hague's claim yesterday that more patients are waiting for operations: "Four years later waiting lists are 55,000 higher." True? No. Waiting lists for operations have fallen by over 130,000, which is 30,000 more than promised at the election. Ah, the Tories reply, but waiting lists for out-patient appointments have risen by 188,000. Deduct the 130,000 from that, and you end up with a 55,000 increase. Fair? Not really. Only 40% of those waiting for out-patient appointments ever need an operation, and the Tories have no idea how long they have been waiting. The number waiting is of no interest to patients, only how long they must wait. In the fog of electioneering, very few figures are what they seem but the battleground will be just such disputed performance figures.

Yesterday Mr Hague promised that "in the coming weeks Conservatives will demonstrate how we can improve public services and cut taxes". How is the magic trick to be done? So far their confection of imaginary savings has been an entertaining porridge of bogus figures looking for savings where few voters will notice - lone parents, industrial injuries, crack -downs on fraud - all airy impossibilities that pass unscrutinised because no one thinks they can win.

For Labour, fantasy Tory accounting is beside the point. In the real world where a Labour win is certain, the serious question is what now to say to the electors. On Frost's sofa and again yesterday, Tony Blair seemed to be marching out ahead of his chancellor, talking up spending, decrying Tory tax cuts. No more big tent, no more tugging on both ends of the rope. Prime ministerial sources volunteer the thought that Mr Brown's 1p income tax cut had zero political impact when it arrived last April, money thrown away. By then politics had moved on: public services are the only issue.

Yet still the chancellor continues to talk of "targeted tax cuts" to come. This is a question Labour must resolve immediately. Last-minute tax cuts in March instead of every penny spent on public services will only encourage the dangerous public cynicism that is Labour's only real threat. Tony Blair's political acumen that dragged Labour on to Tory turf last time may now see that a second term demands a march in the opposite direction.

webTitle: Comment: Voters will only get what they pay for

fields.headline: The truth is that voters will only get what they pay for
fields.standfirst: The major parties should come clean on taxation and spending
fields.trailText: The major parties should come clean on taxation and spending.

webTitle: Week 5: Sydney to Katoomba

fields.headline: Bright lights and a bush home from home
fields.standfirst: Having celebrated the new year in spectactular style in Sydney, Milly and Josh stretch their legs, sample kangaroo burgers, and head for the hills
fields.trailText: Having celebrated the new year in spectactular style in Sydney, Milly and Josh stretch their legs, sample kangaroo burgers, and head for the hills
fields.body:
The day after my birthday I have to admit we were pretty lazy - although I think it was well deserved! In the evening we went out for a belated birthday dinner to a place called Pontoons on Darling Harbour - already one of my favourite areas in Sydney. Dinner was pretty reasonable, although the drinks were more pricey. Besides staying up late chatting at the hostel, we didn't really do much that evening, as we were determined to get up early and be active the next day.

The following morning we took the popular but still pretty walk from Bondai to Coogee beach. It was fairly easy, only complicated by my insistance that we take the more difficult route across the rocks for a challenge. I had a double reason for wanting to get to Coogee - I'm hoping to settle there for a short while to find work, as Sydney is too large and crowded for my liking.

Stopping for a drink at the huge Coogee Bay Hotel, I definitely felt this was somewhere I could stay; the whole atmosphere just seemed that bit more relaxed than Sydney and it sits on the beach, which is a bonus.

In the evening we attempted to cook dinner at the hostel. This is harder than it sounds, as Glebe Village must boast the worst kitchen facilities I've seen - there are no plates, cups or cutlery (although they do have a bafflingly large selection of carving forks). After consuming our meal of pasta and stir-fried fresh vegetables, which felt nutritionally good, we settled in for an evening's drinking. There's a pretty nice atmosphere in Glebe and a good number of outdoor tables, so evenings can be happily spent in this way (with the bonus that it's pretty cheap entertainment).

The next day I had an inexplicable low day, which I occasionally seem to suffer from. By now, I've got used to my various emotions but I'm not so sure that Josh was prepared for it! Still, besides that, he tells me that I haven't changed at all in the last month, aside from being more independent. I'm yet to decide if this is a good thing or not.

New Year's Eve in Sydney was always going to be a significant night for me. That evening, a few of us at the hostel organised a barbeque for the early evening, which really topped off my successful morning's shopping. It was incredible how much food we managed to cook between the eight of us - and even more impressive how much we managed to eat! I can honestly say I've not had that big a meal since leaving home - but it was a special day, after all. In the evening we followed the millions into the city centre to enjoy the various free events put on in Sydney.

Despite being restricted to where we could go by the 'no alcohol' areas, and the unbelievable amount of people who'd appeared as if from nowhere, we still managed to listen to a bit of live jazz before heading to Circular Quay for the first round of fireworks. These were spectacular, but were surpassed by the display a few hours later to call in 2001. Fireworks were going off in every direction, including a golden waterfall under the harbour bridge. The display ended with the rainbow spirit, an Australian symbol of unity, and the crowds went wild. It really was one of the best New Year's Eve celebrations I've ever seen - but it was definitely good to not be alone. I hope Sue and Sam found some good company during what could have been a lonely time of year.

On New Year's Day we got up early (seriously!) to lounge in the sun in the Botanical Gardens. Also, one of our dorm-mates scares us, so it's always nice to get away. In the afternoon we watched the 100 year federation parade. It was a spectacle of weird and wonderful floats celebrating the history of Australia, which was very long but ultimately enjoyable. And if anyone can tell me why Estonia appeared in the middle that will solve a great mystery. The evening was spent watching the live music and street theatre around Darling Harbour - this really is a buzzing time of year to be in Sydney.

The next day, we were determined to complete the more challenging walk from Manly Beach to Spit Bridge. Getting up early(ish), we caught the packed ferry to Manly, which is a lovely journey in itself. Stopping for lunch there, I got to check out the beach, which is claimed to be the best in Sydney - and I have to say, it was pretty beautiiful, if even more crowded than Bondai had been. Grabbing a map, we set off on what should have been a nine kilometre walk - although the way we did it, it was significantly longer. I would definitely recommend it - we came across some spectacular views and saw some Aboriginal carvings as well as parrots, lizards and an unidentified spider all in the space of an afternoon. One tip - take plenty of water. We ran out two kilometres before we came to a shop and were seriously dehydrated by the time we got there. The Australian sun can be pretty relentless at times.

The following day was our check-out day from Glebe, and our chance to escape the hordes for the Blue Mountains. Catching the train from Central to Katoomba, we arrived, as usual, without having booked anywhere to stay. Finding an advert for a place called Wollangambe Lodge in a backpacker magazine, we gave it a call. After a long chat with the owner Shaun, we realised this place was truly in the middle of nowhere - but we both wanted to give it a try. In fact, it's so remote we were told to bring all our groceries with us, and to request to get off at Bell station, as it is so seldom used. This gave Josh just enough time to try a kangaroo burger at the cafe in Katoomba, which was delicious, with a taste closer to steak or venison than chicken. When we arrived at Bell, Shaun himself picked us up in his van, which rattled as though it would fall apart when it went round the bends.

Every hostel is always a new experience, but this one tops the lot. Set deep within the bush in a town that was a once thriving community but now has only five houses, you really couldn't get further away from it all. It felt more like a house than a hostel, with the kitchen, bathroom and living room (complete with open fire) shared by everyone, including Shaun and his son. The only other residents were an American named Scott who'd been there for months, and a Dutch couple who arrived the same night as us bearing a tent. This hostel had no rules and no key deposit - because there was no key.

In the morning Shaun went to work, leaving us to amble round as we pleased. That first evening he took me and Josh for a walk down from his back yard to see some stunning views across valleys, and later that night we stayed up cooking, drinking, and chatting about the walks and the history of the area. We could tell we were going to love staying here, even though it was only for a couple of days.

Until next week (when I'll be having fun in the Blue Mountains),
Milly.

webTitle: Villagers plan Britain's first community windfarm

fields.headline: Villagers plan Britain's first community windfarm
fields.trailText: Villagers in rural south Wales are to go to the polls over proposals for a unique wind farm projects. Under the plans, any profits would be channelled into a charitable trust and used for regeneration initiatives
fields.body:
Villagers in one of the most economically deprived parts of south Wales are being asked to vote in a referendum next month to help determine whether their area should become home to Britain's first community-owned wind farm.

In a unique departure from other wind farm projects, any profits generated by the proposed scheme would be channelled into a charitable trust and used for a variety of regeneration initiatives in the hard-up communities of the upper Swansea and upper Amman valleys.

Emily Hinshelwood, research coordinator for Awel Aman Tawe, a community group set up to take the project forward, said: "The whole focus is on community regeneration."

Working from a small rented office at the village school in Gwaun-Cae-Gurwen, the group has spent almost a year carrying out an extensive consultation exercise with residents, supported by around £75,000 of funding from the Department of Trade and Industry and other bodies such as the Prince's Trust.

The scheme will not go ahead unless there is majority support in the community referendum taking place over a three-week period from the end of next month.

The bilingual postal and telephone ballot, in which more than 8,000 people will be entitled to vote, will be overseen by the independent Electoral Reform Society. Everyone aged 16 and over living in the 14 villages closest to the proposed site is being encouraged to express a view in what will be a significant exercise in local democracy.

In the face of inevitable opposition to the project from some residents, Awel Aman Tawe has spent recent months seeking to raise awareness of the proposed scheme by sending leaflets to homes and arranging public meetings.

Coach trips have also been organised to take people to Britain's biggest wind farm, the 56-turbine operation at Carno, mid-Wales, and a smaller farm near Bridgend in an effort to address the concerns often raised about such projects.

The group says many of the worries arise through lack of information, so to help counter that it has launched its own website.

"The more people understand the issue of renewable energy and climate change and the more people are exposed to wind farms, the more likely they are to support the project," said Ms Hinshelwood.

"We have had an overwhelmingly positive response from people coming back from the farms. Nobody has come back saying they think it is a bad idea and most have returned saying they think it is a good one."

As part of its research, Awel Aman Tawe - the name translates literally as Amman Swansea breeze or wind - sent a member of its steering group to Europe to look at a cooperatively-owned wind farm project in Denmark.

Ms Hinshelwood says the main lesson learned from the trip was that such projects can be done and that communities can and do support wind farms elsewhere.

The proposal being worked on involves the construction of four or five turbines, each up to 50 metres tall, on windswept common land on top of Mynydd Uchaf. The site is close to an open cast coal mine due to close later this year.

The farm would be about two miles from Gwaun-Cae-Gurwen and just over a mile from the small village of Tairgwaith, where several residents have come out strongly against the project fearing visual and noise impact and possible TV interference. One local school would be just under a mile from the site.

Those behind the project say it could produce a profit of up to £350,000 a year by selling the electricity it generates to the national grid or to a local end user such as an industrial estate. The money would be used to support local community projects and businesses in the area.

The farm would be owned and managed by local people. Those living in the area would be entitled to membership for a payment of just £1, giving them the right to elect trustees and make essential decisions about the farm. Those investing more than £1 would not be entitled to more than one vote.

If the project gets the go-ahead in the community referendum, Awel Aman Tawe will need to steer the proposals through the full planning process, including the preparation of an environmental impact assessment, before embarking on the task of raising the £4m needed to turn the dream into reality.

Supporters of the scheme are confident they will be able to tap into the European Objective 1 funds earmarked for west Wales and the valleys, as well as other sources of finance designed to promote renewable energy and others that aim to help former coalfields communities.

webTitle: Ailing princess in hospital

fields.headline: Ailing princess in hospital
fields.trailText: Princess Margaret has been admitted to a London hospital, Buckingham Palace said today.
fields.body:
Princess Margaret has been admitted to a London hospital, Buckingham Palace said today.

After her recent apparent stroke, she has suffered a "severe loss of appetite" and "continued to give cause for concern," a statement said.

The Queen's 71-year-old sister has been ill for some time. According to reports, she spent the Christmas and New Year holiday confined to bed in Sandringham, the Royal family's Norfolk estate.

Following medical tests, doctors believe she may have had a minor stroke or is still suffering the follow-on effects of the first, in February 1998.

Doctors decided to admit the princess to the King Edward VII hospital in Marylebone, central London, so her condition "can be more closely monitored".

All her engagements have been cancelled.

webTitle: Blair and Hague set acrimonious tone

fields.headline: Blair and Hague set acrimonious tone
fields.standfirst: Special report: life in parliament
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair and Conservative leader William Hague set the tone for an acrimonious general election campaign today, with a stormy debate over tax and public spending.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair and Conservative leader William Hague set the tone for an acrimonious general election campaign today, with a stormy debate over tax and public spending.

Mr Hague accused Labour of raising taxes and failing to provide the public services to justify the increase.

He denounced the prime minister as the "great pretender" and said that Labour's claims to have lowered taxes are "specious waffle".

Mr Hague kept up the pressure on the prime minister over taxes, saying that the national tax burden rose from 36.9% to 37.3% over the last year. Mr Blair attributed that increase to a rise in employment and the average income.

Pressed during prime minister's question time about the numbers of teachers, doctors, nurses and police, Mr Blair stressed that Labour's commitment to investing in public services will turn around the recruitment situation faces by police forces, schools and the NHS.

He accused the Conservatives of planning to cut public spending by £16bn while Labour plans to increase spending.

He said: "We stabilised the economy and put the national debt under control. I make no apology for being very tight in the first years, but now we can fund increases in schools, police and the health service."

Mr Blair admitted that the numbers of police have fallen since the last election, but he pointed out that those numbers have been falling across the country for the last seven years.

He said that schools had just seen the first rise in teacher recruitment in eight years.

Mr Hague responded: "If he thinks we're going to fight the next election on a cut in police spending, he's crazy."

webTitle: England announce new friendlies

fields.headline: England announce new friendlies
fields.trailText: England are to take on Mexico and Holland later this year as warm-up games under Sven-Goran Eriksson ahead of the testing World Cup qualifiers away to Greece and Germany.
fields.body:
England are to take on Mexico and Holland later this year as warm-up games under Sven-Goran Eriksson ahead of the testing World Cup qualifiers away to Greece and Germany.

Derby's Pride Park ground will host its first full international when England play the Mexicans on Friday, May 25, while Tottenham's White Hart Lane will be the venue for the game against Holland on Wednesday, August 15.

The announcements of the Nationwide friendly internationals were made after Eriksson and Leicester coach Peter Taylor, who is on his backroom staff, had been consulted about the best preparations for the World Cup qualifiers.

webTitle: Knowledge Unlimited

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: WORLD'S FASTEST SENDING OFF
fields.body:
WORLD'S FASTEST SENDING OFF

"Can you tell me who holds the world record for the fastest sending off (excluding substitutes)?" asks Candy Stephens

We've had plenty of suggestions, but not much of a consensus. However, these facts hold true:

1) The fastest sending-off during a World Cup match is - as many of you point out - Uruguay's Jose Batista, who was red carded after 56 seconds against Scotland during Mexico 86.

2) The fastest sending in British football is held by Sheffield Wednesday keeper Kevin Pressman - who was sent off after just 13 seconds for handling a shot from Wolverhampton's Temuri Ketsbaia outside the area during the opening weekend of this season.

3) But that time is beaten by Bologna's Giuseppe Lorenzo - who as Peter De Gryse points out - was sent off after just 10 seconds for striking an opponent in an Italian league match against Parma on December 9th, 1990.

And if you want to include substitutions, then Walter Boyd (of Jamaica and Swansea) also merits a mention. Last season, Boyd came on just as the Swans were about to take a free-kick - but before it could be taken he became involved in some argy-bargy on the edge of the box, cuffed his opponent and was sent off after a total of 0 seconds. Thanks to Simon Adams for that.

SHARING THE GOALS AROUND

When, I am sorry to say, Cardiff beat Exeter 6-1 on New Year's Day, there were seven Cardiff players each on the scoresheet (they scored ours for us). Has such a democratic sharing of goals ever been matched or exceeded in the past? asks Stephen Pepper

When Liverpool beat Crystal Palace 9-0 during the 1989-90 season, eight different players found the net, a top-flight record.

Steve Nicol opened and closed the scoring, with Steve McMahon, Ian Rush, Gary Gillespie, Peter Beardsley, John Aldridge, John Barnes and Glenn Hysen filling their boots in between.

To add to Palace's misery, Geoff Thomas missed a penalty. What a nice end to the tale there would have been if the vanquished could have taken revenge in a high-profile Cup tie later that season ...

MURPHY'S LAW

"Was Danny Murphy the first Englishman to score against Manchester United in the Premiership this season?" asks Neil Walters

Yes, he was. Before Murphy's cracking curler of a free-kick in Liverpool's 1-0 defeat of the Red Devils, you have to go back to May 6 2000, when Chris Armstrong scored for Spurs during their 3-1 defeat at Old Trafford, for the last Englishman to score against United in the Premiership.

WHICH CROONER PLAYED FOR REAL MADRID?

Which pop star played in goal for Real Madrid? asks Chris

Julio Iglesias, the man who crooned classics such as To All The Girls I've Loved Before and Begin The Beguine, is your man. And a damn fine sexy man at that.

The hairy-chested Spanish crooner played in goal for Real Madrid's youth team during the early 1960s. But in 1963, the young keeper was involved in a near-fatal car crash on the night before his 20th birthday which rendered him paralysed for over two years.

Sadly, Iglesias's footballing career was over. But during his convalescence, he learnt to play guitar, discovered his talent for singing and the rest is history, etc. and so on.

TAFFAREL'S STRIKING CONFESSION

"Was Taffarel, the Brazil keeper during the last World Cup, playing as a striker for some remote European team prior to the tournament? I have a vague memory of one of the commentators saying something about it but I'm not sure?" says Simon Cook

Yes he did. According to Hugh Johnston: "A couple of years ago Taffarel was out of contract and couldn't get a new one so to keep himself sharp and fit he played up front for his local church team in Italy. Can't remember what they were called though," he adds. Can anyone else help?

WHO HAS WON SUCCESSIVE FA CUPS WITH DIFFERENT TEAMS?

Can you think of a player who has been in a winning FA Cup side two years running but for different teams each time? The person's name (either first or last) should be the make or model of a car. It might be a vague link, though. asks Alan Steele

Have you been doing pub quizzes, Alan? The man you're after is Brian Talbot, who was in Ipswich's 1978 Cup-winning side.

A year later, Talbot, now with Arsenal, could be seen at the Wembley showpiece looking pretty narked - and with good reason. He scoring the opening goal against Manchester United in the 1979 final, but received none of the credit from his team-mates, who all charged off after Alan Sunderland instead.

He still got a winner's medal, mind, as Arsenal won 3-2 thanks to a late goal from ... Alan Sunderland.

HIGHEST PREMIERSHIP NUMBER

"What is the highest shirt number that has been used in the Premiership or Nationwide League?"

"Swindon Town, when they were in the Premiership, went through loads of shirt numbers," says Lee Stickings. "And a certain Brian Kilcline, complete with sideburns et al, was wearing a number 62 shirt."

CAN YOU HELP?

"When was the last time that two brothers scored in the same match, either in the same team or opposite?" asks Derek Tonkin

"What is the longest period either in games or time that the newly-crowned World Champions have remained unbeaten after winning their title? England were soon beaten by Scotland, and France have lost a few games. Has any team remained unbeaten until they defended their crown in the following World Cup?" asks Iwan Fox

"Which English football teams have had the best away form over a season? And which have had the worst away form?" asks Mark Templeton

Send your answers to the.boss@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Bright Station shares soar

fields.headline: Bright Station shares soar thanks to deals with Intel
fields.trailText: Shares in internet company Bright Station have soared after it clinched a series of deals with Intel, the world's largest chip maker. By Dan Milmo
fields.body:
Shares in internet technology company Bright Station have soared after it clinched a series of deals with Intel, the world's largest chipmaker.

The stock climbed 38%, or 12p, to 43.5p following the announcement that Intel will pilot Bright Station's Smartlogik software in Europe, with a view to a worldwide roll-out.

Intel will also co-market the Sparza e-commerce operation, which uses the technology behind doomed online retailer boo.com.

Dan Wagner, Bright Station chief executive, said that the link-ups were a "significant endorsement" of the company's technologies.

"These agreements obviously have major implications for the group as a whole, and we are delighted to be entering the new year with this solid relationship in place," he said.

A Smartlogik flotation is still on the cards, although Bright Station has yet to appoint bankers to run the share offer.

Bright Station's WebTop search engine operation will also benefit from the deal by using Intel software. WebTop is headed by Andy Mitchell, who quit as managing director of AltaVista UK last year following the collapse of its unmetered access service.

However, the few analysts who track the stock were breathing sighs of relief following some long-awaited good news from the company, which has just £19.5m left in the bank.

Some analysts warned that time was running out for the company after it announced third quarter losses of £4.6m in November last year.

"It amounts to a strong endorsement of Bright Station's e-commerce products from a major blue-chip player in the US," said Iain Staples of ABN Amro.

Intel sparked fears of a downturn in the new economy in September last year when it issued a profits warning. The surprise statement was swiftly followed by similar admissions from the likes of Apple, Microsoft and Dell.

webTitle: Ronaldo: Nike didn't force me to play

fields.headline: Ronaldo: Nike didn't force me to play
fields.trailText: Brazilian striker Ronaldo has denied being forced to play in the 1998 World Cup Final by his sponsors Nike - and has insisted he was fit, despite suffering convulsions hours before the game.
fields.body:
Brazilian striker Ronaldo has denied being forced to play in the 1998 World Cup Final by his sponsors Nike - and has insisted he was fit, despite suffering convulsions hours before the game.

Ronaldo told a congressional inquiry commission, set up to investigate the Brazilian Football Confederation's (CBF) multi-million dollar sponsorship deal with Nike, that he only played after passed medical tests.

"I only played after medical tests showed I was clinically and physically fit to do so. If the tests had showed otherwise, I would not have played," he said.

A composed Ronaldo gave a measured and lucid account of events on the day of Brazil's 3-0 defeat by France.

He explained that he woke from an afternoon nap to find a group of concerned players around his bed, before being told by team doctors that he had suffered convulsive fits. Colleagues began to console him because he would be unable to play.

"I asked what I could do to show that I was fit to play. The doctors told me I would have to undergo medical tests," he said.

His version tallied with that of former coach Mario Zagallo, who said he selected Ronaldo after seeing the results of tests and confirming with the player that he felt well enough to play.

Questioned insistently by the commission about whether he had suffered pressure from sponsors to play in the game, Ronaldo insisted such speculation was groundless.

"The only thing Nike have asked of me is that I wear their boots," he said.

However, several commission members were dissatisfied with Ronaldo's refusal to reveal the terms of his contract with Nike.

Ronaldo failed to answer whether he had received premium payments for playing for Brazil, and described allegations that the contract obliged him to play in specific games as "absurd and incorrect."

Commission chairman Aldo Rebelo said Ronaldo had no legal right to silence on the issue of his contract, and said the panel would convene a second session behind closed doors. The session is continuing.

Commission chairman Aldo Rebelo said Ronaldo had no legal right to silence on the issue of his contract, and said the panel would convene a second session behind closed doors. The session is continuing.

fields.trailText:
5.30pm: ITV has poached BBC commentator Jon Champion for its football commentary team, writes Jason Deans.

fields.body:
ITV has poached BBC commentator Jon Champion for its football commentary team.

Mr Champion, who will be leaving the BBC at the end of his contract in June, will work on ITV's Premier League coverage, as well as commentating on other football events such as the Champions League, the World Cup and European Championships.

The 35-year-old joined the BBC in 1988 and has worked on three Olympic Games, three World Cups and two European Championships.

He will join an ITV football commentary team comprising Peter Drury, Guy Mowbray, Clive Tyldesley and Peter Brackley.

webTitle: Councils slip up on housing

fields.headline: Councils slip up on housing
fields.trailText: Council housing services have deteriorated in the past year, possibly due to the lack of a full-scale housing inspectorate, figures from the audit commission reveal today. Patrick Wintour reports
fields.body:
Council housing services have deteriorated in the past year, possibly due to the lack of a full-scale housing inspectorate, figures from the audit commission reveal today.

Overall, local councils' delivery of education and social services by contrast have improved, the commission reports. Both of these services are subject to tough inspections, based on best practice and monitoring performance.

The commission also reports deep dissatisfaction from the public at the absence of police foot patrols; less than one in five people surveyed were happy at the number of "bobbies on the beat".

The annual audit commission survey, of more than 100 key performance indicators, covers council services provided in the 12 months to March 2000. Since then the government has introduced its "best value" regime requiring councils to monitor the competitiveness of their services.

The study shows only 88% of council housing repairs are completed within government time limits, and the number of housing lets with rent arrears of more than 13 weeks has also risen, increasing from 4% to 4.6. In London, only 68% of housing benefit and council tax benefit claimants are satisfied with their council services; the figure is 78% across the country.

The crisis in Hackney council, north London, is starkly exposed, with only 68.4% of council tax receipts collected, whereas the average in London is 91%. Hackney also managed to collect only 78.2% of due rent, the lowest figure for any English council. Only 53% of Hackney housing repairs were completed within government time limits. Only Reading and Selby had a worse record.

Hackney also takes 181 days to process new council tax benefit claims and 150 days to process new housing benefit claims; the average across England is 50 days to process council tax and 44 days for housing benefit claims.

The study shows that the police only spend 53% of their time out on the streets. Nottinghamshire police appear the most reclusive, spending only 37% of their working hours in public; Cumbrian police, meanwhile, spend three-quarters of their time outside their offices.

Huge public dissatisfaction - 57% of those surveyed - is expressed at the absence of police foot patrols, and, to a lesser degree, mobile patrols, even though surveys show that having police on the beat does not help in crime detection.

But generally the public is found to be content with the police response to burglary and to violent crime.

The number of crimes solved per officer rose in the year to March 2000, from 12 to 12.2 crimes. The most successful police force in terms of solved crimes per officer is Gwent with 25 clear-ups per officer. The Met is the lowest, with seven per officer.

The number of 999 calls answered within police forces' target times fell from 89.1% in 1998-99 to 88.6% in 1999-00. The number of constables available for work in England and Wales fell, on average from 2.14 per 1,000 of the population in 1998-99 to 2.11.

The survey also finds the proportion of children receiving pre-school education to be rising with 93% of four-year-olds now in nursery school. Lincolnshire claims to have 103% of its four-year-olds in nursery school - a performance it will have difficulty improving on.

The proportion of street lights not working is less than 0.25 % in a few councils, but over 10 times that rate on a handful of others. The darkest London council in terms of most streetlights not working is Ealing. Nationwide, Tameside has the highest proportion of streetlights not working.

The district council which spends least per head of population is Mid Bedfordshire - at £70.38 a head. The most parsimonious county council is wealthy Surrey which spends only £611 per head of its population. York council spends least of unitary councils at £695 per head.

Good, bad and ugly

 The filthiest council, in terms of street cleanliness: Stockton-on-Tees . Only 54.7% of the council's streets were deemed to be of a high or acceptable standard. Residents of Southend, South Buckinghamshire, East Cambridgeshire, Carlisle, Christchurch and 23 other councils will be delighted, or possibly surprised to know that 100% of their streets are clean.

 The city with most public lavatories is Sheffield (65). Liverpool, by contrast, has none

 The population most keen to swim is Reading, with 16,028 swims per 1,000 population.

 The education authority with the most excluded pupils is Doncaster, with 3.12 pupils excluded per 1,000 pupils.

 Tower Hamlets spends most per pupil on primary education: £3,080 per pupil.

 The cheapest school meal in the country can be bought in Worcester at 90p.

 The council spending least on children's services is Rutland, at £14.53 per head of population.
