webTitle: Noel White's Traditional Bread Sauce, Dyson DC04 Nostrils, and Another extremely poor marketing concept

fields.headline: Noel White's Traditional Bread Sauce, Dyson DC04 Nostrils, and Another extremely poor marketing concept
fields.trailText: SWEDE LITTLE MYSTERY
fields.body:
SWEDE LITTLE MYSTERY

All across Europe the talk is of Svennis. In Italy they're wondering why he left. In England they're wondering why he's bothering to come. In Sweden they're wondering what he'll be wearing, and at Luton international arrivals, they're just wondering what they're doing.

Yes, Svennis is expected to fly into Heathrow before the end of the week, on his way to Upton Park for his first official scouting mission as England's head coach. The match will be West Ham versus Sunderland, and the little skinhead waving at the directors' box while balancing the ball on the tip of his nose for five minutes will be Joe Cole. Eriksson is also expected to check out wotsisname, you know the one with the left foot, Michael Beige, or something, before moving onto Filbert Street on Sunday to see if Trevor Benjamin really is ready to step up to international level.

The English press has been quite tame in their response to yesterday's news, and while El Tel found time to remind us it's "a backward step - we have got to win together or lose together" (emphasis on the "lose"), the real surprise has come from Italy. Taking a leaf out of the Fleet Street handbook, the Gazzetta dello Sport today claimed that the FA have sabotaged their national game. "The manoeuvres of the FA to have Eriksson at all costs could have destabilised the Italian champions", wrote Gianni Sadler. "That all this has brought Lazio into a crisis that could damage Serie A and [Big Cup] is of little interest in London." Expect David Davies's head superimposed on a jar of pesto within days.

(On second thoughts, FA-endorsed foodstuffs could be a real winner. "Crozier's Cook-In-A-Pot". "Noel White's Traditional Bread Sauce". Let's make it happen!)

ADVERTISEMENT

Fed up with your team's failures? Overjoyed at your side's success? Find out what genuine fans REALLY think about your club at From The Terrace: http://www.fromtheterrace.co.uk

HE DOESN'T SHOOT, BUT HE SCORES

"And Diego Maradona scores!" Four words the Fiver thought it would never hear again - well, not on a football pitch anyway. But today the brilliant Argentinian with a bag of tricks for every occasion (including that 3am toilet moment) has agreed to come out of retirement to play one final game. For Dundee. Yes, assuming Maradona doesn't lapse from his drug-rehab programme - and when you've got Dyson DC04-sized nostrils itching for some action, there's always a risk - the pot-bellied genius will line up for Ivano Bonetti's side against his former club Napoli at Dens Park at the end of the month.

"As far as I know Maradona has already sent his agreement by fax. He demanded £250,000 for one game and Dundee agreed," Dundee's rather-excited Georgian defender Giorgi Nemsadze told onefootball.com today. "It was Claudio Caniggia who helped arrange everything. I will be delighted to play with the living legend!" he continued breathlessly.

Nemsadze is likely to get his wish, because a Dundee spokesman later confirmed the story. "We hope to settle upon other details such as date and time of game within the next few days, but it's increasingly likely that any match involving Maradona will take place at Dens Park," he revealed. "That is obviously great news for Dundee fans." And a great chance for Scottish football fans to pay homage too. Now where did we put that treasured copy of Hero - the official film of the 1986 World Cup?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Ipswich won't be able to pass the ball [in the Worthington Cup semi-final second leg] like they did yesterday. We will put the cows and the sheep back on the pitch" - Martin Grainger is also likely to get a game. Birmingham City manager Trevor Francis reveals his secret plan to upset the Tractor Boys.

FOOTBALL: C'EST LE CRAZE NOUVEAU!

After winning the World Cup and European Championship, there's nothing much left for the French national team to achieve. They don't even have to qualify for anything, so no wonder droves of bored French football fans are turning to other leisurely pursuits. And let's face it, if you had a chance to play a bit of pétanque, would you bother watching Europe's most successful international side since the early seventies play a friendly? Of course you wouldn't: you'd have your dusty boules in your sweaty little hands quicker than you could licence iconic "French" lager Kronenbourg to a brewery from Reading.

It's no surprise, then, that the French Football Federation have come up with a top PR wheeze to get everyone interested in the team's upcoming friendlies. "The federation thinks that these matches need a lift," explained France coach Roger Lemerre, before a frankly dodgy publicity campaign which will see France's opponents presented as warriors was revealed. "We know that football is not a war but" began FFF president Claude Simonet.

Of course it isn't. That'll be why the Danish are depicted as marauding Vikings, the Japanese as samurais, and the Germans - dey bombed our café - as Teutonic horsemen. "We want to stir up popular support behind the team," mused Simonet, his brain still not quite hitting top gear. "We hope the public will see the campaign as an epic saga in eight episodes," he laboured on under the misapprehension that people will swallow a half-baked idea drummed up over dinner by a load of half-cut and half-witted marketing executives. Of course, maybe the Fiver is being a little touchy over this matter. But if Adam Crozier and his cronies decided to advertise an England game in such a manner, wouldn't you feel just a little ashamed?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leicester are hoping to sign Lazio's 36-year-old striker Roberto Mancini. Manager Peter Taylor admitted: "There is some truth in that rumour. I spoke to Mr Eriksson about the player, but I have not taken it any further yet. We would like to go out and buy the best players available, but we have to consider transfer fees and wages."

Italian sports bible Gazzetta dello Sport claims Lazio are looking to hire John Gregory as the long-term successor to Sven-Goran Eriksson. The paper reports that Gregory's "fluent Italian and ability to work with players" has impressed Lazio chairman Sergio Cragnotti.

David Pleat has denied reports that Spurs are lining up a £9m bid for Real Madrid's Cameroon striker Samuel Eto'o.

Dundee are interested in signing Attilio Lombardo. A Dundee spokesman confirmed today: "Attilio is a good friend of Ivano Bonetti and the club and the fans would be delighted to see him playing for Dundee at any time."

NEWS IN BRIEF

Ronaldo has told a congressional inquiry investigating the Brazilian Football Confederation's multi-million dollar sponsorship deal with Nike that he only played in the 1998 World Cup Final because medical tests showed he was fit to do so. The Brazilian striker, who suffered convulsions hours before the game, said today: "I only played after medical tests showed I was clinically and physically fit to do so. If the tests had showed otherwise, I would not have played," he said.

Questioned insistently whether he had suffered pressure from sponsors to play in the game, Ronaldo insisted such speculation was groundless. "The only thing Nike have asked of me is that I wear their boots," he said. However, commission members remained dissatisfied with the player's refusal to reveal the terms of his own sponsorship contract with Nike.

Tottenham defender Stephen Carr could be out of action for at least two more weeks as fears grow that he may need surgery to correct a nagging groin problem.

Fulham and Portsmouth have escaped disciplinary action following crowd trouble at Craven Cottage earlier this season, during which missiles were hurled at Fulham goalkeeper Maik Taylor, a linesman was hit by a snooker ball and the referee had to wear a motorcycle helmet to leave the pitch.

Coventry defender Paul Williams has had a three-match suspension reduced to one game after a FA hearing in London. Williams was charged with bringing the game into disrepute for kicking the fourth official's electronic board in frustration following his sending-off against Preston in September.

Leyton Orient have signed French midfielder Emmanuel Vasseur, 22, who played for the non-league Calais side that reached the French Cup final last season.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (11.30pm)

"A few years ago, Brian Moore would regularly come into my local newsagents in Bromley, Kent," writes Keith Bennett.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm, 11.30pm)

"Every morning at the same time, around 8am, he would come in looking unkempt and half-asleep and ask for 20 Bensons."

The Last Word (7pm, 11pm SS3)

"Some mornings he would ask for 20 Bensons and a packet of Wrigley's Juicy Fruit."

You're On Sky Sports! (10.30pm, 2.30am)

"One morning he even bought a packet of Rolos."

Sky Sports 2: Live Worthington Cup Football - Crystal Palace v Liverpool (7pm, 12midnight)

"Upon being asked about last night's big game or his views on Kelvin Koogan, he remained silent and left quickly with a pained expression."

British Eurosport: Live Football (7.15pm)

"Strange thing is, he never once bought a newspaper."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm)

"The newsagent said he must get free papers at the TV studio but they couldn't stretch to free smokes and Rolos."

Midweek 6-0-6 with David Mellor (10pm)

Have you spotted a former football commentator buying Tic Tacs and tabs in your local 8-til-late?

Talksport: Football First with Alvin Martin and Adrian Durham (7pm)

Or perhaps you saw David Baddiel completely disappear up his own arse this morning on breakfast television while describing his new sitcom. Simply email the.boss@theguardian.com with your minor celeb stories and we'll sift out the tedious ones (before publishing them).

webTitle: Special deal for NHS lab staff is a healthy sign

fields.headline: Special deal for NHS lab staff is a healthy sign
fields.standfirst: The extra pay rise for laboratory staff is a recognition that they play a vital role in the government's ambitions to improve NHS quality and productivity
fields.trailText: The extra pay rise for laboratory staff is a recognition that they play a vital role in the government's ambitions to improve NHS quality and productivity, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
The above-inflation pay rise offered to laboratory staff and other NHS workers is not merely a nicely timed pre-election sweetener, but an admission that low pay for staff is damaging services.

Last March, health minister John Denham told MPs that laboratory staff recruitment was not critical - indeed it was in a "relatively healthy position" compared to other occupations such as nursing. This week Mr Denham admitted that the pay offer would tackle "specific problem areas - especially in NHS laboratories - where we know there are difficulties in recruiting and retaining the right staff".

What has changed ministerial minds is the realisation that without enough properly qualified staff to run an efficiently functioning laboratory service, Labour's ambitious aims to increase NHS quality and productivity will fail.

Laboratory work is crucial to the diagnosis and treatment of a range of illnesses including heart disease, diabetes, Aids, the so-called hospital killer-bug known as MRSA and tuberculosis. The most high profile work is probably cytolgy - the screening process that identifies cancer. The NHS cancer plan's challenging targets to speed up cancer detection will not be met if laboratories are not working at full capacity.

According to work carried out last year by the University of Warwick, NHS vacancy levels for cytologists were running at 17%. The same study found that one in five laboratory posts were unfilled.

Low pay is the main problem affecting recruitment. A trainee NHS pathologist will have a university degree in science, yet will start on just £9,000 - several thousand less than he or she would earn doing a similar job in the private sector. webTitle: Diary: Stephen Moss

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Even with its CEO (chief eater-out) absent, this column is not standing still. We are considering a name change and have engaged a leading design consultancy (so cutting edge it has no name, only a numbered Swiss bank account) to come up with something new, fresh and innovative. "Diary" is so outmoded, so redolent of story-getting and fact-recording. Inventory (after all, most of the items are invented), Parodia and Gùff have all been mooted, and are being considered by sea breeze-sipping focus groups across Clerkenwell.
fields.body:
 Even with its CEO (chief eater-out) absent, this column is not standing still. We are considering a name change and have engaged a leading design consultancy (so cutting edge it has no name, only a numbered Swiss bank account) to come up with something new, fresh and innovative. "Diary" is so outmoded, so redolent of story-getting and fact-recording. Inventory (after all, most of the items are invented), Parodia and Gùff have all been mooted, and are being considered by sea breeze-sipping focus groups across Clerkenwell.

 Frankly, this is a bit of a scoop. The Labour party yesterday ordered six new Portakabins from the firm's west London office for delivery to its HQ at Millbank. "There must be an election in the offing," said the man taking the order. And what are they for? "More space for the media," according to a Labour spokesman. So a spring election - it's official. Remember where you read it first.

 Ken Livingstone is furious about an interview that appears in the current issue of London listings magazine Time Out. He told the interviewer, Carolyne Culver, that he intended to stand again for the post of mayor of London in 2004, with or without Labour backing. The magazine duly splashed that Livingstone had recanted on his pledge not to stand again. "What pledge?" demanded his office in agitated calls to Time Out and the Press Association, which was running a story based on the interview.

That'll be the pledge you made in August 1998, replied Time Out coolly: "If I am lucky enough to be elected as London's first mayor, and bearing in mind I have already served five years as leader of the GLC, I would not seek to serve more than one term." Ah, but that was two years ago, said the mayor's spokesman. Clearly a very long time in politics.

 "I'm proud to live in Peckham," wrote retired spin doctor Charlie Whelan last month, following what he believed to be sensationalist reporting of the area in which Damilola Taylor was killed. "No one would suggest that Peckham is the most peaceful part of London, but it's my home and I'm going to defend it against misinformed nonsense." Good for him. But now we hear that he is thinking of abandoning his beloved south-east London, where he has lived for 15 years, and moving to the Scottish Highlands, where he can pursue his passion for field sports. "There are not many places to go trout fishing in Peckham," he says sheepishly.

 Talking of the great outdoors, it transpires that the ferocious huntin' and shootin' sports minister Kate Hoey has a spot of previous. As a councillor in Hackney in the early 80s, Hoey - who was responsible for parks - was a vocal member of the League for the Introduction of Canine Control (LICC). Hackney's rangers had powers to shoot dogs which were lingering in Clissold Park after closing time and eating the rabbits in the animal enclosure. Scary.

 This paper is the last to crow, but we take some satisfaction from the Mirror's announcement that it is to begin acknowledging its errors. Its method is highly original - a "corrections and clarifications" column under the auspices of "readers' editor" David Seymour. We trust he will be having a stern word with the leader writer who produced the laboured editorial on mobile phones in yesterday's paper - the one that in 13 tortuous sentences spelt out Bye Bye Pollard. Pathetic.

 The Inventory/Parodia/Gùff has assigned a large team to the dramatic story of the All Saints' break-up, and we expect to be able to reveal something pretty big by Friday. Oh, and thanks to the reader in Powys who wrote to point out that our acrostic in yesterday's Diary was incorrect. The village is of course Mwtplbhy, not Mwtlpbhy.

webTitle: Charity relief over Branson's lottery climbdown

fields.headline: Charity relief over Branson's lottery climbdown
fields.trailText: Charities will be relieved that Sir Richard Branson has decided not to jeopardise money for good causes by continuing his campaign to run the national lottery.
fields.body:
Charities will be relieved that Sir Richard Branson has decided not to jeopardise money for good causes by continuing his campaign to run the national lottery.

Although he promised £1.1bn more than Camelot for good causes, the threat of a further legal wrangle made charities anxious that funding could be delayed or income levels reduced by either side being tarnished by the battle.

His bid was ambitious and commentators believe his claims were over-optimistic. Barbara Bloomfield, editor of Lottery Monitor, said: "He may not have made as much money as he thought as it is such a huge undertaking and the costs are very high."

Stephen Lee, fundraising fellow at the South Bank University, said: "With an overwhelming need to assure continued support to charities from lottery games, one can only applaud Sir Richard's decision. However, until the lottery commission publishes the full details of the justification we cannot be absolutely clear that charities have achieved the best outcome."

In his announcement today, Sir Richard said the People's Lottery took comfort in the fact that as a result of the competition, the amount pledged to good causes by Camelot has increased by £5bn.

Ms Bloomfield added that it would be helpful if Camelot made more of the good causes in its publicity and less of the millionaires. "Camelot said they would promote how the money is spent and this would be good for the country."

However, the saga of who will win the lottery may have already damaged income from the lottery. Research carried out by NOP in September last year showed that almost a fifth of players would either play less or cease playing entirely if Camelot continued to run the lottery for a further seven years. In contrast, 20% claim they would either start playing or play more if the licence was awarded to the People's Lottery.

Around 65% of the adult population (approximately 30m people) still play the lottery regularly. Weekly lottery sales average £90 - £95 million. Camelot originally forecast to raise £9bn for the Good Causes by the end of the licence in September 2001, but raised the forecast to £10.5bn in October 2000, due to the success of the national lottery games.

Dianne Thompson, chief executive, of the Camelot Group, welcomed Sir Richard's announcement and said: "We can now get on with finalising our plans for the next licence and initiating investment of more than £1bn. I was always confident that Camelot's bid was a very good one and believe we can achieve our target of raising £15bn and in the process ensure that our players and the good causes are the true beneficiaries of our exciting plans."

webTitle: Speculation mounts over Barak's election bid

fields.headline: Speculation mounts over Barak's election bid
fields.standfirst:
Israel seems set for further political tumult, as Derek Brown explains

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel seems set for further political tumult, as Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
There is vigorous speculation in Israel that the prime minister, Ehud Barak, is about to abandon his bid for reelection on February 6.

Opinion polls show Barak trailing badly behind his far-right challenger, Ariel Sharon. But one poll - interestingly enough produced by Barak's own brother - shows that Sharon would be beaten by Barak's One Israel party colleague and former prime minister, Shimon Peres.

Several close observers believe that Barak is about to throw in the towel and concede the candidature to Peres.

Such a sensational development would not be out of keeping in the rumbustious context of Israeli politics. And, with less than four weeks to polling day, more sensations may yet emerge.

Sharon has kicked off his campaign with a typically blunt assertion that the Oslo peace accords - Israel's favoured shorthand description for the agreement secretly negotiated in Norway with Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organisation - are dead.

He has already promised dire retaliation against the Palestinians if their current intifada (uprising) continues.

The intifada erupted at the end of September, sparked by Sharon's provocative visit to the main mosque compound in Jerusalem. It has since claimed around 360 lives, the overwhelming majority of them Palestinian.

Most Israelis believe that the violence is being cynically directed by Arafat and his lieutenants, in the hope of squeezing territorial concessions with Barak, who has long portrayed himself as the only man who can bring about a final peace settlement.

Now Barak's drive for peace is over, and the former army chief is widely seen as a lame-duck leader bereft of ideas for quelling the unrest.

Peres, on the other hand, is seen as Israel's most seasoned politician, with more than half a century's experience and an unrivalled relationship of trust with Arafat, his fellow Nobel peace laureate.

Barak's woes, meanwhile, have been deepened by a strident campaign within Israel's Arab minority for a poll boycott. The nation's 1.1m Arab citizens, who identify strongly with their 2m Palestinian kinsfolk in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, are deeply disillusioned with the prime minister.

He promised them rapid improvements in living conditions, and failed to deliver. He pledged himself to peace settlement which, for now, has evaporated in violence.

Most of all, he presided over the heavy-handed response to the rioting in Arab areas which accompanied the start of the intifada.

Thirteen Arab citizens of Israel were shot dead, and the community, which largely supported Barak in the last prime ministerial election in 1999, is in no mood to do so again.

webTitle: Lockerbie prosecutors close case

fields.headline: Lockerbie prosecutors close case
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText:
Lockerbie trial prosecutors today closed their case against the two Libyan defendants they insist are guilty of the 1988 bomb attack on Pan Am Flight 103.
Special report: Lockerbie
fields.body:
Lockerbie trial prosecutors today closed their case against the two Libyan defendants they insist are guilty of the 1988 bomb attack on Pan Am Flight 103.

Alastair Campbell QC said the evidence clearly showed the accused men were responsible for placing an unaccompanied bag containing a bomb on board the plane.

Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, the two accused men, worked together and were constantly in each other's company in the days leading up to the bombing, he said.

"The evidence demonstrates that there was a plan to attack an aircraft and that that plan was successfully brought to fruition," he told the trial, held under Scottish law at Camp Zeist in Holland.

"The sending of a bomb in an unaccompanied bag was a method of attack against an aircraft of which everyone in the airline industry was only too well aware."

The prosecution had also shown that the pair travelled from the Libyan capital, Tripoli, to Malta - where the bomb began its journey - on the day before the attack.

Mr Campbell rejected defence claims that others, namely two Palestinian terror groups, carried out the bombing.

He said there was no evidence to support the "special defences" which blame the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command and named individuals including convicted terrorist Abu Talb for the outrage.

The court adjourned until tomorrow to allow defence lawyers time to study the changes before beginning their final speeches.

Mr Megrahi and Mr Fhimah deny bombing Flight 103 which exploded over Lockerbie on December 21 1988 killing 270 people, 11 of them on the ground in the Scottish town.

webTitle: Channel 4 bags £6m online education contract

fields.headline: Channel 4 bags £6m online education contract
fields.trailText: Channel 4 has won a £6m contract to provide a new government TV and online education service, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has secured a £6m contract to provide a new government TV and online education service aimed at seven to 11-year-olds.

The station beat off rival bids from the BBC, Granada Media and Anglia TV to win the Department for Education & Employment contract for GridClub.

Channel 4, known for education programmes such as Darren Gough's Cricket Academy, History in Action and Geography Junction, is working in partnership with software firm Oracle and internet education consultancy Intuitive Media to develop the site.

GridClub will offer free content to online clubs covering topics including animals, music and sport; a virtual library with material from 4Learning and other educational publishers; and an internet shop where parents and teachers can buy supplementary material.

A Channel 4 tie-in series, What If?, will be broadcast in September as part of the 4Learning schools schedule.

4Learning commissioning editor Simon Fuller said: "This contract demonstrates Channel 4's commitment to imaginative and responsive education and the creative use of new technology for learning."

The online service will use Oracle's Think.com software, which allows school children and teachers to create protected online learning communities.

Bob Hart, Intuitive Media director, said: "We will make GridClub a safe place on the web where children can follow their own interests and work together online, with a rich library of exciting resources to support their learning."

GridClub is being funded by the DfEE as part of its National Grid for Learning project and is designed to support the National Curriculum.

The service is projected to become financially self-sustaining after three years from revenue generated through sponsorship and e-commerce.

webTitle: LWT loses comedy chief

fields.headline: LWT loses comedy chief
fields.trailText: 10.30am: LWT head of comedy Lisa Clark has quit to return to a more hands-on programme-making role.
fields.body:
Lisa Clark has quit LWT where she was head of comedy to return to a more hands-on programme-making role.

She left the TV company on Friday and is considering a number of offers.

Ms Clark was one of the original whizz-kids behind the Big Breakfast and is considered one of TV entertainment's A-list producers.

In just over a year at LWT, she oversaw the adaptation of Aladdin for ITV, the Channel 4 sitcom Spaced and the Big Stage for Channel 5.

An LWT insider admitted that Ms Clark had taken on a "really hard job" with the LWT comedy role, with a primary goal of getting commissions from the ITV Network Centre.

ITV has commissioned very few sitcoms or other comedy shows in the past few years despite the appointment of Sioned Wiliam as controller of comedy.

Ms Clark's credits include the Big Breakfast and Vic Reeves and Bob Mortimer's BBC1 Saturday night vehicle, Families at War.

webTitle: Parents: Joanna Briscoe on childcare

fields.headline: I adore my son, but I'm so bored
fields.standfirst: Being a mother is a magical experience for  Joanna Briscoe. Doing the childcare, though, is proving to be a different story...
fields.trailText: Being a mother is a magical experience for Joanna Briscoe. Doing the childcare, though, is proving to be a different story...
fields.body:
Parenthood is a seething pit of paradox. Due to my grinning, cart-pushing 10-month-old son, Christmas was once again endowed with magic, instead of cursing anticipation and assiduous study of the Radio Times. But thank God for the new nursery term. Thank God for - well, nurseries. And a muttered "thank God" for the looming dearth of bank holidays. The threatened four-day week would not suit.

The biggest contradiction of all is that motherhood is a shockingly lovely state, yet childcare is a spectacularly ghastly activity. We're not supposed to admit it. Recently, however, I've taken to blurted confessions. People are startled, excited, or amused, then promptly offer up a similar version of events.

Dawns and late afternoons are punctuated by cries of, "Look, darling, a giraffe ... No, not the plug sockets, a giraffe." With a bell in it. With orange fur. Minutes seem to haul themselves along on broken clogs. Exhaustion converges with boredom of a kind unknown since O-level maths homework.

The care of a 10-month-old involves pulling him away from stereos, planting kisses, croaking limply about plugs, sneaking in more kisses, wiping snot with a finger, sighing, gritting teeth, and virtually vomiting with passion and frustration in turn. It means a throbbing spine and banana-smeared shoulders and seconds of communication so intense, all expression of love short of cannibalism is inadequate. How I long for him and feel actual addiction to his smell and finally understand the sublime in life. How I quake at the prospect of a mere four hours of solitary childcare.

I actually have endless support and am rarely on my own. I'm deeply contented striding around with the buggy, showing him off, visiting friends and going out as a family. It's just the reality of chasing a toddling being through a tangle of velvet curtains and Fisher Price that is the heart-sinking foundation beneath the smiles and dove-cooing dialogues and visions of life reborn. It's the hidden hours, invisible, swallowed, that shock me. When it's just me and him, I gasp at single mothers. At mothers of more than one. At my grandmother, who had nine. I want to riot for state childcare, manufacture medals, and make all their work visible. I have a paltry afternoon's worth of it, and I'm in a catatonic state of exhaustion by the time he's gone to bed.

Life with a baby is perpetually sweet-sour. I can never get my head around it. Why is motherhood the pinnacle of human loveliness in its essence, yet the hour-on-hour reality can be horrendous?

By staying at home with a toddler, one is also forced to face the squalor and antiquity of one's living conditions. So how I adore my son, yet how I adore that nursery. Six babies, the kindest carers, and phenomenally energetic singing, finger-painting and nappy-changing. It is brilliant. I want to weep with gratitude. Yet still we pay for a full-time place, use it only part-time, and suffer guilt during those short middle hours of the day, even though he appears obviously happy there. Guilt, of course, is easy to suffer when one is happily engaged in that idle activity one used to call "work".

I find the contradiction between the real and the conceptual is more extreme here than in any other area of life. I would throw myself in front of a lorry to prevent damage to the silken little toe of my son, yet half a week's housebound entertaining him due to a cold sets me gagging with boredom and fatigue. In my wildest moments of love, I wish to reside with him alone, preferably naked, in a cave on Dartmoor, breastfeeding and watching storms together. Yet I clock-watch in my comfortable flat with all the glazed fixation of a sweatshop worker.

Perhaps it can be blamed on middle youth. We with our late babies are amazed and outraged at the infringement on life as we knew it. I'm in rebellion even as I'm in love. I see little prospect of change.

No, sweetheart, those are the sockets...

Due to my grinning, cart-pushing 10-month-old son, Christmas was once again endowed with magic, instead of cursing anticipation and assiduous study of the Radio Times. But thank God for the new nursery term. Thank God for - well, nurseries. And a muttered "thank God" for the looming dearth of bank holidays. The threatened four-day week would not suit. The biggest contradiction of all is that motherhood is a shockingly lovely state, yet childcare is a spectacularly ghastly activity. We're not supposed to admit it. Recently, however, I've taken to blurted confessions. People are startled, excited, or amused, then promptly offer up a similar version of events. webTitle: Parents: The panel

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Pilot schemes are under way to make the morning-after pill available in schools, potentially to girls as young as 11. Is this right?
fields.trailText: The Question: Pilot schemes are under way to make the morning-after pill available in schools, potentially to girls as young as 11. Is this right?
fields.body:
Alice Richardson
Spokesperson Education for Choice

We work with young people in schools providing information about contraception, sexual health and abortion from a pro-choice perspective. Any action that may reduce unintended pregnancies is welcome. It is better to be informed and provided with emergency contraception than to continue with an unwanted pregnancy or have an abortion. Emergency contraception needs improved advertising and availability in schools. A school nurse may be more approachable and better placed to make young people to feel safe, so that they can seek advice about future contraception.
Verdict: Yes

Michael Crane
Head teacher John Port school in Derbyshire

My school is one of the largest in the country, with some 2,000 students. We do not have a particular problem with teenage pregnancies, but the governors decided to make the morning-after pill available in school via a trained nurse practitioner. This facility is part of a wide-ranging health education programme within the school and is supported by advice and counselling. The service to our students is highly confidential (unless the nurse considers a student "at risk"). The response to the scheme from parents has been overwhelmingly positive.
Verdict: Yes

Dr Trevor Stammers
Spokesperson Family and Youth Concern

Any school sex education policy should have as its basis giving young people assistance in resisting pressure to have sex, but I think the morning-after pill is the lesser of two evils rather than an abortion which is much more traumatic. But what worries me is whether the school nurse will take on the related health issues. Statistically, teenage girls who get pregnant are far more likely to smoke and take drugs, and they're at risk of sexually transmitted diseases. Just giving these girls a couple of pills and telling them to use a packet of condoms next time is utterly inadequate.
Verdict: No

Mark Blake
Spokesperson Blackliners sexual health project

Blackliners is a black and minority ethnic sexual health project in south London. Part of our area has the highest teenage pregnancy rate in the UK: our work is to prevent those pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases. I think giving the morning-after pill out at school is a good idea because girls do not always want to go along to a clinic; but it should involve parents. It should be available in the context of effective sex and relationship education which will prevent young people from getting to the stage where they need the pill in the first place.
Verdict: Yes

Jenny Bacon
Parents Against Oral Contraception for Children

Sexually transmitted diseases in this country are at epidemic levels and making this sort of contraception available to children won't help. I believe some of these girls wouldn't be getting involved in sex if contraception wasn't so easily available to them. Parents have a right to know if their children are involved in under-age sex. Schools can't give out aspirin without seeking parental permission, but they can give out the morning-after pill, which contains a very high dose of hormones - it's not like eating a Smartie. We should be promoting chastity and abstinence to our children.
Verdict: No

webTitle: Parents: Guide to parenting websites

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: A brief guide to parenting websites
fields.trailText: A brief guide to parenting websites.
fields.body:
Flametree

Its mission: To be inspirational and practical.

Who is it for? Working parents.

How can it help? Flametree has a wealth of practical information for working mothers in particular. Issues such as finding a late-night surgery, knowing your rights at work and maternity leave are well researched and useful. Interviews with high-profile working mothers - currently Nancy Traversy, co-founder of Barefoot Books - give an interesting insight into how others cope with juggling family and work.

Test question: My child's first nativity performance clashes with an important meeting at work. What should I do?

Pass or fail? Fail. I couldn't find a way to put my question to Christine Hill, a chartered physiotherapist and post-grad in paediatrics and obstetrics. In order to ask the question, I first had to register, and was then sent back to a forum. I ended up going round and round in circles before giving up and deciding for myself that I would chuck a sickie.

Shopping facility: None.

Score: 5/10

B4baby

Its mission: No mission statement.

Who is it for? Parents at the pre-conception, pregnancy and new baby phase.

How can it help? I liked the month-by-month section of what changes pregnant mothers can expect to their own bodies, and the development of the foetus. The video clips showing pelvic floor excercises - ouch - are innovative and useful. The site effectively tackles a wealth of subjects pertinent to new parents.

Test question: My eight-month-old baby has a tongue-tie. Should I follow the advice of my GP and let her undergo a general anaesthetic to have it corrected, or wait until she is older?

Pass or fail? Pass. My question was answered the following morning with sound advice from a paediatrician, erring on the side of caution regarding an operation. B4baby.com has all the answers, but felt rather too serious. Lighten up a little, willya?

Shopping facility: A small selection, including its current special offer - half-price Persil non-bio when purchasing anything from the clothing or linen section, which didn't seem all that special.

Score: 7/10

Urbia

Its mission: To entertain, inform and give a platform for your views.

Who is it for? Parents, grandparents, soon-to-be-parents, and anyone who knows any kids.

How can it help? Urbia has a funky edge and its strength is in its forums (discussions are pertinent and well attended), the magazine section, and its sense of humour. It doesn't offer the definitive guide to practical parenting, although serious topics are well researched. Its sections include relationships, health, pregnancy, pre-school and an extraordinary ovulation calender. It will actually text message you at your peak fertility time, which could be interesting in the middle of a meeting.

Test question: Too hard to find online experts, so I sneaked one in to the editorial team, asking: Is it OK to feed my 18-month-old food containing nuts?

Pass or fail: Pass. The editor came back to me within hours with sensible advice. The urbia health visitor responded the next day.

Shopping facility: Snappy and fun links to shopping sites.

Score: 8/10

Family2000

Its mission: No mission statement.

Who is it for? Parents and grandparents.

How can it help? As resources for gay and lesbian families are scant, this site offers a view on subjects such as lesbian mums, coming out when you have kids and gay and lesbian families. It is refreshingly supportive, highly perceptive and informative. It also tackles subjects that other parenting sites often shy away from - step-parenting, divorce issues, single parents, second weddings. A page is dedicated to reviewing books which may be helpful to families who don't fit the 2.4 kids criteria. Articles confront parenting and sexuality issues in an understanding way.

Test question: My kids have learned the word "queer" in the playground. Should I explain why it is offensive, or simply tell them to stop it without going into details? They are six and nine.

Pass or fail? Pass. A same-day response advised me to bring it up in a general chat about sex with my nine year old.

Shopping facility: None.

Score: 6/10

Mumsnet

Its mission: Practical advice and information by parents for parents.

Who is it for? Anyone with kids.

How can it help? User-friendly site which provides a mass of product reviews by parents which is useful for buying equipment, a major outlay. Articles on teaching your child to write, family-friendly holidays, best places for a long weekend with kids and a live chat session were all enjoyable and useful. Check out Gina Ford online shortly. Slight lack of a sense of humour.

Test question: My son has excellent maths skills but is let down by his reading. How can I help him?

Pass or fail? Fail. But my fault partially. I was put off by the statement that not every question would be answered and preferred to use a site where an answer is guaranteed. However, the answer provided to another user's question on Steiner schools was in-depth and constructive.

Shopping facility: 10% discount offer on Urchin, Kid's Stuff, playbug.com and the Great Little Trading Company.

Score: 8/10

Planetoneparent

Its mission? To provide a "life organiser" for lone parents.

Who is it for? Lone parents.

How can it help? The site is easy to navigate, and straightforward. No clever-dick graphics here. It covers topics with particular relevance to single parents - such as how to explain to children what happens during a divorce, with tips on how best to come out unscathed. I thought its idea of a "parenting plan" was spot on. There is an un-manned chatroom where every topic begins with an opening paragraph which assumes that lone parents have gone through some horrific trauma. Saying that, though, as a resource for lone parents, planetoneparent is predominantly practical, sensible and relevant. Coming soon is its holiday portfolio which aims to design holidays specifically for one-parent families.

Test question: No facility for asking experts.

Shopping facility: Links to Tesco, Mothercare, Iceland, Early Learning Centre and more.

Score: 6/10

webTitle: Parents: How to teach a child to cycle

fields.headline: The wobble challenge
fields.standfirst: So you bought your child a new bike for Christmas. All you have to do now is teach them how to ride it. And that, says  Daniel Lee, could leave you both feeling a little saddle-sore
fields.trailText: So you bought your child a new bike for Christmas. All you have to do now is teach them how to ride it. And that, says Daniel Lee, could leave you both feeling a little saddle-sore.
fields.body:
Microscooters are for Christmas, but a bike is for life. Thousands of children will now be cycling for the first time after getting one as a gift. And their older siblings, concerned to stay ahead in the race, will be eager to discard their stabilisers.

Parents greet these challenges with a mixture of delight, anxiety and, perhaps, a tinge of sadness. After all, when a child cycles into the distance faster than their parent can walk, they acquire a new independence. It is the perfect metaphor for how children's lives will later diverge from their parents'.

The problem is that adults, myself included, find it hard not to communicate their anxiety about their children's wobbling progress. What sort of bike should I buy? How will they take to it? And how can I explain how to balance? The worries are endless.

Doug McIntosh and Susan Perolls bought their son Fraser, aged three-and-a-half, his first bike shortly before Christmas. "We were more nervous than he was," says McIntosh. "Before we bought the bike, we asked everyone - friends and neighbours with older children - what sort of cycle to get and, in the end, we just bought one from a catalogue."

Fraser's first reaction when he saw the bike was disappointment. "Why hasn't it got dinosaurs on?" he asked. Why not indeed?

Then he kept pedalling in reverse until, after a fortnight of frustration, he finally got the hang of it. "I think Fraser was not too daunted by the bike," says Perolls, "because he understood the concept from having been on the back of our cycles."

Patrick Field, director of the London School of Cycling, agrees that a good parental example is critical: "It can sometimes be difficult for parents who do not cycle as a normal activity to encourage their children. They feel awkward with it and this, or other anxieties, can rub off on their children."

It is not balance that is the key to cycling, but confidence. "Everyone says that children don't mind falling over and that is wrong," says Field. "They feel just the same about it as adults. But they are used to facing challenges on a daily basis, so are more ready to submit to it. In a similar way, riding a bike is not getting over instability, but learning to surrender to the instability - falling over all the time a couple of degrees to the left and right."

Field's point is based on the observation that, in the language of physics, the bicycle rider is in a continual state of "unstable equilibrium". Staying upright on two wheels must be experienced for the subconscious mind to realise that a cycle's stability increases with speed - just the opposite of what one would expect on foot. But this is the only thing to remember for balance, explains Field, unlike jumping or running where numerous muscles must be co-ordinated.

Learning this skill cannot, however, be forced. "Parents cannot pressurise their children into cycling with or without stabilisers," Field argues, "but with luck kids feel compelled to ride from the example of adults and, ultimately, of their peers." Parents can only provide the opportunities: the bike and then running alongside, perhaps holding the saddle until their child feels confident enough to go it alone.

If a child does not begin cycling at the same time as their peers, it can make it more difficult for them to get started because they begin to feel embarrassed and under pressure. Feeling inhibited is the worst way to tackle what can seem such an alien feeling.

Sandra Henry made the error of getting angry with her son Joe when he first took the stabilisers off his bike at five. "He seemed to be making no effort to stay on the bike what-soever," she says. "I just got so frustrated and finally lost it."

This momentary lapse meant Henry had to re-fit the stabilisers, and Joe wouldn't try cycling without them for another three years. "I tried everything to encourage him," she says, "but he wouldn't have it." Eventually, aged nearly eight, he became so fed up at being unable to join friends on cycle rides that he insisted on spending an afternoon at the park struggling to stay upright until he was steady on two wheels.

Patrick Field teaches both children and adults. The safety organisation RoSPA also runs cycle proficiency courses for children, and the Cyclists' Touring Club (CTC) plans to launch a training course for teenagers and adults soon.

As children grow up, parents inevitably have to face the tricky issue of when to allow their child out to cycle on their own - and in the road. And again, understandably, there is a lot of misplaced anxiety.

"Parental worries about safety usually far outweigh the actual dangers," Field says. "Right from the start of cycling, get a good helmet, make sure the bike is the right size, and encourage your child to take a bold position on the path and later the road. Emphasise to them that it is dangerous to sneak through narrow gaps."

Department of Transport figures confirm that the risks of cycling are not great. Only once in every 300,000 cycling kilometres is a cyclist seriously injured, while only once in every 17m kilometres cycled will a rider be killed.

Whatever risk there is should also be seen in the context of cycling's benefits. Cycling as a child encourages a healthy attitude for later life when the exercise can make a big difference. "A cyclist riding at a moderate speed for 30 minutes [in other words, a typical commuting journey] five times a week has the fitness level of someone 10 years their junior," says CTC director Kevin Mayne.

Overall, cycling promotes health, both directly, as a physical activity that is kinder to the joints and bones than any form of running, and indirectly, as a form of transport that does not harm the environment. Just for the sheer fun of careening through puddles and pedalling up and down hills, it must be worth any amount of parental angst.

Contacts for advice and information

 London School of Cycling; 020 7249 3779
 Cyclists' Touring Club; 01483 417217
 British Cycling Federation; 0161 230 2301
 National Cycle Network information
 For details of cycling proficiency courses (now called practical cyclist training courses) devised by RoSPA, call your local authority road safety officer.

"I just got so frustrated and finally lost it." This momentary lapse meant Henry had to re-fit the stabilisers, and Joe wouldn't try cycling without them for another three years. "I tried everything to encourage him," she says, "but he wouldn't have it." Eventually, aged nearly eight, he became so fed up at being unable to join friends on cycle rides that he insisted on spending an afternoon at the park struggling to stay upright until he was steady on two wheels. Patrick Field teaches both children and adults. The safety organisation RoSPA also runs cycle proficiency courses for children, and the Cyclists' Touring Club (CTC) plans to launch a training course for teenagers and adults soon. As children grow up, parents inevitably have to face the tricky issue of when to allow their child out to cycle on their own - and in the road. And again, understandably, there is a lot of misplaced anxiety. "Parental worries about safety usually far outweigh the actual dangers," Field says. "Right from the start of cycling, get a good helmet, make sure the bike is the right size, and encourage your child to take a bold position on the path and later the road. Emphasise to them that it is dangerous to sneak through narrow gaps." Department of Transport figures confirm that the risks of cycling are not great. Only once in every 300,000 cycling kilometres is a cyclist seriously injured, while only once in every 17m kilometres cycled will a rider be killed. Whatever risk there is should also be seen in the context of cycling's benefits. Cycling as a child encourages a healthy attitude for later life when the exercise can make a big difference. "A cyclist riding at a moderate speed for 30 minutes [in other words, a typical commuting journey] five times a week has the fitness level of someone 10 years their junior," says CTC director Kevin Mayne. Overall, cycling promotes health, both directly, as a physical activity that is kinder to the joints and bones than any form of running, and indirectly, as a form of transport that does not harm the environment. Just for the sheer fun of careening through puddles and pedalling up and down hills, it must be worth any amount of parental angst. webTitle: Parents: Janet and John's revamped

fields.headline: Tell us a snorey
fields.standfirst: Janet and John have come out of retirement to help a new generation of young readers. But is revamping this joyless series really such a good idea, asks children's author  Francesca Simon
fields.trailText: Janet and John have come out of retirement to help a new generation of young readers. But is revamping this joyless series really such a good idea, asks children's author Francesca Simon.
fields.body:
I learned to read on Janet and John's American counterparts - Dick and Jane, and their dog Spot. This was in the early 60s, and these dour books did the deed tediously and joylessly.

See Spot. See Spot run. Run Spot run. My heart sinks just writing the sentences.

No one who had to read those phrases over and over and over as I did could ever forget them. Like a bad pop lyric they echo round your head, all that seeing and running - a strange, stilted, dreary 50s world of prissy children, perfect parents, and hyperactive dogs. And God forbid there should be characters, or a joke or a rhyme. Learning to read was a serious business - and don't you forget it. And woe betide the slow learner. My husband couldn't read until he was 8 or 9, yet was stuck with Janet and John regardless.

In the bad old days, apart from the immortal Dr Seuss, there wasn't much around for beginning readers. So I am bemused that at a time of renaissance in children's literature, when witty, delightful books for children are plentiful, the Janet and John primers are being re-issued. Why?

So parents who endured them the first time round can inflict them on their own kids? To me, it's like choosing to eat Spam and wear crimplene when you can enjoy caviar and sport cashmere. But don't worry, these "classic characters for today's kids" have been updated.

See Dad. See Dad mop. Mop Dad mop. See Mum. See Mum saw. Saw Mum saw.

All right, I made that up. But believe me, the problem with Dick and Jane wasn't the fact that Mom was stapled to her pinny. It was the artificial, stilted language, the goody-goody kids, the complete absence of life and fun as we know it. I'm all for simplicity and repetition - you only have to look at Allan Ahlberg's brilliant Red Nose Readers to see what magic he can create using single words and phrases.

Putting in a few black faces, and dressing Janet and John in clumpy shoes, has not stopped the re-written and re-illustrated books being plodding and monotonous. The Parent's Guide which accompanies the relaunched books suggests asking your child "Who is your favourite character?" These aren't characters. They're stick figures in a dull reading scheme.

I still remember the first real book my parents gave me: The Pancake. It had a mottled purple cover, and it was filled with stories. They were simple, they were repetitive, but they were real, entertaining stories. It was marvellous - my reward for the months spent learning how letters and sounds fit together. Until then, I don't think I realised that books were meant to be fun.

I learned to read on Dick and Jane: I did not become a reader. That was thanks to Enid Blyton, PL Travers, Andrew Lang's wonderful fairytale books, Tintin, Edward Eager's magic books, and Beverly Cleary. I read with great passion and intensity, and I read everything: comic books, biographies, magazines, fiction. I came downstairs every morning with my nose mysteriously smudged blue (from the not-quite dry ink on the pages I would smell at night, I later realised).

Every parent knows learning to read is often a chore, like memorising times tables. It takes forever, progress is fitful, and - for the children - it can be hard to see the point. That is, until they find something they actually want to read. My son learned to read at seven only because he wanted to decipher Monopoly Chance and Community Chest cards. My younger brother finally bothered to learn because his passion was coins, and he needed to read coin catalogues.

So my firm belief is that children should read whatever interests them: football magazines, comics, games manuals. Obviously, as a fiction writer for children, I would rather they read fiction, and preferably mine. My own son loved Asterix, Tintin, role-playing books, and fantasy novels such as the Brian Jacques Redwall series. I've never been much of a fantasy fan, so we compromised.

I read to him books I loved - Mary Poppins, Winnie the Pooh, Little House in the Big Woods, Greek and Norse myths, and anything by Roald Dahl, Quentin Blake, Anthony Browne, Michael Rosen, Jack Prelutsky, Phillip Pullman. He read comics, Horrible Histories and computer game manuals on his own. But I am happy that he enjoys reading. So what if our tastes diverge?

Adults are allowed to read for pleasure; children are supposed to read to learn. Worse still, anxious parents push kids to read harder and harder books. I remember all the parental playground moans that the books their kids were given to read were "too easy". The teachers would protest that the children had chosen the books themselves. No matter: a book that is too easy is a bad book. Children rarely get to enjoy the reading stage they are at. Give them something harder. Harder! Make them learn. Make them sweat.

Here is the next target for the bedtime core curriculum. I've seen well-meaning parents drag kids away from the picture book section in bookshops because the books are no longer "age-appropriate". Where's the pleasure here? My son's teenage babysitter has read picture books all her life. She's now at Cambridge University, so I hardly think she was stunted intellectually by reading "beneath" her.

Another way we punish children for their progress is to stop reading to them the moment they can read for themselves. I find this very sad. There's such a huge gap between what young children are able to read, and what they can enjoy. Reading to them keeps them in contact with a voice, as well as reminding them again and again: reading is a joy, an entry into different, magical worlds. I remember reading Swallows and Amazons to my son, and struggling through a page of mysterious sailing terms. Finally, I stopped and asked if he minded not understanding. No, he said: he liked hearing the words.

In fairness, I should point out that first readers are incredibly difficult to write for. My own Horrid Henry books started as a failed attempt to write one. I just couldn't do it: I couldn't strip my words down sufficiently and still tell a fun story. It is a very tricky skill to acquire (hats off, again, to Allan Ahlberg and Colin McNaughton).

I am always flattered and delighted when parents tell me that the Horrid Henry books are the first ones that their children read voluntarily. Just as adults like reading about outsiders and people who break free from convention, so kids get a thrill from a child who acts impulsively and never worries about the consequences. If Henry sees a door marked "No Entry", he barges through it. He's greedy, he's aggressive, he's anarchic: the imp inside everyone. Kids enjoy characters who have emotions they recognise.

While Henry disrupts the established order, the younger brother he hates, Perfect Peter (Janet and John's direct descendent) is an exaggerated version of the impeccably behaved child parents think they want. I particularly enjoy writing honestly about sibling rivalry - I'm the eldest of four - and looking coolly at parents from a child's point of view.

I walk a tightrope with Horrid Henry's subversiveness. We invest children's books with tremendous power to influence, and many adults seriously believe that giving children books about idealised families such as Janet and John's will make their children grow up to be just like them. As if.

But if you enjoyed Janet and John, by all means enjoy them with your kids. They'll pick up your enthusiasm and that's vital. I'm afraid I could only share them the way my husband shares boarding-school horror stories with our son: see how I suffered.

Run Spot run. As far away as you can.

 The most recent in Francesca Simon's Horrid Henry series, Horrid Henry and the Mummy's Curse, illustrated by Tony Ross, is published by Dolphin Paperbacks at £3.95.

webTitle: Life after the death of community health councils?

fields.headline: Test of patients
fields.standfirst: As MPs debate the abolition of community health councils, local government leader  Jeremy Beecham offers a lifeline
fields.trailText: As MPs debate the abolition of community health councils, local government leader Jeremy Beecham offers a lifeline
fields.body:
It is now a year since the winter crisis in the health service led to the government's increased resource commitment and the subsequent NHS plan to deliver major changes. If the objectives of that plan are to be fully realised, the principal target of creating a patient-led service must be achieved. Indeed, the quality of care for patients, and the value of accountability to taxpayers and citizens more generally, are crucial to the achievement of a modern, responsive public service which demonstrates both competence and confidence to the people it serves.

In the past few weeks, the government's commitment to improving scrutiny and local accountability as part of this process has been overshadowed by growing concern about the proposed abolition of community health councils (CHCs) in England. This was arguably the most unexpected aspect of the NHS plan and the statutory means have now been included in the health and social care bill, currently before parliament.

Growing numbers of MPs, peers and health commentators are expressing unease about the proposed abolition and this is likely to surface today during the bill's second reading in the Commons. There is widespread support for the government's intention of moving the CHCs' scrutiny function to local councils.

This is a logical extension of the new general scrutiny powers in the new Local Government Act and strengthens the community leadership role of local authorities. Although local councillors serve on CHCs, they do so as members of nominated bodies. Local councils are directly elected and can address some of the democratic deficit widely acknowledged to be a feature of the NHS for the past quarter of a century.

Health issues are not self-contained. They impinge on a wide range of services for which local councils are responsible, such as social care, education, housing, public health, transport and leisure. In broader terms, tackling health inequalities will require a holistic and responsive approach from the NHS, working with local authorities and the voluntary sector.

Moreover, CHCs have more limited powers than usually assumed. They never had a formal role in scrutinising primary care, which has at last been acknowledged as centre stage in achieving health objectives. And while the best CHCs have worked constructively on behalf of local communities, performance has varied.

Local authorities, then, are well placed to act as advocates for their communities on the planning and performance of health services, drawing on the expertise of CHC members and officers whose skill and experience should be utilised in the new scrutiny process.

Yet the role of patient advocacy, currently another CHC function, is different. The health and social care bill also proposes the creation of patients' forums to act as the voice of the user in the reformed service. It is envisaged that these would be part of the health system, reporting to the secretary of state who is also accountable for policy and performance of the entire service.

However well these systems might work, it must be recognised that a crucial element of independence and transparency would be missing. This need for independence has to be weighed against the argument that locating patient advocacy within the system might be a more effective way of preventing problems arising. There may, therefore, be a case for the retention, if not of CHCs themselves, at least of their advocacy role. This could be achieved in the form of a reshaped community health council or a patients' forum and advocacy service working alongside the NHS and the local authority in its scrutiny role.

There is little controversy about the government's objective of a patient-led service. The issue is about how it is achieved. The argument about the retention or abolition of CHCs could lead to an unnecessarily negative debate over the next few months. What is crucial is the location of the functions, not necessarily the retention of a particular institution.

The Local Government Association, representing local authorities, and the NHS Confederation, representing health service bodies, are discussing how best to develop the scrutiny role. Scrutiny must be seen as a deliberate, not an adversarial, process, although of course councils must remain able to be critical of local health service policies and their implementation.

There is also a need to consider how best to scrutinise regional specialities, especially where it may not be appropriate to allocate responsibility to an individual authority in which, perhaps, a regional cardiothoracic unit or cancer service may be located.

Modernisation of the NHS will require a greater degree of local accountability and sensitivity than has been the case in a service apparently dominated by needs of the acute medical services. Local government is anxious to play its part in connecting health services to the community and ensuring a strategic approach to preventing, as well as curing, ill health.

 Sir Jeremy Beecham chairs the Local Government Association and sits on the NHS modernisation board.

webTitle: Reuters creates internet role for new boss Glocer

fields.headline: Reuters creates internet role for new boss Glocer
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Reuters has reshuffled its management to let chief executive-designate Tom Glocer concentrate on company strategy, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Global news group Reuters has reshuffled its management to let chief executive-designate Tom Glocer concentrate on company strategy.

Mr Glocer is to leave his job as head of Reuters Information and oversee the transfer of the group's main businesses onto the internet.

His role will be filled by Philip Green, chief executive of Reuters Trading solutions.

Reuters' expansion strategies received several knocks last year, after it postponed the flotation of its Greenhouse technology investment fund and abandoned the launch of a retail version of its Instinet share trading unit.

mr Glocer, who is the first American and non-journalist to head the group, will also relinquish day-to-day management of Reuters' American operations.

He will succeed outgoing chief executive Peter Job in July.

Indeed, the quality of care for patients, and the value of accountability to taxpayers and citizens more generally, are crucial to the achievement of a modern, responsive public service which demonstrates both competence and confidence to the people it serves. In the past few weeks, the government's commitment to improving scrutiny and local accountability as part of this process has been overshadowed by growing concern about the proposed abolition of community health councils (CHCs) in England. This was arguably the most unexpected aspect of the NHS plan and the statutory means have now been included in the health and social care bill, currently before parliament. Growing numbers of MPs, peers and health commentators are expressing unease about the proposed abolition and this is likely to surface today during the bill's second reading in the Commons. There is widespread support for the government's intention of moving the CHCs' scrutiny function to local councils. This is a logical extension of the new general scrutiny powers in the new Local Government Act and strengthens the community leadership role of local authorities. Although local councillors serve on CHCs, they do so as members of nominated bodies. Local councils are directly elected and can address some of the democratic deficit widely acknowledged to be a feature of the NHS for the past quarter of a century. Health issues are not self-contained. They impinge on a wide range of services for which local councils are responsible, such as social care, education, housing, public health, transport and leisure. In broader terms, tackling health inequalities will require a holistic and responsive approach from the NHS, working with local authorities and the voluntary sector. Moreover, CHCs have more limited powers than usually assumed. They never had a formal role in scrutinising primary care, which has at last been acknowledged as centre stage in achieving health objectives. And while the best CHCs have worked constructively on behalf of local communities, performance has varied. Local authorities, then, are well placed to act as advocates for their communities on the planning and performance of health services, drawing on the expertise of CHC members and officers whose skill and experience should be utilised in the new scrutiny process. Yet the role of patient advocacy, currently another CHC function, is different. The health and social care bill also proposes the creation of patients' forums to act as the voice of the user in the reformed service. It is envisaged that these would be part of the health system, reporting to the secretary of state who is also accountable for policy and performance of the entire service. However well these systems might work, it must be recognised that a crucial element of independence and transparency would be missing. This need for independence has to be weighed against the argument that locating patient advocacy within the system might be a more effective way of preventing problems arising. There may, therefore, be a case for the retention, if not of CHCs themselves, at least of their advocacy role. This could be achieved in the form of a reshaped community health council or a patients' forum and advocacy service working alongside the NHS and the local authority in its scrutiny role. There is little controversy about the government's objective of a patient-led service. The issue is about how it is achieved. The argument about the retention or abolition of CHCs could lead to an unnecessarily negative debate over the next few months. What is crucial is the location of the functions, not necessarily the retention of a particular institution. The Local Government Association, representing local authorities, and the NHS Confederation, representing health service bodies, are discussing how best to develop the scrutiny role. Scrutiny must be seen as a deliberate, not an adversarial, process, although of course councils must remain able to be critical of local health service policies and their implementation. There is also a need to consider how best to scrutinise regional specialities, especially where it may not be appropriate to allocate responsibility to an individual authority in which, perhaps, a regional cardiothoracic unit or cancer service may be located. Modernisation of the NHS will require a greater degree of local accountability and sensitivity than has been the case in a service apparently dominated by needs of the acute medical services. Local government is anxious to play its part in connecting health services to the community and ensuring a strategic approach to preventing, as well as curing, ill health.  Sir Jeremy Beecham chairs the Local Government Association and sits on the NHS modernisation board.

webTitle: Say farewell to community health councils

fields.headline: Say farewell to community health councils
fields.standfirst: There should be no going back on plans to abolish CHCs, says NHS Confederation policy director Nigel Edwards, in the first of a series of articles examining the health and social care bill
fields.trailText: There should be no going back on plans to abolish community health councils, says NHS confederation policy director Nigel Edwards, in the first of a series of articles examining the health and social care bill
fields.body:
The new NHS and social care bill receives its second reading today. At first sight this appears to be a technical and rather bitty measure but it contains some vitally important and far-reaching changes to the NHS.

Perhaps the most controversial change is the proposal to abolish community health councils (CHCs). This was the biggest surprise in the NHS plan, published in July 2000, as it had not been trailed in the press and has perhaps generated the most opposition to what has otherwise been an enthusiastically received plan.

CHCs have survived a large number of NHS reorganisations and are one of the few health organisations to remain largely unreformed since 1974.

Their role as public watchdogs has not always been well understood, but they were the only body with the power to object to changes and scrutinise decisions made by local health services.

This power now transfers to local government. This is a major change and it will undoubtedly have significant implications for the NHS and its managers.

It might be expected that the NHS would be nervous about this, but in fact the idea of improved local scrutiny is welcome, even if it is anticipated that it will at times lead to some uncomfortable discussions.

Today, the NHS works in much closer partnership with local government and scrutiny has the potential to improve this. An unresolved tension that may emerge, however, is that local scrutiny implies local priorities - this means variations of a type that ministers running a national NHS regard as anathema.

Once the scrutiny power is gone, the residual role of CHCs is small and consists of providing independent advice about health services and assisting complainants. Not all CHCs did this, but those that did accumulated some first-class expertise that will need to be kept.

There were concerns that there would be no independent assistance for complainants other than the new patients advocacy and liaison service, which would also have other roles that could potentially compromise their independence.

There are signs that this is being addressed in the policy that will accompany the bill.

There is no real going back. Ministers seem adamant that CHCs should be replaced and now that scrutiny is on offer, the genie is out of the bottle and the legitimacy of CHCs seems suspect compared with the prospect of full scrutiny of the NHS by local government.

A second interesting change is a new set of powers for the secretary of state to directly intervene in trusts and replace the board.

In many health care systems politicians have tended (as did many previous secretaries of state) to keep the operational running of hospitals and health services at arms' length.

The reasons for this are obvious - they have a tendency to go wrong and when they do it is high profile. An arms' length approach is useful for avoiding direct blame but very frustrating, particularly for a hands-on politician who is keen to see change.

These new powers will need to be carefully used and have some explicit criteria otherwise ministers will be constantly invited to sack people, intervene or to resign.

The NHS reform process is now underway in the NHS and in parliament. The bill is a vital part of that reform, sweeping up some important changes that will help the NHS move into the 21st century.

With a looming general election, widely thought to be in May, getting this piece of legislation through all its stages in parliament will be difficult, yet we cannot let it fall - the challenge now is to keep up the momentum.

webTitle: MPs attack move to axe community health councils

fields.headline: MPs attack move to axe community health councils
fields.trailText: Government plans to abolish community health councils (CHCs) will come under fire from MPs of all parties today in a debate on the health and social care bill, which receives its second reading. By Patrick Butler
fields.body:
Government plans to abolish community health councils (CHCs) will come under fire from MPs of all parties today in a debate on the health and social care bill, which receives its second reading.

It is likely that some Labour backbenchers will join the Liberal Democrats and the Conservatives in opposing the move, which critics say will remove independent scrutiny of local health services.

Ministers will also be criticised for failing to follow advice to provide free personal care to elderly patients in nursing homes, a key recommendation of the Royal Commission on long-term care, which is likely to be adopted in Scotland.

Nick Harvey, Liberal Democrat health spokesman, will warn ministers that patients' interests would not be served by the dispersal of CHCs' "watchdog" role to new patient advocacy and liaison services and local authorities.

"I wouldn't want to go to the stake to preserve CHCs but I do not like the fragmentation of their functions," he said. Local authorities would only be able to scrutinise service changes such as hospital and ward closures. Their role should be expanded, including taking on responsibility for public health issues, Mr Harvey will argue.

Conservative health spokesperson Liam Fox will say that although the bill has some "welcome provisions" such as enabling nurses to prescribe a wider range of drugs, it will hand too much power to the health secretary.

A motion proposed by the Tories says the bill "reinforces the central bureaucracy and entrenches the micro-management by Whitehall of the NHS which so demoralises NHS staff".

Labour backbencher David Hinchliffe, chairman of the Commons health committee, is also likely to oppose the move to abolish CHCs.
