webTitle: Post Office consigned to history

fields.headline: Post Office consigned to history
fields.standfirst: Workers deride name change and say 350 years of tradition are being dumped
fields.trailText: Workers deride name change and say 350 years of tradition are being dumped.
fields.body:
The Post Office, one of the country's more enduring institutions, has given way to the pressures of an ever changing corporate world. It yesterday announced plans to change its name to Consignia from the end of March. Post Office, it explained, no longer adequately described what it did.

John Roberts, its chief executive, was quick to point out that as far as the general public was concerned there would be little visible change.

Its main brand names and logos will remain the same. The postman delivering letters to the door will still work for the Royal Mail, parcels will be distributed by Parcelforce Worldwide in its distinctive vans and local post offices will still display the familiar logo.

The change immediately came under fire from the Post Office's own workers, however. The Communication Workers Union pledged to campaign against the decision, complaining that it was "dumping" 350 years of tradition. Deputy general secretary John Keggie believed the exercise was "rushed and ill-conceived". He said: "We should be trading on the British Post Office's worldwide reputation."

The driving force behind the name change has been the Post Office's determination to become a leading player in the international distribution and logistics business. The new name is based on to consign: to entrust to the care of.

The Post Office is a generic term which cannot be legally protected and this was hindering its international expansion plans, the organisation said. Overseas people inevitably referred to the organisation as the British Post Office to distinguish it from its local rivals.

"We did not think British Post Office was as strong as Consignia," said Neville Bain, the Post Office chairman. "It would be abbreviated to BPO and the branding consultants said that a word which is recognisable and describes what you do is better than some conglomerate of initials."

The Post Office worked with consultants, Dragon, and ran focus groups to judge reactions to various names. The words "British" and "Royal" got a poor reception. Other names were already registered or meant something unacceptable in other languages.

The Post Office, which faces the rapid erosion of its traditional letter monopoly in Britain, has spent £500m during the past two years buying foreign logistics and parcel companies, largely in mainland Europe.

Mr Roberts said the Post Office would present itself as Consignia overseas and to the big corporate customers who account for the bulk of its business. It would also consider using Consignia as a brand name if it moved into new markets.

Post Office executives stressed that the business was changing rapidly. International operations account for about £1.2bn of its £7.5bn turnover and would account for more in the years ahead.

It is also turning to new activities such as call centres, warehousing, logistics and collection points for goods ordered over the internet.

The change is timed to coincide with the change in the Post Office's status to a government-owned public limited company on March 26. The status gives it greater commercial freedom. Mr Roberts said the organisation was spending £1.5m in connection with the switch to plc status, and that the name change would add a further £500,000.

By comparison Andersen Consulting is spending £100m on promoting its name change to Accenture. "It's the difference between changing a corporate name and changing a whole brand identity," a Post Office executive said.

webTitle: NHS lab workers win above-inflation pay rises

fields.headline: NHS lab workers win above-inflation pay rises
fields.trailText: Ministers have moved to head off a chronic shortage of NHS laboratory staff involved in screening for diseases such as cancer by offering them inflation-busting pay rises of up to 13%. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Ministers have moved to head off a chronic shortage of NHS laboratory staff involved in screening for diseases such as cancer by offering them inflation-busting pay rises of up to 13%.

The offer is accompanied by minimum pay offers of at least 3.7% for more than 300,000 NHS staff, including ambulance officers, clerical staff, and estates and maintenance workers.

The lowest-paid NHS workers such as porters, cleaners and kitchen staff will be guaranteed a £4.20-an-hour rate, although it is unclear whether this will apply to hospital staff employed by private firms.

The cost of the overall offer is £250m, with £3m going to NHS laboratory staff.

Health unions - which have campaigned hard for increases for laboratory staff over the past year, have welcomed the offer - although they will not accept it until they have had time to study the details of the deal, which will take effect on April 1.

The pay offer to hospital laboratory staff was welcomed as a recognition by ministers that recruitment and retention problems related to low pay were threatening to disrupt operations and disease screening initiatives. Ministers have been repeatedly embarrassed by revelations over the past 12 months that some laboratory staff who screened patients for cancer were paid less than a supermarket check-out operator.

Laboratory staff were due receive a rise of around 2.7% from April 2001 under the third tranche of a three year deal. But the 3.7% award to nurses and doctors before Christmas made this untenable, and the agreement was quickly renegotiated.

Under the terms of the new offer, which will add between 3% and 13% to the basic 3.7% award, the starting salary for laboratory workers, who need a degree level science qualification to enter the profession, will jump from £9,720 to £11,180 per year.

London-based staff will receive rises of more than 20% because of increases in London weighting, which will rise by a further 3.7%, and moves to improve salaries for the lowest grades.

MSF general secretary Roger Lyons said of the deal: "It recognises the significance of the contribution made by our scientific members in the NHS.

"The NHS is becoming increasingly dependent on scientists and without this deal recruitment levels would have fallen to a dangerous level, which would have put patients lives in danger."

Health minister John Denham called the awards "fair and affordable pay rises" for an "important group" of NHS staff. "We are taking targeted action to tackle specific problem areas - especially in NHS laboratories - where we know there are difficulties in recruiting and retaining the right staff," he said.

webTitle: BBC Sport boss aims to stem poaching

fields.headline: Salmon moves to prevent further poaching raids
fields.trailText: 8.30am: BBC Sport boss Peter Salmon has acted to prevent further poaching raids from ITV by promoting a number of football production staff, writes Jason Deans
fields.body:
BBC Sport boss Peter Salmon has acted to prevent further poaching raids from ITV by promoting a number of football production staff.

Mr Salmon and his deputy Niall Sloane have reacted after ITV poached Match Of The Day producers Paul McNamara and Tony Pastor to work on their new Premier League highlights.

Paul Armstrong, who is thought to have been offered a job at ONdigital's new Nationwide League channel, has been persuaded to stay at the BBC with a promotion to editor of TV football.

Phil Bigwood is stepping up to be executive producer of TV football.

Mr Salmon said: "BBC Sport is growing the next generation of world class, behind-the-scenes players who will bring fresh ideas and enthusiasm to the creative pool."

Mr Armstrong and Mr Bigwood will oversee Match of the Day in its current Saturday night format until August.

They will also be responsible for developing Match Of The Day Live. This show will be the vehicle for BBC coverage of England's home internationals and FA Cup matches from next season.

In addition, three BBC Sport assistant producers - Paul Wright, Philip Wye and Ian Finch - have been promoted to producer.

Mr Sloane said: "It's an enviable position to be in, to be able to appoint the best in the business from our own talent, who will embrace new technology and new production methods to bring fans the best in football coverage."

webTitle: The true cost of surveillance in the workplace

fields.headline: The true cost of surveillance in the workplace
fields.standfirst: As local authorities and the NHS continue to look to the private sector for best practice in improving productivity, Lynne Friedli asks what lessons can be learnt from the recent Royal and Sun Alliance sackings?
fields.trailText: As local authorities and the NHS continue to look to the private sector for best practice in improving productivity, Lynne Friedli asks what lessons can be learnt from the recent Royal and Sun Alliance sackings?
fields.body:
We live in ironic times when Royal and Sun Alliance, sponsor of National Stress Awareness Day and author of 'Taking the stress out of work', sees fit to sack 10 employees (and suspend another 70), for doing just that.

In partnership with the International Stress Management Association, Royal and Sun Alliance has launched a host of initiatives, including a website, educational kits, conferences and seminars on topics such as "survival in the e-society", apparently in an effort to reduce the costs to the economy of stress related illness.

Significantly, concern about costs to the employer has been the main rationale for Royal and Sun Alliance taking action against staff who read private emails during working hours. Perhaps the company would prefer its 22,000 employees to phone Royal and Sun Alliance counselling and advice lines - provided by its specialist subsidiary FirstAssist - which lend a "sympathetic ear to complement our products that protect people".

So for other major employers, concerned about profits and productivity, how helpful is the Royal and Sun Alliance strategy of surveillance and sacking likely to be? If we look at the evidence, the answer is "not terribly".

There is now good quality research demonstrating that how employees feel about their work, and how they are managed, make a significant difference to organisational outcomes and profitability. Furthermore, poor individual performance nearly always reflects wider system failure. Human factors are more significant than any other aspect of organisational culture in predicting organisations' differential success (in terms of productivity and profitability) over a three to four-year period. Key factors include the extent to which employees:

 feel valued, trusted and supported
 are enabled to be autonomous in undertaking their work roles

In addition, management style clearly affects health. Many of the factors which influence both the physical and mental health of staff are psycho-social and relate to working culture, levels of support and job security. A wide range of studies demonstrate the impact of organisational factors on individual health and suggest that working patterns may be a key source of stress.

The Whitehall II Study published by the Health and Safety Executive, for example, found that low job control, high job demands, low social support at work and a combination of high effort and low rewards were all associated with poor mental and physical health. Low job control, which includes limited opportunity to control the pace of work, to take breaks and make decisions, is also an important risk factor for hypertension and coronary heart disease, leading causes of sickness and death.

These findings have some important implications for employers concerned about both productivity and sickness absence. If productivity is related to levels of trust, support and autonomy, a culture of surveillance and punishment is doomed to failure and indicates the absence of proper procedures for performance managing and motivating staff. What is in effect spying on staff also allows considerable scope for bullying and harassment - and potentially expensive court cases. What is more, the most expensive and sophisticated surveillance technology that IT departments can devise, will never be a match for the everyday subversion of disaffected and disgruntled employees.

In terms of health, the message is equally clear. If Royal and Sun Alliance is really committed to reducing the £3.7bn cost of sickness absence in the UK, it needs to re-think its policies. An effective strategy to improve health at work cannot only focus on one or two work characteristics or on individuals, but must tackle work organisation and management practice. This means:

 redressing effort/reward imbalance
 improving communications and staff involvement
 enhancing social support, especially from managers to subordinates
 increasing job control and decision making latitude
 assessing job demands

The world of work is changing rapidly. This century will see new demands for home/life balance, more people working from home and an increase in freelance and portfolio careers.

New technology will transform the nature of relationships and communications in the office environment. It will also result, in fact has already resulted, in serious skill shortages.

Those companies which cannot adapt their management culture, which use new technology to reintroduce the discredited workplace controls of the 1950s, will be swept aside by the creative energy of organisations that trust their staff and understand the productive power of humour.

Dear reader, I'd sell my shares in Royal and Sun Alliance if I were you. Its stress related sickness absence rates can only escalate.

 Lynne Friedli is chief executive of mentality, a voluntary agency dedicated to mental health promotion

There is now good quality research demonstrating that how employees feel about their work, and how they are managed, make a significant difference to organisational outcomes and profitability. Furthermore, poor individual performance nearly always reflects wider system failure. Human factors are more significant than any other aspect of organisational culture in predicting organisations' differential success (in terms of productivity and profitability) over a three to four-year period. Key factors include the extent to which employees:  feel valued, trusted and supported  are enabled to be autonomous in undertaking their work roles In addition, management style clearly affects health. Many of the factors which influence both the physical and mental health of staff are psycho-social and relate to working culture, levels of support and job security. A wide range of studies demonstrate the impact of organisational factors on individual health and suggest that working patterns may be a key source of stress. The Whitehall II Study published by the Health and Safety Executive, for example, found that low job control, high job demands, low social support at work and a combination of high effort and low rewards were all associated with poor mental and physical health. Low job control, which includes limited opportunity to control the pace of work, to take breaks and make decisions, is also an important risk factor for hypertension and coronary heart disease, leading causes of sickness and death. These findings have some important implications for employers concerned about both productivity and sickness absence. If productivity is related to levels of trust, support and autonomy, a culture of surveillance and punishment is doomed to failure and indicates the absence of proper procedures for performance managing and motivating staff. What is in effect spying on staff also allows considerable scope for bullying and harassment - and potentially expensive court cases. What is more, the most expensive and sophisticated surveillance technology that IT departments can devise, will never be a match for the everyday subversion of disaffected and disgruntled employees. In terms of health, the message is equally clear. If Royal and Sun Alliance is really committed to reducing the £3.7bn cost of sickness absence in the UK, it needs to re-think its policies. An effective strategy to improve health at work cannot only focus on one or two work characteristics or on individuals, but must tackle work organisation and management practice. This means:  redressing effort/reward imbalance  improving communications and staff involvement  enhancing social support, especially from managers to subordinates  increasing job control and decision making latitude  assessing job demands The world of work is changing rapidly. This century will see new demands for home/life balance, more people working from home and an increase in freelance and portfolio careers. New technology will transform the nature of relationships and communications in the office environment. It will also result, in fact has already resulted, in serious skill shortages. Those companies which cannot adapt their management culture, which use new technology to reintroduce the discredited workplace controls of the 1950s, will be swept aside by the creative energy of organisations that trust their staff and understand the productive power of humour. Dear reader, I'd sell my shares in Royal and Sun Alliance if I were you. Its stress related sickness absence rates can only escalate.  Lynne Friedli is chief executive of mentality, a voluntary agency dedicated to mental health promotion

webTitle: Branson throws in lottery towel

fields.headline: Branson throws in lottery towel
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson has decided today to abandon his campaign to run the national lottery. His consortium, the People's Lottery, will not be calling for a judicial review of the decision made last month to re-appoint Camelot as the lottery operator.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson has decided today to abandon his campaign to run the national lottery. His consortium, the People's Lottery, will not be calling for a judicial review of the decision made last month to re-appoint Camelot as the lottery operator.

The consortium has taken the decision "to safeguard the institution of the national lottery and to protect the funds going to good causes".

Sir Richard Branson, chairman of the People's Lottery, said: "We have always maintained - and still do - that the presence of a middleman, creaming off profits for running a government backed monopoly, is unnecessary. The People's Lottery entered into this bid to undo that wrong. And we did so with the sole purpose of maximising the amount of money to good causes."

However, he has heeded advice that if the People's Lottery were successful there would be a serious risk of the national lottery having to be suspended for a significant period of time.

Sir Richard is writing to the national audit office today asking them to review the process by which Camelot has been selected. "They should provide answers to the fact that Camelot's bid would produce £1.1bn less for good causes than our bid and contains costs of £700m more than our bid - an increase incidentally of 50% of its current cost levels."

He is also demanding full publication of both bids, to allow the public to see for themselves the basis on which the decision has been made. "In addition, there should be an immediate publication of the report of the G-Tech cover-up and G-Tech itself, which the national lottery commission originally promised to publish last autumn."

Sir Richard said the People's Lottery takes comfort from the fact that as a result of this competition, it has increased the amount pledged to good causes by an additional £5bn. He warned: "Camelot must now deliver on this."

webTitle: Socks

fields.headline: Socks
fields.standfirst: Socks, the first cat, it about to be retired. We trawl the net to sort the catnip from the kitty litter
fields.trailText: 1 Socks, the once-abandoned feline who rose to become America's first cat, has been given his marching orders from the White House.
fields.body:
1 Socks, the once-abandoned feline who rose to become America's first cat, has been given his marching orders from the White House.

2 And unlike the first dog, Bill Clinton's boon companion Buddy, he will not be taking the trip north to New York.

3 Instead, he will be making his home on a Virginia farm with Betty Currie, the presidential secretary hauled in front of Kenneth Starr's grand jury.

4 For a cat used to wondering the grounds of the White House on a 30-foot leash, he will surely relish the chance to roam for squirrels and field mice.

5 Ms Currie, too, may feel she deserves some kind of reward after the Lewinsky affair (and the two are apparently very fond of each other.)

7 According to legend, Chelsea Clinton discovered Socks in 1991 as a two-month old kitten living under her piano teacher's porch in Little Rock, Arkansas.

8 He was alone until his nemesis, Buddy, joined the Clintons in late 1997. A White House spokesman said last night that Mr Clinton had done "his best to reconcile Socks and Buddy".

9 In Socks's poignant farewell letter, the cat says that his life took a turn for the worse when "the big brown dog arrived", but looks to the future and asks for his fans to support the new first pets.

10 George W Bush, who bragged that he fed his two cats every morning, will move one of them, the de-clawed India, to Washington, but will leave Ernie at home in case he uses the White House furniture as a scratching post.

webTitle: Nottingham feels damaged by tobacco links

fields.headline: Nottingham feels damaged by tobacco links
fields.trailText: The majority of Nottingham University's academic staff believe that the university's reputation has been damaged by the acceptance of funds from British American Tobacco, suggests an email survey carried out last month.
fields.body:
The majority of Nottingham University's academic staff believe that the university's reputation has been damaged by the acceptance of funds from British American Tobacco, suggests an email survey carried out last month.

The academics have also called upon the university to establish an ethics committee to oversee controversial decisions in the future.

The results, which have been sent to the Nottingham's vice-chancellor Sir Colin Campbell, come from a survey carried out by the local branch of the lecturers' union, the Association of University Teachers.

Academic staff were asked to vote on the motion: "We believe the reputation of the University of Nottingham has been damaged by the acceptance of funding from BAT. We call upon the management of the business school and the university to reconsider and in doing so to take the views of the staff and students of the university into account. We further call upon the university to set up an ethics committee to which any such controversial decisions could be referred in the future."

Just under 90% of the 188 academic staff who responded, voted in favour of the motion.

Late last year the university triggered controversy when it accepted £3.8m from BAT to set up a new centre on business ethics.

webTitle: Tension mounts along with couple's 11 years of rubbish

fields.headline: Tension mounts along with couple's 11 years of rubbish
fields.trailText: One of the Yorkshire Dales' less lovely landmarks may at last be removed after one of the longest stand-offs in the history of local government. By Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
One of the Yorkshire Dales' less lovely landmarks may at last be removed after one of the longest stand-offs in the history of local government.

Eleven years of domestic rubbish will be carted through a beauty spot known as "the Switzerland of England" if the health of a couple's toddler grandchild tips the balance against stubborn pride.

The pyramid of sardine tins, cereal packets and teabags has accumulated as a monument to principle since 1989, when architect John Cale and his wife, Margaret, first insisted that "doorstep" collection of refuse should mean what it said.

Harrogate council disagreed, regarding over £100,000 of cumbersome refuse truck as too precious to risk on a rutted track at the head of Nidderdale.

Simon Johnson, head of Harrogate's environmental services, said: "It has been to the ombudsman and we have been upheld.

"It is the same for 180 other very remote residents, and the Cales are the only objectors. It comes up year after year after year."

Mrs Cale yesterday repeated her refusal of the council's decade-old offer to collect the rubbish from the end of the family's half-mile long track, but her granddaughter's health on family visits has now entered the equation.

Nobody is expecting any rapid developments, but the 22ft long pile, which is 10ft wide and 6ft high, will probably have to be moved further from the Cales' isolated farmhouse if it is not finally taken away in a compromise.

"Our goodwill offer stands to send a small van and collect the whole backlog if the Cales will accept lane-end collection," said Mr Johnson.

webTitle: How politics propelled mobile thefts into the news

fields.headline: How politics propelled mobile thefts into the news
fields.trailText: Several senior police officers will have chuckled today as they watched Jack Straw announce new initiatives to combat muggings and mobile phone robberies.
fields.body:
Several senior police officers will have chuckled today as they watched Jack Straw announce new initiatives to combat muggings and mobile phone robberies.

Just before Christmas Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, led the calls for phone manufacturers to "design out crime", pointing to surges in mobile robberies in certain areas of London.

The evidence for the rise was patchy - and still is. Officers thought the increase might be down to school bullying being displaced from the playground, but no proper analysis had been done.

When the British Crime Survey was published last year, the Home Office statistician Paul Wiles warned the 14% increase in robberies had to be taken with a pinch of salt.

Because robberies are rare, the rise was down entirely to reports by 15 teenagers who were mugged for money and their phones. He argued 15 muggings nationwide was not an epidemic.

But someone with influence at the Home Office was obviously listening to Sir John. In fact, the commissioner, whose political skills were questioned before he took over from Sir Paul Condon, has proved quite deft.

He demands more officers. The Home Office gives him more officers. He says police morale low is low. He gets more money for recruits. Sir John wants mobile phone manufacturers brought to book. Of course, says Mr Straw.

And with a General Election looming, and law and order likely to be the key battleground, expect more helpful suggestions from chief constables in the coming months.

Then watch the unedifying spectacle of the government and the opposition competing over who will do more to satisfy them.

"No party ever won a General Election arguing for less officers on the beat," said one senior officer at Scotland Yard.

There is, however, a graver issue over mobile phones which needs to be addressed far more urgently than street muggings.

Nearly every major police investigation requires mobile phone analysis - to track calls between criminals, to pinpoint where villains have been. But manufacturers are under no obligation to help the police. They do help, but it is not considered a priority.

Hundreds of inquiries end up grinding to a halt, waiting in turn. For most detectives, that is a far more pressing, and frustrating, issue.

webTitle: McDonald 'named his price' to bag £2.5m news deal

fields.headline: McDonald 'named his price' to bag £2.5m news deal
fields.standfirst:
ITV revives double-anchor format
Jan 10: BBC claims ratings victory
Jan 9: News at Ten back on Jan 22
Special report: TV news
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Sir Trevor McDonald was able to 'name his price' in renegotiating his ITN contract because of its upcoming flotation, write Lisa O'Carroll and Jessica Hodgson.
ITV revives double-anchor format
Jan 10: BBC claims ratings victory
Jan 9: News at Ten back on Jan 22
Special report: TV news
fields.body:
Sir Trevor McDonald was able to "name his price" when it came to renegotiating his contract because of the upcoming flotation of ITN.

It is believed that he has clinched a record-breaking deal with ITV worth at least £2.5m to present News at Ten for the next four years.

Sources say that Sir Trevor's existing contract runs until March 2002 and under normal circumstances he would have carried on working under the terms of the old deal.

"ITN were very much the driving force behind this new four-year deal," said one insider. "It was very important to have his name attached to the organisation because of the plans to float the company."

Another source said: "Thre wasn't a need for a new contract. The terms of his existing deal were loose enough to enable him to have switched from 6.30pm to 10pm but with talk of the BBC trying to poach him, it was vital to secure him for the four years running up to his official retirement."

Sir Trevor's deal was negotiated by Nick Leeson's lawyer, Stephen Pollard.

His contract means that he retains his position as the highest paid newscaster in Britain.

Top presenters at ITV get a minimum of £250,000 a year but individual deals differ, say sources.

It is thought Sir Trevor's deal also includes his fees for presenting the Tonight programme.

The veteran newscaster spoke of his surprise and pleasure at returning to present the bulletin after two years.

"If anyone had told me a couple of years ago that I would be presenting News at Ten and the Tonight show, I would say they should have a close look at what they'd had for their tea," said Sir Trevor today.

"Ten o'clock is very much an ITV time. It's our time," he added, in a dig at the BBC which last year announced a shock move to put its Nine O'Clock News back to 10pm.

Sir Trevor will present the programme on four nights a week, three of which will be broadcast at 10pm. The fourth bulletin will still be billed as News at Ten even if it is broadcast later.

He also revealed that his presenting section of the ITV flagship current affairs programme Tonight with Trevor McDonald would be made in London to ease his workload.

Sir Trevor denied that the extra work would compromise his family life. He admitted that "any family would like to spend three months in the Caribbean". But he added that it was in his nature to "get too involved" in covering stories.

He said he didn't feel that the shorter bulletin - revived at only 20 minutes - would compromise the programme's prestigious reputation.

"The idea that you can control people's attention span for 30-40 minutes is rapidly changing," he said.

"I even think there's an advantage in getting the news over in a shorter time. People want to move on to other things."

David Liddiment, ITV controller of programmes, said: "I think a longer bulletin is appropriate in the early evening and a shorter bulletin is more appropriate for later on."

ITV and ITN programme bosses talked about the decision to change the 6.30pm Evening News bulletin to a double-anchor format.

Steve Anderson, ITV controller of news, current affairs, religion and arts, said that the double-headed bulletin would "retain its authority, but with a livelier feel."

And the editor of the ITN news on ITV, Nigel Dacre, denied that the decision to put the up and coming Mary Nightingale on the bulletin meant a demotion for Katie Derham.

fields.bodyText: Sir Trevor McDonald was able to "name his price" when it came to renegotiating his contract because of the upcoming flotation of ITN. It is believed that he has clinched a record-breaking deal with ITV worth at least £2.5m to present News at Ten for the next four years. Sources say that Sir Trevor's existing contract runs until March 2002 and under normal circumstances he would have carried on working under the terms of the old deal. "ITN were very much the driving force behind this new four-year deal," said one insider. "It was very important to have his name attached to the organisation because of the plans to float the company." Another source said: "Thre wasn't a need for a new contract. The terms of his existing deal were loose enough to enable him to have switched from 6.30pm to 10pm but with talk of the BBC trying to poach him, it was vital to secure him for the four years running up to his official retirement." Sir Trevor's deal was negotiated by Nick Leeson's lawyer, Stephen Pollard. His contract means that he retains his position as the highest paid newscaster in Britain. Top presenters at ITV get a minimum of £250,000 a year but individual deals differ, say sources. It is thought Sir Trevor's deal also includes his fees for presenting the Tonight programme. The veteran newscaster spoke of his surprise and pleasure at returning to present the bulletin after two years. "If anyone had told me a couple of years ago that I would be presenting News at Ten and the Tonight show, I would say they should have a close look at what they'd had for their tea," said Sir Trevor today. "Ten o'clock is very much an ITV time. It's our time," he added, in a dig at the BBC which last year announced a shock move to put its Nine O'Clock News back to 10pm. Sir Trevor will present the programme on four nights a week, three of which will be broadcast at 10pm. The fourth bulletin will still be billed as News at Ten even if it is broadcast later. He also revealed that his presenting section of the ITV flagship current affairs programme Tonight with Trevor McDonald would be made in London to ease his workload. Sir Trevor denied that the extra work would compromise his family life. He admitted that "any family would like to spend three months in the Caribbean". But he added that it was in his nature to "get too involved" in covering stories. He said he didn't feel that the shorter bulletin - revived at only 20 minutes - would compromise the programme's prestigious reputation. "The idea that you can control people's attention span for 30-40 minutes is rapidly changing," he said. "I even think there's an advantage in getting the news over in a shorter time. People want to move on to other things." David Liddiment, ITV controller of programmes, said: "I think a longer bulletin is appropriate in the early evening and a shorter bulletin is more appropriate for later on." ITV and ITN programme bosses talked about the decision to change the 6.30pm Evening News bulletin to a double-anchor format. webTitle: What's changing in ICT?

fields.headline: What's changing in ICT?
fields.trailText: The lowdown on an array of initiatives in ICT announced at the BETT show.
fields.body:
Learning and technology minister Michael Wills announced an array of revamps, relaunches and new initiatives in ICT for schools today at the BETT show. Here's a round-up of the main changes.

Computers for Teachers Initiative 2001
The carrot: Reimburses half the cost of a personal computer for teachers (up to £500) and a rebate on national insurance and income tax.
The stick: You can't reapply if you received a grant last year - and to apply at all, you must have signed up for, or completed, a New Opportunities Fund ICT Teacher training course, and teach maths at key stage three in the public sector. The FE scheme for 4000 teachers and lecturers starts this autumn.

GridClub
We have to take the department of education's word for it on this one, because GridClub is only accessible to children between 7 and 11 and their teachers - no other adults are allowed in. Apparently, it will encourage key stage two pupils to develop 'hobby clubs' online. Education Unlimited has been promised a brief glimpse of the club shortly, so we'll let you know more later on.

Interactive courses in Latin, Japanese and maths for 11-year-olds
Expect these to appear in the autumn of 2001. They are intended for children who are about to make the transition into secondary school and will include interactive self-test quizzes for pupils, lesson-planning and homework-marking online for teachers, and video-conferences with Japanese pupils to improve language skills.

Courses online
Teachers will be invited to enter a pilot competition to develop primary literacy and numeracy materials online and secondary resources in various subjects.

TeacherNet lesson plans
TeacherNet's scattergun search engine will be upgraded shortly, and in March a pilot scheme offering 1000 lesson plans will be launched.

Virtual Teachers' Centre
Quite why the VTC and TeacherNet inhabit separate sites has never been quite clear - but the former has acquired a new design and adopted a pull-down menu search. The benefits are not immediately noticeable, and the site still suffers from too many broken links.

National curriculum site
A new version launches on 22 January with better links and more 'trusted partners'. Emma Haughton previews the new site here.

webTitle: Jaguar to launch F-type through web-based campaign

fields.headline: Jaguar to launch F-type through web-based campaign
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Jaguar is to launch its new sports car - the F-type - with a web-based campaign, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Jaguar is to launch its new sports car - the F-type - with a web-based campaign in a bid to shake off the 'gin and Jag set' image and target a younger, cosmopolitan consumer.

With footballers, pop stars, and dot.com millionaires in the market for expensive cars, the company is now refocusing some of its marketing drive.

Phil Cazaly, Jaguar marketing director, said the car may be launched through 'viral' internet marketing and may be the first modern Jag to hit the roads without TV advertising support.

Jaguar last week announced that it was to put the F-type into full production. Mr Cazaly said the carmaker intended to take on the hugely successful Porsche Boxster in the 'performance roadster' category with 25,000 sales in its first year.

In order to reach its core audience of professional men and women in their early 30s, Jaguar has brought in web agency Global Beach to devise a new type of campaign.

It is planning to create a dedicated web chat room to create an ongoing dialogue with potential customers and fine-tune the car and its marketing accordingly.

"The Jaguar brand has been defined by the XJ8 - big luxury cars for older white males. But the F-type will appeal to our youngest audience yet, who are highly net-savvy," said Mr Cazaly.

As a result, he said, there may be no need to use the advertising might of Jaguar's retained agencies, J Walter Thompson London and Ogilvy & Mather New York.

The F-type will go on full sale in 2004 and will retail at £30-40,000. Marketing activity will begin this year.

webTitle: The National Lottery

fields.headline: The National Lottery
fields.standfirst:
Sir Richard Branson has decided not to appeal against the decision to deny his consortium the chance to run the National Lottery. Derek Brown explains
Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText:
Sir Richard Branson has decided not to appeal against the decision to deny his consortium the chance to run the National Lottery. Derek Brown explains.
Special report: the lottery
fields.body:
How many runners were in the race?
Just two. The bookies' favourite was the People's Lottery, owned and trained by Richard Branson. But the smart money was on the 1994 winner, Camelot.

What was at stake?
Billions and billions. And that's just the dosh going to charity. Camelot has delivered about £10bn to good causes during its seven-year franchise. Branson claimed he would have raied that to £15bn if he had won the race. He insisted he would not have made a penny out of his not-for-profit lottery company.

So what was in it for him?
Prestige. Influence. Publicity. Another huge ego-trip.

And for us?
Branson said he would have reversed declining lottery sales by having more winners. His version of the game would, he claimed, reduce the odds against winning the jackpot from one in 14m to just one in 3m.

Can he afford it?
There were doubts when, last August, the lottery commission decided to drop Camelot from the bidding and invited Branson to "fine tune" his proposal. It was concerned that the company would not be able to pay out prizes in the event of sales falling. The People's Lottery had agreed to borrowing facilities of around £170m - the commission told it to raise another £50m.

Isn't Branson fabulously wealthy?
His worth, locked into a web of offshore companies, is a matter of some mystery. When it asked him to refine his lottery proposal, the commission in effect demanded proof that he has the means to run a £36bn business. But he certainly has lots of companies labelled Virgin. One of them has promised to dish out billions for the latest super-jumbo Airbus. Another has ordered a fleet of sleek new trains for its legendary awful rail franchise.

So how did Camelot get back in the picture?
The company raised a fearful stink when it was dropped from the bidding in August. It went to court to claim, successfully, that the commission had acted unfairly. The verdict led to the resignation of the commission chairwoman, Dame Helena Shovelton, and the re-entry of Camelot to the bidding.

Why did the commission originally want to ditch Camelot?
It said the company's probity had been compromised by software supplied by controversial US firm GTech. The problem resulted in players being short-changed over a four-year period up to 1998.

Why is GTech controversial?
Two years ago its former chairman Guy Snowden was forced to resign after losing a libel case against Branson, who declared that GTech had tried to bribe him to withdraw from the initial round of bids for the lottery franchise. In 1996, GTech's head of sales, David Smith, was convicted of accepting kickbacks from lobbyists involved in lottery contracts.

webTitle: ITV makes News at Ten promise

fields.headline: ITV makes News at Ten promise
fields.standfirst:
McDonald 'named his price'
Special report: Battle of the Bulletins
fields.trailText:
ITV today threw down the gauntlet to the BBC over the 10pm news clash, insisting it will never again move the News at Ten, writes Jason Deans.
McDonald 'named his price'
Special report: Battle of the Bulletins
fields.body:
ITV bosses today threw down the gauntlet to the BBC over the 10pm news clash, insisting they will never move the News at Ten again.

Director of programmes David Liddiment said that if ratings for the two channels' late evening bulletins suffer after they go head-to-head at 10pm from January 22, "the onus will be on the BBC" to move its news back to 9pm.

He added: "This is the second time we've moved our news in two years. I have no plans to move it again - as far as I'm concerned that's that."

Mr Liddiment said culture secretary Chris Smith "had made it clear that he would expect the BBC to rethink their news move if audiences decline".

ITV controller of news Steve Anderson added that BBC director-general Greg Dyke and chairman Sir Christopher Bland "were on record as saying that if news audiences do decline, they will move their news back".

In the keynote MacTaggart speech at the Edinburgh TV Festival last year, Mr Dyke said: "The main reason for the move is that we believe more people will watch it, it's as simple as that."

Mr Liddiment also contrasted the long process ITV had gone through with the Independent Television Commission to gain regulatory approval for its latest news move, with the BBC's self-regulatory regime that allowed it to move its news at short notice.

"Unfortunately there's no mechanism for making them accountable in the way that we are accountable," he said.

ITV is doing its best to ensure a grand first night entrance for the returning News at Ten, scheduling Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? in the 9-10pm slot.

The following night the bulletin will follow Peak Practice, while on Wednesday, January 24 it will be pushed back to 10.30pm by a 90-minute edition of police drama The Vice.

On Thursday 25 drama At Home with the Braithwaites will run before the news.

On Wednesday nights later in the winter season the ITV news bulletin is to run after Champions League coverage and Coronation Street at 10.15pm, which will also deliver a considerable ratings boost.

Mr Liddiment said: "Assuming I do my job and get the lead-in programming right, then I'm confident that the news audience will not suffer."

webTitle: Bovine tuberculosis

fields.headline: Bovine tuberculosis
fields.standfirst:
Farmers have told MPs that they feel "a growing sense of desperation" about the continued spread of TB in cattle. They want the government to speed up research. Derek Brown explains.

Special report: What's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Farmers have told MPs that they feel "a growing sense of desperation" about the continued spread of TB in cattle. They want the government to speed up research. We explain their concerns.
fields.body:
How widespread is bovine TB?
The latest figures indeed look alarming. A total of 443 outbreaks were reported in England in 1997. In the first nine months of last year, there were 637. In Great Britain as a whole, the corresponding figures are 515 and 745. (The disease is virtually non-existent in Scotland).

Is it a new phenomenon?
Hardly. Before the second world war, as wildlife lobbyists tirelessly point out, some 40% of British cattle were infected. Now the figure is 0.1% - that's just one in a 1,000 beasts.

How is the disease transmitted?
Nobody knows for sure. There are various theories about how myobacterium bovis spreads. Some say is passed from animal to animal through contact. Some say is airborne or that it lurks in the soil. Farmers are strongly inclined to blame badgers, which harbour the same disease. That theory first emerged in the early 1970s.

What is being done about it?
The ministry of agriculture is very keen to eradicate the disease, not least because infected herds have to be destroyed and their owners compensated at market rates. The men from the ministry, together with independent advisers, are working on a five-point action plan, including a detailed study of the alleged badger factor.

What does the badger study involve?
Killing them. At least, killing around 12,500 of them, in selected areas. That is only about 3% of the badger population, but wildlife activists say the cull is unscientific and unnecessary. The ministry points out that it is only part of a much bigger and hugely complex study, and that the purpose is not to eradicate badgers, but establish what part if any they play in the transmission of the disease.

How long will it take them to decide?
That is what is now concerning MPs. The original timetable has slipped badly and the first hard results are not expected before next year. It could be 2004 before they emerge, hence the rising pressure from farmers for more positive action - ie more badger killing.

Whose idea was the badger cull?
It was proposed in 1997 by Professor John Krebs. The Labour party, while in opposition, said that it would not support any such operation. Now they insist that the possible badger connection must be thoroughly investigated.

Isn't the badger a protected species?
Yes - but not from the min of ag. Badger-baiting, that most sadistic of so-called sports, has been outlawed since 1835. Police believe it still goes on though, and that the baiters leave the mutilated corpses of their victims by country roadsides, to give the impression of roadkill.

Can humans get the bovine form of TB?
Yes, but its transmission to humans is extremely rare.

fields.bodyText: How widespread is bovine TB? The latest figures indeed look alarming. A total of 443 outbreaks were reported in England in 1997. In the first nine months of last year, there were 637. In Great Britain as a whole, the corresponding figures are 515 and 745. (The disease is virtually non-existent in Scotland). Is it a new phenomenon? Hardly. Before the second world war, as wildlife lobbyists tirelessly point out, some 40% of British cattle were infected. Now the figure is 0.1% - that's just one in a 1,000 beasts. How is the disease transmitted? Nobody knows for sure. There are various theories about how myobacterium bovis spreads. Some say is passed from animal to animal through contact. Some say is airborne or that it lurks in the soil. Farmers are strongly inclined to blame badgers, which harbour the same disease. That theory first emerged in the early 1970s. What is being done about it? The ministry of agriculture is very keen to eradicate the disease, not least because infected herds have to be destroyed and their owners compensated at market rates. The men from the ministry, together with independent advisers, are working on a five-point action plan, including a detailed study of the alleged badger factor. What does the badger study involve? Killing them. At least, killing around 12,500 of them, in selected areas. That is only about 3% of the badger population, but wildlife activists say the cull is unscientific and unnecessary. The ministry points out that it is only part of a much bigger and hugely complex study, and that the purpose is not to eradicate badgers, but establish what part if any they play in the transmission of the disease. How long will it take them to decide? That is what is now concerning MPs. The original timetable has slipped badly and the first hard results are not expected before next year. It could be 2004 before they emerge, hence the rising pressure from farmers for more positive action - ie more badger killing. Whose idea was the badger cull? It was proposed in 1997 by Professor John Krebs. The Labour party, while in opposition, said that it would not support any such operation. Now they insist that the possible badger connection must be thoroughly investigated. Isn't the badger a protected species? Yes - but not from the min of ag. Badger-baiting, that most sadistic of so-called sports, has been outlawed since 1835. Police believe it still goes on though, and that the baiters leave the mutilated corpses of their victims by country roadsides, to give the impression of roadkill. Can humans get the bovine form of TB? Yes, but its transmission to humans is extremely rare. webTitle: Branson: no challenge to lottery ruling

fields.headline: Branson: no challenge to lottery ruling
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText:
Sir Richard Branson this afternoon confirmed that he will not seek a judicial review of the decision to award the National Lottery franchise to Camelot, the rival to the Virgin boss's People's Lottery group.
Special report: the lottery
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson has decided not to pursue a judicial review of the "cowardly" decision that handed the national lottery franchise to rival Camelot in December.

"In order to safeguard the institution of the National Lottery, we have decided not to proceed with a judicial review," he said.

Sir Richard called for an urgent review of the processs which saw the lottery commission reverse a decision made last August that would have handed the franchise to his People's Lottery bid.

"This was a cowardly decision made in a cowardly way," he said. "Today we are no closer to understanding how they orchestrated their findings."

He claimed that the although he was confident that a legal challenge would be successful, he felt that causes that rely on lottery funding could be hurt by a disruption resulting from court proceedings.

He added that national trust in the lottery had been eroded, and he called on the government to take steps to rebuild respect for the institution.

webTitle: Pressure on Livingstone to rein in police spending plan

fields.headline: Pressure on Livingstone to rein in police spending plan
fields.trailText: London local authorities are launching a bid to persuade mayor Ken Livingstone to rein in police spending plans that could add more than £40 a year to the average council tax bill in the capital.
fields.body:
London local authorities are launching a bid to persuade mayor Ken Livingstone to rein in police spending plans that could add more than £40 a year to the average council tax bill in the capital.

The mayor's proposed budget for his Greater London Authority (GLA) contains plans to raise spending on the metropolitan police by over £150m in the next financial year, of which councils will have to raise around £60m. The increase would bring the met's budget close to £2bn.

Mr Livingstone wants to recruit more than 1,000 extra police officers and implement a package of pay increases to make police desk jobs more attractive to civilians, freeing up deskbound officers. The mayor believes Londoners will be prepared to pay higher taxes in return for more police on the streets.

The increase would, however, mean the overall amount of money the GLA raises from councils would rise by a third. Councils would, in turn, have to raise their tax by around 5% solely to pay for the authority, with their own increases added on top.

A spokeswoman for the Association of London Government (ALG), which represents the capital's 33 councils, said: "We're not against increases in the number of police officers. But we do believe we can achieve what we want at a lower cost."

London councils want to put pressure on the government to raise its share of police funding to offset the council tax increases. The ALG will set out further proposals for cutting costs in a submission to the mayor to be unveiled next week.

The mayor's proposed budget must be approved by members of the London Assembly before it can be implemented. They can choose to reject or amend the budget on a two-thirds majority vote.

In practice, this would mean the Labour and Conservative groups voting together when the assembly meets next month. The spending plans already have the support of the chair of the Metropolitan Police Authority, Labour's Lord Harris.

If the budget is passed, it will represent the second large increase in a row for police spending. Last year, when the government set the GLA's budget, it included a leap of nearly £15, or 17%, in the police precept levied on local authorities.

Lord Harris, then chairman of the ALG, opposed passing the increase on to council tax payers, and called for the government to provide more funds to cushion the blow.

webTitle: Motorola rethinks £266m media account

fields.headline: Motorola rethinks £266m media account
fields.standfirst: Jan 10: Motorola set to add to telecoms gloom
fields.trailText:
1pm: Motorola is to review its £266m global media buying account as it tries to close the sales gap on Nokia and Ericsson, reports Daniel Rogers.
Jan 10: Motorola set to add to telecoms gloom
fields.body:
Motorola, the US mobile phone giant, has announced a review of its £266m global media buying account as it tries to close the sales gap on rivals Nokia and Ericsson.

Its media account is currently with Universal McCann and the company says it will decide the account by early March.

It would not reveal which media agencies will be involved in the pitch.

In September the company consolidated its creative advertising account and moved all work to Ogilvy & Mather New York, which meant that McCann Erickson-Worldwide and Leo Burnett were thrown off the roster.

Motorola is striving to catch up with Finland's Nokia and Sweden's Ericsson in the race to sell mobile handsets. This afternoon it is expected to announce that fourth quarter earnings that are at least 40% down on last year.

While Nokia continues to grow sales by around 36% a year, Motorola's figure is closer to 7%.

The battleground will increasingly move from standard phone handsets towards Wap and next-generation digital technologies.

webTitle: French set to pay Holocaust victims

fields.headline: French set to pay Holocaust victims
fields.standfirst: It's taken over 50 years, but, as Jon Henley reports, France is finally facing up to its anti-Semitic role in the second world war
fields.trailText: It's taken over 50 years, but, as Jon Henley reports, France is finally facing up to its anti-Semitic role in the second world war.
fields.body:
More than half a century after the event, it seems that France is finally set to follow Switzerland and Germany by reaching a multi-million pound settlement with the descendants of Jews who were murdered during the Holocaust.

The French and US governments expect to sign a pact by the end of the month with lawyers representing thousands of death camp survivors or relatives of victims who then lived in France, but are now mostly in the US, Canada, Australia, Israel and elsewhere around the globe.

Under the terms of the deal, which should head off a major diplomatic row between Washington and Paris, eight leading French banks will pay "a substantial, multi-million-dollar sum" into accounts.

These will be held at the disposal of victims or their heirs, who will be invited to submit claims based on lists of names posted on the internet.

In return, the lawsuits against the banks - launched in 1997 in the US, where the courts were felt more likely to look favourably on them - will be dropped.

France's collaborationist Vichy government froze some 80,000 accounts of French or foreign Jews at the start of the Nazis' four-year occupation of the country in 1940.

Some 76,000 Jews - about a quarter of those in France at the time - were deported to Nazi death camps, where all but 2,500 died.

The deal marks another important, if belated, step in France's awakening to the degree of guilt the nation must bear for the horrors of the Nazi occupation.

This is a country that has had more trouble than most in looking one of the darkest eras in its history full in the face.

It took until 1995 before the French president, Jacques Chirac, was able to admit that the state bore a heavy share of responsibility in the mass round-ups and deportations of Jews, as well as in the property and asset seizures that were carried out with the active help of the Vichy regime.

Public awareness was then heightened by the trial in 1998 of Maurice Papon, a senior Vichy official who was sentenced to 10 years imprisonment for complicity in crimes against humanity as a result of the part he played in organising the deportation of 1,590 Jews from the Bordeaux area.

Late last year, a Wall of Memory similar to Jerusalem's Yad Vashem was erected at the Memorial to the Jewish Martyr in Pariss Marais district, the home of most of the capital's pre-war Jewish community.

Dozens of trees were planted along the road leading up to the memorial, forming an "avenue of the righteous" to honour French citizens who sheltered Jews or helped them to escape.

A permanent museum and library recording French Jews' experience of the Holocaust has been installed in cellars beneath the memorial.

And slowly, France is also beginning to make more material reparations. The prime minister, Lionel Jospin, last year announced a new programme under which children whose parents were deported from France by the Vichy regime will get either a lump sum, or a monthly pension.

Last year too, France set up a committee to process individual requests for reparation for all confiscated French property, estimated by the government-appointed Mattéoli commission at well over £1bn.

But very few people around the world actually know of its existence, and the issue of illegally seized assets remains a highly sensitive one.

Many authorities feel that outside lobbying amounts to unhelpful meddling in France's attempts to face up to its responsibilities.

Progress is, however, being made. The French national museum authority - which had taken no action whatsoever since 1954 - has finally started seeking the rightful owners of some 2,000 art works that were taken from Jews during the war and shipped to Germany.

The US lawyers handling the financial class-action suits filed in the US had long complained of similar non-cooperation and delaying tactics on the part of the French banks, which include such well-known institutions as Société Générale, BNP-Paribas and Crédit Lyonnais.

In its vast, 3,000-page report, the Mattéoli commission estimated that the present-day equivalent of some £300m was currently lying dormant in French banks.

The US lawyers, who dispute the commission's findings that most accounts were reclaimed by holders or their relatives after 1945, say that the true figure is probably closer to £1bn.

Michel Japkowicz, a 65-year-old Paris pharmacist who lost his father and 15-year-old brother to the Holocaust, and is one of the people who filed suit against the banks, said "The deal was 55 years late.

"But it's moral satisfaction. For so long, we've had the impression that France was saying, 'we're not guilty - it's the others.' Now they're finally making amends."

webTitle: Jeff Noon's literary manifesto

fields.headline: Film-makers use jump cuts, freeze frames, slow motion. Musicians remix, scratch, sample. Can't we writers have some fun as well?
fields.standfirst:
Jeff Noon sets out his manifesto

How to make a modern novel
fields.trailText: Jeff Noon sets out his manifesto.
fields.body:
We are now living in the future. How disappointing this period seems compared with the world we promised ourselves. With the Dome, the millennial celebrations and the general feeling of "Was that it?" behind us, we have become slaves to cynicism, artificial passions and desperately forced excitements. It is not a time for great art. However, if it is fuelled by world-weariness alone, the future may not last long. Perhaps, in our imaginations, we could bypass this period entirely. I would like to discuss a possible literature, the kind of writing that will take place in the post-future age.

One symptom of the current future is the perceived sorry state of the English novel. The people who complain that the English novel is dead spend the rest of their time praising the latest masterwork that manages to tell a good story in a simple enough manner. In other words, a retreat is made into the past. Almost every novel published this year will use a template invented three centuries ago, and set in stone during the Victorian age.

Those few books that do try a new approach are met with tired groans. This is the fashionable ennui of current emotion. The writers are being too clever, there's too much going on, too many ideas, it's too much like hard work. Oh, the constant laments of this or that book being unreadable.

What the naysayers really mean is that they themselves cannot read it. It's too difficult for them. Compared with what? Jeffrey Archer? James Joyce? What is this benchmark of readability? Ian McEwan, JK Rowling, Salman Rushdie? What are these lines drawn in the sand, over which writers are not supposed to tread? Have we lost the courage to engage with a challenging text?

Two British writers, Nicholas Blincoe and Matt Thorne, recently made a set of 10 rules by which to create fiction. The collection of stories they put together, All Hail the New Puritans, is a peculiar document. Fifteen fairly young writers have decided to remove all traces of formal density from their work. There are to be no flashbacks, no authorial voices, no dual narratives. The writers will "shun poetry and poetic licence in all its forms".

The New Puritans have nailed their colours to the mast, and what a drab, lifeless banner it is. These are the dry, deft, slightly engaging tales that so many of our writers produce already, without any rules other than fixed tradition. The small thing, done well; a fearsome denial of the imagination.

Where does this fixation with the linear narrative come from? By dismissing the textual adventures of Joyce, British writers stayed true to the old pleasures of straightforward storytelling. This leads to our current situation, where the vast majority of novelists are still intent on drawing a single narrative thread through a complex world.

Yet we live daily in a web of connections, all of us becoming adept at riding the multiple layers of information. This is the fluid society. Tracing pathways through this intricate landscape needs a different kind of narrative art. It is in this spirit of adventure that I envisage the post-future novel.

I do not mean a refusal to tell stories. But we need to expand the notion of what a story is, and to seek out new ways of telling these stories. We need to be brave in this, as writers, as critics, and as readers.

It is pertinent, in this regard, to look at the recent novel House of Leaves, by the American writer Mark Z Danielewski. More a vast, convoluted labyrinth than a simple book, House of Leaves contains wondrous delights on every page. There are poems, photographs, quotations, areas of text printed upside down, almost blank pages, footnotes, an index, a playful use of typography. The book also tells a great story. Searching for the narrative clues scattered throughout the text becomes an intense pleasure.

I would propose that this book is one of the first examples of post-futurism. It is exactly the kind of storytelling we now need. House of Leaves was a big success in the States. It is interesting to imagine what the critical reaction to the book would have been in this country if the novel had been written by a British author. Could such a beautifully complex story even be told at this time, on this damp, grey island?

By reaching towards an imaginary literature, the post-future novel offers itself as a way forward. First of all, we have to accept that English writing has been far too slow in its adoption of avant-garde techniques, in comparison with popular music, art and films. The narrative fabric of the latest cult movie is woven through with jump cuts, freeze-frames, montage, slow motion shots, tracking shots, hand-held camera techniques, and the like. House, hip-hop and garage recordings contain elements of remixing, scratching and sampling.

We can also look at the branching narratives of computer games, at the strange connections that hypertext links reveal on the internet, at the games played with image and text in a graphic novel.

All of these are fluid mediums, for a fluid society. Set against such material, no wonder the contemporary novel seems moribund. As writers, we need to open ourselves up to this fluidity. What are the prose equivalents of the tracking shot, the hyperlink, the remix, the freeze-frame? As readers, we need to bring the expertise we use when enjoying a film or a piece of visual art into our appreciation of the novel.

As I write this, I'm playing Decks, EFX and 909, a CD by the techno DJ and musician Richie Hawtin. Listening to it now, an idea has come to me. I'll present this idea as the possible outline of a post-futurist novel. The CD consists of 38 pieces of music, played on a number of turntables, with two or three records being played simultaneously. Hawtin includes a diagram on the CD's sleeve, which depicts where each record begins and ends.

The DJ also employs the other two devices mentioned in the title, a special effects processor, and a Roland 909 drum machine. With these various elements, Hawtin produces a coherent musical narrative. I use the word "narrative" without compromise. Anybody who has enjoyed a good DJ set in a nightclub will attest to this sense of a story being unfolded through the music.

With this in mind, we could use Richie Hawtin's CD as the template for a novel. We need to create 38 stories, which then blend into each other using the CD's diagram as a guide. As one story comes to an end, another story, or two other stories, are mixed into it. These new stories are then carried on, until further stories are added to the mix.

Hawtin will return to the same record twice, or to a different remix of the record; we can use this technique to allow our various stories to reappear at different places in the narrative. The special effects and the drum machine elements can be interpreted in their own ways, according to the individual imagination. There are no rules, only opportunities. Above all, imagine the pleasure gained from following the various stories through the mix.

This gives just one possible structure for a post-futurist novel. I now want to talk a little about the language that such a novel could use. We have become very adept in this country, at writing "books". By this, I mean that we tend to concentrate on the big picture, rather than the interplay of words.

Looked at in a different light, however, words become a liquid medium, a malleable substance capable of being transformed in surprising ways. Words can be stretched, broken, melted, drugged, mutated, forced into submission, set free. We need writers who revel in the wild excitement of language, at this deepest level, creating a kind of dub fiction.

Our writing will then be charged, sensual, and alive with the poetic effects the New Puritans fear so much. Let us not be afraid of intensity of expression.

Hip-hop DJs have a phrase to describe the detailed, moment to moment controlling of a set of turntables, celebrated in the classic early track by Gang Starr, "DJ Premier in Deep Concentration". The post-futurist novel will employ just such a concentration in its use of language.

At the same time, it will utilise a fluid, organic structure, a network of storylines. It will be experimental, and yet will place a firm accent on the portrayal of human desires. It will be Raymond Chandler writing Ulysses, James Joyce writing The Big Sleep. It will move away from lazy cynicism and nihilism. Post-futurism reveres the narrative imagination. If the English novel is truly dead, we should place a flower on its grave, trample down the dirt. Now is the time to raise up the fragile, blossoming ghost.

 Jeff Noon's new book, Cobralingus, is published by Codex, price £9.95.

How to make a modern novel

Over the past few years there has been an upsurge of interest in experimental electronic music. Allied to the outer fringes of dance culture, and produced by groups such as Pole, Autechre, Oval, and Mouse on Mars, this is the music of machines with diseases. Decay, static, the raw buzz of a frayed connection.

Reading interviews with the people involved, I started to learn a little about the computer software employed, and the techniques of creation, and to wonder if the same processes could be used to manipulate and transform the written word.

Imagine a musical signal travelling along a pathway. The signal passes through various gates, or filters, each of which has a different effect on the music. These effects might include distort, echo, overload, and so on. Described like this, it sounds a very cold, mechanical operation; in fact, the music created in this way often reveals an astonishing, ruined beauty.

Sometimes, a diagram of the signal's pathway will be included in the sleeve design. One of the earliest examples can be found on the back cover of Brian Eno's 1975 album, Discreet Music.

The idea behind the Cobralingus project is quite simple: could a piece of text be pushed along a similar pathway?

The first task was to create a set of filter gates. These came out of a period of experimentation, playing games on screen, and on paper, thinking up different ways in which language could be transformed. Some of the filters, such as Randomise, Decay, or Explode, break text down, whereas others, such as Enhance, Control, and Find Story, have a more constructive property.

I could also drug the language, using such concepts as Anagramethane, Metaphorazine and Fecundamol. These are not computerised effects; they are imaginary technologies, designed to fire the writer's imagination.

The book of Cobralingus contains my first explorations in this process of metamorphiction, each piece starting with a passage sampled from another writer. How the text is to be transformed by any particular filter is entirely up to the individual. The filters can be used in any order, so that the text undergoes a continuous mutation, as it passes along the pathway.

It's fun, and more than a little scary sometimes, especially when a piece dissolves down into pure nonsense. But it can always be rescued and, eventually, some phrase or image will emerge from the process, some clue as to how the overall piece will end, and the work can now be pushed along in this direction. I am always amazed when this happens. I can only think that some hidden text has been brought to light, out of the original inlet. This can be seen as the ghost, or unconscious desire, of the original text.

One particular piece starts with the description of a horse, taken from The Taming of the Shrew, which transforms, eventually, into a poem containing these lines: "Infect the text! Inspect, reflect, enrage! Have sex! Let language fashion, fuse and breed, explode and hatch anew." In this way, Cobralingus attempts a new kind of writing, somewhere between poetry and prose, that revels in the secret life of words.
