fields.bodyText: We are now living in the future. How disappointing this period seems compared with the world we promised ourselves. With the Dome, the millennial celebrations and the general feeling of "Was that it?" behind us, we have become slaves to cynicism, artificial passions and desperately forced excitements. It is not a time for great art. However, if it is fuelled by world-weariness alone, the future may not last long. Perhaps, in our imaginations, we could bypass this period entirely. I would like to discuss a possible literature, the kind of writing that will take place in the post-future age. One symptom of the current future is the perceived sorry state of the English novel. The people who complain that the English novel is dead spend the rest of their time praising the latest masterwork that manages to tell a good story in a simple enough manner. In other words, a retreat is made into the past. Almost every novel published this year will use a template invented three centuries ago, and set in stone during the Victorian age. Those few books that do try a new approach are met with tired groans. This is the fashionable ennui of current emotion. The writers are being too clever, there's too much going on, too many ideas, it's too much like hard work. Oh, the constant laments of this or that book being unreadable. What the naysayers really mean is that they themselves cannot read it. It's too difficult for them. Compared with what? Jeffrey Archer? James Joyce? What is this benchmark of readability? Ian McEwan, JK Rowling, Salman Rushdie? What are these lines drawn in the sand, over which writers are not supposed to tread? Have we lost the courage to engage with a challenging text? Two British writers, Nicholas Blincoe and Matt Thorne, recently made a set of 10 rules by which to create fiction. The collection of stories they put together, All Hail the New Puritans, is a peculiar document. Fifteen fairly young writers have decided to remove all traces of formal density from their work. There are to be no flashbacks, no authorial voices, no dual narratives. The writers will "shun poetry and poetic licence in all its forms". The New Puritans have nailed their colours to the mast, and what a drab, lifeless banner it is. These are the dry, deft, slightly engaging tales that so many of our writers produce already, without any rules other than fixed tradition. The small thing, done well; a fearsome denial of the imagination. Where does this fixation with the linear narrative come from? By dismissing the textual adventures of Joyce, British writers stayed true to the old pleasures of straightforward storytelling. This leads to our current situation, where the vast majority of novelists are still intent on drawing a single narrative thread through a complex world. Yet we live daily in a web of connections, all of us becoming adept at riding the multiple layers of information. This is the fluid society. Tracing pathways through this intricate landscape needs a different kind of narrative art. It is in this spirit of adventure that I envisage the post-future novel. I do not mean a refusal to tell stories. But we need to expand the notion of what a story is, and to seek out new ways of telling these stories. We need to be brave in this, as writers, as critics, and as readers. It is pertinent, in this regard, to look at the recent novel House of Leaves, by the American writer Mark Z Danielewski. More a vast, convoluted labyrinth than a simple book, House of Leaves contains wondrous delights on every page. There are poems, photographs, quotations, areas of text printed upside down, almost blank pages, footnotes, an index, a playful use of typography. The book also tells a great story. Searching for the narrative clues scattered throughout the text becomes an intense pleasure. I would propose that this book is one of the first examples of post-futurism. It is exactly the kind of storytelling we now need. House of Leaves was a big success in the States. It is interesting to imagine what the critical reaction to the book would have been in this country if the novel had been written by a British author. Could such a beautifully complex story even be told at this time, on this damp, grey island? By reaching towards an imaginary literature, the post-future novel offers itself as a way forward. First of all, we have to accept that English writing has been far too slow in its adoption of avant-garde techniques, in comparison with popular music, art and films. The narrative fabric of the latest cult movie is woven through with jump cuts, freeze-frames, montage, slow motion shots, tracking shots, hand-held camera techniques, and the like. House, hip-hop and garage recordings contain elements of remixing, scratching and sampling. We can also look at the branching narratives of computer games, at the strange connections that hypertext links reveal on the internet, at the games played with image and text in a graphic novel. All of these are fluid mediums, for a fluid society. Set against such material, no wonder the contemporary novel seems moribund. As writers, we need to open ourselves up to this fluidity. What are the prose equivalents of the tracking shot, the hyperlink, the remix, the freeze-frame? As readers, we need to bring the expertise we use when enjoying a film or a piece of visual art into our appreciation of the novel. As I write this, I'm playing Decks, EFX and 909, a CD by the techno DJ and musician Richie Hawtin. Listening to it now, an idea has come to me. I'll present this idea as the possible outline of a post-futurist novel. The CD consists of 38 pieces of music, played on a number of turntables, with two or three records being played simultaneously. Hawtin includes a diagram on the CD's sleeve, which depicts where each record begins and ends. The DJ also employs the other two devices mentioned in the title, a special effects processor, and a Roland 909 drum machine. With these various elements, Hawtin produces a coherent musical narrative. I use the word "narrative" without compromise. Anybody who has enjoyed a good DJ set in a nightclub will attest to this sense of a story being unfolded through the music. With this in mind, we could use Richie Hawtin's CD as the template for a novel. We need to create 38 stories, which then blend into each other using the CD's diagram as a guide. As one story comes to an end, another story, or two other stories, are mixed into it. These new stories are then carried on, until further stories are added to the mix. Hawtin will return to the same record twice, or to a different remix of the record; we can use this technique to allow our various stories to reappear at different places in the narrative. The special effects and the drum machine elements can be interpreted in their own ways, according to the individual imagination. There are no rules, only opportunities. Above all, imagine the pleasure gained from following the various stories through the mix. This gives just one possible structure for a post-futurist novel. I now want to talk a little about the language that such a novel could use. We have become very adept in this country, at writing "books". By this, I mean that we tend to concentrate on the big picture, rather than the interplay of words. Looked at in a different light, however, words become a liquid medium, a malleable substance capable of being transformed in surprising ways. Words can be stretched, broken, melted, drugged, mutated, forced into submission, set free. We need writers who revel in the wild excitement of language, at this deepest level, creating a kind of dub fiction. Our writing will then be charged, sensual, and alive with the poetic effects the New Puritans fear so much. Let us not be afraid of intensity of expression. Hip-hop DJs have a phrase to describe the detailed, moment to moment controlling of a set of turntables, celebrated in the classic early track by Gang Starr, "DJ Premier in Deep Concentration". The post-futurist novel will employ just such a concentration in its use of language. At the same time, it will utilise a fluid, organic structure, a network of storylines. It will be experimental, and yet will place a firm accent on the portrayal of human desires. It will be Raymond Chandler writing Ulysses, James Joyce writing The Big Sleep. It will move away from lazy cynicism and nihilism. Post-futurism reveres the narrative imagination. If the English novel is truly dead, we should place a flower on its grave, trample down the dirt. Now is the time to raise up the fragile, blossoming ghost.  Jeff Noon's new book, Cobralingus, is published by Codex, price £9.95. webTitle: Bergkamp: Vieira is a target

fields.headline: Bergkamp: Vieira is a target
fields.trailText: Arsenal striker Dennis Bergkamp has accused opponents of deliberately targeting his team-mate Patrick Vieira.
fields.body:
Arsenal striker Dennis Bergkamp has accused opponents of deliberately targeting his team-mate Patrick Vieira.

Vieira was the victim of a two-footed lunge by Carlisle United midfielder Richard Prokas during Saturday's FA Cup third round tie at Carlisle, which Arsenal won 1-0.

Bergkamp told The Sun that the tackle, which broke Vieira's shinpad, could have ended his career.

"If you look at the provocation, the abuse and even the racialism he that he has had to endure it's a tribute to him that he has kept his head," Bergkamp said.

"I don't want to make a big deal of that but I do think Patrick's treatment is an issue that needs to be addressed."

Prokas apologised yesterday for the challenge. Referee Steve Lodge said after viewing a TV replay that he would have sent him off had he seen it from the same angle.

The Football Association said they could take no action because Lodge had misread the tackle and its video advisory panel could act only act on incidents officials had totally missed.

The FA has said it will be talking to Prokas about the incident and warning him as to his future conduct.

However, Vieira is still facing a possible ban from the FA because of incidents in a match against Leeds in November and because of comments he made in last month's issue of Onze Mondial magazine in which he criticised the English FA and referees.

webTitle: Deal clinched as BBC and China make up

fields.headline: Deal clinched as BBC and China make up
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Beijing will allow the BBC's satellite television service, BBC World, to be received in China for the first time, writes John Gittings.
fields.body:
Beijing will allow the BBC's satellite television service, BBC World, to be received in China for the first time, after years of strained relations between the government and the corporation.

The deal will allow the channel to be distributed to hotels of from three to five stars, as well as luxury guest houses and foreign apartments. The restrictions are similar to those imposed on other foreign news services.

Last night the BBC hailed the deal as "a major thaw" in its relations with China. Observers say Beijing was unhappy with the BBC's coverage of the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations. It later became extremely sensitive about other BBC programmes about China carried on the domestic services.

A programme on Chairman Mao Zedong, based on a book by the Chinese leader's doctor and including allegations about his sex life, caused great anger. Programmes on ethnic tensions in Tibet and Xinjiang were also disliked. BBC World was broadcast to China until 1994 on the Hong Kong-based Star TV, but the contract was terminated when Rupert Murdoch bought the channel.

BBC World hopes to reach other agreements with China, pointing out that this is the first time it has received permission to broadcast. China is a vast potential market for British feature programmes.

BBC World is owned by BBC Worldwide, the corporation's commercial arm, but carries reports from the BBC's news services. The BBC's overseas radio broadcasts to China have been jammed with varying degrees of severity, and news websites have been blocked.

But the deal is unlikely to make it easier to deal with sensitive issues such as the current controversy over the "Tiananmen Papers", released at the weekend in the US.

Beijing yesterday said that the dossier of allegedly secret documents about the crushing of the 1989 pro-democracy movement, said to have been smuggled out of China, was fabricated

A Chinese foreign ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, told a news conference that "any attempt to play up the matter again and disrupt China by the despicable means of fabricating materials and distorting facts will be futile".

In an earlier statement Mr Zhu insisted that there would be no reassessment in Beijing of the 1989 events. The Communist party "had already made a correct conclusion about the political disturbances" of 1989, he said.

 China fired a pre-emptive verbal strike at George W Bush's incoming administration on Tuesday, saying that US plans to build a national missile defence system would trigger an arms race and jeopardise regional security.

In a report in the official China Daily, published as Mr Bush began following up on campaign pledges to beef up the military and build the "son of star wars" system, China also condemned Washington's arms sales to Taiwan, using codewords for US power such as "hegemony" and "power politics".

webTitle: Ethnic equality inquiry to shape social housing agenda

fields.headline: Setting the pace on race
fields.standfirst: Ethnic equality inquiry to shape social housing agenda
fields.trailText: Ethnic equality inquiry to shape social housing agenda
fields.body:
A shake-up of housing association provision for ethnic minority clients is in the pipeline, following the launch of an inquiry into racial equality in social housing. The investigation, which will also look at recruitment and development of black and Asian staff, aims to establish a new code of practice on race and housing for social landlords.

The inquiry is calling for ideas and evidence of good practice from tenants' groups, government bodies, think tanks and academic institutions, as well as members of the national housing federation (NHF) and the federation of black housing organisations (FBHO).

Set up by the commission for racial equality, the housing corporation and the NHF and FBHO, the inquiry panel will invite some contributors to attend hearings across Britain in April. It will produce a report in July, setting out a three-year action plan for improving racial equality.

Leading the inquiry is Leroy Phillips, who chairs Hexagon housing association. He says that although many registered social landlords (RSLs) have changed their approach to racial equality, good practice has not been consolidated since the watershed inquiry into the death of Stephen Lawrence.

"The Lawrence report did provide a renewed commitment to racial equality," says Phillips, a census area manager for Lambeth, south London.

"It highlighted the need for landlords to do more to support victims of racial harassment and take action against the perpetrators. That is still limited. If we don't put tangible actions in place then we will have lost the moment."

He points to a forthcoming report from De Montfort University, Leicester, which is expected to show that many RSL policies and practices fail to look at the needs and aspirations of black and minority ethnic communities. While racial equality policies have been adopted by 98% of housing associations, only 21% have action plans.

He also cites a Salford University report for the housing corporation, showing that ethnic minorities are seriously under-represented at senior levels in housing associations - 56% of governing bodies have no ethnic minority members and black and Asian staff report discriminatory practices in recruitment, selection and promotion.

"It's what is commonly referred to as a glass-ceiling. Minorities have found that they progress through these organisations before being blocked. The inquiry intends to establish a holistic response to change that," Phillips says.

"We want good, modern examples of practices that have worked in promoting racial equality and I hope we come up with solutions that are not just London-centric. We want far-reaching solutions that have appeal outside the capital."

 Submissions should be sent by March 2 to the Race and Housing Inquiry, c/o National Housing Federation, 175 Gray's Inn Road, London WC1X 8UP. Further information from Helen Williams on 020-7843 2261.

webTitle: TV ratings January 9

fields.headline: C4's Perfect Breasts out in front
fields.trailText: 12.30pm TV overnights: Channel 4's move into C5-style programming has paid off with its Perfect Breasts documentary pulling in 3.4m viewers, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Channel 4's adventurous move into Channel 5-style programming has paid off, after its Perfect Breasts documentary pulled in 3.4m viewers.

The station's in-depth study of teenagers who have breast implants gained a 19% share of the 10pm to 11pm slot, outgunning Gail Porter's Pulling Power on ITV, which registered 3m viewers at 10.30pm.

Channel 5 ran Jon Voight action film Most Wanted against the documentary, but only managed 2.6m and a 12% share, its biggest audience of the day.

Elsewhere yesterday, BBC1's Martin Shaw vehicle Judge John Deed held up well against ITV big-hitters The Bill and Peak Practice.

The feature-length drama took 6.6m and 27% share for 8pm, against 8m for The Bill and 33%.

However, it failed to cling onto EastEnders' audience of 14.3m, who tuned in to watch nasty Nick Cotton's increasing woes at 7.30pm. The whopping share of 59% more than halved for Judge John Deed.

Peak Practice predictably dominated the 9pm slot with 8m viewers and 34% of the audience. Channel 4 trailed behind with 2.6m with its To Diet For documentary on the history of dieting.

webTitle: Blood clots 'kill one air passenger a month'

fields.headline: Blood clots 'kill one air passenger a month'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Deep vein thrombosis claims the life of at least one airline passenger a month at Heathrow, according to a study published today.
fields.body:
Deep vein thrombosis claims the life of at least one airline passenger a month at Heathrow, according to a study published today.

The hospital closest to the arrivals hall has dealt with 30 passengers killed by the thrombosis in the last three years.

Many die within minutes of landing at the airport, says the research by John Belstead, a consultant at Ashford hospital, Middlesex.

The condition, linked to cramped seating aboard airliners, is known as "economy class syndrome" but can affect passengers in more expensive seats.

On long haul flights a blood clot forms in a vein, usually in the leg, and works its way into the heart or lungs where it causes death.

Doctors say a simple aspirin tablet taken a few hours before take-off thins the blood during long periods of inactivity. The number of victims would fall significantly if more passengers followed this advice.

A third of the study's patients, who were aged between 28 and the late 70s, had flown to Heathrow from Australia in economy class seats.

In a comparable study last month, Japanese doctors said that more than three people a year die at Narita airport in Tokyo from the thrombosis. Between 100 and 150 long-haul passengers are treated for the syndrome upon arrival in Tokyo annually.

webTitle: BBC claims ratings victory for Ten O'Clock News

fields.headline: BBC claims ratings victory for Ten O'Clock News
fields.trailText: 12pm: The BBC is claiming a ratings victory in its decision to move its news bulletin to 10pm, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The BBC today claimed a ratings victory in its decision to axe its Nine O'Clock News and replace it with a 10pm bulletin.

The corporation says that so far audience figures have held up with the 10pm bulletin pulling in an average of 5.2m viewers

This is slightly ahead of the old Nine O'Clock News, which disappeared in October last year after 30 years. It was getting an average of 5.1m viewers.

However, ratings are expected to take a dive when ITV's News at Ten returns on January 22.

ITV believes that viewing figures will be split in its favour with around3m tuning into the BBC every night but 4m plumping for Sir Trevor McDonald's News at Ten.

But BBC head of TV news Roger Mosey said today that he believed that viewers would opt for the regular five-nights-a-week option on the BBC.

"ITV are bringing back their News at Ten for as few as three days a week, and it's going to be considerably shorter than the old News at Ten," he said.

webTitle: BBC 'not racist' says Alagiah

fields.headline: BBC 'not racist' says Alagiah
fields.trailText: 11.45amThe poor representation of ethnic minorities in the BBC is caused by 'culture, not race' claims presenter George Alagiah. ByJessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Under-recruitment of people from ethnic minorities in the BBC is caused by "culture, not race" according to George Alagiah.

Mr Alagiah, who presents the Ten O'clock News, writes in today's Daily Telegraph that the corporation is "not, in my experience, racist".

But he claims that senior BBC management are "a world away from some of the talent they are so keen to find and nurture".

Mr Alagiah blames the culture of the BBC and its tendency to institutionalise its staff.

He says that many senior managers at the corporation "joined the BBC straight out of university and have known each other from their early days on the BBC graduate trainee schemes."

And he claims that it is this, rather than explicit racism, which puts young black and Asian talent off applying for jobs at the BBC.

"While the recruitment of black and Asian journalists has moved on apace, there has been a lamentable lack of progress higher up the management structure," says Mr Alagiah, "a failure reflected in other parts of the BBC's colossal hierarchy."

Mr Alagiah's remarks follow BBC director general Greg Dyke's controversial claim that the BBC is "hideously white" and that more effort must be made to recruit people from ethnic minorities.

webTitle: Casting news: John Cusack finds focus in physics

fields.headline: John Cusack finds focus in physics
fields.standfirst: Plus: Kurt comes to Sharon's rescue - for $5m; Daniel Day-Lewis takes to the high seas; Rachel Griffiths ready for Disney heartwarmer; Britney gets all wholesome in her big screen debut
fields.trailText: Plus: Kurt comes to Sharon's rescue - for $5m; Daniel Day-Lewis takes to the high seas; Rachel Griffiths ready for Disney heartwarmer; Britney gets all wholesome in her big screen debut
fields.body:
 John Cusack has signed on to produce and star in Cosmic Banditos, a wild, Pynchon-esque tale of marijuana smugglers adrift in the jungles of Columbia based on the novel by AC Weisbecker. According to screenwriter Jimmy Fishman (who wrote the film in tandem with Abbe Wool) the film is about a group of rogues: "Whose chaotic and random lives are suddenly given meaning by the laws of physics." Cusack has been interested in physics ever since filming the A-bomb drama Fat Man and Little Boy back in 1989. "Those first atomic physicists were real cowboys," he explains. "Like mystics, only they dealt with numbers instead of language." The script for Cosmic Banditos, he say, "Is just really original. It deals with quantum mechanics in a gonzo, gung-ho sort of way."

 Just days after it appeared as though the Basic Instinct sequel was set to founder without a male lead, Kurt Russell appears to have ridden to the rescue. According to American gossip columnist Liz Smith, MGM has offered Russell a cheque for $5m (£3.36m) to star opposite Sharon Stone in the follow-up to Joe Eszterhas's hugely profitable 1992 psycho-thriller.

 Although still toiling away on Martin Scorsese's The Gangs of New York, Daniel Day-Lewis may have his next job already mapped out. The British actor is reported to have beaten out several major Hollywood names to take the lead in the Moby Dick-style saga In the Heart of the Sea.

 Rachel Griffiths - star of Hilary and Jackie and Me, Myself, I - is in talks to play the wife of Dennis Quaid in Disney's feel-good sports drama The Rookie. The story of a high-school baseball coach who becomes a star in the major leagues is based on the true-life tale of pitcher Jim Morris, who signed to the Tampa Bay Devil Rays at the ripe old age of 35.

 And finally, it had to happen. Perky songstress Britney Spears is poised to make her movie debut in a tailor-made role in a coming-of-age outing directed by Tamra (Billy Madison) Davis. The film will focus on three childhood buddies - a level-headed student (played by Britney), a ditzy cheerleader and a troubled rebel - who are reunited when they travel cross-country to a singing contest in California. Presently entitled "The Untitled Britney Spears Project" (snappy - let's hope they keep it), the film is budgeted at around $10m (£6.72m) and goes before the cameras in March.

webTitle: Scoot.com shares surge on takeover rumours

fields.headline: Scoot.com shares surge on takeover rumours
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Scoot.com shares have surged after renewed speculation of a takeover bid from French media giant Vivendi Universal, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in online directory service Scoot.com have surged on the back of renewed speculation of a £1.7bn takeover bid from French media giant Vivendi Universal.

Scoot stocks rose 23% to 91.5p in early trading following reports that Vivendi, which has a 22.4% stake in the company, was set to bid for the whole firm.

Scoot and Vivendi were not available for comment.

Aside from the shareholding link, Scoot also has ties with Vivendi through a deal with the French company's Vizzavi Internet service. Vivendi has become a global media force following last year's merger with Seagram of Canada, owner of Universal Music and Universal Studios.

Rumours of a Vivendi takeover of Scoot surface regularly and reached a peak in September last year, when the UK company's shares soared to as much as 191p. Concerns about the sudden leap in buying activity sparked an investigation by financial watchdog the FSA.

Scoot needs a financial boost after reporting full-year losses of £38.5m in November last year, almost double the deficit in 1999. It also revealed a 34% drop in underlying sales.

webTitle: Straw calls for help to cut mobile phone crime

fields.headline: Straw calls for help to cut mobile phone crime
fields.standfirst: Special report: Policing crime
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, is calling on the mobile phone industry to play its part in reducing street crime by making it harder for thieves to steal mobile phones.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, is calling on the mobile phone industry to play its part in reducing street crime by making it harder for thieves to steal mobile phones.

Mr Straw will be holding a briefing later today on the issue, and hopes to meet manufacturers sometime discuss the possibility of building greater security measures into the phones.

The mobile phone industry estimates that 15,000 handsets are stolen every month, and Metropolitan police figures show that the number of street crimes involving mobile phones increased more than fourfold in the period from April 1998 to July 2000.

Even Mr Straw admits that such security measures will not be easy to achieve, particularly given the prevalence of pay-as-you-go plans that do not link a phone to an identifiable owner.

He has likened the problem to that faced by car manufacturers who built security measures into car stereos in order to make them unattractive to thieves.

The home secretary will also unveil the government's latest plan to reduce violent crime. The British Crime Survey showed a 10% fall in total crime between 1997 and 1999, but robberies were up by 14%.

In the 12 months to March 2000, the number or robberies reported to the police rose by 26%.

Shadow Home Secretary Ann Widdecombe described Mr Straw's claim that it was impossible to say whether, overall, violent crime had gone up or down, as his "feeblest excuse yet".

"If, overall, it had gone down, he would be shouting that from the rooftops," she said.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, urged Mr Straw to encourage police officers approaching retirement to stay on for up to five years and also to invite back good officers who had recently retired.

He said, "I am today formally asking Jack Straw to invite police officers approaching retirement to stay for up to five years and to invite back good police officers who have retired in the last five years."

Mr. Straw answered both points. He said: "The number of police officers who have been retiring or resigning has actually gone down in the last three years.

"We have pushed up the pay for London officers by £3,500 and recruitment is now in many parts of the country at its highest level.

"Conservatives have basically nothing to say on crime. During their period in office, crime doubled," he added.

 Home Secretary Jack Straw surprised a Big Issue seller today by handing over a tenner - then asking for his change.

Homeless Big Issue salesman Jaz Walter offered the politician a copy of the £1 magazine during a walkabout in King's Cross, central London.

Mr Walter said that he thought Mr Straw was going to give him the whole lot when he took the £10 note out of his wallet.

But confusion followed when he then had to dig round in his pockets to reimburse him.

Mr Straw, who was viewing the success of a scheme to tackle street crime, eventually settled for £8, which was all that Mr Walter had with him.

fields.headline: What the professionals think
fields.trailText:
"Sven-Goran Eriksson's resignation at Lazio is great news for England, but he hasn't got long to work out the best way forward for the team. He must stand and fall by his beliefs. But if he is rigid in his 4-4-2 approach and it all goes wrong, then he will be in for a torrid time."

Alan Hansen
fields.body:
"Sven-Goran Eriksson's resignation at Lazio is great news for England, but he hasn't got long to work out the best way forward for the team. He must stand and fall by his beliefs. But if he is rigid in his 4-4-2 approach and it all goes wrong, then he will be in for a torrid time."

Alan Hansen

"I am not surprised England have opted for a foreign coach. In this day and age, people from different countries are working all over the world ... [but] at the end of the day it is all about winning matches, and whether you are foreign or English it is still going to be a bloody hard job."

Glenn Hoddle

"When he was named England coach, fans were saying what a fantastic appointment, but they changed which is sad, because he is an excellent coach. I know Sven wanted to see the job through at Lazio. But it's better for England this way."

Peter Taylor

"It's wrong for people to say he's coming here after failing at Lazio because he won the title, he won the Cup and he won the Uefa Cup."

Gerard Houllier

"It's going to be difficult for him because he is the first foreign coach. Lots of sports have gone down that road and now that football has as well, he has to be given that chance."

Trevor Brooking

webTitle: Nato pledges to investigate use of 'safe' weapons

fields.headline: Nato pledges to investigate use of 'safe' weapons
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Nato secretary general George Robertson said today there is no evidence of a link between the use of depleted uranium weapons and leukaemia but announced a wide-ranging action plan to reassure soldiers and civilians.
fields.body:
Nato secretary general George Robertson said today there is no evidence of a link between the use of depleted uranium weapons and leukaemia but announced a wide-ranging action plan to reassure soldiers and civilians.

He pointed to research in the Balkans which showed leukaemia rates were below average for the area last year. But he said that Nato is to carry out further research and clean up 112 sites where missiles were dropped during bombing raids in the Balkans.

His comments came after the British government bowed to pressure to join European governments in screening troops for signs of contamination from depleted uranium used in US anti-tank shells. Concern follows a spate of leukaemia deaths among Balkan veterans in Italy, France, Portugal and Denmark, though scientists are divided on whether the incidence is unusually high.

After a meeting of Nato leaders in Brussels this morning, Mr Robertson said Nato was committed to getting all the facts.

"The brave, dedicated people who are serving as our peacekeepers in the Balkans will be reassured that their safety and their health is our priority," he said. "We have not and never will be complacent."

Mr Robertson said Nato leaders were to ask medical experts to review the situation next week and report back immediately. Nato is also to set up a DU committee and act as a clearing house for information on the issue, so government programmes and research information could be shared.

"We have nothing to hide and we have a lot to share," he said.

"The existing medical consensus is clear: the hazard from depleted uranium is both very limited and limited to very specific circumstances.

"This is not a new issue, we have addressed it in the past. We are naturally concerned at suggestions depleted uranium could be causing harm to troops who served in Bosnia or the people who live there." But he said screening of troops who had served in Bosnia showed no evidence of effects, adding: "Based on our evidence it is highly unlikely soldiers carried a high risk of developing leukaemia."

webTitle: Harry Potter books are sexist, says US academic

fields.headline: Harry Potter books are sexist, says US academic
fields.trailText: JK Rowling's Harry Potter stories are sexist, tedious and grating, according to a book out later this month.
fields.body:
JK Rowling's Harry Potter stories are sexist, tedious and grating, according to a book out later this month.

The author, Jack Zipes, professor of German at the University of Minnesota, says the wildly successful books are part of the "process by which we homogenise our children".

"Rowling's books conventionally repeat much of the same sexist and white patriachal biases of classical fairy tales," he says in his book, Sticks and Stones: The Troublesome Success of Children's Literature from Slovenly Peter to Harry Potter, to be published by Routledge.

"Rowling has intended from the beginning to write seven novels altogether, a magic number, but if you've read one, you've read them all: the plots are the same, and the storylines become tedious and grating after you have read the first," Zipes writes.

"What distinguishes the plots, however, are their conventionality, predictability, and happy ends despite the clever turns of phrases and surprising twists ... They sell extraordinarily well precisely because they are so cute and ordinary."

Rowling's publishers, Bloomsbury, said the author was away.

webTitle: In brief: Steven Soderbergh's winning streak continues

fields.headline: Steven Soderbergh's winning streak continues
fields.standfirst: Plus: Veteran British director John Schlesinger suffers stroke
fields.trailText: Plus: Veteran British director John Schlesinger suffers stroke
fields.body:
 The American Film Institute yesterday released its list of the ten greatest US movies of 2000. Selected by a 12-member panel, the prestigious verdict was based on a variety of criteria: films that inspired audiences, made a mark on American society, advanced the art form or enhanced Hollywood heritage. This year's selection contained few big surprises, however, only serving to further strengthen the form of the Oscar front-runners. The night's big winner was director Steven Soderbergh (pictured), who has two films (Traffic and Erin Brockovich) included. The AFI list runs as follows: Almost Famous, Before Night Falls, Best in Show, Erin Brockovich, Gladiator, High Fidelity, Requiem For a Dream, Traffic, Wonder Boys, You Can Count on Me.

 Director John Schlesinger is recuperating at his home in Palm Springs, California, after suffering a moderate stroke at the weekend. webTitle: ITV revives double-anchor news format

fields.headline: ITV revives double-anchor news format
fields.trailText: 11am: ITV is reviving the double-anchor format for its teatime news, with Mary Nightingale hosting alongside Dermot Murnaghan. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITV is reviving the double-anchor format for its teatime news, with rising star Mary Nightingale flying straight into the top seat alongside Dermot Murnaghan.

ITV bosses today also they will be reuniting Sir Trevor McDonald with the News at Ten on January 22.

But the biggest promotion goes to Ms Nightingale, long a favourite of ITV bosses.

She made her name as Alastair Stewart's co-presenter on London's local TV news service but has been groomed for greater things ever since joining Carlton TV as presenter of ITV holiday programme Wish You Were Here.

Ms Nightingale will be standing in for Kirsty Young, who is due to give birth in February.

But the maternity cover will be longer than usual because Ms Young was forced to quit work early because of pregnancy-related illness, giving Ms Nightingale a golden opportunity to establish herself as a household name.

The decision to relaunch the teatime news with co-anchors comes eight years after the format was dumped for News at Ten.

The promotion means newscaster Katie Derham stays put to present the ITV Weekend News from Fridays to Saturdays and will continue as media and arts correspondent for ITV News.

Some say this is a blow for Ms Derham, who was tipped as the face of the millennium.

ITV bosses, however, say that the weekend news is one of the network's biggest showcases with big audiences.

ITV also revealed that they would be sticking with the News at Ten title, referring to the bulletin as ITV News at Ten.

Mr McDonald said: "I am delighted to be back with the news in the 10 o'clock slot. I'm looking forward to the new programme immensely and to the challenge of taking ITV News head-to-head with the BBC for the first time."

Sir Trevor, along with other high-profile ITN journalists, was known to be furious at the decision by ITV at the beginning of 1999 to move News at Ten, a national institution.

John Suchet will anchor the ITV Lunchtime News at 12.30, while Nicholas Owen will be a floating presenter across the schedule.

webTitle: Unclaimed Halifax shares fund £3m charitable foundation

fields.headline: Unclaimed Halifax shares fund £3m charitable foundation
fields.trailText: A new charitable foundation is to be born out of the proceeds of a building society conversion and public inertia, writes Nicola Hill.
fields.body:
A new charitable foundation is to be born out of the proceeds of a building society conversion and public inertia. The Halifax Foundation will be set up in spring 2001 with funding from shares that have not been claimed by former members of the building society. This will result in an annual £3m programme of charitable giving.

Approximately 145,000 people have not claimed their Halifax shares, worth an estimated £170m. The company has given a deadline of April 7 before the shares will be sold. But whatever the take-up, the company has pledged to invest a sum equivalent to the proceeds of 5m shares and donate the interest to the foundation.

A spokesperson said: "The foundation will initially focus on the same areas that the company has chosen to fund over the last 10 years. These include debt counselling, education - especially for adults - developing online capabilities for charities and community support."

The company has spent £10m over the past 10 years on these areas and has also helped umbrella organisations that assist voluntary and community groups and those working with minority and low income groups to address urban and rural inclusion.

Organisations that have benefited in the past include Business in the Community, CSV - community service volunteers, the National Homeless Alliance, internet advice service TheSite.org and the Royal Society for the Encouragement of Arts.

Further details of the foundation will be announced in spring 2001.

webTitle: Enemy at the Gates to open Berlin Festival

fields.headline: Enemy at the Gates to open Berlin Festival
fields.trailText: Jean-Jacques Annaud's second world war epic is just one of a varied selection of films from around the world that will be presented at the Berlin Film Festival in February
fields.body:
The Berlin International Film Festival opens its doors this year with an opening night screening of Jean-Jacques Annaud's second world war epic Enemy at the Gates, starring Joseph Fiennes, Jude Law (pictured), Ed Harris and Rachel Weisz. Shot primarily on location in Berlin, the film, which presents an epic re-enactment of the siege of Stalingrad, goes on general release in the UK on March 9.

The announcement of Enemy at the Gates as the Berlin opener is just the top of a string of confirmations. Also playing in the official selection are Philip Kaufman's Marquis de Sade saga Quills, Mike Nichols' tart comedy Wit and Gus Van Sant's master-pupil drama Finding Forrester, a Good Will Hunting-style outing starring Sean Connery as a ageing novelist who takes an artistic sportsman under his wing.

Variety also reports other possibles for inclusion. These include Spike Lee's Bamboozled, John Boorman's The Tailor of Panama, Michael Winterbottom's The Claim and Chocolat, from director Lasse Hallstrom. From Asia, the festival looks set to include premieres of Raymond To's Heaven and Earth and Zhang Yimou's eagerly anticipated Happy Times.

The Berlin International Film Festival runs from February 7-18.

webTitle: Stars quit charity in corruption scandal

fields.headline: Stars quit charity in corruption scandal
fields.trailText: Luciano Pavarotti has walked out of the high-profile overseas aid charity, War Child UK, with five other celebrity patrons after discovering that its co-founder had taken a bribe from contractors building a prestigious music centre named after him in Bosnia.
fields.body:
Luciano Pavarotti has walked out of the high-profile overseas aid charity, War Child UK, with five other celebrity patrons after discovering that its co-founder had taken a bribe from contractors building a prestigious music centre named after him in Bosnia.

The opera maestro - who along with the rock musician Brian Eno persuaded other stars like Elton John, Bono and Eric Clapton to perform in concerts and donate royalties to raise millions of pounds for the charity - quit after discovering that two people involved with the organisation had taken bribes and that there were concerns over financial and management controls. Pavarotti himself has raised more than $10m (£6.6m).

High profile patrons of the charity included the playwright Sir Tom Stoppard, film and Royal Shakespeare Company actress Juliet Stevenson, pop star David Bowie, and MTV chief Brent Hanson. They have also resigned because they are not happy about the direction of the organisation which helps children rebuild their lives in war-torn countries from former Yugoslavia to Liberia and Rwanda.

A spokeswoman for Pavarotti said: "He did not want to be associated with anything that was corrupt and wanted every dollar that he had raised to be accountable. On one project - the Liberian children's village - he had to wait one year before he could get the accounts and then found most of the money had been spent on the project in London but without practical result."

As a result, the world-famous tenor personally directed that money for former War Child UK projects in former Yugoslavia, Liberia and Guatemala be chanelled by other charities.

A joint investigation by the Guardian and Channel 4 News - to be shown at 7pm tonight - has discovered that the decision by the celebrities to quit and resignations from 11 trustees over the last two years has led to an inquiry by the charity commission into the running of War Child UK.

The inquiry - conducted with the co-operation of the remaining trustees - has confirmed the payment of bribes in Bosnia, excessive administrative expenditure and that too many staff took trips abroad to visit projects and attend fund-raising concerts. The charity commission says the new trustees are well on the way to restructuring their management and cutting administrative costs.

Documents passed to the Guardian and Channel 4 News show it was the bribery revelation that forced the patrons and former trustees to take action. Bill Leeson, the charity's co-founder, and Mike Terry, employed as a consultant, took a DM40,000 (£14,716) gift in November 1996 from Hydrogradnja, the main contractor, for building the Pavarotti music centre in Mostar. The pair offered to share the proceeds with David Wilson, the Mostar centre director and co-founder, who refused and notified trustees.

The trustees convened an extraordinary meeting and ordered that the money to be returned - only to discover that Mr Leeson had six months earlier also taken DM5000 (£1,670) from the sale of bakery machinery. The charity says this was authorised.

Nigel Osbourne, director of music for the centre and professor of music at Edinburgh University, described the "bung" as "a catastrophic betrayal" for "those who have risked their lives and livelihoods for the music centre".

Bill Leeson, who had spent some of the cash, defended his decision to Mr Wilson saying: "It was a totally legitimate business gift ... a small consolation for the price I have paid financially and emotionally and probably physically for the last four years."

The trustees hushed up the episode from the patrons, kept Mr Leeson in his post and told Mike Terry he must quit.

Two years later Mr Terry was re-engaged on fresh projects against the trustees' advice. This led David Wilson to inform Luciano Pavarotti in New York about the scandal. Within a month, on April 9 1999, Brian Eno and Sir Tom Stoppard met trustees at the charity's office in London to try to sort out the problem.

They called for the retirement of Bill Leeson, the disolution of the management committee, and the transfer of Pavarotti projects out of War Child UK. But nothing happened and the patrons and nearly all the trustees quit.

Sir Tom Stoppard told the Guardian: "It was a very confusing situation and I became confused myself and I felt it could only be resolved by a thorough inquiry, so I decided to leave."

Bill Leeson, who could not be contacted, has inflamed the situation by now saying on behalf of War Child that he wanted to get rid of the celebrities all along.

Rosie Boycott, editor of the Daily Express, a current trustee of War Child, said yesterday that she hoped the charity would overcome what she admitted had been a nightmare and continue its unique work.

Daily Express readers raised £165,000 for a War Child bakery in Kosovo last year - a project praised by Parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, and given £350,000 by the government.

webTitle: Profile:  Gloria Laycock, head of the new Jill Dando Institute

fields.headline: Appliance of science
fields.standfirst: Gloria Laycock, head of the new Jill Dando Institute
fields.trailText: Profile: Gloria Laycock, head of the new Jill Dando Institute
fields.body:
Exactly two years after the murder of TV presenter Jill Dando, an academic institute set up in her memory and devoted to devising and promoting ways to prevent and detect crime is to open in London. Its director will be Gloria Laycock, who is swapping her backroom role as a Home Office criminologist for the frontline job selling a new approach to crime control.

She has been in the civil service for 30 years, but Laycock, a feisty 53-year-old, says she is well known for "calling a spade a spade". So perhaps her move to a professorship at the Jill Dando Institute for Crime Science, which opens on April 26 as part of University College, London, will be painless.

One of her first tasks will be to explain the meaning of crime science, a term coined by Nick Ross, Dando's Crimewatch co-presenter. Most people think the appliance of science to crime is about DNA, fingerprints and forensics. And research at the institute will indeed look at ways to refine and develop these approaches.

Laycock, though, defines the newly-emerging discipline as "science in the sense of trying to get logical thought and scientific method applied to crime."

That means preventing an offence before it occurs, by making it hard - or impossible - to commit. "Designing out crime," as she puts it. And, typical of her practical approach, she cites the near disaster a fortnight ago when a deranged passenger forced his way into the flight deck of a BA jumbo jet bound for Kenya.

"Shouldn't doors between flightdeck and passenger cabin be angled and hinged outwards, so that the out-of-control passenger can't come barrelling directly on to the pilot?" she asks. That's not a rhetorical question but one she has every intention of putting directly to airlines, designers, and manufacturers. And she will put similar design queries to the car industry, mobile phone networks, credit card companies and - with an eye to new products likely to attract thieves - digital TVs.

Her mission at the institute, which will offer short courses this year, postgraduate teaching in 2002, and, later, first degree courses, is this: "We want to change the way industry and the public sector create crime opportunities."

Most of the public believe the way to cut the number of offences is more police on the streets. Laycock doesn't agree, pointing out that the Conservatives' call for 3,000 more officers, divided among 43 police forces, divided again by the number of shifts and the number of estates in England and Wales classed as crime hot spots - 500 - would mean very few extra personnel per area.

Yet she does not want too much time spent, either, considering whether improving social deprivation would cut the crime rate. If she was poor, she says, she would find the idea of such a link offensive. But she does concede that some families struggle under disproportionate burdens. "Being a single mother is hard; I am a single mother," she says - though her three children are grown-up.

Some of her professional colleagues have long agreed it is time for a different approach to crimebusting. But until now, little has been done about it. "Jill's death was a kind of spark," she says.

The wave of sympathy after the murder, and the public's wish to do something, led Ross and Dando's fiancé, Alan Farthing, among others, to set up a trust to fund a groundbreaking project.

Of the £5m needed to start a fully-fledged teaching and research department at UCL, £1.5m has been raised. The Home Office contribution is a promise to fund Laycock's chair during her tenure.

Laycock intends to make contact quickly with academics in other fields. She believes a cross-disciplinary approach is crucial - "all the sciences have a part to play" - and she lists engineers to develop ways to authenticate personal identity; geneticists to work on offender profiling; chemists to find ways of detecting rape drugs in drinks; and economists whose forecasts could throw light on future crime trends.

Tony Blair and home secretary Jack Straw are supportive, she says, acknowledging there is some risk in that for ministers under pressure to increase police numbers. She recognises that the government will need proof that this approach to such a politically sensitive issue is working. After all, only 8% of burglaries are cleared up.

Laycock reckons she might have an ally in the Treasury, which is exercised by the increasing cost of law and order. The police, generally, are aware that they have to deliver and she thinks they will listen to the institute. But at the moment, she admits, mention crime science to the average bobby "and he won't know what you're talking about."

If anyone can change that, it is probably Laycock. Some of the institute's ideas are likely to make the ordinary PC's job more difficult, she says. "They'll have to learn to think laterally about solving problems. They could get quite excited about it. More difficult to win over are the detectives and the CID."

And Ann Widdecombe, of course. Laycock - "I suppose I'm a common sense sort of person" - insists that she would love to talk to the shadow home secretary.

If she was poor, she says, she would find the idea of such a link offensive. But she does concede that some families struggle under disproportionate burdens. "Being a single mother is hard; I am a single mother," she says - though her three children are grown-up.

Some of her professional colleagues have long agreed it is time for a different approach to crimebusting. But until now, little has been done about it. "Jill's death was a kind of spark," she says.

The wave of sympathy after the murder, and the public's wish to do something, led Mr Ross and Ms Dando's fiancé, Alan Farthing, among others, to set up a trust to fund a groundbreaking project.

Tony Blair and home secretary Jack Straw are supportive, she says, acknowledging there is some risk in that for ministers under pressure to increase police numbers. She recognises that the government will need proof that this approach to such a politically sensitive issue is working. After all, only 8% of burglaries are cleared up.

Ms Laycock reckons she might have an ally in the Treasury, which is exercised by the increasing cost of law and order. The police, generally, are aware that they have to deliver and she thinks they will listen to the institute. But at the moment, she admits, mention crime science to the average bobby "and he won't know what you're talking about."

If anyone can change that, it is probably Ms Laycock. Some of the institute's ideas are likely to make the ordinary PC's job more difficult, she says. "They'll have to learn to think laterally about solving problems. They could get quite excited about it. More difficult to win over are the detectives and the CID."

And Ann Widdecombe, of course. Ms Laycock - "I suppose I'm a common sense sort of person" - insists that she would love to talk to the shadow home secretary.

webTitle: Trinity Mirror titles see circulations slump

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror titles see circulations slump
fields.trailText: 10.30am: UK newspapers are facing a tough year after market leader Trinity Mirror reported a slump in circulation, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
UK newspapers are facing a tough 2001 after market leader Trinity Mirror reported a slump in circulation.

The owner of the Mirror and Sunday People said in a trading statement that circulation at its regional and national titles had fallen last year, although its Daily Record and Sunday Mail titles improved their share of the Scottish market.

"The group's regional newspapers continued to experience a decline in circulation during the second half of the year in line with the regional newspaper market," the group said.

Trinity Mirror added that the Mirror, the Sunday Mirror and Sunday People had suffered "small losses" in market share.

In line with the rest of the media sector, Trinity Mirror's national newspapers experienced a fall in advertising growth.

The group said that revenues had grown by just 0.6% in the last six months of 2000, against 5% for the first half of the year.

However, Trinity Mirror said that full-year revenues were in line with the company's expectations, buoyed by better sales in the final two months of last year.

Worries about falling ad revenues have been compounded by rising newsprint costs, which are expected to increase by 15% this year and hit margins at newspaper publishers.

Analysts are concerned that manufacturing costs are climbing at a time when earnings are under increasing pressure.

Trinity Mirror hopes to offset the rising price of paper with increased revenues from its internet businesses and £4m-worth of savings from its acquisition of Southnews last year.

Trinity Mirror's shares fell 1%, or 4.5p, to 454p in early trading.

webTitle: Clooney and Cage circle new Parker film

fields.headline: Clooney and Cage circle new Parker film
fields.trailText: George Clooney is considering taking the title role in The Life of David Gale, an ethical prison drama that may also star its producer, Nicolas Cage
fields.body:
George Clooney (pictured) is currently in final negotiations to take the lead role in The Life of David Gale, a co-production between Universal and Intermedia that will be directed by Britain's Alan Parker. The film will be overseen by a production company run by Nicolas Cage, who also looks set to take a supporting role in the movie.

Scripted by Charles Randolph, The Life of David Gale will be an ethical prison drama in the vein of Dead Man Walking. Clooney will play the title role of a respected college professor, a staunch liberal and opponent of capital punishment, who is convicted of the murder of a fellow activist. The bulk of the picture will focus on the hero's experiences on Death Row. It is rumoured that Cage will play the role of a fellow inmate.

In the meantime the film's backers are eager to get the project before the cameras before the arrival of an actors strike that still threatens to paralyse Hollywood. Production is set to begin on The Life of David Gale just as soon as Clooney finishes shooting his starring role in Steven Soderbergh's Ocean's Eleven.

webTitle: Journalist's murder recalls mob mysteries

fields.headline: Journalist's murder recalls mob mysteries
fields.standfirst: People remain fascinated by organised crime and, as Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles, a recent killing will only fuel the interest
fields.trailText: People remain fascinated by organised crime and, as Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles, a recent killing will only fuel the interest.
fields.body:
When Bugsy Siegel, the gangster and casino owner, was shot dead in his Beverly Hills home in 1947, one of the first reporters on the scene was Florabel Muir of the New York Daily News.

Siegel's eye had been blasted out of his head and had ended up on the tiled floor. Being a diligent reporter, Ms Muir found it and, as she later explained, "picked up the sliver of flesh from which his long eyelashes extended."

No one has ever been arrested for the murder and it must be fair to say that no one ever will be.

But Siegel's murder is being recalled this week in the light of a murder in Benedict Canyon, another of Los Angeles's wealthier districts.

The victim was Susan Berman, a 55-year-old journalist and author, and the daughter of Davie Berman, who was Siegel's partner in the Flamingo Hotel in Las Vegas and the man who took over the running of it after Siegel's death.

She was killed with a single bullet to the head some time before December 24 when her body was discovered.

No one has yet been arrested for this murder either and there is no obvious reason for it. Most murders in Los Angeles these days are described as "gang-related", but the gangs concerned are the gangs of the streets rather than the gangs of old mobland.

However, the fact that Ms Berman wrote extensively about gangsters and Las Vegas has prompted speculation that there could be some connection there.

In her books Lady Las Vegas and Easy Street, she had described the life of a daughter of the Jewish mafia. She had supposedly been planning to write more books.

Davie Berman himself died in 1957 and his wife killed herself the following year.

So far, the police are not buying the mob theory; as one detective has pointed out, most of Davie Berman's contemporaries would now be aged between 80 and 100.

But this week a new side to the murder has emerged. It transpires that the New York police had been planning to interview Susan Berman in connection with the disappearance 19 years ago of Kathleen Durst, the wife of a prominent East Coast developer called Robert Durst.

Ms Berman had been to UCLA with Robert Durst in the '60s and had been a close friend. The police were planning to interview her amongst many others who might be able to shine any light on the case.

Ms Berman had acted as an informal spokeswoman for Durst after the disappearance of his wife.

So three mysteries have become intertwined. When Ms Berman wrote Easy Street in the late seventies, there was interest in a possible film. It came to nothing.

Now, for sad reasons, that interest will surely revive.

webTitle: Checking on charity

fields.headline: Checking on charity
fields.standfirst: The commission has been too slow to act
fields.trailText: The commission has been too slow to act.
fields.body:
War Child UK, the charity set up to help victims of the Bosnian war, is in serious trouble. Luciano Pavarotti and five other celebrity patrons have walked out of the high-profile overseas aid charity. Eleven trustees have resigned. A joint investigation by the Guardian and Channel 4 News shows that Bill Leeson, one of its co-founders, and Mike Terry, a consultant, took a bribe from contractors building a Bosnian music therapy centre, named after the Italian tenor. Though it was later repaid to the charity,the two men are still involved with the charity. There is also grave concern about high administrative expenses, poor accounting, inadequate management structures.

A spokesman for Mr Pavarotti said yesterday that he did not want to be associated with anything corrupt. He had asked about a Liberian children's project, but had had to wait for a year before he could get the accounts to discover that administration had absorbed much of the expenditure. As a result, he personally directed that all future money from him for former War Child UK projects in Yugoslavia, Liberia and Guatemala should be funded by different charities, following which, when the Kosovo crisis broke, a $1m donation was sent to the United Nations refugee agency.

Nigel Osborne, professor of music at Edinburgh University and former director of music for the centre, described the bribe as "a catastrophical betrayal". It was the revelation of the bribe that prompted patrons to act. They called for the retirement of Mr Leeson, the dissolution of the management committee, and the transfer of the Pavarotti project out of War Child UK's control. But nothing happened, leading to an exodus of patrons and trustees. It was a sad development in a charity that won the support of a new generation of pop stars. Many of the biggest names helped raise money for it in the mid 1990s. Other patrons included Sir Tom Stoppard, the playwright, and Juliet Stevenson, the actor.

What lessons can be learned? The trustees clearly behaved responsibly. Thwarted by the charity's management, they wrote to the charity commissioners in June 1998 about the lack of reports to trustees and the refusal to arrange suitable meetings. They also complained of the "financial impropriety". Two further letters were sent the same year complaining about the lack of financial information, the reluctance of Mr Leeson to cooperate, and the need for a full-time paid trustee to fill in the gaps in their knowledge and to examine whether Mr Leeson could be dismissed. The chairman of the trustees called in an independent auditor and independent solicitors. Yet they were still unable to budge the charity's management. Hence the decision of 11 trustees to resign.

The charity commission is conducting a financial audit but has moved much too slowly. It is 30 months since it was alerted to serious problems in the charity and yet it has still not produced a report or made public any recommendations. The commission's procedures are notorious for being ponderous and antiquated. John Stoker, the chief charity commissioner, is planning to upgrade its monitoring role, helped by a two-year 40% boost to its funding that begins in April 2002. But with a current £20m budget and a staff of 500, it should already be able to move more quickly to deal with a serious complaint. Quite separate from its regulatory role, the commission needs to review the advice it gives trustees. War Child trustees wanted to dismiss their unsatisfactory managers but failed. With better advice, they should have been able to get their way.

webTitle: Stars quit charity in corruption scandal

fields.headline: Stars quit charity in corruption scandal
fields.trailText: Luciano Pavarotti has walked out of the high-profile overseas aid charity, War Child UK, with five other celebrity patrons after discovering that its co-founder had taken a bribe from contractors building a prestigious music centre named after him in Bosnia. David Hencke reports
fields.body:
Luciano Pavarotti has walked out of the high-profile overseas aid charity, War Child UK, with five other celebrity patrons after discovering that its co-founder had taken a bribe from contractors building a prestigious music centre named after him in Bosnia.

The opera maestro - who along with the rock musician Brian Eno persuaded other stars like Elton John, Bono and Eric Clapton to perform in concerts and donate royalties to raise millions of pounds for the charity - quit after discovering that two people involved with the organisation had taken bribes and that there were concerns over financial and management controls. Pavarotti himself has raised more than $10m (£6.6m).

High profile patrons of the charity included the playwright Sir Tom Stoppard, film and Royal Shakespeare Company actress Juliet Stevenson, pop star David Bowie, and MTV chief Brent Hanson. They have also resigned because they are not happy about the direction of the organisation which helps children rebuild their lives in war-torn countries from former Yugoslavia to Liberia and Rwanda.

A spokeswoman for Pavarotti said: "He did not want to be associated with anything that was corrupt and wanted every dollar that he had raised to be accountable. On one project - the Liberian children's village - he had to wait one year before he could get the accounts and then found most of the money had been spent on the project in London but without practical result."

As a result, the world-famous tenor personally directed that money for former War Child UK projects in former Yugoslavia, Liberia and Guatemala be chanelled by other charities.

A joint investigation by the Guardian and Channel 4 News - to be shown at 7pm tonight - has discovered that the decision by the celebrities to quit and resignations from 11 trustees over the last two years has led to an inquiry by the charity commission into the running of War Child UK.

The inquiry - conducted with the co-operation of the remaining trustees - has confirmed the payment of bribes in Bosnia, excessive administrative expenditure and that too many staff took trips abroad to visit projects and attend fund-raising concerts. The charity commission says the new trustees are well on the way to restructuring their management and cutting administrative costs.

Documents passed to the Guardian and Channel 4 News show it was the bribery revelation that forced the patrons and former trustees to take action. Bill Leeson, the charity's co-founder, and Mike Terry, employed as a consultant, took a DM40,000 (£14,716) gift in November 1996 from Hydrogradnja, the main contractor, for building the Pavarotti music centre in Mostar. The pair offered to share the proceeds with David Wilson, the Mostar centre director and co-founder, who refused and notified trustees.

The trustees convened an extraordinary meeting and ordered that the money to be returned - only to discover that Mr Leeson had six months earlier also taken DM5000 (£1,670) from the sale of bakery machinery. The charity says this was authorised.

Nigel Osbourne, director of music for the centre and professor of music at Edinburgh University, described the "bung" as "a catastrophic betrayal" for "those who have risked their lives and livelihoods for the music centre".

Bill Leeson, who had spent some of the cash, defended his decision to Mr Wilson saying: "It was a totally legitimate business gift ... a small consolation for the price I have paid financially and emotionally and probably physically for the last four years."

The trustees hushed up the episode from the patrons, kept Mr Leeson in his post and told Mike Terry he must quit.

Two years later Mr Terry was re-engaged on fresh projects against the trustees' advice. This led David Wilson to inform Luciano Pavarotti in New York about the scandal. Within a month, on April 9 1999, Brian Eno and Sir Tom Stoppard met trustees at the charity's office in London to try to sort out the problem.

They called for the retirement of Bill Leeson, the disolution of the management committee, and the transfer of Pavarotti projects out of War Child UK. But nothing happened and the patrons and nearly all the trustees quit.

Sir Tom Stoppard told the Guardian: "It was a very confusing situation and I became confused myself and I felt it could only be resolved by a thorough inquiry, so I decided to leave."

Bill Leeson, who could not be contacted, has inflamed the situation by now saying on behalf of War Child that he wanted to get rid of the celebrities all along.

Rosie Boycott ,editor of the Daily Express, a current trustee of War Child, said yesterday that she hoped the charity would overcome what she admitted had been a nightmare and continue its unique work.

Daily Express readers raised £165,000 for a War Child bakery in Kosovo last year - a project praised by Parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, and given £350,000 by the government.

Two years later Mr Terry was re-engaged on fresh projects against the trustees' advice. This led David Wilson to inform Luciano Pavarotti in New York about the scandal. Within a month, on April 9 1999, Brian Eno and Sir Tom Stoppard met trustees at the charity's office in London to try to sort out the problem. They called for the retirement of Bill Leeson, the disolution of the management committee, and the transfer of Pavarotti projects out of War Child UK. But nothing happened and the patrons and nearly all the trustees quit. Sir Tom Stoppard told the Guardian: "It was a very confusing situation and I became confused myself and I felt it could only be resolved by a thorough inquiry, so I decided to leave." Bill Leeson, who could not be contacted, has inflamed the situation by now saying on behalf of War Child that he wanted to get rid of the celebrities all along. Rosie Boycott ,editor of the Daily Express, a current trustee of War Child, said yesterday that she hoped the charity would overcome what she admitted had been a nightmare and continue its unique work. Daily Express readers raised £165,000 for a War Child bakery in Kosovo last year - a project praised by Parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, and given £350,000 by the government.

webTitle: A charity caught up in chaos

fields.headline: A charity caught up in chaos
fields.standfirst: Unique projects in ravaged areas hid the financial mess of a dream that turned sour
fields.trailText: Unique projects in ravaged areas hid the financial mess of a dream that turned sour.
fields.body:
It started as a daring and innovative charity that was prepared to give practical help in places where no-one else would go. War Child was set up in 1993 by two friends, David Wilson, a former teacher and art agent, and Bill Leeson, a film maker. The rock musician Brian Eno describes both as "heroic figures" for being brave enough to go to Bosnia when bullets and bombs were flying and ethnic cleansing was at its height. It was launched at the Royal Festival Hall, London, during a three-day event at which the playwright Sir Tom Stoppard, its first patron, gave a reading.

The charity's first big project was a mobile bakery in Bosnia that was feeding 15,000 people a week in east Mostar and frontline villages.

Stoppard also describes their work as heroic: "Here it was a bakery in the centre of the war zone - feeding people whether they were Muslims or orthodox Christians. It was a tremendous thing to do - when it was really needed in an area where nobody would go."

The success of the bakery also led to their first contact with the world of pop. A radio report of the work of the mobile bakery persuaded Eno's partner, Anthea Norman-Taylor, to take a £2,000 cheque to War Child's office.

From those small beginnings, the charity's development snowballed. The music business became increasingly alarmed at the unfolding crisis in war-torn former Yugoslavia which led to the launch of a fundraising CD, Help.

Brian Eno persuaded his megastar friends, like U2's Bono and the Edge, to stage a concert to raise money to get musical instruments and tapes to Sarajevo. But his biggest breakthrough was to convince the world-famous tenor, Luciano Pavarotti, to sing in the same concert as Bono at Modena in Italy in 1995. It was the first of three Modena concerts inspired by War Child.

War Child's plans were upgraded. Instead of supplying musical instruments to Sarajevo, the charity decided to build a £3m music therapy centre. "It was like a dream come true," said David Wilson.

But as the dream was realised, the problems began. The charity began to lose control of its new-found wealth. Money began pouring in from CD royalties and one of the co-founders, Bill Leeson, accepted a gift from the contractors of the music centre.

The taking of the bribe - detailed on page one - shocked trustees. One, Elizabeth Huhne, said: "It was anathema for me. I know this happens sometimes in business but we are running a charity. We must be completely above board."

Berry Ritchie, a former chairman of trustees, said: "I was appalled. It staggered me that anybody involved in a charitable exercise, particularly one of the founders, should actually consider that he was justified in taking the money."

The fall-out was worse. After agreeing that Mr Leeson could stay, the trustees found themselves increasingly kept out of the picture. War Child UK was becoming increasingly ambitious, with sister organisations established in Holland, West Africa, Italy and the United States.

Mr Ritchie said: "It took us some time to realise we didn't know how much money was coming in. We certainly didn't know how much was being spent."

Mrs Huhne said: "It concerned me that at every meeting we had, we didn't have full financial reports. We could see the costs going up and up. It was like uncovering a can of worms every time you heard something."

There were complaints about Lynne Kuschel - then a member of the management committee and now chief executive - taking trips to Sarajevo and flying club class to attend an embassy cocktail party, and Mike Terry, a consultant to the charity's Mostar music centre, flying club class to meet the Croatian deputy prime minister. War Child said its policy for both aid and fundraising trips has always been to spend as little as possible on flights and accommodation.

The biggest row broke out over plans to send 19 employees to a concert for Liberian children organised by Pavarotti at Modena in 1998. Khawar Qureshi, a barrister in the chambers of Lord Neill (later to become chairman of the committee for standards in public life) who had taken over as chairman of trustees, warned at the time that this was excessive. "We are working with public money for the public and are accountable to the public," he said in a memo sent on June 2 to Bill Leeson. War Child eventually sent 11 people and yesterday defended their role there.

The trustees became increasingly unhappy. Mr Ritchie wrote to the charity commission on June 15 1998 on behalf of the trustees asking for "urgent advice" on handling the problem, disclosing the "financial impropriety" and asking for guidance on the "flouting of our authority."

Mr Qureshi says he called in independent accountants and solicitors to sort out the charity's finances and reform procedures but met resistance from the directors until he resigned in January 1999.

Problems were exacerbated when the patrons were belatedly informed in 1999 about the bribe and demanded action. Pavarotti demanded to see how much money had been spent on the Liberian project and accounts of all the money that had been ringfenced for the Mostar project. He was not happy and neither was Brian Eno.

Figures supplied by Amela Saric, the music centre's present director in Mostar might explain why. They show that between 1996 and September 1999 when War Child UK officially severed its link with Mostar some £2.190m was handed over. This compares with£3.209m raised for the centre and a further DM432,000 (£144,000) since then.

Some specific sums including money earmarked by Island records - a cheque for £133,259, royalties from a single called Miss Sarajevo, and £7,961 from profits on the Passengers single - have not reached the centre, according to the director.

The chairman, Peter Smith, last night released figures showing that the money from the Island cheques and other sums had reached the charity but had been used to cover their management fees in London. Altogether, he said £4,395,578 had been spent on the centre, including a management fee for War Child UK of £343,789.

There have also been disputes over the Liberian project. War Child's accounts show £287,464 was spent on the project. Yet according to Myrtle Gibson, the Liberian government senator in charge of the project: "The only thing we have seen on the ground is a Range Rover."

"We believe that between $300,000 (£198,000) and $500,000 (£330,000) does not seem to have reached us from the Modena concert in 1998." War Child UK said they had not had anything to do with the project since March 1999. They had passed the money to War Child Italy.

The charity's failure to sort out its problems led to Pavarotti withdrawing his money from Mostar, Liberia and another project in Guatemala. Most of the patrons also left. All the then trustees also quit - a new group chaired by businessman Peter Smith and including the editor of the Daily Express, Rosie Boycott, took their place. Ms Boycott said: "We all understood that the charity had been in trouble in recent years, but we all felt that War Child is an important organisation with a great deal to contribute to world poverty and the trauma caused to children in the aftermath of the conflict."

The projects have been saved by action taken by the patrons. The Mostar centre and Liberian children's village are being funded by Future Trust, a new charity set up by David Wilson and backed by Brian Eno and Pavarotti. Liberia also receives support from War Child Italy, now called Music for Peace, and War Child USA supports Guatemala.
