webTitle: 'It seemed close to deceitful that our money hadn't gone where it ought to'

fields.headline: 'It seemed close to deceitful that our money hadn't gone where it ought to'
fields.trailText: Brian Eno, the rock musician, broke a year's silence to tell the Guardian and Channel 4 News about his concerns over the War Child charity's handling of the millions of pounds raised for the Pavarotti music centre in Mostar
fields.body:
Brian Eno, the rock musician, broke a year's silence to tell the Guardian and Channel 4 News about his concerns over the War Child charity's handling of the millions of pounds raised for the Pavarotti music centre in Mostar.

He said he became involved - and persuaded fellow musicians to give long-term aid to the centre - as a "cultural mission" with the aim of leaving a permanent presence in Bosnia.

"Like a lot of people, I felt that we ought to be in some way involved. There were a lot of civilians and children being hurt and - whichever side was right or wrong or deserved one's sympathies - certainly the women and children, the non-combatants, who were really the target, did.

"What wasn't being done, I felt, was putting in place a sort of cultural infrastructure that would flower after the war had finished."

He said he received a lot of goodwill from his millionaire rock friends once the idea of the music centre had taken root.

"A lot of people responded to that idea. Like me, they felt we couldn't be impotent in the face of a local war and a particularly brutal one. They also responded to the idea that used what we do as artists as part of the solution."

"We made a lot of people think there was something we could do there and it's not that difficult to do something. In fact, it was embarrassingly easy to make a good difference there. One of the big outcomes is that we built this place called the Pavarotti music centre, which exists and is still flourishing."

He said he first became disillusioned when the two co-founders fell out and the money started going to new projects - and not all of it was getting to Mostar. Some of it was being used for other projects.

"What happened was the money didn't end up going to those projects. Events that had been staged to raise money for particular projects never got to those projects. I'm not saying it was corruptly spent or anything like that, but it didn't go where we felt it ought to have gone. PMC was somewhat abandoned and to abandon it, apart from anything else, I thought would be terrible PR".

He is particularly critical of the failure to send money from the proceeds of the Miss Sarajevo record to the centre. "It was done specifically for the music centre and everyone knew that. The money from that was spent on a lot of things including expenses for keeping a big office going."

"We were given the explanation that 'we're the charity and should be free to determine how we spend the money'. It seemed close to deceitful that our money hadn't gone where we felt it ought to have gone."

He went on: "There was a breakdown in communication. People felt that their contribution wasn't being received with any gratitude any longer. They were being treated as petulant celebrities who had to be kind of kept out of things. A lot of the people had strong feelings about these issues. They were not just people who blindly walk into any charity and start doing things like this. Bono, Bob Geldof, myself - there are a lot of people who have some kind of history of being involved in charitable work and in somehow using whatever power they have to change the world and they feel insulated when they are told their views don't count."

Stars who gave support

David Bowie

Rock musician and businessman with a personal fortune estimated at £500m. Born in Brixton, Bowie became a rock superstar in the 1970s. Now known as much as a big Wall Street player as a rock star, he was introduced to War Child through Brian Eno

Juliet Stevenson

Royal Shakespeare and film actress who was recently awarded a CBE. Now 44, she juggles her acting career with a family. She saw herself "more as a sleeping patron" but backed the other patrons over the issues which led to her resignation from her role at War Child

Sir Tom Stoppard

The renowned playwright was a strong patron of War Child from the start - he even dipped into his own pocket to help David Wilson and Bill Leeson survive in Mostar. He quit the charity with Brian Eno after the ill-fated trustee meeting in 1999

Brent Hanson

The head of the 24-hour MTV Europe music channel is not a traditional TV executive. He left TV New Zealand in 1986 because he was "pissed off that it was getting so corporation-minded" and still describes himself as "pretty hip". He was encouraged to join War Child by Brian Eno and quit at same time

The Patron who stayed

Neil Morrissey

An actor who still strongly supports War Child. Morrissey was a tearaway who spent much of his teens in care. The 38-year-old actor admits his feelings of anger have subsided "an awful lot" since he began working as a goodwill ambassador for the charity War Child: "Before this job started, I was in Rwanda and Sudan, and before that Kosovo. When you come back you don't have road rage, believe me."

webTitle: Things can't get better in just one term, says Blair

fields.headline: Things can't get better in just one term, says Blair
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is set to unveil a 10-year plan to crack down on crime within the next few weeks, swiftly followed by schemes for widespread reform of welfare to work and of secondary education, he revealed yesterday. By Sarah Hall
fields.body:
Tony Blair is set to unveil a 10-year plan to crack down on crime within the next few weeks, swiftly followed by schemes for widespread reform of welfare to work and of secondary education, he revealed yesterday.

The initiatives - to be unveiled before the anticipated May 3 election - are expected to follow the model of the 10-year NHS and transport plans, both announced in July. The reforms were described by Mr Blair as a "massive programme", suggesting Labour's confidence in winning a second term in office.

The commitment came as Mr Blair spoke to Labour members, businessmen, health officials and schoolchildren at a conference centre in Bristol in what was the first serious salvo of the unofficial election campaign. Before fielding questions on renationalisation of the railways, student tuition fees, and inadequate funding of student nurses, Mr Blair admitted that "for 20 years or more, Britain has suffered from chronic underinvestment in our public services - schools, hospitals, police, transport".

He pledged to rectify this by announcing "the largest ever sustained investment in public services Britain has seen".

The prime minister said money would be channelled into schools - particularly secondaries - the rail system, hospitals, and more police officers. But spending was not the only answer, and, as with the NHS plan which highlighted inefficiencies in the system, each area would undergo radical reform, with "steadily higher standards" demanded.

In an upbeat speech, in which he stressed the skill of the government in handling the economy - repeating the mantra "choice not chance" several times - and the importance of not blowing this economic stability, Mr Blair suggested his reforms were prompted by "one big overarching national purpose: to build a Britain in which prosperity spreads to every corner of the land, every party of every city, every family and child.

"It won't happen by chance, but the choices we as a nation make," he said.

As the Tories stepped up their pre-election campaign by unveiling new posters attacking Labour's pledges on public services, Mr Blair argued "20 years of neglect" were "never going to be put right in just one term of office".

He derided the Tories as the "people who doubled the national debt" for "telling us how to spend the surplus", and, "most comic of all, the people who gave us a botched privatisation of the railways, and failed to invest in them, say things would be better if they were in charge again".

But he also told his audience: "The biggest danger we face is apathy and cynicism; those people saying they're all the same - what's the point of voting."

In contrast to his earlier appearance in the day, when he was pelted with tomatoes, the invited questioners were largely appreciative, though there were cries of "shame" when Bristol West MP Valerie Davey tried to bring the session to a close after just nine questions.

Mr Blair faced tough questioning from Susan Lowther, aged 35, a student nurse at the University of the West of England and mother of three, who told him she could barely afford accommodation in Bristol on her meagre £390-a-month student nurse bursary, and was having to work seven days a week "just to make ends meet. Don't you care about us, so we can care about other people?" she asked, her voice breaking.

webTitle: Express owner hits back in website closure row

fields.headline: Express owner hits back in website closure row
fields.standfirst:
Jan 10: Staff slam 'cynical' sale
Jan 10: Website staff fight back
Jan 9: Express websites dumped
Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
12.45pm update: Northern & Shell will fight any legal case against it following the closure of the Express websites, writes Guy Middleton.
Jan 10: Staff slam 'cynical' sale
<A HREF=""Jan 10: Website staff fight back
Jan 9: Express websites dumped
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Northern & Shell will fight any legal case against it following the closure of the Express Newspapers websites.

Staff are planning legal action against the sites' new owner, investment group Seymour Pierce, and new Express owner Northern & Shell as their sites face liquidation.

A spokesperson for Northern & Shell said: "We do not believe that any of the individuals concerned have any grounds for legal action against Northern & Shell.

"Northern & Shell sold the websites in good faith to Seymour Pierce, who took on responsibility for all the assets associated with the portfolio."

The sale of the four websites was criticised by staff as a "cynical ploy to avoid paying redundancies".

Staff claim that they have not been paid since December 15 and allege that the sale of the sites may have been a ploy by Express owner Richard Desmond to avoid making redundancy payments.

"None of the kit was sold with us - why would that be if you actually intended to maintain the websites?" he said.

"If this can happen to us, then why can't it happen to the newsdesk at the Express?"

webTitle: House price gap likely to narrow

fields.headline: House price gap likely to narrow
fields.trailText: The north-south divide in Britain's housing market is likely to narrow this year as a recovery in the hard-pressed manufacturing sector boosts demand for property in the industrial heartlands, Halifax bank said yesterday.
fields.body:
The north-south divide in Britain's housing market is likely to narrow this year as a recovery in the hard-pressed manufacturing sector boosts demand for property in the industrial heartlands, Halifax bank said yesterday.

Although the past two months saw a widening of the gap between the two halves of the country, the bank said sales in the south would be affected by the explosive rise in prices recently, which had put them beyond the reach of many potential buyers.

Halifax's regional house price survey for the fourth quarter of 2000 found that property was dearer than in the third quarter but the annual pace of growth slowed to 5.7% from a peak of 14.5% in the first three months of last year.

In 2000 as a whole, prices tended to rise fastest in regions south of a line from the Bristol Channel to the Wash, with the fastest rates in East Anglia (13.7%) and the south-west (12.1%). However, house prices also rose by 10% in the West Midlands, despite its reliance on manufacturing. The two regions that saw a fall in prices were the north (-2.2%) and Scotland (-4.3%).

Greater London, where prices were rising at an annual rate of 29.5% early last year, saw the market cooling during 2000 with property inflation down to 8.3% in the final three months of the year. This trend was mirrored in the south-east, where prices fell in the final quarter of 2000. The average cost of a semi-detached house - the Halifax's benchmark of the market - in Greater London (£226,050) is five times that in South Humberside (£46,600). Surrey and Berkshire are the two next most expensive counties.

"The substantial rise in prices in this part of the country during 1999 resulted in affordability becoming an issue in these regions, making it increasingly difficult for buyers to enter the market," Halifax said. "This dampened demand and slowed price growth last year."

It added that the housing market had remained much more subdued outside the south of England, with little evidence of the"ripple effect", where a boom in one part of the country gradually spreads to other regions.

"This again largely reflects less buoyant economic conditions in most parts of Britain compared with the south of England.

"Slower economic growth in these regions has in part been due to their greater dependence on the manufacturing sector, which has continued to face difficult trading conditions."

Prices in the country as a whole rose by 0.9% in the fourth quarter of last year, slightly down on the 1.2% recorded in the third quarter.

webTitle: Branson remains bullish over prospect of capturing lottery

fields.headline: Branson remains bullish over prospect of capturing lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's hopes of running the national lottery were still alive last night after his team claimed that legal advice suggests he has a strong case for overturning the award of the next licence to Camelot. By David Teather
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's hopes of running the national lottery were still alive last night after his team claimed that legal advice suggests he has a strong case for overturning the award of the next licence to Camelot.

After meeting lawyers yesterday, Simon Burridge, chief executive of Sir Richard's People's Lottery, said "the world looked a better place".

He hinted there was a likelihood that the company would now take action.

Executives of the People's Lottery were locked in further meetings with their legal team late last night before reaching a decision.

"We have been told we have an extremely good case to argue that the process was flawed and substantively unfair," Mr Burridge said. "The decision made by the lottery commission was riddled with contradictions."

Sir Richard was outraged when the lottery commission last month awarded the next seven-year licence to Camelot. Camelot had used the high court to muscle its way back into the contest, he said.

Further legal action is likely to raise fears among charities that the licence term, due to begin in October, could be delayed.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, appeared to endorse Sir Richard's case. On BBC Radio 2, Mr Smith said the selection process had given an unfair advantage to the incumbent operator and should be reviewed.

The members of the People's Lottery are now considering launching an alternative game to raise money for good causes if they decide not to pursue their case, or if they lose in court.

"We would review the possibilities if we reach that point. We have had a fantastic response from the public who are very angry about what has happened," Mr Burridge said.

Mr Smith said the government would not stand in Sir Richard's way if he chose to start up an independent lottery.

webTitle: Website staff fight back

fields.headline: Website staff fight back
fields.standfirst:
Liquidation brings threat of legal action

MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
fields.trailText: Staff at the Express Newspaper websites - until recently owned by Richard Desmond - have threatened legal action after being told the sites had been put into liquidation, leaving them without compensation. By David Teather and Rob Griffin.
fields.body:
Staff at the Express Newspaper websites - until recently owned by Richard Desmond - have threatened legal action after being told the sites had been put into liquidation, leaving them without compensation.

After a hastily arranged meeting described as "angry but determined" the 46 staff said they were shocked by their treatment. Some had worked at the Express Newspaper group for several years when the sites were still owned by Lord Hollick's United Business Media.

The websites were sold to Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell as part of his acquisition of Express Newspapers in November. They were then sold on to SP Investments, an offshore company owned by his financial advisor Seymour Pierce several weeks later for just £1.

January salaries, which were due to be reach bank accounts next week, will not be paid.

Michael Streeter editor of one of the sites, Express.co.uk, said: "This bears all the hallmarks of a cynical legal ploy to avoid paying staff any notice or redundancy money. If this is not illegal, it is certainly immoral.

"We are consulting with lawyers to see whether the deal that Seymour Pierce and Northern & Shell have done is within the law.

"We now have a situation where three multi-million pound companies - United Business Media, Northern & Shell and Seymour Pierce - have played "pass the parcel" with their financial obligations to 46 staff. When the music stopped, none of them wanted to pay."

Staff need to wait in line with other creditors for the sale of assets to see if they will receive any money. The onus will otherwise be on the government to pay any arrears and notice period monies, capped at £230 a week.

Staff contracts had been transferred from Express Newspapers to five separate companies last year while still owned by Lord Hollick.

webTitle: Industry Standard publisher axes 36 jobs

fields.headline: Industry Standard publisher axes 36 jobs
fields.trailText: 9am: Standard Media, the parent of leading new economy magazine the Industry Standard, has shed 36 jobs, reports Guy Middleton.
fields.body:
Standard Media, the parent of leading new economy magazine the Industry Standard, has shed 36 jobs.

The cuts, accounting for 7% of the company's workforce, were accompanied by the departure of chief financial officer Herb Montgomery, group publisher Steve Thompson and vice-president of corporate marketing Kerry Zeida.

Job were axed in Standard Media's San Francisco-based marketing, internet and conferencing team.

A senior source within the company said that the redundancies had come after a year of "phenomenal and unprecedented growth" that had required rapid expansion.

"We have been known for covering the ups and downs of the internet, now we are part of that story," added the source.

The Industry Standard has a reputation for taking less of a "cheerleader" approach than some of its rivals. It features a "lay-off tracker" on its website that keeps tabs on new media redundancies and the company has duly added its own job cuts to the page.

New economy titles in the US, such as Red Herring, Business 2.0 and the Industry Standard have ridden the same wave of internet enthusiasm as the industries they report on.

All were looking at rapid growth and an IPO last year, but have suffered as technology and finance companies' advertising budgets were trimmed and some start-up advertisers fell by the wayside.

London-based Industry Standard Europe is not affected by the cuts, the company said.

webTitle: Motorola set to add to telecoms gloom

fields.headline: Motorola set to add to telecoms gloom
fields.trailText: 9am: The City is bracing itself for more bad news today when US mobile phone maker Motorola reports fourth quarter results, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The stock market is bracing itself for more bad news this afternoon when US mobile phone maker Motorola reports fourth quarter results.

Finnish handset maker Nokia yesterday sent shock waves through the technology and telecoms sector with below par sales figures, and analysts fear that Motorola will add to the gloom.

Motorola has already primed the markets for bad news by issuing a profit warning in December, saying that earnings would be 40% lower.

"People should not expect any further surprises, but it depends what Motorola says about the overall outlook for the mobile phone market," said Susan Anthony, telecoms analyst at Credit Lyonnais.

Motorola has joined the growing ranks of US technology and telecoms firms who have been hit by falling consumer confidence and saturated markets. Microsoft and Intel are among the big players who have warned that forthcoming profit figures will not be up to scratch.

Nokia's shares tumbled up to 17% after the company said that it had sold 128m handsets last year, below analysts' estimates of 140m.

The market leader's announcement came after Orange, BT Cellnet, Vodafone and One2One posted record UK Christmas sales, buoying investor sentiment in a sector which has been hit by concerns over mounting debts.

However, some industry observers were surprised by the reaction to Nokia's news, saying it should have boosted investor confidence ahead of Motorola's announcement.

Last year's sales total was a 64% increase on the year before, and Motorola's figures will be nowhere near as impressive.

Ms Anthony added: "Nokia are completely bewildered by the reaction. Nokia is a company that clearly understands this industry better than anyone else It is clear that there is still a lot of nervousness in the market."

Nokia said there were about 700m mobile phone users worldwide, and the total will top 1bn in the first half of next year.

webTitle: Charity urges protocols on care home closures

fields.headline: Charity urges protocols on care home closures
fields.trailText: The growing number of care home closures has prompted charity Counsel and Care to call for official protocols on what happens when a home faces shutdown.
fields.body:
The growing number of care home closures has prompted charity Counsel and Care to call for official protocols on what happens when a home faces shutdown.

Many recent home closures have taken place in "unseemly haste", the charity says. In an otherwise highly regulated sector, there is nothing to protect the interests of vulnerable elderly and disabled residents. Counsel and Care, which provides advice on residential and nursing care, says 800 closures have taken place over the past year.

Given the "low" level of fees offered by local authorities for residents funded by the community care system, it warns, the attrition looks likely to continue. Les Bright, the charity's deputy director, argues that lack of closure protocols makes the care sector the poor relation.

School closures take place only after lengthy consultation, and council housing stock transfers depend on a vote among tenants, he said, adding: "If a home is earmarked for closure, residents and patients should be protected and their views sought to ensure that the anxiety and distress they experience is minimised."

Protocols would delay closure so that every other possibility was examined, especially in the interests of residents and patients without close family. "In the past, there have been deaths among patients transferred from homes in which they have lived for many years," said Mr Bright. "It seems not only practical but humane that the Department of Health should consider that closure protocols should be put in place."

The charity's call is being backed by Unison, the public services union, which blames the rash of closures on the fact that the care home sector has become dominated by for-profit operators. Malcolm Wing, the union's national secretary for local government, said: "Local authorities were forced to dispose of the majority of homes because the private sector said it could run them cheaper and better. The sight of elderly people being, in effect, evicted because they were no longer making a profit for their home owners is a scandal which should not be allowed to continue."

webTitle: Adam and Joe star in E4 revival show

fields.headline: Adam and Joe star in E4 revival show
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Adam and Joe are set to star on new Channel 4 station E4 in a revival of the show that launched their careers.By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Camcorder puppeteers Adam and Joe are set to star on new Channel 4 station E4 in a revival of the show that launched their careers.

And the mavericks who brought the world puppet masterpieces Toytrainspotting, Chew Wants to be a Millionaire? and Saving Private Lion, will invite members of the public to submit their home-made masterpieces via the internet.

The new channel will revive Takeover TV, the programme which launched their careers, but with a difference.

E4 will be accompanied by a new website where viewers will be invited to submit video spoofs.

Then the best of the offerings will be broadcast on the programme, which will be broadcast on E4.

The move to incorporate the internet into the E4 commissioning structure is part of Channel 4's broadband strategy.

Broadband chief Peter Grimsdale, who discovered Adam and Joe when working as a commissioning editor for Channel 4, said the project could prefigure more extensive use of the internet to trail programmes.

A spokeswoman for E4 said a name for the show had yet to be decided, as had transmission details.

Adam Buxton and Joe Cornish were originally dismissed by Channel 4 commissioners when they sent in a tape hoping to grab a slot on public access show Takeover TV.

Describing themselves as "third-division celebrities", the pair won the affection of the public when they were invited to present the links on the show, comprised of spoof sketches sent in by members of the public.

Channel 4 eventually let them front their own show, The Adam and Joe Show, which was a hit with viewers.

webTitle: Psychiatric services slow to learn lessons of ward suicides

fields.headline: Psychiatric services slow to learn lessons of ward suicides
fields.standfirst: Linda Hart has twice tried to commit suicide on a psychiatric ward. Wendy Moore looks at the dilemmas faced by the NHS in reducing the risks to patients
fields.trailText: Linda Hart has twice tried to commit suicide on a psychiatric ward. Wendy Moore looks at the dilemmas faced by the NHS in reducing the risks to patients
fields.body:
Nobody was watching when Linda Hart went to her room, took the cord from her dressing gown, stuffed it up her jumper, then went to the bathroom. Nobody saw her tie the cord around her neck, throw the other end around a waste pipe then stand on a box. And nobody saw her jump.

Yet Ms Hart was a patient on an NHS psychiatric ward, compulsorily detained for her own safety because she was known to be suicidal and supposedly under constant supervision by staff. She is one of the lucky ones. Her absence, at least, was noted and she was cut down and eventually revived.

"It was quite easy," said Ms Hart, 53, who is diagnosed psychotic but now lives at home in the midlands. Nurses supervising her were chatting about their holidays when she made the suicide attempt seven years ago. She survived a further attempt last summer, on the same ward, when she drank bath cleaner she had smuggled to her room.

Others are not so lucky. About 180 psychiatric in-patients commit suicide each year. Almost half the suicides happen on the ward itself, or in hospital grounds, and the rest while patients are on leave, according to the national confidential inquiry into suicide and homicide by people with mental illness. Hanging, usually from shower or curtain rails, is the most common method. A quarter of wards where suicides happen have nursing shortages. One in five patients is under special observation - 3% "constantly" - at the time they kill themselves.

One of them was a friend of Ms Hart's, a 56-year-old man who hanged himself in 1999 from the same pipe Ms Hart had used. The pipe has finally, said Ms Hart, been boxed in.

Psychiatric services appear slow to learn the lessons. Since 1971 repeated reports have recommended wards could reduce suicides at a stroke by replacing fixed curtain and shower rails with collapsible versions. Yet data to the ongoing confidential inquiry reveal such deaths are still happening. At the same time, other means of committing suicide are readily available while obvious preventive measures are ignored.

Now the government wants all suicides by hanging from non-collapsible rails eliminated by March next year. Mental health lobby groups would like to go further and prevent all suicides on the wards. So is the NHS doing enough to stop psychiatric patients taking their lives? Louis Appleby, director of the confidential inquiry, thinks not. And now, as the recently appointed mental health tsar, he is in the unusual position of implementing his own recommendations.

They include removing from wards all structures that could be used for hanging, eliminating obstructions to observing patients and ensuring staff in contact with suicidal patients are trained in recognising, assessing and managing that risk. He finds it "staggering" that one in 25 of all suicides takes place on a psychiatric ward - almost twice the rate of suicides in prisons, although these receive far more publicity.

And although many psychiatric wards have already removed obvious hanging points, he says reports of deaths from fixed rails continue. Services could do more to reduce suicides through more training, increased vigilance, improved ward design and better assessment of risk, he believes. But eliminating suicides entirely is "unrealistic". He said: "Admission is often because people are suicidal so we are already dealing with a very high risk group. A completely risk-free environment would be stark and oppressive. You always have to balance these issues of safety against the dignity of the surroundings for people."

Margaret Clayton, who chairs the mental health act commission, agreed: "Unless you have constant one-to-one observation, which would be totally unacceptable to the patients, it is impossible completely to rule out suicides." She backed the inquiry's recommendations, which have been echoed in commission reports. An audit by the commission in 1999 found that 31 people detained under the Mental Health Act, supposedly for their own or others' safety, hanged themselves in the 12 months up to February 1998 and 20 had had ready access to belts or dressing gown cords, as well as the means, such as rails, from which to hang themselves.

The key factor - highlighted in a repeat audit out shortly - is assessing risk, argues Ms Clayton. "If you have more and better trained staff that always helps, but you have to draw a balance somewhere between almost harassing the patient," she said.

Leading psychiatrists also regard some suicides as inevitable. "There is always a tension between being oppressive and being safe," said Geoff Searle, consultant psychiatrist at St Ann's hospital, Poole. Leaving fixed rails in place is "stupidity", he said. But removing all means of committing suicide - including door knobs, pictures and crockery - would turn psychiatric wards into prisons.

"You can end up with an incredibly arid environment," he said. Truly determined patients will still find ways to kill themselves. He recalled a patient on a locked ward who propped up his bed, tied a sheet to the rungs and dropped to his knees to hang himself.

Tony Maden, professor of forensic psychiatry at Imperial College, London, says all suicides are theoretically preventable but the emotional cost can be too high. While suicides could be stopped through one-to-one, arms-length observation by staff, this would be extremely intrusive.

But lobby groups condemn the attitude that suicide is unavoidable on psychiatric wards. "It should not be seen as an outcome of mental illness. It is not inevitable," said Gary Hogman, head of policy at the National Schizophrenic Fellowship, which has been campaigning since 1993 to reduce suicide rates.

An estimated one in 10 people with schizophrenia kill themselves - far more than kill anyone else, despite the media circus this generates. "Many families think their son is in hospital and they can sleep at night then two days later he has managed to kill himself," said Mr Hogman. He blames a combination of factors, including increased pressure on wards from over-occupied beds, under-staffing, more violence and more detained patients. Poor ward conditions also do not help.

Research last autumn by the mental health charity, Mind, concluded that depressing ward conditions were hindering patients' recovery. Its survey found that more than one in two ex-patients described wards as "untherapeutic" with complaints about dirty bathrooms, insufficient food and drink, lack of contact with staff and sexual harassment.

Angela Hampton (not her real name) has been in and out of hospital for the past eight years with various mental health problems. The 45-year-old has attempted suicide four times in the past year, the last time after being sent home when refused a bed at her local unit because it was full.

When she is admitted, she says staff are demoralised and overworked. "We are left on our own to sit around and smoke," she said. Last time she smuggled in scissors, a penknife, a mirror and sewing needles which she kept hidden until discharged three weeks later. "I used the penknife to scratch myself and I did think about committing suicide." Talk among patients frequently centres on means to commit suicide, she said. "We are like prisoners learning about crime."

 Linda Hart has written a book describing her experiences on a psychiatric ward. Phone at Nine Just to Say You're Alive is published by Pan at £6.99.

Taking their lives in their hands

 A quarter of the 2,370 people who committed suicide in England and Wales between April 1996 and March 1998 had had contact with mental health services in the previous year

 Of these 16% - about 180 a year - were psychiatric in-patients

 A third of suicides took place on the wards, 13% on hospital premises and just over half on leave

 Hanging was the means of suicide in 68% of ward deaths

 Nursing shortages and difficulties observing patients were reported in a quarter of in-patient suicides

 Mental health teams believed that one in five suicides could have been prevented

webTitle: Name and shame

fields.headline: Name and shame
fields.standfirst: Does it matter whether we are described as patients or clients?  Theodore Dalrymple  thinks it does.
fields.trailText: Does it matter whether we are described as patients or clients? Theodore Dalrymple thinks it does.
fields.body:
Whenever I hear a patient called a client I shudder, just as I used to when my teacher caught her nail on the blackboard as she was writing on it with chalk. There is something about the term - it is simultaneously unctuous and euphemistic, as if some unpleasant reality were being concealed by its use. I can't help thinking we will soon hear prisoners referred to as "clients": even the term "con" would be preferable to that.

Patients in psychiatric services are now rarely referred to except as clients and the usage is now nearly universal. Indeed, if one still uses "patient", one can almost feel the disapproval. One is regarded as a reactionary and almost as an enemy of the people.

A paper in the latest Psychiatric Bulletin reports the first (admittedly small) survey of psychiatric patients and terminology: did they prefer to be called patients or clients? Overwhelmingly they preferred patients. Social class didn't matter nor did their diagnosis; in fact there was no identifiable subgroup that preferred to be called clients.

As the authors of the survey - psychiatrists at the Royal Free Hospital in London and at the Royal Park Hospital in Melbourne - point out, the two words have quite different connotations. A patient is a suffering person who either seeks or needs care. A client is a person who buys a service. Patients go to doctors, clients go to lawyers (or prostitutes).

The authors quote Ben Pimlott's introduction to the Penguin edition of Nineteen Eighty-Four: when Orwell noted the eagerness with which truth evaders shy away from well-known words and substitute their own he was observing it as something as relevant to petty bureaucrats as to dictators.

The demand that patients should become clients clearly did not originate with the patients themselves. I have never heard a single one ask to be called a client, though some, who wish to be left alone with their delusions and hallucinations, don't want to be called patients either.

Two questions emerge, one historical and one practical. Why did the change in terminology occur, and what happens next?

Ostensibly, the term client was introduced to equalise the relationship between the provider and recipient of help and attention. A client, after all, actively chooses his adviser and pays him: his payment stands guarantor of his dignity. In the NHS, no one pays his doctor or even chooses him. The patient gets whom he's given.

And a patient is much more passive, even when he does pay. He has things done to him. A patient, but not a client, is worthy of compassion because it is acknowledged that he is, by definition, a sufferer and therefore in need of succour and relief. An involuntary patient is not a contradiction in terms; but an involuntary client is.

The real reason for the change was a power struggle between various factions in the psychiatric services. It had nothing to do with the wishes of patients, or even with increasing professional respect for them.

Some people who worked in the psychiatric services just felt that doctors needed demoting, or putting in their place: and doctors above all see patients, therefore patients had to be turned into clients, whether they wanted it or not. As Humpty Dumpty so acutely remarked: "The question is, which is to be master - that's all."

It is not to be expected, therefore, that practices will change as a result of this survey. The march of the term client will continue, until it has been so widely used for so long that it becomes completely accepted, and no one will even be able to remember a time when it wasn't. A return to using the term patient would be a political defeat, its elimination a victory. In all this, patients (and clients for that matter) are mere pawns.

I suppose one might call the change from patient to client a little piece of linguistic engineering. I find it sinister: but perhaps I'm paranoid. In which case, of course, I need to become a client.

webTitle: BBC claims belated Christmas ratings victory

fields.headline: BBC claims belated Christmas victory
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITV claimed victory on the day, but with the official figures in its hands, the BBC has declared they won the ratings battle on Christmas Day. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV claimed victory on the day. But now with the official figures in their hands, BBC bosses have declared they were the ultimate winner on Christmas Day.

Although the festive season is long gone, there is clearly much to play for in the ratings battle, even if the difference between the two is only half a percentage point.

BBC1 and ITV are both claiming a Christmas Day peak-time ratings victory, following the publication of the official Barb statistics for the final week of 2000.

The new ratings, which include video-recorded viewing, push BBC1 ahead of ITV for the 6-10.30pm period on Christmas Day. Its share of audience went up slightly from a 39.8% to 40.3%, putting it ahead of ITV, which had 40%.

Although the two stations are neck and neck, the BBC is determined to go down in history as the winner.

Until a few years ago ITV didn't bother to compete with the BBC but now it has made a much bigger effort with Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, Emmerdale and Coronation Street specials.

The Royle Family Christmas Day special was a contributing factor in the BBC1's improved figures. After video recordings were taken into account, the comedy's audience went up by 1.5m, to 9.8m.

But ITV, which defines peak as 7-10.30pm, can also still claim a Christmas Day ratings victory, with 41.4% during this period compared with BBC1's 39.8%.

webTitle: ASA raps The Sun

fields.headline: ASA upholds complaints against The Sun
fields.trailText: The Sun has been given a warning by the ASA over its millionaire scratchcard game, reportsDaniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The Sun has been rapped by advertising watchdogs over its handling of its millionaire scratchcard game last year.

Readers complained they couldn't get through to the bonanza phonelines and one man who believed he had hit a minor jackpot was told his scratchcard was a "misprint".

The Advertising Standards Authority received 16 complaints from the public about the Guaranteed Millionaire game which the paper, and its sister title News of the World, ran back in August.

The most serious involved a man who believed he had followed the rules and won £5,000, only to be told by the promoters that his card was invalid because of a printing error.

Other complainants claimed the phone lines were so busy they were unable to get through.

The ASA upheld the complaints against the Sun saying that it "was not satisfied that the promotion had been properly administered or that enough had been done to avoid disappointing participants." It warned the newspaper to take more care in the future.

It was particularly concerned that the £5,000 winner had not been given an explanation as to why his claim had not been honoured.

The Sun's marketing director was unavailable for comment on the complaints, but a spokeswoman pointed out that two lucky readers had become millionaires already.

webTitle: Leader: Mr Dyke in the stocks

fields.headline: Mr Dyke in the stocks
fields.standfirst: Those who pelt him have dubious motives
fields.trailText: Those who pelt BBC director-general Greg Dyke have dubious motives.
fields.body:
Sometimes reaction to an event is more instructive than the event itself. This one took the ephemeral form of an interview with BBC director-general Greg Dyke on a programme called The Mix, broadcast on BBC Radio Scotland at the weekend. His remarks were unscripted and the BBC's formidable publicity machine did not promote them. They were, however, picked up and have become an anvil on which the smiths of rightwingery have over the past few days beaten a chorus of racial enmity and contempt for the diversity the BBC - the British broadcaster - must embody.

Mr Dyke has long been a red rag, so to speak: he once was a community worker, he had Labour inclinations and connections, he is rich but chooses to work for the public sector, etc. Yet all he did here was repeat a pledge to extend the employment and promotion policies of his predecessor John Birt: to make the BBC more mixed, in front as well as behind the microphones, cameras and computer screens, and in its senior management. That means mixed in terms of skin colour, ethnic origin and provenance. Just like modern Britain. To make his point, Mr Dyke said the BBC was "white", adding the emphatic adverb "hideously".

This was original sin. The Daily Mail, having recovered after a momentary lapse into sympathy with the Lawrence family, mobilised the hit men. The Daily Telegraph, after a bilious leading article, opened its letters columns to the Home Counties' haters who seem, still, to make up the bulk of its readers. If Mr Dyke needed a demonstration of where the enemies of his vision of the BBC are located, he has got it.

As an employer, he will brush them aside and go on modernising and diversifying a large organisation that probably needs occasional shocks from the top to make it move. But he is also editor-in-chief and needs to give thought to the theory of "balance" of which BBC producers' codes and editorial manifestos make much. The BBC likes to see itself as a fulcrum. In discussions as in news reports, it seeks voices from one side to counter those from the other. Yet its news agenda is often set by the papers now busy doing Mr Dyke in. The issues they choose to promote become part of the BBC's agenda too. That may be done in the name of balance, but except in the narrowest sense, balance is scarcely what it achieves. There is scope for another pithy Dyke definition here.

webTitle: Bob the builder heads for US

fields.headline: Bob heads for US to build a fortune
fields.standfirst: Backers of TV character launch attack on lucrative American market
fields.trailText: Backers of TV character launch attack on lucrative American market. by John Cassy.
fields.body:
Britain's latest pop sensation touches down at New York's JFK airport this afternoon, with his backers hoping for scenes reminiscent of the height of Beatlemania. Around 600 members of the media and hordes of screaming pre-schoolers are expected to meet the star, who will be taken by motorcade to Manhattan for a meeting with former president Jimmy Carter, then on to an appearance on the Rosie O'Donnell chat show.

Bob the Builder, the animated DIY expert and idol of the under-fives, arrives in town hoping to make it where several of Britain's biggest acts have failed.

He has already "fixed it" in every other leading market around the world, from Australia to Japan, but America remains the biggest and most important country to conquer. And not every character has succeeded. Budgie the Helicopter, the Duchess of York's much-hyped childrens' cartoon, failed to live up to expectations and the company that originally owned the rights got into financial difficulty.

Imagination

Similarly, veteran glove puppet Sooty never really captured the imagination of American children.

From Monday, half-hour episodes of Bob the Builder's adventures will be aired five times each week on Nickelodeon, the Viacom-owned television network that reaches an estimated 9m American pre-school children each week.

Shortly afterwards, toy maker Hasbro will start selling a range of Bob merchandise, while publishers Simon & Schuster and Golden have prepared a range of story and activity books respectively.

Yet nobody will be hoping Bob hits the nail on the head more than Peter Orton, chief executive of HIT Entertainment, the children's entertainment firm that created Bob and owns all broadcasting and licensing rights.

"The US market tends to be the acid test that defines whether a childrens' character can become a truly global property," explained Mr Orton, who in previous jobs played leading roles in the commercial success of classic shows such as The Muppets and Sesame Street

"I'm optimistic. In the UK, Bob is every bit as big as the Muppets when they were at their most popular. He has a tremendous opportunity to become a major pre-school property over the next 10 years."

Around $3.5m (£2.5m) is being spent by HIT, its licencees and the network on launching Bob in the US. Much of the cost for HIT has come from knitting together its standard 10-minute Bob slots with new two-and-a-half minute "bridging" pieces to make 26 22.5 minute programmes, which - with adverts and credits - fill a half-hour slot.

Nickelodeon pays HIT about £100,000 for each episode it airs, but the most lucrative revenues as far as the British firm is concerned will come from its cut of merchandising and video sales. About 200,000 Bob videos were sold in Britain over the Christmas period alone, taking the total well past the 1m mark.

"The US market is around five times as big as the UK so I'd hope we'd sell around 5m or 6m videos over there for every million we sell here," Mr Orton said. Each video retails for about £9.99, with HIT taking about £4.50 of that. Once manufacturing and marketing costs are taken into account, £2 per video is clear profit.

Yet Mr Orton is proceeding with caution. "The size of the US market is significant but how well we do depends on how well we manage it. With Bob we're trying to build a brand which becomes a classic. We want parents to feel the products represent value and quality. Bob's integrity has to be preserved."

There are 60 licencees to make Bob products; many more were turned down.

HIT has decided to take total control of its video sales in the US and set up its own video label which will also sell tapes of Angelina Ballerina, another HIT character. "It means we control the whole process from the editorial stage right through to publishing. We're not exposed to the vagaries of agents who may oversell," said Mr Orton. Sensible management or not, Mr Orton will nervously await the first week's viewing figures.

The price of HIT shares has climbed sharply over the past two years, largely due to the success of Bob, which will increase group revenues from £20m now to about £26.5m in 2001. Then the shares traded at about 140p; today they change hands at 407.5p, valuing HIT at £390m.

Favourite

Many investors have already bought in anticipation of US success. The States is expected to account for 35% of total group sales in 2001; by 2004 that figure is expected to jump to 60%.

Britt Allcroft-owned Thomas the Tank Engine, which is probably the premier British children's property and a big favourite in the US, is thought to be worth £130m. On that basis analysts believe Bob could eventually be worth more.

The Tweenies could also enter that league - if they are a success in the US.

Yet some analysts caution that Bob's success could eventually count against HIT. "If their next big character isn't as successful people are likely to say they have failed," said one analyst.

HIT's new product pipeline includes Oswald the Octopus and a show set in a bath tub with the title of Splish, Splash, Splosh.

A rubber duck claiming the Christmas number one? If Mr Blobby can make it, why not?

webTitle: Reality TV unreal

fields.headline: Reality TV unreal
fields.standfirst:
Big Brother imitators assault screens

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: In the stampede to copy a winning formula, a rash of 'reality TV' shows is to hit the screens. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Big Brother, the trailblazer of a genre of television entertainment, has spawned an entire family of siblings. In the stampede to copy a winning formula, a rash of "reality TV" shows is to hit the screens. As each vies for ratings supremacy, the formats get ever more bizarre.

One show requires its participants to submit to the demands of viewers by phone poll, another follows the trials of TV dating, and in a third - GMTV's Inch Loss Island - viewers see fat-busters trying to lose weight on a dream island.

The assault begins tonight on ITV with Popstars, and continues tomorrow with the Mole on Channel 5 and the BBC's Bare Necessities. In the longer term, Big Brother 2 and Castaway 2001 are in preparation.

Popstars follows the creation of a teen band from the auditioning of 3,000 largely tuneless aspirants, through the selection of six of them, to the real-time release of a CD. It is cringe TV - viewers will surely cower as teenagers splutter their way through S Club 7 hits and murder Ricky Martin numbers.

In the "nasty Nick" tradition, the show has its own pantomime villain. Nigel Lythgoe, controller of entertainment at LWT and the arbiter of who gets picked, is the subject of the show's advertising campaign ("Nigel, pick me!")

In a former life, Lythgoe was a member of the BBC's dance troupe Young Generation, so he knows what he is looking for. He promises that the cameras will not get turned off "when the going gets tough". He said: "It's like a soap opera. It's got great characters, in that you want to follow them through. It's not just an entertainment show, it's a real life drama."

Kieron Collins, executive producer of the BBC's Bare Necessities, which puts two teams in a foreign location for a week with only 10 basic tools for survival, says the latest breed of shows plays to the viewers' appetite for voyeurism. "It's about eavesdropping on people's discomfort and delighting in their misfortune. But also, it's about mentally comparing yourself to them: you like to think that you could do better, but the reality is that you probably wouldn't come close."

Some commentators fear for the future of television. In the US, there has been outrage at Temptation Island. The show puts couples "at a crossroads in their relationship" on a romantic island with single men and women, and sets them up on dates together.

But Collins does not believe that, in the battle for ratings, British TV would sink as low as the Jenny Jones show in America, when a participant killed a neighbour after revelations on the show. "I don't think anybody would go to the nth degree of letting someone die on a reality TV show just for ratings."

Popstars (ITV)

Thousands of aspiring pop singers compete for just six places in a manufactured band: cameras follow the whole process; a deal with Polydor awaits. Watch out for Claire from Glasgow - big girl with a big voice.

The Mole (C5)

Ten people compete to complete a challenge, knowing that one of their number is a plant whose sole goal is to frustrate their ambitions. Will the viewers work out the mole's identity before they do?

Inch Loss Island (GMTV)

Viewers desperate to lose weight are taken to a desert island to complete their goal.

Shipwrecked (C4)

Sixteen under-25s are taken to a Pacific island were they must survive for 10 weeks with limited food and shelter. Plenty of glistening flesh to keep the ratings up.

Bare Necessities (BBC)

Another survival show: teams divided by profession (journalists v paramedics, for example) are sent to a remote location and must get by with 10 basic survival tools. Do they perform to stereotype?

Jungle Janes (C4)

Yet more survivor TV - a dozen women swap middle England for deepest Brunei, where their gruelling expedition is followed by the cameras.

webTitle: Infidelity TV tempts US viewers

fields.headline: Infidelity TV tempts US viewers
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's Fox television network's Temptation Island takes reality television to a new level, writes Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's Fox television network has been able to resist everything except temptation.

Tonight it is screening just the kind of flamboyantly exploitative and voyeuristic reality show that Fox executives vowed would never happen again after last year's controversial Who Wants to Marry A Millionaire.

Temptation Island takes reality television to a new level. Four couples have been flown to an island off Belize where they will be confronted by a team of 26 attractive and scantily-clad creatures of both sexes who attempt to test their commitment to each other.

The four men go to one side of the island with the single women and the women stay with a group of single men. The tempters and temptresses include Miss Georgia 2000, a former Playboy model and a masseur.

The resulting flirtations and tensions are what make up the six hour-long episodes. As in Big Brother and Survivor, two other successful reality programmes, the couples have a chance to vote people off the programme, if they think they constitute temptations.

Already church and family groups have attacked the programme. The American Family Association, a conservative pressure group, has asked its members to complain about the show and a Texas rabbi has asked his local affiliate station not to show it - all moves that have garnered more publicity.

"The producers of Temptation Island should be ashamed of themselves for trying to force the destruction of four relationships for the entertainment purposes of those low-lifes who consent to watch this trash," said Brent Bozell, of the Parents' Television Council.

However, Fox is unrepentant. "This is not a show, as you will see, that is about sex," said Sandy Grushow, the chairman of Fox Television Entertainment Group. "This is a show that is exploring the dynamics of serious relationships."

Fox have also pointed out that the couples are not married. But just in case the relationships should get really serious, participants were tested for sexually transmitted diseases before participating.

Last year, Fox was heavily criticised for its screening of Who Wants to Marry A Millionaire.

It transpired that Rick Rockwell, the millionaire groom, had had a restraining order brought against him by a former fiancee. His marriage to his choice, Darva Conger, was never consummated. She has since modelled for Playboy.

The success in the US of Survivor has led to a demand for other similar shows, many of which seem beyond parody. But currently doing the email rounds in the US is a 'New Texas Version of Survivor' under which contestants must travel around the state "driving a Volvo with a bumper sticker reading: 'I'm for Gore, I'm Gay and I'm Here to Take Your Guns' ; the first to complete the round trip is the winner."

It could be the next big thing.

webTitle: Prodi needles Swedes over fear of euro

fields.headline: Prodi needles Swedes over fear of euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Sweden got an uncomfortable public reminder of its deep-seated euro-scepticism yesterday when Romano Prodi said he wished its commitment to three "Es" during its EU presidency included a fourth - the euro.
fields.body:
Sweden got an uncomfortable public reminder of its deep-seated euro-scepticism yesterday when Romano Prodi said he wished its commitment to three "Es" during its EU presidency included a fourth - the euro.

Mr Prodi, president of the European Commission, was in Stockholm for a day of talks with Goran Persson, the prime minister, at the start of Sweden's six-month stint in the union's rotating presidency.

With both men diplomatically stressing their appreciation for each other, Mr Prodi told reporters that he was delighted with Sweden's focus on enlargement, the environment and employment - a deliberately catchy and alliterative trio of high-priority EU policies.

But he added, in a characteristically jokey aside that barely concealed a more serious truth: "I am only sorry that these three Es are not followed by a fourth - euro."

Sweden, Britain and Denmark are now the only members of the 15-strong EU not in the single currency zone following Greece's accession on January 1 after it met the Maastricht treaty's tough convergence criteria.

Mr Persson repeated that a referendum was a long way off and depended on economic conditions and wage settlements, though his Social Democratic party wants to join.

But he acknowledged that last September's Danish "no" to the euro was a setback, as is the uncertainty about Tony Blair's position on a British referendum, which is unlikely to be clarified until after a spring general election.

Polls show more than 60% of Swedes are opposed to scrapping the krone in favour of the single currency. General dislike of the EU is the strongest in the union.

Earlier, Mr Prodi sounded a sour note by arguing that the system of rotating the presidency was untenable.
fields.bodyText: Sweden got an uncomfortable public reminder of its deep-seated euro-scepticism yesterday when Romano Prodi said he wished its commitment to three "Es" during its EU presidency included a fourth - the euro. Mr Prodi, president of the European Commission, was in Stockholm for a day of talks with Goran Persson, the prime minister, at the start of Sweden's six-month stint in the union's rotating presidency. With both men diplomatically stressing their appreciation for each other, Mr Prodi told reporters that he was delighted with Sweden's focus on enlargement, the environment and employment - a deliberately catchy and alliterative trio of high-priority EU policies. But he added, in a characteristically jokey aside that barely concealed a more serious truth: "I am only sorry that these three Es are not followed by a fourth - euro." Sweden, Britain and Denmark are now the only members of the 15-strong EU not in the single currency zone following Greece's accession on January 1 after it met the Maastricht treaty's tough convergence criteria. Mr Persson repeated that a referendum was a long way off and depended on economic conditions and wage settlements, though his Social Democratic party wants to join. But he acknowledged that last September's Danish "no" to the euro was a setback, as is the uncertainty about Tony Blair's position on a British referendum, which is unlikely to be clarified until after a spring general election. Polls show more than 60% of Swedes are opposed to scrapping the krone in favour of the single currency. General dislike of the EU is the strongest in the union. Earlier, Mr Prodi sounded a sour note by arguing that the system of rotating the presidency was untenable.

webTitle: Film: The best gallery scene

fields.headline: The best gallery scene
fields.standfirst: Unbreakable
fields.trailText: Unbreakable
fields.body:
In his comic-book art gallery, Elijah Price (Samuel L Jackson) shows a potential customer a sketch.

"This is from Fritz Campney's own library. It's from before the first issue of the comic book even hit the stands. It's a classic depiction of good against evil."

Elijah moves around the board.

"But what makes this work very, very special is its realistic depiction of its scene. By the time these characters hit the streets, they were exaggerated. As always happens. This is vintage."

The customer stands back for a moment.

"Wrap it up."

Elijah beams.

"You've made a considerably wise decision."

"Oh, my kid's going to go

berserk."

Elijah freezes in mid-stride.

"Once again, please?"

"My son Jeb. It's a gift for him."

"How old is... Jeb ?"

"He's four."

Elijah shakes his head violently.

"No. You need to go. Now."

"What'd I say?"

"Do you see any Teletubbies in here? Do you see me wearing a brightly coloured shirt with my name printed on it? Well, you must do. Because that's what you see in a toy store. And you must think you're in a toy store, because you're shopping for a gift for an infant called Jeb."

He ushers the customer towards the door.

"One of us has made a grave error of judgement, and wasted the other's valuable time. This is an art gallery, my friend. And this... is art!"

See also: Your Friends And Neighbours, Pecker, Beverly Hills Cop

Don't see also: 9 Weeks

webTitle: Millions watch lunar eclipse

fields.headline: Millions watch lunar eclipse
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Millions of people in Britain enjoyed a clear view of the first lunar eclipse of the millennium last night despite forecasts that clouds would spoil the event.
fields.body:
Millions of people in Britain enjoyed a clear view of the first lunar eclipse of the millennium last night despite forecasts that clouds would spoil the event.

The eclipse started at about 6.40pm as the moon entered the Earth's shadow. At first it appeared as if a small "bite" had been taken out of one side of the moon.

Gradually the "bite" - the curved edge of the Earth's shadow - crept across the moon's face until its surface was covered at about 7.55pm.

The moon then darkened and changed colour from silver to red as the sunlight was filtered and bent by the Earth's atmosphere.

The best views were had in Northern Ireland, western Scotland and Cumbria. But people in the south-west of England and on the south coast had to contend with thick cloud.

The astronomer Patrick Moore said: "It's been lovely to look up at and I've been able to take pictures. It's definitely a red eclipse. It's not that bright, what is called a semi-bright eclipse."

Robin Scagell, vice-president of the Society for Popular Astronomy, was surprised by how dark the eclipse had been as it is almost a decade since the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines threw dust into the upper atmosphere, making the moon less clear.

He said: "Some eclipses are so bright that it's hard to notice them. We thought this one was going to be but it's been fairly dark and that's made it difficult to see the moon. This is probably due to cloud in the atmosphere but air pollution could also be a factor."

The phenomenon brought thousands out of their homes on a particularly chilly winter night to witness the event.

In Iran, tens of thousands braved freezing weather and gathered on rooftops in the capital Tehran to watch it as state radio and television called on Iranians to perform the ayat prayers, a Muslim ritual in which the powers of God are marvelled at.

The eclipse also was visible in Iraq, Jordan, Syria, Egypt, Yemen and most of the Gulf region.

webTitle: Rescue delay forced stunt man into death jump

fields.headline: Rescue delay forced stunt man into death jump
fields.trailText: A coroner criticised a blundering rescue attempt and said she would write to the Norwegian embassy demanding an inquiry, after recording an open verdict yesterday on the death of a British stuntman.
fields.body:
A coroner criticised a blundering rescue attempt and said she would write to the Norwegian embassy demanding an inquiry, after recording an open verdict yesterday on the death of a British stuntman.

Terence Forrestal, 52, an experienced stuntman who appeared in Titanic and James Bond films, died base-jumping from a 3,000ft mountain in Norway during rehearsals for a forthcoming film, St Pancras coroner's court, London, heard.

Mr Forrestal, a former SAS soldier, broke both legs when he had difficulty with his chute and landed on a ledge 2,000ft down after leaping from the top of Kjerag Mountain in Lysefjord, Stavanger.

After a 10 hour wait for rescuers to reach him, he made a second leap using his reserve parachute. He was too near the ground for this to open properly and he received further multiple injuries.

The inquest was told how, on the ledge, the former soldier wrapped himself in his parachute and awaited rescue. But after a helicopter finally arrived nearly four hours later worsening weather prevented it from landing on the ledge.

Allan Hewitt, his jump partner, said his friend, from Childray in Oxfordshire, tried to save himself at around 10.50pm by leaping from the ledge. "He did not have enough time to slow down before he hit the ground on his feet, which ruptured his pelvis and damaged his spine."

Mr Forrestal's body was not recovered until the next day, the court heard. The cause of his death was given as multiple injuries.

The coroner, Susan Hungerford, criticised the botched rescue attempt by the Norwegian base jump team leading the expedition and pledged to write to the Norwegian embassy demanding an inquiry.

"His death may have been prevented if certain safety precautions had taken place. In my view there should be serious concerns about whether the jump should have been made in changeable conditions," she said.

Mr Forrestal's sister, Toni Jerman, spoke of her disgust at the failed rescue and vowed to take legal action against those she felt were responsible.

Ms Jerman, from Hampstead, north London, said: "How could they have left him there for 11 hours? They made one helicopter trip, realised they could not land and just flew off."

webTitle: About turn as Ben Elton sings a welcome to Bush

fields.headline: About turn as Ben Elton sings a welcome to Bush
fields.trailText: Ben Elton, former scourge of the rightwing establishment, is to celebrate the arrival of the Republican US president, George W Bush.
fields.body:
Ben Elton, former scourge of the rightwing establishment, is to celebrate the arrival of the Republican US president, George W Bush.

The comedian and writer is to present songs at the president's inaugural gala in Washington on January 18, taken from the hit show The Beautiful Game - a love story set in Northern Ireland, following the fortunes of youngsters involved in a Belfast-based football team as the Troubles begin, a show he devised with Andrew Lloyd Webber.

Lord Lloyd-Webber said: "I am naturally honoured and flattered to have been approached to bring The Beauti ful Game to this concert. I'm sure the show's themes of inclusion and reconciliation will reflect the mood that everyone in Washington will be keen to capture. When we wrote [the musical] we wanted to cover issues that could come out of the conflicts in Kosovo and Afghanistan as much as Northern Ireland. Presenting the musical in Washington reinforces that international context."

The Beautiful Game opened in London in September to an audience including former British and Irish prime ministers, John Major and Albert Reynolds.

webTitle: Blair's day more fruitful than expected

fields.headline: Blair's day more fruitful than expected
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: His deputy, John Prescott has had water hurled over him, and his agriculture minister a chocolate eclair thrust in his face, but Tony Blair has always escaped every politician's nightmare - being pelted with food.
fields.body:
His deputy, John Prescott has had water hurled over him, and his agriculture minister a chocolate eclair thrust in his face, but Tony Blair has always escaped every politician's nightmare - being pelted with food.

Until yesterday, that is. Opening the new City of Bristol College, the prime minister came under sustained attack from up to 30 protesters campaigning against sanctions on Iraq. Oranges were hurled, rotten tangerines lobbed, and an over-ripe beef tomato splattered on the back of his shoulder.

It was, said one observer, as if a tub of pasta sauce had been thrown over him: the offending item sat dripping, as Mr Blair carried on shaking hands with those eager to greet him.

He did not flinch when the tomato struck, and even behaved calmly when other protesters tried to lunge at him. As police restrained the crowd, he was whisked inside, only to be confronted by a woman who screamed: "How many Iraqi children have you killed?"

Two women were arrested for public disorder and were last night being held in the city's Bridewell police station.

Downing Street was eager to play the incident down, with a spokesman insisting: "This isn't the first time, and it won't be the last that people choose to protest like this."

When Mr Blair appeared for a question-and-answer session with some 300 voters in the city's Council House half an hour later, the only sign was a damp patch where the tomato had been sponged away.

Quizzed on whether Britain could claim to have an ethical foreign policy while sustaining sanctions, he told his 29-year-old interrogator, Chris Congreve, that Saddam Hussein had committed an "act of barbarism" in invading Kuwait, and that, if he wasn't contained, he could strike again.

Mr Blair also made a speech in which he said crime, secondary education and welfare to work would be reformed during a second term.

webTitle: Where's the money gone, Hague asks the voters

fields.headline: Where's the money gone, Hague asks the voters
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague and Michael Portillo yesterday accused Labour of raising taxes by the equivalent of 10p in the £ since 1997 - and of wasting the money instead of improving public services.
fields.body:
William Hague and Michael Portillo yesterday accused Labour of raising taxes by the equivalent of 10p in the £ since 1997 - and of wasting the money instead of improving public services.

Under the slogan "You've paid the tax, so where's all the money gone?", Mr Hague launched a poster campaign and taunted Tony Blair as the "great pretender" who had left schools and hospitals in crisis, streets without enough police and transport at a standstill.

"People aren't fooled any more by Tony Blair, the great pretender. They have paid the tax and they want to know where all the money has gone," Mr Hague told a press conference after an attempt to project the new Tory poster on to the Millennium Dome at Greenwich had been thwarted by security staff. Charles Kennedy, the Lib Dem leader, attacked both rival parties for "pretending you can get something for nothing" in modernising services and cutting taxes. The GMB leader, John Edmonds, condemned "Tory hypocrisy".

But some unions were impressed by the Hague posters showing people waiting for trains or NHS operations. "It's typical Tory black propaganda, but it's effective and needs a swift response," conceded one.

Ministers criticised the Tory strategy of linking extra taxes with embattled public services, while ignoring the buoyant state of the economy as a whole, and said the Tories were still vulnerable to charges that there is a £16bn hole in Mr Portillo's own tax-and-spend package.

Yesterday the shadow chancellor said there was a risk of Labour creating "a form of boom and bust in the public finances" which means either spending cuts after three years or even higher taxes to sustain the 3% growth in spending. Voters also suspected that Labour's extra taxes were producing no real benefits, Mr Portillo said.

The Tories claim they can cut taxes, protect spending on the NHS and schools at Labour levels and improve efficiency because Labour has wasted money on the dome, on bureaucracy, failure to reform welfare and preparing to join the euro. They have promised to cut £8bn worth of waste, though Mr Portillo is waiting to see Mr Brown's budget before detailing £2bn worth. Outside experts like the Institute for Fiscal Studies are sceptical of his cuts so far. Mr Portillo prefers to call them "spending changes".

webTitle: Cheers greet Apple goodies

fields.headline: Cheers greet Apple goodies
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Apple Computer started its fightback yesterday against falling sales and heavy losses by announcing a revamp of its professional range of computers, new consumer-orientated software and a March release date for its long-awaited operating system, Mac OSX.
fields.body:
Apple Computer started its fightback yesterday against falling sales and heavy losses by announcing a revamp of its professional range of computers, new consumer-orientated software and a March release date for its long-awaited operating system, Mac OSX.

The announcements were made by the company's chief executive officer, Steve Jobs, to an adoring crowd of 5,000 people at the Macworld show in San Francisco.

The adulation could not hide the fact that Apple has been struggling recently. In December it forecast a loss for the first quarter of this year, the first since Mr Jobs returned in 1997 to the company he founded.

Industry researcher PC Data reported that Apple's US sales in the first half of December fell 40% against an industry-wide fall of 20%. Apple is expected to report this month a last quarter loss of $250m (£168m) due to disappointing sales of its new Cube desktop computer and its colourful iMac machine.

Yesterday Mr Jobs admitted: "The last few months have been particularly challenging for Apple and the rest of the industry," but added: "We've decided to start 2001 with a bang."

The most gasps were reserved for Mr Jobs's final announcement - a new ultra-thin PowerBook laptop computer called Titanium, the metal from which its case is made. The new machine is only 1in thick, weighs 5.3lb and sports a 15.2in display.

There were whoops of delight for a range of G4 machines which take the company's top-rated chip to 733MHz.

Perhaps more significant for Apple's long-term prospects was Mr Jobs's declaration of the company's vision, based around what he termed the "digital lifestyle". Included in his presentation was a trio of software packages: iMusic was presented as sophisticated software for handling digital music files, which Apple will give away from its website. He also announced iDVD, a new DVD creation program.
