webTitle: Analysis: Railtrack could be a non-profit trust

fields.headline: Railtrack could be a non-profit trust
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Renationalisation of the railways has the support of the public and the unions - the accident at Hatfield highlighted fundamental weaknesses in the structure of privatisation, which were admitted even by the Tories.
fields.body:
Renationalisation of the railways has the support of the public and the unions - the accident at Hatfield highlighted fundamental weaknesses in the structure of privatisation, which were admitted even by the Tories.

But renationalisation is unlikely to find favour with New Labour. Besides, another period of revolutionary upheaval is probably the last thing that the railways need at the moment. The government's creation of the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA), which gains its full statutory identity on February 1, has yet to have a chance to work. It will publish its plans for the development of the railways later this month. Anything that is done is likely to be evolutionary rather than revolutionary.

One option is to let the system as it is weather the post-Hatfield storm. Railtrack would complete the emergency track replacement programme as the SRA got on and finished the job of replacing the current short-term passenger franchises with fewer and longer-term franchises. Against this background the massive investment programme promised in John Prescott's 10-year transport plan of July last would be implemented step by step.

Because Sir Alastair Morton, chair of the SRA, believes that Railtrack does not have the financial or project skills to manage both the existing network and its development, he wants enhancements to the network to be carried out as joint ventures between Railtrack and the train operating companies.

Some people argue that the problems revealed by Hatfield are not inherent in the separation of track and train operations. Railtrack's choice to carry out track maintenance and renewal work through byzantine layers of subcontracts within contracts is a mistake that can be rectified. The structure could be simplified and lines of accountability made clearer. Appointing a more effective chair to the board than the retiring Sir Philip Beck, as well as one or two new members who know something about railway operation, might help to restore public confidence.

Taking a public share in Railtrack is a variation on this theme. At present, taxpayers appear to be getting a poor deal. Over the next five years, Railtrack is due to receive almost £5bn in direct grants for projects such as the upgrading of the west coast main line, in addition to billions in indirect support through subsidy to the train operators. A place on the board and a share in the future profits of Railtrack might be seen as a fair return for taxpayers' investment. Understandably, the government is reluctant to take a minority stake in Railtrack, giving the appearance of control without the reality.

But this would do nothing to address the inherently adversarial structure of the privatised industry that pits Railtrack against train operators in deciding who is to blame for the latest delays and cancellations, and therefore who will have to pay the penalty. The profit motive and the public interest do not always coincide.

Another option is to divide the network into regional railways, with integration between track and train operations. It is, however, a revolutionary option, more complex than wholesale renationalisation. There is no simple correspondence between train operators and geographical regions. Most lines are used by more than one operator. Not only would the current train operating franchises have to be wound up but it would also be back to the drawing board for the new franchise map. By fragmenting the network this option is also likely to create as many problems as it solves.

There is another way forward. It is to transform Railtrack into a non-profit stakeholder trust, a new form of public enterprise learning from the successful model that Canada has adopted for its air navigation services. This would be a true partnership with train operators, SRA, passengers and trade unions all represented on the board and none having a majority.

A culture of co- operation and shared objectives would be institutionalised. The cost to taxpayers of buying out Railtrack's shareholders need not be great. The money could be raised by issuing government guaranteed private sector bonds, a facility provided for the Channel tunnel rail link. In effect, Railtrack's profits would be converted into interest payments.

One of the spin-offs of this approach is that there would no longer be a need for a rail regulator separate from the SRA. The main job of the rail regulator is to set Railtrack's charges so that it raises enough money to make a reasonable rate of return on its capital assets but does not abuse its monopoly by making excessive profits. Without shareholders or profits, there would be no need for this kind of economic regulation. If the government wants to make good use of the singular intellect of the current rail regulator, Tom Winsor, he could be made the first chair of the Railtrack trust board.

The past year has been a roller-coaster ride for the railways of Britain. It began with high expectations but ended at a new low. Until Hatfield, as the graph shows, the railways continued five years of strong passenger growth. In July, the government published the 10-year transport plan including a £60bn programme to increase passenger miles by a further 50% and rail freight by 80% over the next 10 years. The fuel depot blockades in September saw the train take the strain. Then in October it all went horribly wrong at Hatfield. The legacy of a botched privatisation and decades of under-investment became all too visible.

In spite of this, there is no reason why the railways should not make a strong recovery. The main driving forces for growth are still in place: a strong economy, road traffic congestion and key fares regulated to increase by one percentage point less than inflation each year (notwithstanding off-peak fare increases by some companies). And every cloud has a silver lining. Crisis in the railways could result in a new, more pluralist approach to public enterprise and Railtrack could be at its cutting edge.

t.grayling@ippr.org.uk
fields.bodyText: Renationalisation of the railways has the support of the public and the unions - the accident at Hatfield highlighted fundamental weaknesses in the structure of privatisation, which were admitted even by the Tories. But renationalisation is unlikely to find favour with New Labour. Besides, another period of revolutionary upheaval is probably the last thing that the railways need at the moment. The government's creation of the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA), which gains its full statutory identity on February 1, has yet to have a chance to work. It will publish its plans for the development of the railways later this month. Anything that is done is likely to be evolutionary rather than revolutionary. One option is to let the system as it is weather the post-Hatfield storm. Railtrack would complete the emergency track replacement programme as the SRA got on and finished the job of replacing the current short-term passenger franchises with fewer and longer-term franchises. Against this background the massive investment programme promised in John Prescott's 10-year transport plan of July last would be implemented step by step. Because Sir Alastair Morton, chair of the SRA, believes that Railtrack does not have the financial or project skills to manage both the existing network and its development, he wants enhancements to the network to be carried out as joint ventures between Railtrack and the train operating companies. Some people argue that the problems revealed by Hatfield are not inherent in the separation of track and train operations. Railtrack's choice to carry out track maintenance and renewal work through byzantine layers of subcontracts within contracts is a mistake that can be rectified. The structure could be simplified and lines of accountability made clearer. Appointing a more effective chair to the board than the retiring Sir Philip Beck, as well as one or two new members who know something about railway operation, might help to restore public confidence. Taking a public share in Railtrack is a variation on this theme. At present, taxpayers appear to be getting a poor deal. Over the next five years, Railtrack is due to receive almost £5bn in direct grants for projects such as the upgrading of the west coast main line, in addition to billions in indirect support through subsidy to the train operators. A place on the board and a share in the future profits of Railtrack might be seen as a fair return for taxpayers' investment. Understandably, the government is reluctant to take a minority stake in Railtrack, giving the appearance of control without the reality. But this would do nothing to address the inherently adversarial structure of the privatised industry that pits Railtrack against train operators in deciding who is to blame for the latest delays and cancellations, and therefore who will have to pay the penalty. The profit motive and the public interest do not always coincide. Another option is to divide the network into regional railways, with integration between track and train operations. It is, however, a revolutionary option, more complex than wholesale renationalisation. There is no simple correspondence between train operators and geographical regions. Most lines are used by more than one operator. Not only would the current train operating franchises have to be wound up but it would also be back to the drawing board for the new franchise map. By fragmenting the network this option is also likely to create as many problems as it solves. There is another way forward. It is to transform Railtrack into a non-profit stakeholder trust, a new form of public enterprise learning from the successful model that Canada has adopted for its air navigation services. This would be a true partnership with train operators, SRA, passengers and trade unions all represented on the board and none having a majority. A culture of co- operation and shared objectives would be institutionalised. The cost to taxpayers of buying out Railtrack's shareholders need not be great. The money could be raised by issuing government guaranteed private sector bonds, a facility provided for the Channel tunnel rail link. In effect, Railtrack's profits would be converted into interest payments. One of the spin-offs of this approach is that there would no longer be a need for a rail regulator separate from the SRA. The main job of the rail regulator is to set Railtrack's charges so that it raises enough money to make a reasonable rate of return on its capital assets but does not abuse its monopoly by making excessive profits. Without shareholders or profits, there would be no need for this kind of economic regulation. If the government wants to make good use of the singular intellect of the current rail regulator, Tom Winsor, he could be made the first chair of the Railtrack trust board. The past year has been a roller-coaster ride for the railways of Britain. It began with high expectations but ended at a new low. Until Hatfield, as the graph shows, the railways continued five years of strong passenger growth. In July, the government published the 10-year transport plan including a £60bn programme to increase passenger miles by a further 50% and rail freight by 80% over the next 10 years. The fuel depot blockades in September saw the train take the strain. Then in October it all went horribly wrong at Hatfield. The legacy of a botched privatisation and decades of under-investment became all too visible. In spite of this, there is no reason why the railways should not make a strong recovery. The main driving forces for growth are still in place: a strong economy, road traffic congestion and key fares regulated to increase by one percentage point less than inflation each year (notwithstanding off-peak fare increases by some companies). And every cloud has a silver lining. webTitle: Lockerbie pair now face sole charge

fields.headline: Lockerbie pair now face sole charge
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: Prosecution lawyers in the Lockerbie trial yesterday surprised the court by withdrawing two of the charges faced by the defendants and announcing they would concentrate solely on the charge of murder.
fields.body:
Prosecution lawyers in the Lockerbie trial yesterday surprised the court by withdrawing two of the charges faced by the defendants and announcing they would concentrate solely on the charge of murder.

In an unexpected move, the advocate depute, Alastair Campbell QC, told the Scottish court in the Netherlands the crown would no longer attempt to prove the two accused Libyans were guilty of conspiracy to murder and a breach of the Aviation Security Act.

Instead, Mr Campbell said the crown had proved beyond reasonable doubt that Abdelbaset Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah were guilty of the murder of the 270 people who died when the jet exploded.

"The decision to delete two of the charges suggests that the prosecution are confident they can prove beyond reasonable doubt the charge of murder," said Clare Connelly, of Glasgow University's Lockerbie trial briefing unit.

Although the crown continued to maintain Megrahi had carried out the bombing while operating as a member of the Libyan intelligence agency, the JSO, it withdrew the allegation that Fhimah ever had been a member of the JSO.

In his closing speech, Mr Campbell told the court that when all the circumstantial evidence surrounding Megrahi and Fhimah was taken together it was enough to prove their guilt.

After 232 witnesses, only three of whom were called by the defence, and 77 days of evidence, Mr Campbell made it clear that the crown's case relied on painstaking forensic evidence and the testimony of a handful of star witnesses.

In the scenario put forward by prosecutors, the bomb which blew up Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie on December 21 1988 began its journey on an Air Malta plane from the island's Luqa airport.

It was at that airport that Fhimah worked as a station manager for Libyan Arab Airlines, and, in a diary produced in evidence, Fhimah referred to obtaining Air Malta baggage tags for Megrahi.

The baggage tags are alleged to have been used to get a bronze Samsonite suitcase containing the Toshiba RTSF16 radio cassette recorder which housed the bomb on board flight KM180 from Luqa to Frankfurt.

At the German airport, it is alleged, the bag was then transferred to the jumbo.

The prosecution traces this scenario back to Megrahi and Fhimah through a series of key facts.

Around 80% of Toshiba's RTSF16s were sold solely to Libya and the timer used in the bomb inside the cassette recorder was made by a Swiss company, Mebo. Mr Campbell said the evidence proved Mebo had supplied this timer uniquely to Libya and Megrahi would have had easy access to it.

Forensic investigators also traced clothing which was contained in the suitcase with the bomb back to Mary's House, a shop owned by Tony Gauci in Malta.

During his testimony, Mr Gauci said a Libyan similar to Megrahi had purchased the clothing a few weeks before Christmas 1988. Mr Campbell, however, said Mr Gauci had made a full identification on two previous occasions.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Deal offered on NHS watchdog body

fields.headline: Deal offered on NHS watchdog body
fields.trailText: The government will seek today to head off a backbench Labour revolt against its health bill by backing plans for a national patients' organisation to strengthen the voice of consumers in the running of the NHS.
fields.body:
The government will seek today to head off a backbench Labour revolt against its health bill by backing plans for a national patients' organisation to strengthen the voice of consumers in the running of the NHS.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will announce the concession during the second reading of the health and social care bill. He will say he is ready to fund a new body to collect information about patients' experiences of the NHS and use it to fight for improvements.

The government had been facing the threat of a mutiny at the bill's committee stage from Labour MPs worried about its plan to abolish community health councils that have served as patient advocates for the past 26 years.

David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the health select commitee, said yesterday the bill was "a dog's breakfast that complicates the complaints procedure for patients when it should be simplifying it".

More than 90 Labour MPs signed a motion on the Commons order paper before the Christmas recess raising concerns about abolition of the CHCs. Mr Hinchliffe said he hoped ministers would bring forward amendments to answer their worries.

Mr Milburn will respond by backing a plan produced four weeks ago by voluntary and patients' groups. They proposed a national body to support the recruitment and training of local patient representatives. It would assemble information about patients' experiences of the NHS and use it to give them an effective national voice.

The government will fund a steering group to work up a detailed plan by March before the bill completes its passage through parliament.

Mr Milburn told colleagues: "If a national patients' organisation proves possible and practical, we will back it and fund it. We believe patient power is the most important way of raising standards of care, cleanliness and convenience across the NHS."

His concession comes after the Consumers' Association warned yesterday that the bill would have left patients without any organisation to take a national overview of their experience in hospitals and GP surgeries.

Further doubts about the bill were raised by Jeremy Beecham, Labour chairman of the Local Government Association and member of the NHS modernisation board. In an article today in Guardian Society, he said patient forums reporting to the health secretary would lack independence and transparency.

webTitle: Councils slip up on housing and police on the beat

fields.headline: Councils slip up on housing and police on the beat
fields.trailText: Council housing services have deteriorated in the past year, possibly due to the lack of a full-scale housing inspectorate, figures from the audit commission reveal today.
fields.body:
Council housing services have deteriorated in the past year, possibly due to the lack of a full-scale housing inspectorate, figures from the audit commission reveal today.

Overall, local councils' delivery of education and social services by contrast have improved, the commission reports. Both of these services are subject to tough inspections, based on best practice and monitoring performance.

The commission also reports deep dissatisfaction from the public at the absence of police foot patrols; less than one in five people surveyed were happy at the number of "bobbies on the beat".

The annual audit commission survey, of more than 100 key performance indicators, covers council services provided in the 12 months to March 2000. Since then the government has introduced its "best value" regime requiring councils to monitor the competitiveness of their services.

The study shows only 88% of council housing repairs are completed within government time limits, and the number of housing lets with rent arrears of more than 13 weeks has also risen, increasing from 4% to 4.6. In London, only 68% of housing benefit and council tax benefit claimants are satisfied with their council services; the figure is 78% across the country.

The crisis in Hackney council, north London, is starkly exposed, with only 68.4% of council tax receipts collected, whereas the average in London is 91%. Hackney also managed to collect only 78.2% of due rent, the lowest figure for any English council. Only 53% of Hackney housing repairs were completed within government time limits. Only Reading and Selby had a worse record.

Hackney also takes 181 days to process new council tax benefit claims and 150 days to process new housing benefit claims; the average across England is 50 days to process council tax and 44 days for housing benefit claims.

The study shows that the police only spend 53% of their time out on the streets. Nottinghamshire police appear the most reclusive, spending only 37% of their working hours in public; Cumbrian police, meanwhile, spend three-quarters of their time outside their offices.

Huge public dissatisfaction - 57% of those surveyed - is expressed at the absence of police foot patrols, and, to a lesser degree, mobile patrols, even though surveys show that having police on the beat does not help in crime detection.

But generally the public is found to be content with the police response to burglary and to violent crime.

The number of crimes solved per officer rose in the year to March 2000, from 12 to 12.2 crimes. The most successful police force in terms of solved crimes per officer is Gwent with 25 clear-ups per officer. The Met is the lowest, with seven per officer.

The number of 999 calls answered within police forces' target times fell from 89.1% in 1998-99 to 88.6% in 1999-00. The number of constables available for work in England and Wales fell, on average from 2.14 per 1,000 of the population in 1998-99 to 2.11.

The survey also finds the proportion of children receiving pre-school education to be rising with 93% of four-year-olds now in nursery school. Lincolnshire claims to have 103% of its four-year-olds in nursery school - a performance it will have difficulty improving on.

The proportion of street lights not working is less than 0.25 % in a few councils, but over 10 times that rate on a handful of others. The darkest London council in terms of most streetlights not working is Ealing. Nationwide, Tameside has the highest proportion of streetlights not working.

The district council which spends least per head of population is Mid Bedfordshire - at £70.38 a head. The most parsimonious county council is wealthy Surrey which spends only £611 per head of its population. York council spends least of unitary councils at £695 per head.

Good, bad and ugly

 The filthiest council, in terms of street cleanliness: Stockton-on-Tees . Only 54.7% of the council's streets were deemed to be of a high or acceptable standard. Residents of Southend, South Buckinghamshire, East Cambridgeshire, Carlisle, Christchurch and 23 other councils will be delighted, or possibly surprised to know that 100% of their streets are clean.

 The city with most public lavatories is Sheffield (65). Liverpool, by contrast, has none

 The population most keen to swim is Reading, with 16,028 swims per 1,000 population.

 The education authority with the most excluded pupils is Doncaster, with 3.12 pupils excluded per 1,000 pupils.

 Tower Hamlets spends most per pupil on primary education: £3,080 per pupil.

 The cheapest school meal in the country can be bought in Worcester at 90p.

 The council spending least on children's services is Rutland, at £14.53 per head of population.

webTitle: 'It seemed close to deceitful that our money hadn't gone where it ought to'

fields.headline: 'It seemed close to deceitful that our money hadn't gone where it ought to'
fields.trailText: Brian Eno, the rock musician, broke a year's silence to tell the Guardian and Channel 4 News about his concerns over the War Child charity's handling of the millions of pounds raised for the Pavarotti music centre in Mostar.
fields.body:
Brian Eno, the rock musician, broke a year's silence to tell the Guardian and Channel 4 News about his concerns over the War Child charity's handling of the millions of pounds raised for the Pavarotti music centre in Mostar.

He said he became involved - and persuaded fellow musicians to give long-term aid to the centre - as a "cultural mission" with the aim of leaving a permanent presence in Bosnia.

"Like a lot of people, I felt that we ought to be in some way involved. There were a lot of civilians and children being hurt and - whichever side was right or wrong or deserved one's sympathies - certainly the women and children, the non-combatants, who were really the target, did.

"What wasn't being done, I felt, was putting in place a sort of cultural infrastructure that would flower after the war had finished."

He said he received a lot of goodwill from his millionaire rock friends once the idea of the music centre had taken root.

"A lot of people responded to that idea. Like me, they felt we couldn't be impotent in the face of a local war and a particularly brutal one. They also responded to the idea that used what we do as artists as part of the solution."

"We made a lot of people think there was something we could do there and it's not that difficult to do something. In fact, it was embarrassingly easy to make a good difference there. One of the big outcomes is that we built this place called the Pavarotti music centre, which exists and is still flourishing."

He said he first became disillusioned when the two co-founders fell out and the money started going to new projects - and not all of it was getting to Mostar. Some of it was being used for other projects.

"What happened was the money didn't end up going to those projects. Events that had been staged to raise money for particular projects never got to those projects. I'm not saying it was corruptly spent or anything like that, but it didn't go where we felt it ought to have gone. PMC was somewhat abandoned and to abandon it, apart from anything else, I thought would be terrible PR".

He is particularly critical of the failure to send money from the proceeds of the Miss Sarajevo record to the centre. "It was done specifically for the music centre and everyone knew that. The money from that was spent on a lot of things including expenses for keeping a big office going."

"We were given the explanation that 'we're the charity and should be free to determine how we spend the money'. It seemed close to deceitful that our money hadn't gone where we felt it ought to have gone."

He went on: "There was a breakdown in communication. People felt that their contribution wasn't being received with any gratitude any longer. They were being treated as petulant celebrities who had to be kind of kept out of things. A lot of the people had strong feelings about these issues. They were not just people who blindly walk into any charity and start doing things like this. Bono, Bob Geldof, myself - there are a lot of people who have some kind of history of being involved in charitable work and in somehow using whatever power they have to change the world and they feel insulated when they are told their views don't count."

Stars who gave support

David Bowie

Rock musician and businessman with a personal fortune estimated at £500m. Born in Brixton, Bowie became a rock superstar in the 1970s. Now known as much as a big Wall Street player as a rock star, he was introduced to War Child through Brian Eno

Juliet Stevenson

Royal Shakespeare and film actress who was recently awarded a CBE. Now 44, she juggles her acting career with a family. She saw herself "more as a sleeping patron" but backed the other patrons over the issues which led to her resignation from her role at War Child

Sir Tom Stoppard

The renowned playwright was a strong patron of War Child from the start - he even dipped into his own pocket to help David Wilson and Bill Leeson survive in Mostar. He quit the charity with Brian Eno after the ill-fated trustee meeting in 1999

Brent Hanson

The head of the 24-hour MTV Europe music channel is not a traditional TV executive. He left TV New Zealand in 1986 because he was "pissed off that it was getting so corporation-minded" and still describes himself as "pretty hip". He was encouraged to join War Child by Brian Eno and quit at same time

The Patron who stayed

Neil Morrissey

An actor who still strongly supports War Child. Morrissey was a tearaway who spent much of his teens in care. The 38-year-old actor admits his feelings of anger have subsided "an awful lot" since he began working as a goodwill ambassador for the charity War Child: "Before this job started, I was in Rwanda and Sudan, and before that Kosovo. When you come back you don't have road rage, believe me."

webTitle: G2: Francis Wheen on party funding

fields.headline: Cash for no questions
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: On how Enron wins friends and influence and on parking up the wrong tree.
fields.body:
How surprising to see even such a hard-headed newspaper as Sunday Business succumbing to the notion that it is corrupt or dishonourable to receive favours in return for a generous bung to Labour party funds. "It is unfortunate," its editorial lamented last weekend, "that public-spirited donations can often resemble a bribe."

This is the sort of pious whingeing that we expect from liberals and unreconstructed lefties - but not, surely, from champions of free-market capitalism. Suppose the editor of Sunday Business hands a motor dealer thousands of pounds and gets a reconditioned Ferrari in exchange: does his behaviour resemble bribery, or merely a normal commercial transaction? Since New Labour now believes that "market solutions" are always to be preferred, even in the public sector, there should be no shame in extending the principle to political funding.

In Maundy Gregory's heyday, 80 years ago, the going rate for a peerage was £100,000 - which, I reckon, is the equivalent of about £2m today. (Now where have we heard that figure recently?) Everyone knows that the "sale" of honours has taken place under Harold Wilson, Margaret Thatcher and Tony Blair, in the sense that a hugely disproportionate number of new peers turned out to be party benefactors.

So why not formalise the arrangement and publish a tariff? "It is a far cleaner method of filling the party chest than the methods used in the United States," Lloyd George argued. "Here a man gives £40,000 to the party and gets a baronetcy. If he comes to the leader of the party and says, 'I subscribe largely to the party funds, you must do this or that,' we can tell him to go to the devil."

Rank ingratitude, I'd say. In New Labour's classless New Britain, not all squillionaires hanker after a peerage, or even a baronetcy. Some would prefer their reward in some other form - planning consent for a new shopping mall, say, or a large PFI contract - and they should be given it.

Such a system already exists in the US. On December 5, even before Al Gore conceded defeat, a press release from the Bush-Cheney team included this delightfully candid announcement: "Applicants interested in serving in the administration will be able to apply online via a secure server. Contributions are limited to $5,000 (£3,358) and can be donated online or via mail to the Bush-Cheney transition effort." Quite a bargain, eh? But the "limit" of $5,000 is little more than a gratuity: the actual bill has already been paid.

Take the case of Kenneth Lay, the founder and chairman of the energy company Enron, who donated $310,500 (£208,473) to the Republican party in the past two years and raised about another $1m (£671,534) from his company and its employees. According to the Centre for Public Integrity, an American watchdog group, Enron gave more money to Dubya's campaign than any other corporation.

Lo and behold, Lay has now been appointed to the Bush transition team as "an adviser to the energy department". He was also one of the lucky 32 "business leaders" invited to the Texas governor's mansion last week to "give their ideas" to the new president. I think it safe to assume that these ideas will tend to benefit the balance sheet of Enron Corp.

As we all know, the Blairites pinch most of their own ideas from across the Atlantic. And, by happy coincidence, Lay's company is a great favourite of New Labour.

To the untrained eye this may seem rather surprising. In 1995 Enron was named by Multinational Monitor as one of "the world's 10 worst corporations". Two years later it became the only company (rather than government) to be the subject of a special investigation by Amnesty International, following violent attacks by Enron's private police against poor Indian villagers who objected to its power station in the state of Maharashtra, which was polluting fisheries and depleting the local water supply. The World Bank also denounced the plant, which forces Maharashtra to pay three times as much for its electricity as other Indian states.

Worse still, until the 1997 general election Labour frontbenchers were loudly committed to saving the coal industry and opposing the Tories' "dash for gas" - bad news indeed for Enron, which was eager to break into the British utilities market. The firm hired Karl Milner, a former aide to Gordon Brown who had found more lucrative employment with the political lobbyists GJW. It also made three payments to the Labour party totalling £27,500.

Seldom has a small investment paid bigger dividends. Three weeks after the 1998 Labour party conference, at which Enron spent £15,000 sponsoring a "gala dinner", the government decided not to refer the company's £1.5bn takeover of Wessex Water to the monopolies commission - thus giving the American giant a monopoly of water supplies in much of south-west England. After being renamed Azurix, Wessex Water was floated on the New York stock exchange, to the great enrichment of its Enron-appointed directors, while the hapless customers endured price increases of up to 34%.

The new chief executive, Rebecca Mark, who had a pay-and-incentives package worth £33m, promised that the company would soon control water supplies around the globe. (Alas, the results failed to match the world-conquering ambition: Mark resigned last summer, and Enron has now agreed to repurchase the stock at less than half the flotation price.)

But the best was yet to come. When the Observer investigated the Lobbygate scandal in the summer of 1998, Milner boasted to the paper's undercover reporter how he would get Enron exempted from the government's moratorium on the building of private gas plants. "The way you go about it is that you play on the existing prejudices within the cabinet for coal, you play on the existing prejudices within the cabinet for competition, and you play the forces off against each other. It's intimate knowledge of what's going on that produces results in the end."

Just so. In the summer of 1999 the government relaxed its ban to allow Enron Europe Ltd to build a gas-fired power station at Teesside. On November 16 last year Stephen Byers sounded the death knell of the coal industry by lifting the moratorium altogether and giving his consent to another Enron gas plant, on the Isle of Grain in Kent. And, in a glorious finale to this modern morality play, the latest new year honours list included a CBE for Ralph Hodge, the chairman of Enron Europe - "for services to the power generation and gas industries".

True, he didn't get a peerage. But for a mere £27,500 you can't expect everything.

No future in the tsars

Motoring organisations are demanding an inquiry into the nefarious conduct of London's privatised traffic wardens and car-clampers. "The public are often treated appallingly," says Rebecca Rees of the AA. "We'd like a complete rethink of parking enforcement, starting with the appointment of a parking tsar."

And why not? Thanks to New Labour we already have a homelessness tsar, a drugs tsar, a red-tape tsar, a cancer tsar, a fat tsar and a heart tsar. In the past month alone there have been demands for the appointment of a manufacturing tsar, a fuel poverty tsar and a Scottish snow-clearing tsar.

But I fear that Rees has missed the point of all these grandees. Ministers hire tsars to give the impression of decisive action without actually having to do anything - rather as, in the old days, Harold Wilson would set up royal commissions. Can you think of a single achievement for which the existing tsars and tsarinas can claim the credit? A "complete rethink of parking enforcement" will not only start with the appointment of a new tsar: it'll end there.

Still, if Rees's suggestion is taken up, the parking tsar will at least be able to claim the title which a Guardian reader proposed unsuccessfully for London's new transport commissioner: tsar of all the rush-hours.

webTitle: Fear of violence as Adair stays in jail

fields.headline: Fear of violence as Adair stays in jail
fields.standfirst:
Security sources warn of new wave of sectarian attacks as anger mounts at decision to keep loyalist leader in prison

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Security sources warn of new wave of sectarian attacks as anger mounts at decision to keep loyalist leader in prison.
fields.body:
Fears were growing yesterday that the decision to keep Belfast paramilitary boss, Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair, in jail could provoke loyalists disillusioned with the Northern Ireland peace process to launch a fresh wave of sectarian attacks on Catholics.

The Ulster Freedom Fighter leader is to lodge a high court appeal against the Northern Ireland sentence review commission's ruling, announced yesterday, arguing he was not given a chance to dispute police intelligence that he was re-involved in terrorism.

"The decision is disappointing but not totally unexpected, given that he was not allowed to defend himself against allegations made against him," said John White, a friend of Adair and chairman of the Ulster Democratic party, the political wing of the UFF and the Ulster Defence Association.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, who had Adair re-arrested last August and challenged the commission's earlier inclination to release him, said the verdict was in the best interests of the whole community.

He added: "I will not hesitate again to revoke the licence of any prisoner, who, having benefited from the early release arrangements under the Good Friday agreement, then becomes involved in the commission, preparation or instigation of acts of terrorism."

Adair and his aides have called for calm, urging supporters not to take to the streets in protest but to let the matter be settled in the courts.

But security and loyalist sources admitted the sentence review commission decision, coupled with growing loyalist cynicism about the Good Friday agreement, could be used by some paramilitaries as an excuse for violence.

The UDA/UFF and Ulster Volunteer Force declared their ceasefire in October 1994, and its political representatives played an important role in negotiating the Belfast peace accord. But several of the UDA/UFF's top commanders and many grassroots members are now thought to be turning against the deal.

A loyalist source said: "It's typical that there is one rule for republicans and another for loyalists. Four IRA men get the Queen's pardon and Johnny Adair gets banged up."

"It was the right decision to keep Adair in," said a senior security source. "He can do less harm where he is than on the streets. But there is a fear that loyalist paramilitaries disenchanted with the peace process could be moving toward sectarian attacks.

"If that happens, then there is a risk it will bring a response from dissident republicans and perhaps ultimately from mainstream republicans."

The senior Sinn Fein politician Gerry Kelly said nationalists, particularly those living near flashpoint areas with loyalist communities, were concerned about possible attacks.

Adair, head of the UFF's notorious C battalion, was jailed for directing terrorism in 1995 but served less than five years of his 16-year sentence when freed under the Good Friday early release scheme in September 1999. He claimed to be a fervent supporter of the peace process, but Mr Mandelson ordered his incarceration last August, blaming him for orchestrating the bloody UFF/UVF feud, in which seven men were murdered.

During last week's two-day private hearing at Maghaberry prison, Co Antrim, the RUC chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan and other senior policemen, including two top Special Branch officers, gave the sentence review commission details of Adair's activities since his release in 1999.

These included buying and distributing guns and ammunition, ordering murders and punishment shootings, paying illegal organisations from the proceeds of drug dealing, and fuelling sectarian tensions in Belfast and Portadown.

webTitle: Two youths arrested in Damilola inquiry

fields.headline: Two youths arrested in Damilola inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Two youths were yesterday arrested by detectives hunting the killers of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor, the Nigerian boy stabbed in the leg as he walked home in Peckham, south-east London.
fields.body:
Two youths were yesterday arrested by detectives hunting the killers of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor, the Nigerian boy stabbed in the leg as he walked home in Peckham, south-east London.

The youths, aged 13 and 14, were arrested at separate homes in Peckham at 6.30am and taken to a police station in south London where they remained until their release on police bail last night.

A spokesman for Scotland Yard confirmed the teenagers had not been arrested before.

Yesterday's arrests brought the number questioned about Damilola to 15-14 teenage boys and a 39-year-old woman.

Damilola bled to death in a stairwell on the North Peckham estate minutes after he was stabbed in the left leg, severing the femoral artery. He was attacked in Blake's Road as he walked home from an after-school computer class at Peckham library.

Witnesses saw three youths running from the scene. None of them has come forward. Damilola's parents believe their son was being bullied at Oliver Goldsmith primary school.

Seventy officers and support staff have been assigned to the murder squad, which is led by Detective Chief Inspector Trevor Shepheard.

webTitle: Bush sweats over labour nominee

fields.headline: Bush sweats over labour nominee
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: A mounting furore over George W Bush's nominee as secretary of labour is threatening to overshadow the incoming Republican administration's efforts to fulfil its pledge to "change the tone in Washington".
fields.body:
A mounting furore over George W Bush's nominee as secretary of labour is threatening to overshadow the incoming Republican administration's efforts to fulfil its pledge to "change the tone in Washington".

At issue is whether Linda Chavez broke US laws by paying an illegal immigrant and accepting household help from her during the early 1990s, and whether the prospective cabinet member was entirely open about the relationship when she was vetted by Mr Bush's advisers before her nomination.

Yesterday the controversy took a further turn when the Wall Street Journal, a strongly pro-Bush paper, reported that Ms Chavez may have tried to brief a former neighbour, who had also employed the Guatemalan immigrant, Marta Mercado, about how to answer questions on the subject from the media and FBI investigators.

On Monday, Mr Bush was forced on to the defensive over the issue in a succession of questions from reporters.

Mr Bush was not told until this week, several days after he nominated Ms Chavez, that she had paid and given a room to Ms Mercado in the early 1990s. Ms Mercado performed chores for Ms Chavez, including tidying the rooms of her two teenage sons, doing the laundry and walking the dog. Ms Chavez said she gave Ms Mercado "spending money" but denied employing her.

There were increasing signs yesterday that any further revelations could bring the Chavez nomination to an abrupt end, just as similar accusations did to two of Mr Clinton's nominees as attorney general in 1993. At the time, Ms Chavez condemned one of the nominees, Zoe Baird, for employing an illegal immigrant as a nanny.

Quoting officials close to Mr Bush, news agencies reported "increasing concern" about Ms Chavez, saying that an internal review and FBI interviews had raised questions about the credibility of her answers.

The silver lining for the Bush administration is that the row about Ms Chavez has taken the heat off his controversial nomination of the conservative ex-senator, John Ashcroft, as his attorney general.

The Ashcroft nomination is nevertheless likely to resume centre-stage when he begins his own confirmation hearings in front of the Senate judiciary committee later this month. Senate Democrats have already made clear that they regard the Ashcroft hearings as a major opportunity to flex their muscles in the new Congress, as well as sending a signal to Mr Bush about the kind of grilling that any nominees to the supreme court may face during his period in office.

Yesterday a coalition of liberal pressure groups announced that more than 200 organisations had formed an alliance to fight Mr Ashcroft's nomination. The groups include civil liberties, environmental, gun control and women's organisations.

In a further embarrassment for Mr Bush, his nominee for defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, has been accused of agreeing with racist comments about black people made on 1970s White House tape recordings of his conversations with President Richard Nixon. Mr Rumsfeld was an adviser to Mr Nixon at the time.

In a 1971 tape, Mr Nixon criticised his vice-president Spiro Agnew for saying that black Africans were more intelligent than black Americans. "Most of them are basically just out of the trees," Mr Nixon says about Africans. "That's right," Mr Rumsfeld replies.

"It doesn't help with the rednecks because the rednecks don't think any negroes are any good," Mr Nixon goes on. "Yes," Mr Rumsfeld says.

fields.headline: Big man of the Shankill 'still holds sway - in or out of jail'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Jay Adair, two, pulled at the talisman on a gold chain around his little neck - a tiny clenched fist, symbol of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, the loyalist terror organisation of which his father, Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair, is a leading member, writes Rosie Cowan.
fields.body:
Jay Adair, two, pulled at the talisman on a gold chain around his little neck - a tiny clenched fist, symbol of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, the loyalist terror organisation of which his father, Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair, is a leading member, writes Rosie Cowan.

Nearby, his six-year-old sister, Chloe, was putting up a poster of her dad at their lower Shankill Road home, where red, white and blue bunting decks the heavily reinforced doors and windows. It bears the legend "Victimisation - Free Johnny Adair Now".

Adair's wife, Gina, their four children, and his wider paramilitary "family" had hoped they would be welcoming him home from prison this week, but it seems like they may be looking at posters for some time to come.

On the Shankill, the mood was tense yesterday. Adair has appealed for calm, but there is much anger.

"Adair is respected in this area," said a man. "He holds sway, whether he's out or in. But this means there'll be trouble. The peace process is a one-way street for republicans. People are asking, what are loyalists getting out of it?"

In nearby nationalist west Belfast, people were nervous and scared. "They did the right thing keeping him in, should have never let him out, but people are afraid there will be some kind of retaliation for this," one man said.

Peter Mandelson was determined to keep Adair, 37, behind bars. The Northern Ireland secretary had him re-arrested last August, blaming him for orchestrating loyalist feuding.

But his supporters claim that far from fuelling inter-loyalist strife, he has worked tirelessly for the peace process, encouraging Protestant paramilitaries to keep talking rather than turning back to their guns.

"I doubt if we would have come so far in the past six years if it hadn't been for people like Johnny Adair," said close friend, John White, chairman of the UFF's political wing, the Ulster Democratic party. "The loyalist feud only escalated after he was put back in jail, proving the secretary of state was only making a scapegoat of him."

Others are not so sure. One said: "He has to be top dog. If he got out, it would only be a matter of time before he started asserting himself again and that just gets up other people's noses."

Born and bred in the Shankill, Adair graduated from neo-Nazi hooliganism to become one of the most ruthless terrorists of his generation. He headed the UFF's C battalion, notorious for its naked sectarianism and implicated in the murders of at least 20 Catholics.

Adair told a Guardian reporter in October 1983 that the only Catholic he'd previously had in his car was a dead one. "Once you get your first Fenian [Catholic] blood, it's easy after that," he explained.

A senior police source, who has known him for many years, described him as "totally bigoted, totally crim inal, totally dangerous."

His fearsome reputation made him many enemies. The IRA Shankill Road bomb, which killed 10 people in 1993, was widely believed to have been meant for him. He was attacked at a concert in Belfast's Botanic Gardens while out on parole in May 1999, although some said loyalists, not republicans, did it because of a row over drugs.

In September 1995, he was found guilty of directing terrorism, but had served less than five years of his 16-year sentence when he was freed in September 1999, despite the deep reservations of of the then-secretary of state, Mo Mowlam.

"He loves the high life and he loves being the 'big man' on his patch," a security source said. "But his ego always takes over. There's this internal battle between wanting to outsmart the police and wanting everyone to know he is top dog."

Adair continued to keep a high profile and was a frequent visitor to Portadown during last year's protests against the ban on the Drumcree Orange march.

He was spotted almost nightly on Drumcree hill, with his Alsatian dog, Rebel, both of them wearing T-shirts with the slogan "Simply the Best - Their Only Crime was Loyalty".

He insisted he was only there to calm the situation down but he was captured on film, laughing and applauding as masked LVF men fired a volley of shots in a show of strength on a Portadown housing estate.

Back in Belfast, as the UFF threatened to end its ceasefire because of attacks on Protestant homes, he claimed republicans were behind a pipe bomb attack on his car but they denied it, saying it was a set-up.

The simmering tensions between the UFF and UVF boiled over. Police finally arrested Adair on August 22, as the feud exploded into murder but even now, with him behind bars and a truce declared, the situation remains precarious.

"He's better in than out, he can do less damage," said a security source. "We'll contain any street protests in the area. But if some of his cohorts take this as an excuse to attack Catholics, and there is retaliation, then things could get very bad indeed."

webTitle: Branson remains bullish over prospect of capturing lottery

fields.headline: Branson remains bullish over prospect of capturing lottery
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's hopes of running the national lottery were still alive last night after his team claimed that legal advice suggests he has a strong case for overturning the award of the next licence to Camelot.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's hopes of running the national lottery were still alive last night after his team claimed that legal advice suggests he has a strong case for overturning the award of the next licence to Camelot.

After meeting lawyers yesterday, Simon Burridge, chief executive of Sir Richard's People's Lottery, said "the world looked a better place".

He hinted there was a likelihood that the company would now take action.

Executives of the People's Lottery were locked in further meetings with their legal team late last night before reaching a decision.

"We have been told we have an extremely good case to argue that the process was flawed and substantively unfair," Mr Burridge said. "The decision made by the lottery commission was riddled with contradictions."

Sir Richard was outraged when the lottery commission last month awarded the next seven-year licence to Camelot. Camelot had used the high court to muscle its way back into the contest, he said.

Further legal action is likely to raise fears among charities that the licence term, due to begin in October, could be delayed.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, appeared to endorse Sir Richard's case. On BBC Radio 2, Mr Smith said the selection process had given an unfair advantage to the incumbent operator and should be reviewed.

The members of the People's Lottery are now considering launching an alternative game to raise money for good causes if they decide not to pursue their case, or if they lose in court.

"We would review the possibilities if we reach that point. We have had a fantastic response from the public who are very angry about what has happened," Mr Burridge said.

Mr Smith said the government would not stand in Sir Richard's way if he chose to start up an independent lottery.

webTitle: Clintons give Socks the sack

fields.headline: Clintons give Socks the sack
fields.trailText: After eight years of unstinting loyalty to Bill and Hillary Clinton, one of the most popular members of the current White House team is being cruelly thrown overboard.
fields.body:
After eight years of unstinting loyalty to Bill and Hillary Clinton, one of the most popular members of the current White House team is being cruelly thrown overboard.

Socks, the nine-year-old black and white cat brought to Washington eight years ago by the Clintons, is no longer wanted by America's departing first family.

Instead, he is to be adopted by Mr Clinton's secretary, Betty Currie, who is proposing to take him to live with her in Virginia as a living memento of her White House years.

The abandonment of Socks contrasts with the treatment being accorded to his nemesis, Buddy, Mr Clinton's four-year-old chocolate labrador, who will get to live the good life with the shortly to be ex-president.

But Socks, who had his own fan club and website, and was shamelessly exploited in one of Mrs Clinton's publishing ventures - a book entitled Dear Socks, Dear Buddy - is now surplus to requirements.

As Socks moves out of the White House, India, the Bush family's black cat, is moving in, along with the family's two dogs, Spot and Barney.

webTitle: Pinochet agrees to health tests

fields.headline: Pinochet agrees to health tests
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet shifted his defence strategy on Monday evening and consented to medical tests that will determine if he is fit to stand trial in Chile.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet shifted his defence strategy on Monday evening and consented to medical tests that will determine if he is fit to stand trial in Chile.

The former dictator, who was on the verge of being arrested, agreed to be examined by doctors today.

He is then expected to be questioned by Judge Juan Guzman on January 15. Judge Guzman is leading the investigation into allegations that Gen Pinochet played a direct role in ordering the execution of some 75 civilians in 1973.

The shift by Gen Pinochet followed a series of defeats in court, pressure from the army leadership and a thinly veiled threat from Judge Guzman to proceed with an arrest order. But in another act of defiance, Pinochet lawyers said their client would not answer the judge's questions.

The medical tests include neurological and psychological examinations that are expected to take several days.

Under Chilean law, all defendants over the age of 70 are required to take such tests, although the criteria for avoiding prosecution are far narrower than in English law.

If Gen Pinochet is declared incompetent to stand trial, he could avoid the 202 criminal cases moving through the courts. But other actions would continue, including attempts to freeze the general's assets, and a parliamentary investigation into charges that the Chilean armed forces were involved in smuggling cocaine into Europe in 1988.

Jaqueline Pinochet, the general's youngest daughter, lashed out at the army on Monday for not protecting him "The army ought to take a more energetic decision because my father was their commander in chief and this situation could bring a bad image to the armed forces," she said.

She continued to deny that human rights violations were committed during her father's government, insisting that "there were no disappeared".

But a recently released government report indicates that 120 bodies were thrown into the Pacific, and yesterday's newspapers were filled with lists of the victims' names.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Tried and tested
fields.trailText: Judge John Deed | Blood On The Carpet
fields.body:
The trailer made me nervous. A judge who does not play by the rules. Like a train which does not run on the tracks, this is guaranteed to disturb.

Judge John Deed (BBC1) is an attractive maverick, who strides around the place in braces and is catnip to the ladies. These are chappishly called Georgie, Charlie, Jo and - when Rita defies abbreviation - Coop.

Deed is chummy with Coop his clerk, who titivates his cravat tenderly, and a great deal too chummy with defence counsel. (It seems to be the done thing, when in bed with a judge, to address him as "Judge". Deed thinks "My Lord" pretentious, and I think we would all concur with that. This is one of those little etiquette tips which come to you at no extra cost and may well prevent an embarrassing faux pas.)

According to the writer and producer, GF Newman, Deed is, hang onto your wig here, in touch with his feelings. He reminds me, as so many things seem to do, of Dylan the laid-back rabbit in The Magic Roundabout. Reproached for unrabbity behaviour, Dylan said "We're trying to change the image."

You can see why Martin Shaw's interestingly intense eyes would light up at the sight of the part. And, once he was secured, why the other names came tumbling after. Donald Sinden shaking his wattles. Burnside of The Bill giving his glare.

Deed has the usual tiresome teenage daughter ("The whole planet is doomed!"), who is de rigueur for all high- fliers on TV. So he is in touch with his feelings when trying a father, who has murdered his daughter's killer. Deed's eye-popping innovation is to ask the jury to reconsider their guilty verdict and bring in one he likes better. As the double-barrelled, sorely tried prosecution counsel protests, "My lord, you can't do this!"

At some point Deed turns into Robin Hood, feared by the bad, loved by the good. He is beset by enemies in the Lord Chamberlain's Office. Simon Dymock (Simon de Dymock, surely) and his nark the clerk threaten to throw him to the wolves on The Guardian ("You might like to consider resignation as an alternative, my lord"). But our hero, who probably does wear tights under his scarlet robe, fights them off. That fencing scene is not just there for prettiness. Threatened, he proves a ruthless mover.

Talking of merry men, did I really hear his fencing partner, the Deputy Assistant Commissioner, say that Scotland Yard was full of gay policemen?

Judge John Deed is a one-off drama, but everything about it threatens a series.

Oliviero Toscani's father took the last photograph of Mussolini, killed by partisans and hung upside down like a carcass of beef, with his mistress, Claretta Petacci, beside him. I still remember the shock of it. He passed on his genes in perfect working order to his son. Oliviero Toscani's posters for Benetton had exactly the same shock-horror effect.

In Nick Mirsky's witty Blood On The Carpet (BBC2), Luciano Benetton looked like a bishop, who has drifted abstractedly into ladies' blouses. Toscani looked like Brian Blessed. He seemed to live in an uproar of laughter. For 18 years this odd couple were inseparable. Toscani put Benetton on the map with increasingly provocative and, latterly, thought-provoking posters such as black and white hands handcuffed together. "Who is the assassin? Who is the policeman? Of course, people say the white is the policeman. Is not true. Is not true. Makes you think, what's going on here?"

When Benetton negotiated to open 800 outlets in Sears, the all-American store, Toscani's poster campaign showed the faces of men on America's death row.

And that is when Donata Nelson, switching on her TV in Louisville, Kentucky, saw the face of her young son's murderer selling sweaters. The Nelsons led a protest, devastating in its simplicity. Benetton braked with a dislocating jerk and Toscani was left swinging in the wind like Mussolini. "Everyone was disappearing from Benetton. No one was there. They chicken out. Naw, naw, we're not here!" Sears threw out Benetton. Benetton threw out Toscani. Donata Nelson said "That tickled me to death."

Toscani stood defiantly disconsolate in Times Square, surrounded by the loudest glare of advertisement in the world.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Random views

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What waiters are watching on television
fields.trailText: What waiters are watching on television.
fields.body:
Dean Rapton: "I think that the stuff they put on Channel 5 is rubbish. We all had this new channel and I thought I could get some of my ideas on - I write sitcoms and stuff, I'm not just a waiter! I had some really good ideas, and it turned out to be another cack channel which shows programmes with Gail Porter on, it's nothing new. My ideas aren't all poncy BBC2 stuff, but I thought it could be an opening. What are they about? FHM girls, but with brains, like Charlie's Angels, I think. Good TV. Honest, don't laugh."

Ben Hines: "I watch all the crap they put on Saturday night before I go out, when I'm arguing with my old man. I watch Jim Davidson and you know what? My dad's like an old, short, fat version of Jim Davidson. Except without the birds in stockings. And he's not funny. Do I watch soaps? Do I hell. My life is a soap opera, darling, you should watch me some time."

Val Dauxerre: "Pardon? I watch very little British TV. I think I don't understand it as much as French TV, which I'm used to. I have watched The Royle Family and I think it is very British. Why? Very depressing. The people are fat. Boring."

Ida Fanslin: "I like the films, I think there's always something to watch. I do like EastEnders, I think it gives an insight into a certain way of life. I study at the University of North London so I don't get to watch TV much. What do I study? Politics. That's why I like EastEnders, it's like a world war in Albert Square. People against each other. Nick Cotton as the terrorist. The one who blows everything up. I like Pauline Fowler (pictured), who represents the female anti-aggressor, but even she has her masculine moments. I think it's fascinating. Realistic? Of course not."

Mel Adule: "I've just got cable and I can watch BBC Choice and MTV and Sky and everything and I think it's fantastic. I never want to work! I could sit and watch TV all day."

 Siân Pattenden spoke to waiting staff at restaurants on the Holloway Road, London.

That's why I like EastEnders, it's like a world war in Albert Square. People against each other. Nick Cotton as the terrorist. The one who blows everything up. I like Pauline Fowler (pictured), who represents the female anti-aggressor, but even she has her masculine moments. I think it's fascinating. Realistic? Of course not." webTitle: Governor cracks down on energy companies

fields.headline: Governor cracks down on energy companies
fields.standfirst: California to probe possible racketeering by 'profiteers'
fields.trailText: California to probe possible racketeering by 'profiteers'.
fields.body:
The governor of California yesterday attacked deregulation of the state's electricity industry as a "colossal and dangerous failure" and threatened the privatised industry with criminal investigations for racketeering.

In a scathing attack on "profiteers", Gray Davis proposed an energy authority that could buy plants from companies and build new ones.

California deregulated its electricity system under the state's previous Republican administration as part of the bullish free market philosophy of the time. But the two-year experiment has turned into a costly failure, with blackouts, power shortages and consumer prices due to rise high above the inflation rate.

For the governor, the most embarrassing moment came last month when he had to order the state capital's Christmas lights to be turned off as an energy-saving measure, just after he had lit them.

Mr Davis, a centrist Democrat with an eye on his party's 2004 presidential nomination, chose his "state of the state" speech in Sacramento to mount an astonishing attack on deregulation.

"We have literally lost control over our own power," he said. "We have surrendered the decisions about where electricity is sold, and for what price, to private companies with only one objective: maximising unheard of profits."

Deregulation had been a "colossal and dangerous failure", he said. "It has not lowered consumer prices; it has not increased supply. It has resulted in skyrocketing prices and an unreliable supply of electricity. In short, an energy nightmare."

Among his proposals is the appointment of 50 new inspectors for the public utilities commission - to monitor and "if necessary, stand guard at any facility suspected of deliberately withholding power from the grid". He seeks to make it a crime to "deliberately withhold power from the grid if it results in an imminent threat to public health or safety".

More dramatically, he said the state attorney general would "investigate and prosecute possible racketeering, market manipulation, price fixing and other potential violations by generators... If they are illegally manipulating the market, the attorney general will track them down."

"Make no mistake," he said, "we will regain control over the power that's generated in California and commit it to the public good... Never again will we allow profiteers to hold Californians hostage."

Mr Davis has seen his approval rating drop from 67% to 49% in the last year, mainly because of the sharp increase in electricity prices and the inefficiency of the suppliers. But his strong attack on deregulation chimes with the Californian public's attitude to the power companies. A poll last week by the Los Angeles Times found that 54% of the public believe there is no real electricity shortage and blame greedy power producers for manufacturing a crisis.

Mr Davis said the public would have to play its part, too, by reducing electricity consumption by 7%. Cash incentives are to be offered to people who replace old refrigerators and air conditioners with "energy-smart" ones.

His speech, on the eve of an energy summit in Washington, will be seen as a rallying cry by those who feel that the US is facing an energy crisis and that the deregulation of public services is not the way to tackle it. There will also be a backlash. Mr Davis is already being accused by conservative commentators of being a protectionist who will fall foul of a Bush administration committed to deregulation.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Love Me Or Leave Me | When Worlds Collide | Apt Pupil
fields.body:
Love Me Or Leave Me
(Charles Vidor, 1955)
3pm, TCM

Unusually tough biopic of 20s singer Ruth Etting, focusing on her liaison with vicious hoodlum Gimp Snyder. Girl-next-door Doris Day and onetime grapefruit-in-the-mush James Cagney are a juicy pairing, with Cameron Mitchell the piano player she is drawn to. Includes fine renditions of standards such as You Made Me Love You.

When Worlds Collide
(Rudolph Maté, 1951)
4pm, Sky Cinema

Pretty topical, what with scientists scanning the skies for errant asteroids. In this case though it's a whole planet about to play cosmic billiards with earth, while Richard Derr, Barbara Rush and Larry Keating lead the rats hoping to jump the sinking ship in a space rocket. The then state-of-the-art special effects ratchet up the tension, despite the stilted acting.

Apt Pupil
(Bryan Singer, 1997)
10pm, Sky Premier

This adaptation of a Stephen King story by the director of The Usual Suspects and X-Men is a sobering portrayal of the lure of fascism and human corruption. Brad Renfro plays the bright young Californian teenager who, obsessed by the Holocaust, encounters one of its perpetrators - Ian McKellen's Kurt Dussander. In exchange for not exposing him, the former SS man recounts the horrors of his past actions. The pair's twisted relationship makes for fascinating but uncomfortable viewing.

Blue Velvet
(David Lynch, 1986)
10.30pm, FilmFour

Disturbing, voyeuristic peep at smalltown America, with a Buñuelian sense of the surreal. Kyle MacLachlan is the cherubic young chap whose discovery of a severed ear is an entrée into a macabre underworld: the relationship between nightclub-singer Isabella Rossellini and a deeply disturbed Dennis Hopper is gut-churning, his Frank Booth one of the great screen studies in evil. It's all a far cry from Lynch's most recent sortie into America's rural belt, The Straight Story.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Afternoon Play: Peacemakers | The Countryside Debates
fields.body:
In August 1976, after British troops in Northern Ireland killed an IRA gunman in his car, the vehicle mowed down a passing woman and her three children. The resulting outcry brought a demonstration in Belfast, organised by Betty Williams and the children's aunt, Mairead Corrigan, with 30,000 women demanding an end to the conflict. For the Afternoon Play: Peacemakers (2.15pm, Radio 4), Annie Caulfield has dramatised the story of the women's campaign and their eventual receipt of the Nobel Peace Prize.

The second of The Countryside Debates (8.0pm, Radio 4) finds Edward Stourton in Grantham, Lincolnshire, exploring with 20 representative locals the proposition that "rural people are suffering because they have no control over the levers of power". It may seem an odd point to make in Mrs Thatcher's home town, but the iron lady's heritage seems to have rusted a little over the past decade. Could regional devolution offer a way to revitalise England's rural areas?

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Stonehenge

fields.headline: No: 1797
fields.standfirst: Stonehenge
fields.trailText: Stonehenge
fields.body:
Status: Ancient, mystical monument-type thing.

Location: Just off that road on the way to Exeter.

Age: Really, really old.

No, seriously - how old? Oh, you know. Stone age. Um. Iron age. No, prehistoric. It's really old, in any case.

Look, I just want to know how old it is. OK, OK. Next you'll be wanting Pass notes to be properly researched. Right - it says here the earliest part of the complex (ie the bank and ditch and all the easy bits) date from about 3000BC.

Ah, so it's middle neolithic. No, smartarse. Not all of it. The famous bit - you know, the big goalposts that came from Wales on rollerskates ...

You mean the trilithons. Yeah, whatever. Anyway, they date from 2550-1600BC. And it was finally finished in ... hang on, that can't be right.

What? It says here Stonehenge was finished in 1964. I told you it was better to make this stuff up.

Do they mean the period in which the sarsen circle was erected, around 1964BC? No. They mean the period in which the Beatles were top of the hit parade and you could get a pint for thruppence ha'penny, around 1964AD.

But what about the druidic calendar and the perfect sunrise only once a year and all that? Well that's the thing. The stones might not be in the same spot. They have been moved, you see.

The rollerskates again? Not likely. Gangs of navvies, a few heavy duty cranes and not a little concrete.

I get it - known in archaeological circles as the meddling period. Quite. It has been revealed that in the first half of this century the landmark was given a number of "facelifts" by over-enthusiastic amateur historians. And almost none of the stones is in the position in which its original builders first put them.

Do say: "The long and honourable tradition of improving the site goes back millennia."

Don't say: "Don't you think it would be a good idea to put in pine-veneer flooring and clad the stones in MDF?"

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Cornwall
fields.trailText: Cornwall
fields.body:
To celebrate the New Year, a dozen of us walk 10 miles along the north coast path, from Boscastle to Lower Tresmorn for dinner. Clouds hang over lately snow-covered Bodmin Moor, but the northern horizon and Lundy are clear - lumpy, pale blue sea broken with the purple shadows and pearly reflections of clouds. Sheer black cliffs of contorted slate, lichened stone walls founded on massive white "spars" (quartz), and Pentargon's waterfall were all part of Thomas Hardy's dramatic setting for A Pair Of Blue Eyes.

Beeny Cliff's defunct boundaries are covered in browned thrift and, above Gull Rock, another chunk of land has slumped. Steep, hummocky Rusey is in winter shade, its brackeny turf, thickets of blackthorn and gold flowered "fuzz" (gorse) trampled and tracked by a few caretaker bullocks. Up on High Cliff, a group of Ken Crocker's grass-fed herd face the afternoon sun, 223m above the surf on Strangles.

Approaching Cambeak we look back against the light down Cornwall's Heritage Coast - a succession of silvery headlands and hazy islets towards Tintagel and beyond, as far as Stepper Point. Three surfers wallow in the swell of quiet Crackington Haven and we make our final big ascent to splashy pastures above St Genny's pinnacled church tower.

Inland, across Cleave's stunted wood, up a muddy sheep track, the lights of our destination outshine the moon, now veiled with approaching rain clouds. Our meal includes roast lamb reared on this remote farm which has diversified to cater for visitors.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Court circular

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge.
fields.body:
It's a case of good news, bad news for the Culkin clan. Against all odds former cutie pie Macauley has an entirely unexpected career revival with a role in Madame Melville, and will soon be heading to Broadway. Meanwhile, his family is being sued by insurance company Travelers Property Casualty for $113,000 following a fatal fire in their Manhattan apartment building in 1998.

Mac wasn't involved, having moved out to live with wife Rachel Miner, but his mother, Patricia Brentrup, is being accused of allowing the fire, which started in the Culkins' apartment, to spread to the rest of the building after leaving the door open. Four people were killed trying to escape - and their families, and others who were injured, are suing Brentrup for $80m.

She's more used to being on the wrong end of legal action, but slut-rocker turned Versace clotheshorse Courtney Love has filed a lawsuit against a woman she claims is "on a mission to destroy" her. The woman, Lesley Barber, also happens to be the ex-wife of music executive Jim Barber, who is currently dating, you guessed it, Courtney Love.

The Hole frontwoman alleges that Barber told her, "You're a bitch and I'm going to get you." Barber is also accused of running over Love's foot in a Volvo (causing injuries which meant her missing out on a starring role in John Carpenter's Ghosts Of Mars), and of threatening to plant cocaine in her car. Love is seeking damages of over $1.5m for assault, trespassing and infliction of emotional distress.

Meanwhile, Michael Costanza, the New Yorker who filed a $100m lawsuit against the makers of Seinfeld accusing them of basing the character of ultimate loser George Costanza on his life, has had his case thrown out of court. He's also been ordered to pay $5,000 for filing a frivolous lawsuit. Judge Harold Tompkins said: "While a programme about nothing can be successful, a lawsuit must have more substance."

webTitle: Arts: An eight-hour marriage

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.trailText: Arthur Smith: True Tales for Winter Nights, number 14. My friend Dave was doing his comedy act for a works do in a posh hotel up north.
fields.body:
True Tales for Winter Nights, number 14. My friend Dave was doing his comedy act for a works do in a posh hotel up north. It went down well and he duly repaired to the bar for compliments and drinks. Both arrived swiftly, delivered by a man with large eyebrows and a desperate look.

"You were very funny. Put your booze on my tab. Tell me, are you married?" Dave is not married but he saw the man wanted him to be. "Yes." The eyebrows knitted together alarmingly. Dave didn't want to be stuck with this bloke all night. He indicated a woman who had just arrived at the bar. "I'm married to her." "How long?" "Eleven years," said the woman, who was, of course, very beautiful.

"We're still really happy," added Dave. Dave and the woman exchanged a glance of complicity as Eyebrows launched into an account of his own woeful marriage. Dave was feeling increasingly guilty that the poor man was obviously in despair about his relationship, whereas Dave was in a long, happy relationship with a woman he had only clapped eyes on 10 minutes before.

He wanted to admit the lie, but he and his "wife" were in too deep. By now they had two children and owned a small cottage in Suffolk. Dave had also described the magic evening on a mountain in the Pyrenees when he had proposed. "And do you still fancy each other?" asked the sad husband.

"Oh yes," said Dave's spouse, squeezing his hand, and she proceeded to elaborate at length on their sexual antics. Eventually the sad husband had heard enough about this sickeningly successful liaison and he and his eyebrows scuttled off.

Dave and his wife were alone together for the first time in their 11-year marriage. She introduced herself, they laughed, drank and later they went back to his room. In the morning she was gone, and Dave was single once more. He tells me he does not intend to get hitched again. What's the point when his first marriage was sublime, perfect - and all over in eight hours?
