webTitle: TV and Radio: ITV's Popstars programme

fields.headline: Almost famous
fields.standfirst: Tonight, ITV takes us into the private world of Britain's latest teen pop idols. But you won't have heard of them - in fact, they don't even exist yet. But soon, you won't be able to get away from them.  Adam Sweeting  explains
fields.trailText: Tonight, ITV takes us into the private world of Britain's latest teen pop idols. But you won't have heard of them - in fact, they don't even exist yet. But soon, you won't be able to get away from them. Adam Sweeting explains.
fields.body:
Welcome to the era of "It Could Be You" television. It could be you who gets rich via the National Lottery or Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? Now, on ITV's new 13-part series Popstars, it could be you who finds yourself picked from teeming hordes of ambitious yoof to become part of a brand new manufactured pop group. After all, as we are informed in tonight's opening episode, "it's every youngster's dream to become a pop star". ITV is going to milk that dream for every penny.

The idea of the undiscovered young hopeful being whisked sensationally out of the crowd and into the limelight of a superstar career has been a scriptwriter's favourite since mass media began. But back in the 30s and 40s, showbiz Cinderella stories about the understudy who steps into the leading role or the chorus girl suddenly thrust into the spotlight were more like fairy tales than attempts to palm off a naked commercial venture as entertainment.

Twenty years ago, Sheena Easton received a handy career leg-up by appearing on Esther Rantzen's show The Big Time, but compared to Popstars this was still pretty innocent stuff. Though the programme followed Easton while she auditioned for EMI, recorded her first single and was then processed through the EMI charm school, it was essentially passive - it watched the process rather than being a part of it.

Popstars is different. Fittingly for an era when the entertainment industry has evolved into the equivalent of a robot-controlled automobile production line, when it has become disturbingly easy to invent and market stars and starlets for popular consumption, Popstars takes the manufacturing process itself as its subject.

The three judges who will decide the fates of the armies of contestants are Polydor's A&R director Paul Adam, Billie Piper's manager Nicki Chapman from Brilliant PR, and LWT's Controller of Entertainment and Comedy Nigel Lythgoe, each of whom has plenty to gain from the process. LWT get a massively hyped network TV show; Polydor stand to gain a new pop group, which has been designed to their own specifications, for their roster; and Brilliant PR must be licking their lips in anticipation of the management and media work heading their way. What Popstars is trying to do is to take the risk out of inventing a successful pop group, a process which loses record companies millions of pounds every year. The series will deliver a finished product, already familiar to the public and with most of the pre-marketing already done.

Even the format of Popstars has been cloned from abroad. It was first seen on Australia's Seven Network, where it hit a staggering peak viewing figure of 52 per cent of audience share as it traced the auditioning and creation of a five-piece girl band called Bardot. Here was a group so synthetic that they weren't allowed to choose their own name; it was decided by public vote. Nonetheless, their debut album thundered to the top of the charts in Australia and New Zealand, offering some evidence that at least it isn't only the British public that has an insatiable appetite for gormless teen slop.

Yet despite the fact that concocting pop groups is one of the biggest growth industries of UK PLC, what's striking about watching the auditions in this home-grown edition of Popstars is how old-fashioned it all is. Much of this is down to the way the judges approach their task.

While Adam and Chapman treat their prospective career fodder like passive plasticine people who should be grateful for the chance to be moulded (Chapman throws a strop when one auditionee has the cheek to ask if she can sing a different bit of her audition song from the stipulated fragment), Lythgoe is an old-school Light Entertainment veteran who likes cutting applicants down to size with a dash of belittling sarcasm. Interestingly, he is both executive producer and star of Popstars.

"That superficial manufactured look is not for me, I'm afraid", comments Lythgoe about pop groups in general, a baffling observation from a man at the centre of one of the most blatant manufacturing exercises ever undertaken.

It's this chilling element of total control which sets Popstars apart from previous similar efforts in the genre. The harmless idiocy that is the hallmark of Stars In Their Eyes would be entirely out of keeping with the new show's steely-eyed professional calculation. Making The Band, Channel 4's American import about prefab boy band O-Town, at least had the saving graces of infinite tackiness and unintentional hilarity, but Popstars views its mission with unspeakable seriousness.

Another recent precedent was BBC1's Get Your Act Together from 1999, where Ronan "Precocious, moi?" Keating played host while eager young contestants were given the full makeover from swarms of stylists, choreographers and studio Svengalis. The results were hair- raisingly frightful, but at least Keating managed to feign a degree of sympathy for his nail-biting pop hopefuls.

In Popstars, you feel that the judges view the process as nothing more or less than a priceless commercial opportunity. Television is never ashamed of a bit of self- promotion, but it has rarely looked as mercenary as this.

webTitle: G2: The All Saints' split up

fields.headline: When the saints go marching out
fields.standfirst: They've been on the verge of it before, but this time it looks as though All Saints are finally splitting up.  Caroline Sullivan laments the passing of a band which, despite the tensions, never lost its credibility
fields.trailText: They've been on the verge of it before, but this time it looks as though All Saints are finally splitting up. Caroline Sullivan laments the passing of a band which, despite the tensions, never lost its credibility.
fields.body:
The title of the current All Saints album, Saints & Sinners, could describe the two factions of the band: saintly Shaznay Lewis and Mel Blatt, whose idea of a frolic is staying in and writing a song, and the bad Appleton sisters, who would turn up at the opening of an envelope, provided the envelope had a free bar. The opposing sides have locked horns before, with one or other member storming out in high dudgeon but always returning before complete meltdown.

This time, though, the foursome are in "crisis talks", which evokes visions of the Appletons louchely sipping cocktails as Lewis and Blatt wag schoolmarmish fingers. The official word is that it's business as usual, but someone close to the group says, "I think this time there are internal differences that are beyond sorting out."

Which is really too bad. All Saints were the girl group's girl group, nocturnal sensualists in a world of shrill stage-school airheads. They wrote their own material (or rather Lewis did, and her proportionately heftier pay cheques were reputedly a source of contention) and, unusually, the material got better as they went along. Pure Shores was the second-biggest-selling single of 2000, and is almost unique among recent pop songs in still being listenable a year later.

They had the sense to enlist William Orbit's production skills for Saints & Sinners, and he worked his ambient tomfoolery as successfully as he did on Madonna's career-saving album Ray of Light. (By contrast, the Spice Girls hired American producer Rodney Jerkins, whose attempt to give them R 'n' B credibility was embarrassingly misguided.)

Their other number one single of last year, Black Coffee, was even better than Pure Shores in its beguiling treatment of a domestic scenario. "Brush your teeth, pour yourself a cup of black coffee," they crooned, in easily the most alluring depiction of a bleary-eyed morning routine ever recorded. Refusing to milk their two albums, they put out only a handful of singles, each as shimmery as the last.

The others were the slow-burning debut I Know Where it's At, the 1m-selling Never Ever, which features an Appleton pleading, "A few questions I need to know" (and a few answers she needs to ask, presumably), the glorious Red Hot Chili Peppers cover Under the Bridge, and the ones nobody remembers: Bootie Call and War of Nerves.

Best not to get into their new one, All Hooked Up, wherein the girls coo, "I know that you want a piece of mah ass" under the misapprehension that they're Mary J Blige. Shaznay amplifies the silliness by adding, "Why's this guy all up in my ass?", which doesn't make her sound like anything but an English girl trying to do ghetto-fab.

Little missteps aside, they never lost their credibility. You may not agree with me that their version of Under the Bridge was as touching in its own way as the Chili Peppers', but you probably don't hate it. It's hard to find anyone who actively dislikes All Saints; Nicole and Natalie's string of celebrity boyfriends and Met Bar antics roused contempt, but the group's identity was remarkably untarnished.

Their appeal went across the board, from teenage girls to Elle-reading twentysomethings (Nicole and her latest boything, Liam Gallagher, were on last month's cover) to older men who didn't mind at all when the girls' low-slung combat pants drooped dangerously southward.

They achieved the cross-generational success that eluded the Spice Girls simply by being themselves. Like the Spices, each Saint was a personality archetype - earth-mother Mel (whose reluctance to leave her baby, Lilyella, at home forced the cancellation of a Far East tour in November), party girls Nicole and Natalie and musicianly Shaznay, who wrote Pure Shores while the other three were away making Dave Stewart's flop film Honest.

They were perfectly imperfect - pretty rather than stunning, dishevelled rather than groomed, inclined to boast, as Mel once did, "I farted and told my boyfriend the baby did it." Posh Spice, of course, would die before compromising her brittle image in such a human way.

With such different personalities in the mix, the group equilibrium was always compromised. Nicole's pregnancy, which came about after she'd been dating Gallagher for a whole month, can't have helped. Blatt has commented that being a working mother creates divided loyalties, and perhaps the split is the inevitable consequence. "A lot of the problems are down to Mel's inability to commit of late," says the insider. "Nicole and Natalie were more and more frustrated because they felt she wasn't holding up her end."

The future? I predict that Lewis will prosper as a songwriter, perhaps in a backroom role that will enable her to step out of the spotlight she says she hates. Blatt will raise a brood of children and become a session singer during term time, as long as she can be home for the school run.

Nicole and Liam will celebrate the birth of baby McCartney, then realise they have nothing in common, by which time Billie Piper will be old enough to become his next blonde bit. Natalie will follow the Princess Margaret road to dissipation, lounging around in a Marlboro Light fug with minor TV presenters on Caribbean islands.

It's a pity they've split up. Any chance they could take Atomic Kitten with them?

webTitle: Arts: Mime play Bertrand's Toys

fields.headline: They're alive!
fields.standfirst: How on earth did a bunch of clockwork dolls and jack-in-the-boxes leave  Lyn Gardner  trembling?
fields.trailText: How on earth did a bunch of clockwork dolls and jack-in-the-boxes leave Lyn Gardner trembling?
fields.body:
It is hard to make audiences feel really scared in the theatre. You can give them a momentary shock with a loud noise or piercing beam of light, but it is difficult to sustain the kind of fear and tension that movies such as The Blair Witch Project create. When the going gets tough in the theatre, the audience can simply refuse to suspend its disbelief. We disengage; we know that we are sitting in a theatre and the people onstage are merely actors playing a role.

But not in the case of Bertrand's Toys, which arrives in London this week as the opening show in this year's London International Mime festival. Produced by a homeless, unfunded Moscow theatre company called blackSKYwhite Teatr, Bertrand's Toys is a terrifying 60 minutes of bizarre and freakish physical theatre in which mechanical toys, dolls, clowns and jack-in-the boxes come to life in the middle of the night.

There is nothing in the slightest bit winsome about the spectacle that follows. Illuminated by a single shaft of light, a clockwork doll - limbs jerking so violently that it is impossible to believe she could be a human actor - moves judderingly across the stage. She is both mesmerising and monstrous, and is followed by a parade of other marionette monsters who appear onstage as if arriving from the depths of hell. There is a featureless mannequin who is deaf, dumb and blind, a menacing joker and other deformed, freakish figures.

"It reflects the inner world of the people who look at it," says Dmitri Ariupin, BlackSKYwhite's founder and artistic director. "It is like seeing your own intestines. It's as cruel as only a mirror can be." Ariupin has been strongly influenced by the shock tactics of Antonin Artaud's Theatre of Cruelty, in which the audience is made to confront basic human nature, warts and all.

A chance meeting between Ariupin, Marcella Soltan and Andrej Ivashnev led to the setting up of BlackSKYwhite (originally known as Chernonebobeloe Teatr) 12 years ago. None of the founders had any professional experience of theatre but all had an urge to create a performance. They set about teaching and training themselves from scratch, spending five years studying the possibilities of the human body.

That this rigorous self-training has paid dividends is obvious from Bertrand's Toys. It is almost impossible to believe that Soltan and Ivashnev are the only performers in the piece, or that the human body can be bent and stretched in such a fashion.

Pressed on the difficulty of the piece, Ariupin quotes Mozart - "It is very simple to play piano. It is just necessary to press the right keys in the right time" - but he is inclined to be dismissive about the company's overall achievement.

"Even during those five years of training we were never interested in creating any kind of system. From the thousands of exercises we have created during the last 12 years we have fixed nothing. Everything is just an instrument to create a new performance. We have no connections. No politics. We have no messages and no concepts and no plots. I cannot say why theatre exists, but I don't believe it is there to teach the audience the best way to live."

Bertrand's Toys may not be able to teach you how to live, but it can certainly show you how you'd prefer not to die. Part of the power of the show is that the faceless marionettes are both what we fear most and yet also clearly ourselves.

They have a seductive beauty, so that while watching the show you have the sense of being lured into a trap and being quite unable to resist. You witness things that you would rather not see. The music pounds relentlessly, making it difficult to think clearly, and all the while you wonder about the unseen manipulator and the apparently absent Bertrand. If his toys are this grotesque and scary, what about their owner?

Ariupin says that Bertrand's Toys grew out of his own fear of serial killers and other bogeymen and a belief that evil really does exist. "For me the show is about the existence of people who have felt the abyss inside themselves, people who have been burnt out completely from the inside and become mere shells."

Certainly, for the show's 60 minutes you feel there is no escape, as if you have been forced to endure a terrible nightmare. As Ariupin says: "If it is a dream, then you will never wake up. If it is a reality, then where is the door leading out of this world?"

 Bertrand's Toys is at the Purcell Room, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), from Saturday till January 17, and Phoenix Arts, Leicester (0116-255 4854), on January 19 and 20.

webTitle: Comment: The incompetents

fields.headline: The incompetents
fields.standfirst:
Railways: A crucial public service is collapsing. What's to be done (as Lenin said)?

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railways: A crucial public service is collapsing. What's to be done (as Lenin said)?
fields.body:
As usual, Mother went too far. When I described my latest travel fiasco to her, she replied: "But Richard, the answer is simple: expropriate the railroads." Mother, I should explain, inhabits a peculiar corner of the left; she once described the fiery miners' leader Arthur Scargill as an "un homme sympatique", nicely blending worker solidarity and class distance. Still, she has a point.

For the past 20 years the private sector has claimed it could do a better job running essential public services than governmental functionaries. The privatisers draw a cartoonish contrast between lean, fit, profit-seeking organisations and slow, fat, time-serving public servants. We all know by now this is nonsense. Even in America, land of the free market, there has emerged a strong outcry against the shambolic workings of private health maintenance organisations.

Companies such as Railtrack are both incompetent and profitable. Part of the reason for this seeming paradox is that in the last decade, capital has become impatient. The average stock is held for eight months today; in 1975 it was held for 46 months. Since the shareholders are not interested in long-term results, the companies have little compulsion to deliver them. Impatient shareholders want immediate signs of change in a company, signals that the company is dynamic, in play. Cutting costs is high on this list, improved quality of service much lower.

Customer service stands low in the estimation that markets make of privatisation because travellers or patients are a captive audience. In the US a cancer patient has little chance of choosing among competitive service providers once he or she has embarked on treatment, no more than the rail commuter in Britain can choose among railways. There is no free market; rather, a move from public to private monopoly. The only rationale for making this monopoly transfer is that government is strapped for cash - which neither the American nor the British treasuries are.

The devil lurking in many privatisations is institutional knowledge loss. The markets want to see fresh faces and established procedures replaced by something new. The result, in any corporate re-engineering, entails losing the knowledge that accumulates through experience of how to make things work - the kind of knowledge that resembles customising a computer program.

In the public sector, with its complex thickets of rules and competing interests, the most important members of an organisation are the people who have learned to adapt a formal system to the needs of the public. Yet these old hands are the first to leave or to be pushed, like the senior doctors currently draining out of the national health service.

So what, in the words of Mother's favourite author, is to be done?

The government is currently pondering Lenin's question in thinking about Railtrack. Its chairman, Sir Philip Beck, has taken an indefensible position; he argues the company will not tolerate government "interference" in the choice of his successor, as reported in the Guardian on January 4. This claim is indefensible not only because the company is incompetent, but because it owes its very existence to the government, which handed it a private monopoly five years ago and will give the company a further £15bn over the next five years.

One way for the public to "interfere" is for Railtrack to issue new shares earmarked for government ownership. A more complicated route is a general shares issue, underwritten by the government, which raises more private money while the government buys a stake on the open market.

The best solution, in my view, is political rather than economic. Big German companies allot seats on their boards to unions; the idea could be extended by reserving seats on privatised services not only to unions or employee groups but even - even - to representatives of the public. To make this kind of renationalisation truly effective, government and public seats ought to outnumber private ones.

Beck and his ilk would moan, but who would want to invest in such a concern? German companies do not seem short of investors; moreover, big quasi-public institutional investors, such as the teacher's pension scheme TIAA-CREF in the United States, could easily take the place of short-term investors and day-traders. No public service company should be run to serve their impatient interests. Equally, services such as the tube or the air control system should not be privatised at all, if the pursuit of immediate profit is going to entail lower performance or lessened public accountability.

I once proposed something like this political plan to a task force on American private medical insurance, chaired by Hillary Clinton. Her minion at the meeting stared at me blankly then said: "But that would be socialism." Well, yes. But I had, I think, done Mother proud.

 Richard Sennett, formerly professor of sociology at New York University, is now professor of sociology at the London School of Economics .

In the US a cancer patient has little chance of choosing among competitive service providers once he or she has embarked on treatment, no more than the rail commuter in Britain can choose among railways. There is no free market; rather, a move from public to private monopoly. The only rationale for making this monopoly transfer is that government is strapped for cash - which neither the American nor the British treasuries are. The devil lurking in many privatisations is institutional knowledge loss. The markets want to see fresh faces and established procedures replaced by something new. The result, in any corporate re-engineering, entails losing the knowledge that accumulates through experience of how to make things work - the kind of knowledge that resembles customising a computer program. In the public sector, with its complex thickets of rules and competing interests, the most important members of an organisation are the people who have learned to adapt a formal system to the needs of the public. Yet these old hands are the first to leave or to be pushed, like the senior doctors currently draining out of the national health service. So what, in the words of Mother's favourite author, is to be done? The government is currently pondering Lenin's question in thinking about Railtrack. Its chairman, Sir Philip Beck, has taken an indefensible position; he argues the company will not tolerate government "interference" in the choice of his successor, as reported in the Guardian on January 4. This claim is indefensible not only because the company is incompetent, but because it owes its very existence to the government, which handed it a private monopoly five years ago and will give the company a further £15bn over the next five years. One way for the public to "interfere" is for Railtrack to issue new shares earmarked for government ownership. A more complicated route is a general shares issue, underwritten by the government, which raises more private money while the government buys a stake on the open market. The best solution, in my view, is political rather than economic. Big German companies allot seats on their boards to unions; the idea could be extended by reserving seats on privatised services not only to unions or employee groups but even - even - to representatives of the public. To make this kind of renationalisation truly effective, government and public seats ought to outnumber private ones. Beck and his ilk would moan, but who would want to invest in such a concern? German companies do not seem short of investors; moreover, big quasi-public institutional investors, such as the teacher's pension scheme TIAA-CREF in the United States, could easily take the place of short-term investors and day-traders. No public service company should be run to serve their impatient interests. Equally, services such as the tube or the air control system should not be privatised at all, if the pursuit of immediate profit is going to entail lower performance or lessened public accountability. I once proposed something like this political plan to a task force on American private medical insurance, chaired by Hillary Clinton. Her minion at the meeting stared at me blankly then said: "But that would be socialism." Well, yes. But I had, I think, done Mother proud.  Richard Sennett, formerly professor of sociology at New York University, is now professor of sociology at the London School of Economics . webTitle: Arts: British theatre is booming

fields.headline: We've never had it so good
fields.standfirst: This is a golden age of playwriting. Britain's theatres - especially its small theatres - are awash with talent. So why has nobody noticed, asks director  Dominic Dromgoole
fields.trailText: This is a golden age of playwriting. Britain's theatres - especially its small theatres - are awash with talent. So why has nobody noticed, asks director Dominic Dromgoole.
fields.body:
The 1990s was a decade of renaissance in playwriting. That is beyond question to all but the most deliberately obtuse. For a few happy years, plays were popping up all over the place. You never knew where you would next enjoy a new voice and a treasured evening next - it could be in Manchester, in Glasgow, in Dublin, in London; it could be at the Finborough, the Bush, the Royal Court, the Royal Shakespeare Company, the Old Red Lion; it could come from the multicultural argot of a south London estate or from an etiolated tradition of Oxbridge erudition. Theatre's greatest asset, its capacity to surprise and to shock you with your own stupidity, was never more in evidence.

An extraordinary energy was rolling in, wave after wave of new plays. Many of them were unspeakable, but every seventh wave washed up a gem, and the occasional tsunami bore a revelation. Where that energy came from, nobody knows. My guess is that its source was the world, rather than the theatre, and it could not be unconnected to the upheavals that shook the world at the end of the 1980s.

There was a joke at the time about how overearnest theatre people would connect everything they did to something earth-shattering. A couple playing Judith and David Bliss in Hayfever would suddenly turn to each other with a revelatory insight: "My god, it's just like the Ceasescus!"; or a director would instruct his Henry IV and Bolingbroke: "OK - you're Gorbachev and you're Yeltsin. Think coup!"

The comparisons were of course inflated and silly, but they revealed a truth - that theatre felt then and feels now the pressure of the time more acutely than the other arts. The 1990s couldn't fail to bear the fruit of the spirit and rhythms of history's brief quickstep.

As tyrants bled into the snow and walls crumbled, a whole collection of our own certainties and rules fell to pieces. Theatre is inherently political - it has to address an audience and share its air - and it must respond to political change.

When the world announced to itself that the old politics was a construct, a lie told by bitter old men to create unnecessary division among the young - when those politics effectively ceased to exist - a door swung open to a whole new world.

A world to be addressed in new terms - those of the spirit, of identity, of individual morality, of imagination and sensuality. And of course a whole new politics. These are the terms that theatre is ideally placed to use.

Plays with a new form, new content and new ideas suddenly emerged. First there was a resistance, later a welcoming, then a blooming and, as the energy waned, a last stage of exploitation. The final - inevitable - stage is the sad one where those who initially scoffed at the new smell the change in fashion, and decide to buy up the innovations of others, softly and cannily diluting them for a wider audience.

One of the most exhilarating qualities of the early 1990s was the breadth of origin of the writers. There was a real sense of the enfranchisement of a whole class into the theatre. Rather than one brilliant, surprising and fresh Andrea Dunbar in a year, there would be five, 10 or 20, among them Richard Cameron, Jonathan Harvey, Catherine Johnson, Billy Roche and David Eldridge. There was also a profusion of dark imaginers, of wild spirits: Philip Ridley, David Ashton, James Stock, Anthony Nielsen, Biyi Bandele, Chris Hannan and many others. And there were the historians who brought a breadth of imagination into their large parables, among them Tony Kushner, Helen Edmundson, April de Angelis, Naomi Wallace and David Harrower.

Beyond these new voices there is of course a wealth of talent and genius in our theatrical tradition that long pre-dates the 1990s. My book, The Full Room: An A-Z of Contemporary Playwriting, is as ardent about Pinter, Ayckbourn, Stoppard, Arden, Mamet, Miller, Storey, Churchill, Griffiths and many more, as it is about any of the newcomers. Just to write the names above is an act of pleasure.

Even with all that it excludes, the book is a record of a time when there were more great playwrights than ever in the history of the craft. We spend far too little time celebrating that simple fact. This must be a golden age by dint of sheer number.

"Yes, there may be many, but where are the few?" theatre's self-appointed Olympians will always ask. "Where are the truly great plays?" The truth is none of us know, and we can only hope that time is a judicious sieve, and will sort out the fakes from the true. Where I do feel fairly certain is in my optimism that time's list of what is great will not concord with fashion's. There are essentially two rivers running through the history of playwriting.

Tributaries run between the two, but they remain essentially separate. There are those who write about life, and there are those who write life. If there is one thing that draws together all the writers named above - as diverse a list as you could wish for - it is that they all write life. This has nothing to do with kettles or kitchen sinks. They can write life on the moon, in history, in Wonderland or in Walthamstow, but they write life, they create it, they make it happen anew in front of an audience.

If there is anything that coheres the aesthetic of The Full Room (and I hope there isn't - there's too much coherence in the world already), it is that this is the mark of great writing, the ability to write life. It is only life that will always surprise, and only surprise that will always replenish.

But the ability to write life is not the entry card to fashion's top 10. That is reserved for the other school of writer, those who write about life. For some reason that mystifies me our culture continues to promote journalists, analysts and essayists above artists. For some reason we prefer to celebrate not the creators, but those who keep life at one remove.

One of the greatest plays of the 1990s was a modest piece called Uganda by Judith Johnson, which played for three weeks at the Royal Court's Theatre Upstairs. One of the greatest of the 1980s was Singer by Peter Flannery. One of the pre-eminent postwar playwrights is David Storey. How often do these authors feature on top 10 lists? Too rarely, and mainly because they don't work for them. Profile, across a wider range than just playwriting, is often thought to be a result of talent. It is not.

It is a matter of hard graft by those who want it. It is a matter of hanging about at press nights; joining boards and appearing on endless platforms, panels and television shows; writing books about your own genius and filling in as many "My Book of the Year" submissions as you can get your hands on. We all perceive the nakedness of the greed and desire in these self-promoters, but we all eventually give in, just out of exhaustion, as if to a persistent seducer, and wearily relent: "Yes, all right, you are a great playwright/actress/film director. Now please, be quiet a moment. I'm trying to think."

There are 112 essays on as many playwrights in my book, of which only nine are on balance negative. Those nine all figure in the ranks of those who write about life. It is unfortunate (in that it encourages snap judgments of the book) that they are also among the best known and the most ardent self-promoters.

There is of course an honourable tradition of playwrights who write about life, who promote themselves, and draw the praise of today, if not tomorrow. The river that bears Euripides, Ben Jonson and Shaw is not a bad one to risk your brand-new canoe in, even if others risk the naked night swim in the rougher river that bore Sophocles and Shakespeare and Chekhov. Discursive, digressive, prismatic work has a place, of course. Life has another.

But, no matter, negative thoughts aside, there were and are too many truly great new writers to list. The richness, the range, the fancy, the heart and the soul that have been on view have been breathtaking. If the energy has ebbed a little of late, no doubt it will return again soon. It has a newly politicised world to respond to now. And if the results build on the platform of what has been achieved already, we are in for treats. And, most importantly, for surprises.

 The Full Room: An A-Z of Contemporary Playwriting by Dominic Dromgoole is published by Methuen at £18.99.

webTitle: Obituary: John Carter

fields.headline: John Carter
fields.trailText: Frequently at loggerheads with the Guild of Showmen,  he founded an independent association of roundabout operators to speak for the mavericks.
fields.body:
The Saturday night lads sometimes turned up at Carter's Royal Berkshire Steam Fair drunk and spoiling for a fight. It was usually enough for John Carter, who has died aged 59, simply to stand in front of them, blotting out a large part of the night sky, for the troublemakers to slink away.

John and his wife, Anna, started their travelling fair only in 1977. But it was so convincing, particularly at night when the steam engines filled the air with belching smoke and showers of sparks, that most people took it to be a miraculous survival from Victorian times.

Carter himself could have stepped from a fairground illustration, a gigantic figure with an Old Testament prophet's beard, sleeves rolled up over massively muscled arms, belted and braced. He was, in fact, a rank outsider, and frequently at loggerheads with the Guild of Showmen, representing generations of fairground ride operators and regulating a circuit of fairs where pitches pass from father to son. He founded an independent association of roundabout operators to speak for the mavericks.

Born in Windsor, the son of a police sergeant, he studied at the Berkshire College of Art and won a place at the Slade, but never graduated. He was already spending too many days at stock car races and steam rallies, collecting classic American cars, vintage motor bikes, jazz records and slot machines. He funded his hobbies by working for several years as a court bailiff.

In 1976, he found a derelict set of Victorian gallopers - he just tolerated the term "roundabout"; anyone who used the American "carousel" was in trouble - rotting in a Buckinghamshire park. The first slot machine collection was sold to buy and restore the ride to its gold and crimson steam-powered glory.

Initially, he intended it simply as an extra attraction at his rallies and collectors' fairs, but more Victorian, Edwardian and early 20th-century rides followed, rescued from warehouses, scrap yards, and tumbledown sheds, including several which were unique survivors.

Carter was a great ranter - he was disgusted with Mrs Thatcher because, in wrecking the Welsh mining industry, she destroyed his source of good, steam coal - but he valued craftsmanship, in a tenor sax solo, a wooden horse's tossing mane, a piece of journalism, or a nicely machined piston.

Sadly, last July bone cancer was diagnosed, and he was given 10 days to live. The beard and flowing locks went and he dwindled to 18 stone. But when we met in the last weeks of his life, he was triumphant at beating the medical experts' odds - and delivered a diatribe on the shoddiness of workmanship since decimal currency destroyed the slot machine.

He is survived by Anna, an expert on fairground art, and their five children, Zed, Seth and Joby, who live and work on the fair, Amber and Rosie.

: John Carter, steam fair proprietor, born 1941; died December 17 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Daniel Singer

fields.headline: Daniel Singer
fields.standfirst: Gifted commentator on the French political scene
fields.trailText: Gifted commentator on the French political scene.
fields.body:
Daniel Singer, who has died in Paris aged 74, had all the qualities of a great journalist. Writing for the Economist in Britain, and for the Nation in the United States, his articles were forceful, well-informed and revealing. He made his readers reflect, influenced their thinking and had the essential quality of being, at times, controversial. He was a historian and a political thinker; an intellectual who longed for, and dreamed of, action.

The son of Bernard Singer, himself a famous journalist, Daniel was born in Warsaw, but found himself, with his mother, in France when war broke out. They took refuge in the south after the armistice, but were tracked down by the French police. With the help of the resistance, they escaped to Switzerland. Bernard Singer, who had been imprisoned by the Russians, was released after the Nazi attack on the Soviet Union, and made his way to London. Daniel studied in Geneva until after the war, when he joined his father.

Leftwing politics and discussions were the vogue in postwar London, and Daniel formed a lasting friendship with the Marxist historian Isaac Deutscher. It was, in part, thanks to his influence that Singer began to work for the Economist in 1948. He wrote about eastern Europe, especially Poland and the Soviet Union, but was always particularly interested in France.

In 1956, he married a French expert on economic matters, Jeanne Kérel (who survives him), and his ambition to become Paris correspondent of the Economist was realised two years later.

The political situation of France in 1958 was particularly dramatic. Singer was only moderately impressed by General de Gaulle, who was in danger of mistaking "the France of today for the France in the world of 1919". As the general was enthroned as president of the republic, Singer wrote that "the stroke of retrenchment that the French economy needs most is in General de Gaulle's own idea of national ambition".

What interested him was the inactivity of the French Communist party (PCF). It would have been possible to prevent de Gaulle from coming to power if the party had supported, or at least tolerated, a government that functioned with the normal parliamentary majority.

Singer was fascinated by all those movements that were disillusioned by the PCF and the Soviet Union, whether they were Trotskyist, anarchist or inspired by the new humanistic or structuralist versions of Marxism. He took an active part in all these discussions, while remaining devoted, as he had been since his youth, to the Polish-born revolutionary socialist Rosa Luxemburg.

The student revolts of 1968, and the strikes that followed, seemed to fulfil Singer's dreams of mass revolution aimed at freedom. In 1970, he published Prelude To Revolution, a challenging and defiant book that hailed the events as quickening the pace of historical change in Europe. He proclaimed that the PCF had been shown to be a bureaucratic, anti-revolutionary organisation, and that the students and workers could proudly look forward to the future.

The first effect of May 1968 was the rejection of de Gaulle, and, in a longer perspective, Singer believed that the year's events had asserted the importance of rights, a point of view that seemed to be confirmed in November 1986, when some 600,000 students protested successfully against the proposed Devaquet law introducing a selection process to university recruitment.

Although Singer lived in the Rue Bièvre in Paris, the same street as François Mitterrand, he did not admire his presidency. In 1988, he published Is Socialism Doomed? The Meaning Of Mitterrand, which attacked the president for the decline of the non-communist left, and for his lack of ideas and ideals.

After 1970, Singer worked for the Nation. He continued to write, and to follow the ideas of Rosa Luxemburg; his last book, Whose Millennium: Theirs Or Yours?, put forward an alternative to capitalism and to the notion that we had reached the end of history.

At his request, the announcement of his death was accompanied by a quotation from Luxemburg: "Tomorrow, the revolution will raise its head again, Proclaiming to your horror amidst a blaze of trumpets, I was, I am, I always shall be."

webTitle: Obituary: Florynce Kennedy

fields.headline: Florynce Kennedy
fields.trailText: Once called "the biggest, loudest and, indisputably the rudest, mouth on the battleground where feminist-activists and radical politics join in mostly common cause".
fields.body:
Florynce Kennedy - Flo to friend and enemy alike - who has died aged 84, was once called "the biggest, loudest and, indisputably the rudest, mouth on the battleground where feminist- activists and radical politics join in mostly common cause".

Born in Kansas City, Missouri, she was the second of five daughters of Wiley and Zella Kennedy, who were part of the "pooristocrats" of the black community and taught their children to stand up for themselves. Flo finished top of her class at Lincoln high school in 1934, after which she ran a hat shop, performed on a radio show and operated a lift.

After her mother died in 1942, she moved to New York to live with her sister, Grayce. She graduated from Columbia University in 1948, but was denied admission to the law school - a decision only reversed after she threatened legal action on grounds of racial discrimination. She was the only black person among just eight women in her class. After graduating in 1951, she established her own practice, eventually representing the estates of Billie Holiday and Charlie Parker, and the black power leader H Rap Brown.

Though not a strong supporter of wedlock, she married Charles Dudley Dye in 1957; his alcoholism made it a short-lived union. She never remarried or had children.

Kennedy's political involvement took shape as she began to entertain doubts about her profession, and whether justice was possible when courts themselves were bigoted: "Not only was I not earning a decent living, there began to be a serious question in my mind whether practising law could ever be an effective means of changing society or even of simple resistance to oppression." In 1966, she founded the National Organization for Women (Now) and created the Media Workshop to fight media discrimination.

The following year, she took to the stage at an anti-Vietnam war convention in Montreal to protest at the refusal to allow the black radical, Bobby Seale, to discuss racism. The action marked the beginning of a speaking career characterised by bluntly effective utterances, whose impact was the greater when combined with her unconventional dress style, which often featured cowboy hat and boots.

Kennedy's mission was to tell it like it was, combined with advocacy of direct action. This unfailingly drew attention to her concerns, which, beyond sexism and racism, also included championing the civil liberties of homosexuals, prostitutes and other minorities.

"Don't agonise, organise," she proclaimed. "Niggerisation is the result of oppression - and it doesn't just apply to the black people. Old people, poor people and students can also get niggerised . . . There are very few jobs that actually require a penis or a vagina. All other jobs should be open to everybody."

In 1971, Kennedy formed the Feminist party, which lent support to Shirley Chisholm as a US presidential candidate, and, in 1975, founded the National Black Feminist Organisation. She was a member of the legal team instrumental in liberalising the New York state abortion laws, and co-authored one of the first books on the topic, Abortion Rap.

As leader of the Consumer Coalition, she campaigned to influence the output of US television in favour of women, minorities and better programming: "These people who programme television for the consumption of the world audience should look around the world and see what's wrong with it. If we are successful in our fight to alter the pattern of television here in America, I would hope that we would come to know as much about the African woman as we know about football, basketball and tennis."

Kennedy was never afraid to tackle the biggest causes and, though increasing health problems left her bedridden by the late 1990s, her crusading spirit remained undampened. Her autobiography, Color Me Flo: My Hard Life And Good Times (1976), contains this unapologetic self-description: "I'm just a loud-mouthed, middle-aged, colored lady with a fused spine and three feet of intestine missing, and a lot of people think I'm crazy. Maybe you do too, but I never stop to wonder why I'm not like other people. The mystery to me is why more people aren't like me."

 Florynce Rae Kennedy, lawyer and activist, born February 11 1916; died December 21 2000

webTitle: Drug tests at work would cut illicit use, doctors claim

fields.headline: Drug tests at work would cut illicit use, doctors claim
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The drug-testing of employees at work would have a big impact on cutting illicit drug use in Britain, according to the findings of a medical report to be debated at a conference on drugs today.
fields.body:
The drug-testing of employees at work would have a big impact on cutting illicit drug use in Britain, according to the findings of a medical report to be debated at a conference on drugs today.

The report by the royal colleges of psychiatrists and physicians said that although there were complex legal and ethical issues concerning companies regularly drug-testing their staff, the technology did exist for such an idea to be a realistic proposition.

"It would provide a record of drug use over the previous three months and could, therefore, have a major impact on the prevalence of drug use in the future," the royal colleges' working party concluded in its report for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

The working party was chaired by the former chief medical officer for Scotland, Robert Kendall. It will present its findings at the Joseph Rowntree Foundation conference in London today.

The report also warned that the government's ambitious target to cut heroin and cocaine abuse among young people by 50% by 2008 was unlikely to be achieved without a much stronger ministerial commitment to invest in drug prevention programmes.

The report echoed the findings of the Police Foundation report into the future of the drugs laws in concluding that cannabis was almost certainly less damaging to health than tobacco or alcohol, and backing the decriminalisation of it for medical purposes.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, dismissed one of the Police Foundation's main recommendations - to reclassify cannabis so that those found guilty of possession were no longer sent to prison - within hours of the report's publication last March.

Dame Ruth Runciman, one of its authors, said she was disappointed that 10 months later the government had yet to give its considered response to all its recommendations.

"Our proposals are firmly located in the common sense and undogmatic middle ground between unrealistic legislation on one side and an unwinnable war on drugs on the other. That is also the territory on which any rational debate must be conducted."

She warned that if Mr Straw's considered opinion simply echoed his early rejection then it would be no more than a cherry picking exercise which ignored the proposals to reform the drugs laws based on a more realistic "hierarchy of harm".

A Home Office spokeswoman said the official response to the Police Foundation report would be published shortly.

webTitle: Treat crowds with respect to avoid riots, police told

fields.headline: Treat crowds with respect to avoid riots, police told
fields.standfirst:
Psychologists warn authorities of dangers of treating crowds as mindless hooligans and relying on blanket profiles of suspects

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Psychologists warn authorities of dangers of treating crowds as mindless hooligans and relying on blanket profiles of suspects.
fields.body:
Police could do much more to stop demonstrations erupting into violence if they had a greater understanding of the subtle dynamics at work in large crowds, a conference in Liverpool was told yesterday.

Researchers who have studied disturbances such as the anti-capitalism riot in the City of London in 1999 challenged the notion that trouble was usually caused by a handful of well-organised activists. They claimed that violence tended to flair up if normally law-abiding citizens felt they were being treated as a dangerous, anonymous mass. Such treatment inevitably provoked them into acting exactly in that way.

The researchers argued that historically the authorities had assumed that a crowd was a primitive, "pathological" mass - either that it was made up of individuals compulsively motivated or that in a crowd everybody became "pathological". But close study of disturbances such as the anti- capitalist demonstration and football violence, had shown a different picture.

Steve Reicher, of St Andrew's University, told a conference of investigative psychologists at Liverpool University that most crowds contained a variety of smaller groupings with different values and outlooks. The dynamics of how the crowd acted depended on how it was perceived and treated.

Professor Reicher, who worked with the Association of Chief Police Officers and the Metropolitan police, said: "If you pre-suppose that a crowd is dangerous and pathological then it's bound to be like that."

Clifford Stott, a lecturer in psychology at Liverpool University, said that the clashes between the police and the demonstrators in the poll tax riot had led to changes in the nature of the participants' social identity. Those who had previously rejected violence began to see fighting with the police as both possible and even proper. He said: "There was a tendency by the police to be indiscriminate. This aggravated the crowd and people felt their legitimate right to protest was compromised. It changed their view about how they felt about violence."

Dr Stott also studied football hooliganism and found similar patterns. He pointed out there was no reason why England fans and Scotland fans should act so differently abroad, but while Scots were welcomed most places, the arrival of England fans was greeted with fear. Dr Stott believed England fans tended to misbehave not because a hard core of hooligans organised the violence but because they were treated as a dangerous mass. Because the Scots fans were treated with respect they did not cause trouble.

The riot that occurred during an anti-capitalist demonstration in London's City area in June 1999 was also examined at the conference. Forty-four people were injured and £2m of damage was caused as protesters went on the rampage. A police review soon after blamed the commanding officers' lack of experience, failure in communication, and the sheer scale of the violence, for the policing errors on the day.

Research by Patrick Cronin, of St Andrews University, concluded that officers' decisions on the day were guided by differing ideas on accountability and that those differences led to confusion. Similarly, the City of Police had looked to protecting City institutions in the Square Mile, while the Met felt more beholden to the Home Office. The research has been passed to the police.

The researchers agreed the starting point for the police and other authorities dealing with crowds ought to focus on how they should help the crowd achieve its aims.

Professor Reicher said: "The police need to ask, how can we facilitate the legitimate aims of the majority - not how can we contain the minority."

webTitle: Crime profilers' efforts denounced as crackers

fields.headline: Crime profilers' efforts denounced as crackers
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Vague descriptions in criminal profiles which are frequently used by detectives to trace suspects often trick officers in exactly the same way that bogus fortune-tellers and astrologers deceive their clients, psychologists revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Vague descriptions in criminal profiles which are frequently used by detectives to trace suspects often trick officers in exactly the same way that bogus fortune-tellers and astrologers deceive their clients, psychologists revealed yesterday.

Most big criminal investigations now involve psychologists who, like the television character Cracker, draw up a profile of the offender.

But research presented yesterday suggested many profiles were so vague that they could apply to any number of suspects. Perhaps more worryingly, in experiments police officers seemed to mould whatever information was supplied in a profile to fit in with what was definitely known about an offender. The researchers called for more guidance to be given to police on how they should use such profiles.

The starting point for the research, revealed at the conference of investigative psychology at Liverpool University, was the long-accepted theory that people tend to accept vague and ambiguous personality descriptions as uniquely applicable to themselves, not realising the description could be applied to almost anyone.

Astrologers and fortune-tellers are often accused of using this tendency to make their predictions believed. Psychologists know the trait as the "Barnum effect" after PT Barnum's claim that his circus had "a little something for everyone".

Experts from Liverpool and Liverpool Hope universities wanted to find out if the Barnum effect could be applied to police officers using criminal profiles.

webTitle: Obituary: Les Brown

fields.headline: Les Brown
fields.standfirst: His Band of Renown launched Doris Day and lived to see the dance band revival
fields.trailText: His Band of Renown launched Doris Day and lived to see the dance band revival.
fields.body:
In terms of public acclaim and record sales, the career of the bandleader Les Brown, who has died of lung cancer aged 88, took off in the 1940s, towards the end of the dance band era. As musical tastes changed, ballrooms with stages built to contain brass and reed sections would soon disappear, taking from such bands their most obvious source of regular income.

Several, however, devised ways of carrying on far beyond what seemed their sell-by dates, and none more so than Brown: in 1996, the Guinness Book Of World Records credited him with having led the longest-lasting musical organisation in popular music history. During 50-plus years as a bandleader, he was, among much else, responsible for launching Doris Day on the road to stardom.

Brown was born in Tower City, Pennsylvania. His father, a baker who was also a skilled musician, tried to interest all his sons in music. Les took to the soprano saxophone, and was playing in his father's band before he was 10. With his father's encouragement, he dropped out of school to study at the Ithaca Conservatory of Music, where he played in the orchestra and started a big band, for which he wrote the arrangements.

In 1929, he went to the New York Military Academy on a scholarship before switching to Duke University, having been headhunted by their big band, the Duke Blue Devils. He soon became leader, and the band was considered good enough to record commercially.

After Duke, Brown settled in New York, arranging for Isham Jones, among others. In 1938, he was invited by Eli Oberstein, of Victor Records, to take a band into a Broadway hotel, from which the music was relayed over national radio. A contract with Victor's subsidiary Bluebird label followed, a deal arranged by Louis Armstrong's agent, Joe Glaser.

The band was clearly being groomed for stardom - Glaser recruited the top trumpeter Billy Butterfield, and the drummer Shelley Manne was briefly a member - but the catalyst was the teenage Doris Day, who joined in 1940. Her voice gave the band an audience rapport that continued when she temporarily left.

Soon after, Brown had his first big record success, Joltin' Joe DiMaggio, named for the baseball star's 1941 achievement of striking at least one base hit for an unprecedented 56 consecutive games. Brown's arranger, Ben Homan, who wrote the number with disc jockey Alan Courtney, later came up with Sentimental Journey, recorded in 1946. Brown himself contributed to the tune and, with Doris Day back to sing the words written by Bud Green, Sentimental Journey became a massive hit, not least with returning war veterans. It topped the hit parade and stayed in the charts for months.

That success put the band, now known as Les Brown And The Band Of Renown, into the big time. However, Brown decided to break it up while he relocated to Los Angeles.

The break proved shorter than expected: a booking had been arranged for the Hollywood Palladium in 1946 and, the following year, he and his new band were asked to back Bob Hope's radio show. The money involved was less than Brown could earn on tour, but he was tired of travelling and wanted to see more of his family. He made the right choice; the band business, as he had known it, soon collapsed.

This association of Hope and Brown lasted to the end, taking in Hope's military tours from 1950; a television documentary was made of their 1966 Christmas show entertaining troops in Vietnam. The band had another hit in Skippy Martin's bouncy arrangement of I've Got My Love To Keep Me Warm and, in 1949, Hope reunited Brown with Doris Day, by now a Hollywood star, for a national tour. Brown also backed Dean Martin and Steve Allen on TV shows, and performed annually at Disneyland from its 1955 opening, as well as benefiting from a renewed interest in ballroom dancing.

With his son, Les Jr, occasionally filling in, Brown continued to lead in person until very recently. As president of the Los Angeles chapter of the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, he engaged the support of Bing Crosby, Hope and Frank Sinatra in getting the Naras's Grammy Awards televised.

Brown's appeal ranged from swinging jazz, performed somewhat in the manner of Woody Herman, to ballads, novelties and comedy items involving Butch Stone or the leader's brother Stubby Brown. Among the better-known jazz musicians involved at times were Ted Nash and Dave Pell on saxophones, trombonist Ray Sims, clarinettist Abe Most and drummer Jack Sperling. Singers after Doris Day included Lucy Ann Polk and Jo Ann Greer.

Brown is survived by his wife Evelyn and his son and daughter.

 Les Brown, musician and bandleader, born March 14 1912; died January 4 2001

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Turkey said yesterday that its security forces had killed more than 23,000 separatist Kurdish rebels since establishing an emergency rule zone in the country's mainly Kurdish south-east 14 years ago.
fields.body:
Turkey 'killed 23,000 rebels'

Turkey said yesterday that its security forces had killed more than 23,000 separatist Kurdish rebels since establishing an emergency rule zone in the country's mainly Kurdish south-east 14 years ago.

The Kurdistan Workers' party rebel group took up arms for autonomy in 1984, but scaled back its demands to cultural rights after Turkey captured its leader, Abdullah Ocalan, and sentenced him to death in 1999. Since then, clashes have dropped off significantly.

Reuters, Diyarbakir

Tension on Burma border

Bangladesh sent reinforcements to its border with Burma yesterday, amid fears of renewed hostilities between Dhaka and Rangoon.

The deployment followed an exchange of heavy gunfire between border guards on Monday over Burma's building of an embankment in a disputed area of the Naf river, which lies on the boundary.

Six weeks ago an armed conflict was narrowly avoided after seven Bangladeshis were killed by landmines laid along the border by Burma.

Arshad Mahmud, Dhaka

Plea to tackle plane syndrome

Walking machines should be put on planes flying long-haul routes to help passengers avoid potentially fatal "economy class syndrome", an Australian politician said yesterday.

The proposal from Neil O'Keefe, an opposition MP, comes amid concern about passengers on planes developing deep vein thrombosis after sitting in cramped seats for hours.

Australian lawyers are preparing a lawsuit on behalf of some 800 people seeking damages over deaths and injuries allegedly caused by the condition.

AP, Sydney

30 injured in Kashmir blast

webTitle: Virtual Internet beefs up its board

fields.headline: Virtual Internet beefs up its board
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Virtual Internet, the domain name, brand and trademark group that suffered an alarming slump in its share price last year, yesterday moved to beef up its board by appointing former LineOne boss Ajay Chowdhury.
fields.body:
Virtual Internet, the domain name, brand and trademark group that suffered an alarming slump in its share price last year, yesterday moved to beef up its board by appointing former LineOne boss Ajay Chowdhury.

Mr Chowdhury - who left LineOne last spring - joins Virtual Internet with the firm insisting it has turned the corner after a period when the launch of promising new products has been delayed and losses have widened.

"Virtual Internet has made encouraging progress during a very turbulent period, growing revenue base ahead of the revised expectations indicated at the half year," said chairman William Slee.

Figures for the year to October 31 showed losses widening from £1.26m to £4.3m but revenues more than trebling to £6.26m.

Mr Slee said that Virtual Internet was "relatively immune" from the series of dot.com collapses because of the increasing number of established brands looking to protect and enhance their online image.

The likely introduction of new domains such as dot.biz, dot.info and dot.pro to go alongside dot.com, dot.net and dot.org should also fuel demand for its services, Mr Slee claimed. The business has £19m cash in the bank after raising £25m in April as it moved from the junior AIM market up to the full stock exchange list.

The shares edged up 7.5p to 122p last night but remain a long way off the highs of last year when they traded at more than £9, valuing founder Jason Drummond's stake at around £120m.

At the time BT was strongly rumoured to have been considering a takeover bid for the five-year old firm. Mr Drummond's shares are now worth £15m.

webTitle: Bush labour nominee pulls out

fields.headline: Bush labour nominee pulls out
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush suffered the first major defeat of his presidency last night before it has even begun, when his nominee for labour secretary was forced to withdraw.
fields.body:
George W Bush suffered the first major defeat of his presidency last night before it has even begun, when his nominee for labour secretary was forced to withdraw after failing to tell investigators the truth about an illegal immigrant who lived in her house in the early 1990s.

A still defiant Linda Chavez threw in the towel last night following 48 hours in which it had become increasingly clear that she had hidden some of the key facts about her relationship with a Guatemalan woman, Marta Mercado, from Mr Bush's vetting officials. But not before Ms Chavez launched a stinging attack on "the game of search and destroy" which she blamed for her downfall.

The central issue in the mounting furore was originally whether Ms Chavez knew that Ms Mercado was an illegal immigrant and whether Ms Chavez had employed her for household jobs in defiance of the labour laws which she had been nominated to enforce.

But it also emerged yesterday that Ms Chavez had kept the fact that Ms Mercado was an illegal immigrant secret from Bush officials and FBI agents who had vetted her before her nomination was announced. In addition, Ms Chavez coached a Maryland neighbour to back up her version of events if questioned by vetting officials or the press, the Wall Street Journal reported yesterday.

"I think I always knew that she was here illegally," Ms Chavez admitted during questions from reporters.

These deceptions appear to have been what sealed her fate, causing the Bush campaign to abandon Monday's efforts to back their nominee and instead to throw her to the wolves.

"I have decided I am becoming a distraction and therefore I have asked President Bush to withdraw my nomination," Ms Chavez told a press conference in Washington, at which she appeared accompanied by a succession of immigrant Americans whom she had helped over the years.

But Ms Chavez did not leave the stage without firing a few volleys at the press. "I think that what has happened over the past few days is quite typical of what happens in Washington DC and unfortunately is very typical of what has happened in politics in America today," she said. Her fall was another example of the "politics of personal destruction", she claimed.

Ms Chavez's withdrawal is a severe short-term blow to Mr Bush, who campaigned on the need to "restore honour and integrity" to American government.

In the long term, however, Mr Bush is less likely to dwell on the episode than are his conservative supporters. The original choice of Ms Chavez, a high profile campaigner and commentator, was a calculated concession to the Republican party's conservative wing.

Mr Bush is certain to be criticised by rightwingers for not standing up for Ms Chavez, not least after she refused to go without a fight, and for "giving in to the left", as one conservative campaigner put it.

Mr Bush is likely to look for a less high profile and less controversial candidate in order to avoid making the same mistake twice. Speculation in Washington last night was that the former Republican congressman Jim Talent of Missouri, a labour lawyer, was a front runner.

The silver lining for the Bush administration is that the row about Ms Chavez has taken the heat off his controversial nomination of the conservative ex-senator John Ashcroft as his attorney general, at least for the time being.

Yesterday a coalition of liberal pressure groups announced that more than 200 organisations had formed an alliance to fight Mr Ashcroft's nomination. The groups include civil liberties, environmental, gun control and women's organisations.

webTitle: Rail repairs close delivery centre

fields.headline: Rail repairs close delivery centre
fields.trailText: The Post Office last week suffered its worst delays as a result of rail repairs and floods.
fields.body:
The Post Office last week suffered its worst delays as a result of rail repairs and floods.

Neville Bain, Post Office chairman, said Willesden, its main rail distribution centre, was out of operation for days and even now was only partly functional.

As a result, next-day delivery of first class mail had fallen from 91% last year to about 85% now. About a quarter of all mail is usually transported by train.

Railtrack initially initially informed the Post Office, the railways' biggest customer, that it would have no access to the Willesden depot between Christmas and the new year. This was changed to 70% access after the Post Office protested. But this plan failed and there was no access on a number of days.

The repair work is still going on and some mail trains are being delayed by up to six hours, resulting in first class delivery times being missed.

The Post Office is entitled to compensation from English Welsh and Scottish Railways - one of the two rail freight companies - under a performance-related contract. But it also wants payment for the £500,000 a week cost of additional road and air services and for loss of business and damage to its reputation.

webTitle: Companies admit foreign bribes

fields.headline: Companies admit foreign bribes
fields.trailText: Multi-national companies, including BP and Unilever, yesterday admitted paying small bribes known as "facilitating payments" and "petty dispersals" to get results in developing countries, but denied it was the slippery slope to full-scale corruption.
fields.body:
Multi-national companies, including BP and Unilever, yesterday admitted paying small bribes known as "facilitating payments" and "petty dispersals" to get results in developing countries, but denied it was the slippery slope to full-scale corruption.

In evidence to a Commons committee investigating overseas corruption, executives for six leading firms suggested that such payments were "tolerated, not encouraged", and were made in line with local practice to get a phone line or similar service installed.

Reg Hinkley, group vice president and general auditor of oil company BP Amoco, told the international development select committee that managers often had to make judgments in difficult situations.

Such payments may be made sometimes to prevent delays, rather than to gain an unfair advantage over competitors. "I don't think it's the beginning of a slippery slope - it's not something that we like," Mr Hinkley said.

Under international law, small payments to officials are not always illegal, although companies should clearly label them in their accounts.

The committee, chaired by Tory MP, Bowen Wells, has had difficulty persuading private sector firms to give evidence in public. "They think the mud will stick to them," one frustrated MP said last night.

Unilever, the food conglomerate, admitted to the committee yesterday that modest facilitating payments were "tolerated, not encouraged" as long as they met specified conditions. The payment must be small, must facilitate something that would happen anyway, is in line with local practice, transparent and in public.

Balfour Beatty, which is behind the controversial Ilisu dam project in Turkey, also gave evidence, as did the crown agents whose director, Ian White, admitted he was "a little shocked" to hear that BP and Unilever sanctioned payments.

His colleague, David Phillips, said companies sometimes included these payments in their accounts under "petty dispersals" in the "customs clearance" section.

Crown agents said its policy was to advise clients to blow the whistle on officials demanding such payments.

The MPs, who have been encouraged in their campaign by the international development secretary, Clare Short, believe that corruption inhibits development. The committee hopes to get witnesses from Nigeria to give evidence about the way western firms helped lure the oil-rich state into its current near-bankruptcy, the fault of endemic corruption.

webTitle: Dateline.com finds instant bliss

fields.headline: Dateline.com finds instant bliss
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Dateline.com, the online version of the matchmaking agency that has been bringing lonely hearts together for 34 years, has made a profit in its first year, bucking the trend among dot.com start-ups.
fields.body:
Dateline.com, the online version of the matchmaking agency that has been bringing lonely hearts together for 34 years, has made a profit in its first year, bucking the trend among dot.com start-ups.

Parent company OneSaturday said yesterday that Dateline's online offering would generate £400,000 in annual turnover and provide considerable savings over the agency's mail order service.

Group chairman Chris Matthews, who found his own partner through a dating agency, said the strong take-up of Dateline.com was a reflection of the brand's enduring strength.

In contrast, however, the group's new alternative online service for younger lonely hearts - OneSaturday.com - has struggled to draw in revenue despite offering free articles on fashion, cinema, food and dating etiquette.

"We were under pressure [last year] to get a funky dot com website going," said chief executive Terry Pudwell. "Thankfully, given the current market, we haven't wasted a huge amount on marketing it."

The group has scaled back a promotional programme for OneSaturday.com in the light of Dateline.com's strong performance, but is still considering developing its web presence. Additional online offerings might include financial services, single events, cinema and theatre ticket bookings and restaurant reservations.

OneSaturday, which includes two upmarket sister dating agencies - Club Sirius and Elite - and has more than 40,000 members a year, yesterday posted a £1.03m operating loss for the six months to end-October and a £1.77m pre-tax loss after exceptional costs. Much of the losses were due to investment in online services and the cost of creating and floating the umbrella company on AIM last August.

Shares in OneSaturday closed up 0.5p at 9p yesterday.

webTitle: Germany's BSE crisis claims two ministers

fields.headline: Germany's BSE crisis claims two ministers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Germany's centre-left government was last night pitched into crisis by the resignation of two cabinet ministers accused of mishandling the fallout from the spread of BSE.
fields.body:
Germany's centre-left government was last night pitched into crisis by the resignation of two cabinet ministers accused of mishandling the fallout from the spread of BSE.

The sudden turn of events posed a new threat to British farming since the politician tipped to take over as Germany's health minister is best known as a determined opponent of the lifting of the ban on beef imports from Britain.

The departures of Andrea Fischer, the health minister, and Karl-Heinz Funke, the agriculture minister, represented the biggest shock to Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's administration since the resignation of his controversial finance minister, Oskar Lafontaine, in early 1999.

The chancellor's own judgment is under scrutiny in this latest crisis. Until last Friday, Mr Schröder backed both ministers in the face of media and opposition claims that their handling of the BSE crisis was a shambles. Their resignations suggest he has been driven by the outcry into an abrupt change of direction.

They also marked the latest phase in a giddying turn-around in the fortunes of the government which, until recently, had been riding high in opinion polls. Since Christmas, three of the most senior ministers in Mr Schröder's Social Democrat-Green party coalition have come under sustained attack.

Joschka Fischer, the foreign minister (no relation of Ms Fischer), has had to fend off calls for his resignation following the publication of photographs from his radical youth showing him beating a fallen policeman.

The defence minister, Rudolf Scharping, is under pressure because of the Europe-wide controversy over the use of depleted uranium weapons in Kosovo and the finance minister, Hans Eichel, is in trouble over allegations that he used air force planes for journeys unconnected with his work as a minister.

Mr Schröder was last night expected to hand the health portfolio to Bärbel Höhn as a way of signalling a new and more decisive handling of the BSE crisis.

As environment minister in Germany's biggest regional administration - that of North Rhine-Westphalia - Ms Höhn, a member of the Green party, attracted widespread attention for her warnings that BSE could spread to Germany. She fought long and loud against last year's lifting of the ban on the purchase of British beef.

The discovery in November that BSE had entered German herds came as a profound shock to a nation of big meat eaters whose ministers, led by Mr Funke, had insisted German farms were free of mad cow disease. By yesterday, the number of confirmed BSE cases had grown to 10.

Ms Fischer, a leading member of the Green party, first fell foul of the crisis last month when she was forced into a u-turn over the need to recall sausages containing mechanically retrieved meat products.

She later admitted that a warning from government experts on practices in the sausage industry had lain unattended for 10 days in her ministry.

As the crisis unfolded, it began to resemble a three-way battle between the health and agriculture ministries and the European commission. Brussels said a warning of the possible spread of BSE to Germany had gone unheeded in Berlin and criticised Mr Schröder's government for not taking more strenuous measures after the crisis broke.

Choked by emotion at her farewell press conference, Ms Fischer said: "Everyone should take responsibility for their own mistakes".

She said the chancellor had expressed regret at her decision, which she insisted was hers alone.

In a peculiarly damaging admission for the government she left behind, Ms Fischer admitted that "the confidence of German citizens in the government's ability to solve the [BSE] crisis has been shaken".

Mr Schröder's problems will increase before they abate. Next week, Joschka Fischer is due to give evidence at the trial on terrorism charges of a friend from his days as a militant radical. The case has focused attention on his past, and in particular his attitude to violent protest.

Last night, representatives of the two parties in coalition were meeting at the chancellery in Berlin to discuss and whether the cabinet should be reshuffled following the departure of Ms Fischer and Mr Funke, a Social Democrat.
