webTitle: Detroit feels pinch as boom turns to bust

fields.headline: Detroit feels pinch as boom turns to bust
fields.standfirst:
In the second part of a series on the world's largest economy, we ask whether the car industry is on the scrapheap

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: In the second part of a series on the world's largest economy, we ask whether the car industry is on the scrapheap
fields.body:
January in Detroit is nobody's idea of fun, even in the week of the Motor City's normally glitzy annual auto show. There is an unmistakable economic chill in the air. The car industry is sliding inexorably towards a serious slowdown and today even the Tamla Motown museum, where the Supremes recorded "Where Did Our Love Go?", is temporarily closed.

In the centre of Dearborn, the suburb from which Henry Ford revolutionised the 20th-century world and made Detroit into a byword for industrial modernity, the signs of hard times are easy to spot. Store fronts on Michigan Avenue are boarded up. The only places that look as if they are doing good business are pawnshops and pornshops. The place is scattered with signs saying "Checks cashed" and "Payday advances".

"Things are slowing down, it's all around us right now," says Calvin Willis, as he ducks into the fierce wind outside the Henry Ford Memorial Library. "We've had it good here for too long. It's hard for some folks to remember that it was going to change some time."

At the Montgomery Ward store in Dearborn town centre the signs in the windows say it all: "Going out of business". The closure of the famous retail chain on December 29 marked the end of an era almost as iconic as the one started by Henry Ford himself. For 128 years, Montgomery Ward's 250 stores - seven in the Detroit area - have been part of America.

This was the company which many credit with the invention of mail-order shopping, the pre-internet retail lifeline for rural America. It came up with a slogan that entered the culture: "Satisfaction guaranteed." And it claims to have invented Rudolph the red-nosed reindeer. But Christmas was the end of the dream.

"The structure of retail changed faster than Montgomery Ward could keep up," says Pat Anderson, a local business watcher. "Nimbler, lower-cost companies moved in, like Wal-Mart and Target."

This is one of the many parts of America that the 10-year economic boom never reached. The people who live here are on low wages, they struggle for a living, and they don't have anything in the way of the computers and hi-tech gizmos that have fuelled the good times elsewhere. They are the underside of the America of staggering corporate success, in which economic inequality is rising faster than at any time since the pre-Crash 1920s.

But Detroit is still above all the Motor City. The indexes which matter here are those of motor vehicle production and sales. This is the city of Fords, centred in Dearborn, and of troubled Chrysler, a few miles north in Auburn Hills, and of General Motors, whose main production plants are an hour to the north in what is still the classic one-industry town of Flint.

And those indexes are looking bad. American car sales fell by 8% in December 2000, the second consecutive month of decline. The big three are suddenly scared, dampening down production in line with reduced demand, putting some plants on short time and warning of closures if things get worse, which most industry analysts expect that they will.

"The edge is clearly off the industry, and the industry is slipping beyond what many of us expected," says Paul Ballew of General Motors.

"The economy has definitely transitioned. We know it. Intel knows it and Banana Republic [a clothing company] knows it," says Ford spokesman George Pipas.

The big question for the car industry - and by extension for American business as a whole - is whether this is a slowdown or a slide. Panic selling in the stock market, beamed into offices around the country on cable television channels, can create an exaggerated effect. In Detroit, where they are well-versed in the business cycle, the mood is less hysterical than it sometimes appears to be in New York.

Economists at the big car companies say that sales will be well down in 2001 compared with the past two years. General Motors said yesterday that it expects a 10% drop, the worst fall for 10 years. But the gloom has to be seen in perspective. All the industry economists point to the spectacular success of the motor vehicle market over most of the past decade, and believe that a bad 2001 is still likely to be a good year in overall terms.

"Given the state of auto sales in December it's hard not to think we're heading into a recession," says Van Bussman, an economist at the DaimlerChrysler company. "But there's enough strength in the economy to keep us going. By the end of the year, we'll be back on track."

As the motor industry gathers in downtown Detroit this week for the Auto Show, there is no denying the general sense of anxiety. "Under Siege" ran the headline in the show supplement in the Detroit News this weekend.

But even if the mega-good times are over, it takes more than a downturn to dampen the American capacity for optimism. Last week, Detroit's mayor, Dennis Archer, opened a copper "time capsule" which had been sealed at the end of the 19th century by one of his predecessors, William Maybury.

The box contained a letter referring to the great advances which allowed telephone calls to be made across the country and travellers to reach Chicago by train in eight hours.

"How much faster are you travelling? How much farther have you annihilated time and space and what agencies are you employing to which we are strangers?" Mayor Maybury wrote to Mayor Archer.

"Just think of it. Mayor of Detroit and he'd never heard of Henry Ford," Mr Archer's spokesman commented on a local radio show. "I think the lesson for us is to always expect the unexpected."

webTitle: Shipman patient killed says coroner

fields.headline: Shipman patient killed says coroner
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Families of hundreds of possible victims of the serial murderer Harold Shipman could now seek inquests after a coroner recorded yesterday that one of his patients who had been cremated had been unlawfully killed.
fields.body:
Families of hundreds of possible victims of the serial murderer Harold Shipman could now seek inquests after a coroner recorded yesterday that one of his patients who had been cremated had been unlawfully killed.

Dr Shipman, whose surgery was in Hyde, Greater Manchester, was convicted of murdering 15 patients a year ago.

Since then the south Manchester coroner, John Pollard, has recorded that three other patients whose bodies were buried had been unlawfully killed.

But yesterday's inquest on 81-year-old Hilda Hibbert was the first of a series of 24 on possible victims who were all cremated. The verdict is bound to give comfort to other families who know Shipman will never return to court to face more murder charges.

Many had feared that, without postmortem evidence, the coroner would have been obliged to record an open verdict.

Yesterday's hearing followed a Department of Health report which suggested that Shipman, now serving life in Frankland prison, Durham, could have killed up to 300 people.

Relatives who packed the hearing at Ashton-under-Lyne gasped with relief as Mr Pollard announced his conclusion on Mrs Hibbert, who was found dead at home in Hyde on January 2 1996.

She was found sitting upright in her favourite armchair shortly after a visit from Shipman.

"I have to say, yes, there is some doubt as to whether Mrs Hibbert was unlawfully killed," said Mr Pollard. "But I could no way describe that doubt as reasonable doubt, bearing in mind all the circumstances. It beggars belief to reach any conclusion in this case other than to say she was unlawfully killed."

Mr Pollard was not permitted by law to name anyone who might have been responsible for Mrs Hibbert's death but her family said they were pleased with the verdict. "We were hoping for this outcome but didn't expect it," said her daughter-in-law Janice Hibbert.

Jane Ashton-Hibbert, Mrs Hibbert's granddaughter and leader of a support group for the families of suspected victims, said: "I know all the other inquests have to be dealt with on an individual basis but I would like to think this verdict has given the other families some hope."

During the hearing, Mr Pollard was told that Shipman had recorded that Mrs Hibbert had suffered a stroke two days before her death.

But Ms Ashton-Hibbert said she had not noticed any signs of a stroke as the family celebrated Christmas. She described her grandmother as "a lovely woman ... very active, sprightly and self-sufficient". At lunchtime on the day she died, she played hide and seek with her great-granddaughter.

Ms Ashton-Hibbert said she had left Mrs Hibbert's home at 2.30pm but returned an hour later to learn that her grandmother had been found in her chair as if asleep.

As ambulance men attempted resuscitation, Shipman burst in and told the crew to stop. "She's dead," he said. "There will be no need for a postmortem as I was the last person to see her before her death. I will issue a death certificate."

Ms Ashton-Hibbert said she had known Shipman for 20 years. When police inquiries into his activities began in 1998, she and her husband, Martin, had tried to lend him their support: she had tried to send a card and Martin had attempted to transfer from his own doctor to Shipman.

webTitle: Bosnian Serb in talks at Hague tribunal

fields.headline: Bosnian Serb in talks at Hague tribunal
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Biljana Plavsic, the former president of the Bosnian Serb republic, and a close colleague of indicted war crimes suspects Radovan Karadzic and General Ratko Mladic, voluntarily flew to the Hague yesterday for talks with officials of the war crimes tribunal.
fields.body:
Biljana Plavsic, the former president of the Bosnian Serb republic, and a close colleague of indicted war crimes suspects Radovan Karadzic and General Ratko Mladic, voluntarily flew to the Hague yesterday for talks with officials of the war crimes tribunal.

She rang her brother in Serbia yesterday, sources in Belgrade said, to tell him she was there. She has not been indicted publicly but says she wants to find out if she is on a secret list. If so, she has told friends, she will stand trial.

The International Criminal Tribunal for Yugoslavia started making secret indictments two years ago, partly to make it easier to arrest suspects.

Mrs Plavsic, 70, was dubbed the Iron Lady of Bosnia's Serb Republic for her opposition to the then-Serbian president, Slobodan Milosevic, whom she publicly snubbed when he introduced sanctions in 1994 to press Bosnian Serbs into making peace.

In 1997, she bolted from the ultra-nationalist Serb Democratic party, set up the Serb People's Alliance party and elicited western support for her anti-corruption drive. The move led to a removal of hardliners from the government and the Bosnian Serb parliament's election of the moderate Milorad Dodik as prime minister of the Serb Republic.

She remained a nationalist, albeit a less vocal one.

The net is tightening round the top Bosnian Serbs now that Mr Milosevic has been overthrown and they cannot rely on sanctuary in Serbia. Momcilo Krajisnik, another wartime colleague, was arrested and taken to the Hague a few months ago on a charge of genocide.

webTitle: Merrill negative on M&S

fields.headline: Merrill negative on M&S
fields.trailText: It is tempting to think 2001 could be the year that Marks & Spencer finally makes a recovery. The shares are up about 8.5% so far, flying in the face of reports that Christmas trading has been every bit as bad as expected.
fields.body:
It is tempting to think 2001 could be the year that Marks & Spencer finally makes a recovery. The shares are up about 8.5% so far, flying in the face of reports that Christmas trading has been every bit as bad as expected.

However, the investment bank Merrill Lynch is advising clients not to take up the M&S gamble and has selected the stores chain as its "retail bear stock" of the year.

With M&S property assets confirmed at just 100p per share, Merrill says support levels for the stock - around 190p for latter part of 2000 - might be lower than the market had expected.

Furthermore, with sales running below forecast, Merrill reckons there is a significant risk that profit forecasts for the current fiscal year might have to come down by as much as £30m-40m. Looking further ahead, Merrill says it cannot see the current management team turning around the business.

webTitle: L&G leaves strings untied

fields.headline: L&G leaves strings untied
fields.trailText: The City hates unfinished business and if there is one loose end it would like to see tied up this year it is the future of life assurer Legal & General, down 4p to 180p.
fields.body:
The City hates unfinished business and if there is one loose end it would like to see tied up this year it is the future of life assurer Legal & General, down 4p to 180p.

Since NatWest failed to buy the company for £10bn last year, the Square Mile has been convinced that its days as a independent company are numbered. With monotonous regularity tales of an "imminent" offer for L&G sweep the market, the latest being a 230p-a-share offer from Barclays, off 15p to £21.85.

According to well informed market sources, the two sides are indeed talking, but only about a deal that will allow L&G to sell its products through Barclays' branch network.

Neither institution would comment last night but it is understood that the negotiations are taking place ahead of planned changes to the "polarisation" rules which are used to tie financial institutions into selling only their own products.

Matt Barrett, the charismatic Barclays boss, has acknowledged in the past that his bank needs to beef up its presence in the life market. He has also said he would rather do so by "forging alliances" rather than buying a company outright.

It is far from clear that a deal is close to being reached and there is nothing to prevent L&G reaching agreements with other leading financial institutions to sell the stakeholder pensions which the government wants the financial community to start selling from April.

L&G is regarded as having a head start in this area, and the ability to sell products through Barclays branches would solve the problem it faced after NatWest's takeover attempt failed.

Other blue-chip shares, meanwhile, had another rough session yesterday, undermined once more by a poor performance from Vodafone.

Shares in the market heavyweight, which declined 14.5p on Monday, fell 7.75p to 220p - a 20-month closing low - after Nokia, the world's biggest mobile phone maker, reported lower than expected handset sales for the year 2000.

This news, combined with sharp declines for BP, off 17 to 526.5p and Shell, down 13p to 539p, and a succession of programme trades weighted to the sell side, pulled the FTSE 100 index down 61.5 points to 6,088.1.

Elsewhere, things were a lit ter better. The FTSE Techmark 100 index eased just 4.95 points to 2,433.34, helped by sharp gains for the likes of Scoot.com, up 10.25p to 74.25p, and Thus, 5.5p higher at 60.5p, both on the back of renewed bid speculation.

In spite of the gloomy news from Nokia, not all telecom stocks were heading south.

BT moved up 9.5p to 642p with dealers reporting buying from institutional investors impressed by the early efforts of new finance director Philip Hampton to cut group debt.

Energis and Colt Telecom both moved higher, advancing 20p to 485p and 65p to £16.75 respectively.

Other climbers included advertising outfit WPP, up 19.5p to 872p, with dealers citing positive feedback from a media conference hosted by Schroder Salomon Smith Barney in the US. It was being reported that WPP's finance director, Paul Richardson, told the conference the company remained committed to organic revenue growth of 8% and was targeting a one-point improvement in operating margins this year.

In the mid-cap world, Geo Interactive fell 35p to 545p as dealers reacted to news that its main rival, privately owned US group PacketVideo, had forged a partnership with handset maker Motorola. However, Geo's chief executive, Eli Reifman, was quick to play down the significance of the link.

Repeating his view that Geo's technology is 12-18 months ahead of the competition, Mr Reifman said he believed PacketVideo had issued the statement to help with its current round of funding.

webTitle: At this price?  Alfred McAlpine

fields.headline: At this price?  Alfred McAlpine
fields.trailText: Construction group Alfred McAlpine watched its shares soar yesterday after revealing 2000 was a bumper year and predicting more of the same over the next 12 months.
fields.body:
Construction group Alfred McAlpine watched its shares soar yesterday after revealing 2000 was a bumper year and predicting more of the same over the next 12 months.

The company said house prices had risen 18% to an average of £133,800 which helped lift its housebuilding profit margins ahead of the 12% target.

This success has, primarily, been due to focusing more closely on the higher value area of the market and attempting to trim back costs.

And as the London markets closed last night the company was enjoying the fruits of its announcement with a 5% leap in its share price.

The stock closed at 244.5p, an 11.5p increase.

This is a good performance, especially as the firm is notoriously difficult to value accurately. Housebuilding may be boasting 12% margins, but its construction side operates on between 3% and 4%.

Investors keen to jump in may be well advised to sit tight as the next few months could prove decisive.

Analysts say the company has done well to achieve its aims, but insist the real evidence will be what targets it decides to set itself over the next couple of years.

"What they have done to date should be applauded but it's a case of what we are going to see now," said one. "The likelihood is that house prices are not going to go up that much further and we want to know where the growth is going to come from."

Also of concern is the spectre of a takeover that has been rumbling around in the background for many months. In December the company announced it had dismissed a 235p-a-share approach and, although refusing to disclose the bidder's name, reports suggested the suitor was Gerald Ronson's Heron International.

Until the company provides firm evidence of volume growth in 2001, coupled with an indication of whether it would consider a merger, it is unlikely the share price will move dramatically. Hold.

Analysts say the company has done well to achieve its aims, but insist the real evidence will be what targets it decides to set itself over the next couple of years. "What they have done to date should be applauded but it's a case of what we are going to see now," said one. "The likelihood is that house prices are not going to go up that much further and we want to know where the growth is going to come from." Also of concern is the spectre of a takeover that has been rumbling around in the background for many months. In December the company announced it had dismissed a 235p-a-share approach and, although refusing to disclose the bidder's name, reports suggested the suitor was Gerald Ronson's Heron International. Until the company provides firm evidence of volume growth in 2001, coupled with an indication of whether it would consider a merger, it is unlikely the share price will move dramatically. Hold.

webTitle: Engineers display unusual optimism

fields.headline: Engineers display unusual optimism
fields.trailText: British engineering firms are seizing on the growing strength of the euro to increase exports to mainland Europe dramatically, with the sector likely to outperform the overall economy this year.
fields.body:
British engineering firms are seizing on the growing strength of the euro to increase exports to mainland Europe dramatically, with the sector likely to outperform the overall economy this year.

The Engineering Employers Federation accompanied this upbeat forecast yesterday with an equally astonishing reluctance to press the Bank of England for a cut in interest rates this week - or for the next few months.

The EEF, harbinger of woe during the long period of sterling appreciation, forecasts declining job losses this year - to 30,000 compared with 40,000 last year and 65,000 in 1999.

Its quarterly survey carried out in November before fears of recession prompted last week's cut in US interest rates, suggests engineering will grow by 3.5%, outpacing the rest of manufacturing.

The only blots on the landscape are a squeeze on margins and profits, especially for firms exporting to the EU, and a flat outlook for investment. Even the threat of a mild US recession scarcely troubles the EEF.

The EEF wants the chancellor to give bigger tax incentives for capital spending and refrain from over-generous tax cuts in his Budget in March so the bank's monetary policy committee has scope for lower rates. Stephen Radley, EEF chief economist, said yesterday interest rates should come down "at some time this year but when there's a strong case for them doing so. We don't want to see a knee-jerk reaction to what's happened in America."

webTitle: Pint wins over the fizz in drinks battle

fields.headline: Pint wins over the fizz in drinks battle
fields.trailText: Christmas cheer rubbed off on pub chain JD Wetherspoon last month, with like-for-like sales up 10% as festive revellers clamoured for a value-for-money pint.
fields.body:
Christmas cheer rubbed off on pub chain JD Wetherspoon last month, with like-for-like sales up 10% as festive revellers clamoured for a value-for-money pint.

But the picture was patchy at the more expensive end of the drinks trade, as Majestic Wine suffered from a post-millennium slump in champagne sales.

Wetherspoon's chairman, Tim Martin, said December had exceeded his expectations, with five-week sales up 31% to £49.7m. This was boosted by 38 openings over the year, taking the total to 466.

The company's shares gained 25.5p in trading yesterday to 372.5p as analysts welcomed the trading news. Stuart Price of CSFB raised his recommendation from "sell" to "hold", saying: "They're slightly ahead of where people were expecting them to be. There's an ongoing emphasis from consumers for value-for-money offerings and JD Wetherspoon has benefited from that."

Christmas was less kind to Majestic Wine, which reported a 2.7% drop in like-for-like sales for the last nine weeks of the year, due to a 22% dive in sales of champagne. Its chief executive, Tim How, said: "We were very pleased with the way things went, although I guess any performance which is down can't be described as spectacular."

Majestic had expected champagne sales to be down as much as 40%, after drinkers over-stocked at the end of 1999.

 Luminar, the nightclub and restaurant operator, which acquired the Northern Leisure group last July, has reported strong trading over the Christmas period.

Yesterday it said that its December turnover rose 260% at its string of nightclubs and restaurants.

webTitle: View from over here

fields.headline: View from over here
fields.trailText: If the season of giving is any judge of consumer confidence, then the European economy had a cracking Christmas that contrasted starkly with the miserly mood of the US.
fields.body:
If the season of giving is any judge of consumer confidence, then the European economy had a cracking Christmas that contrasted starkly with the miserly mood of the US.

Germans have a special word for the ceremony of handing out Christmas gifts - Bescherung. According to the country's national retail association, they gave generously at Christmas and a similar picture is emerging from other European countries.

But in the US, stores had their most frugal holiday for five years, mirroring a slump in customer sentiment that was a key factor in provoking the Federal Reserve into a surprise half point cut to 6% interest rates last week.

Analysts say that the news trickling out from European stores and shopkeepers associations provides reliable insight into the state of the eurozone's consumer confidence.

National retail sales data covering the December period will not be available for several weeks.

However, the verdict from the high street is that the region is in better shape than the US.

webTitle: Brewing chief's recklessness exposed

fields.headline: Brewing chief's recklessness exposed
fields.standfirst: No reassurance in this gamble
fields.trailText: Interbrew's Stella Artois lager is supposed to be "reassuringly expensive". Chief executive Hugo Powell has certainly proved to be so. The Indian-born Englishman who runs the Belgian company was nowhere to be seen since trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers called time on his attempt to snatch a third of Britain's brewing industry last week.
fields.body:
Interbrew's Stella Artois lager is supposed to be "reassuringly expensive". Chief executive Hugo Powell has certainly proved to be so. The Indian-born Englishman who runs the Belgian company was nowhere to be seen since trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers called time on his attempt to snatch a third of Britain's brewing industry last week.

He was last heard of in Florida, but when he resurfaces he needs to do some fast talking. Throughout last year, Mr Powell was beaming with confidence. He was sure Mr Byers would smile on his £2.3bn purchase of Bass Brewers and of the success of the subsequent flotation of the Interbrew business, when investors were persuaded to part with £1.8bn.

His advisers point out that the float prospectus warned there was a risk of regulatory intervention. But investors will be interested to hear that there was no space in the document for the cautionary views of Lehman Brothers, which was closer to the Bass deal than anyone. The highly paid investment bank was so concerned it advised Mr Powell to postpone the float. But he pressed on.

His reckless gambles have savaged the Interbrew share price and most observers agree the fiasco will cost the company a cool £800m as it is forced to unload Bass Brewing at a huge loss.

Few chief executives could get away with such a glaring misjudgment. Mr Powell is lucky that his future is in the hands of the handful of Belgian families which still hold a majority of Interbrew's shares. Having sold stock, they gained from the company's flotation. If Mr Powell was answerable to the usual crowd of institutional fund managers, he would be spending more time en famille by now.

Service charge

Europe's single market does not work very well. Who says? The European commission, that's who.

True, reforms have brought European consumers cheaper electricity and telephone calls. Price differentials on a range of goods have shrunk. But the concept of free movement of services, one of the main aims of the single market, still has a long way to go, according to the latest evidence. A commission report yesterday said half the service sector companies in the EU earn less than 10% of their revenues in other EU countries. It believes barriers to competition in the postal, energy, transport and communications sectors need to be removed without delay. A strategy is promised later this week.

To an extent the commission has its own agenda. The more it can dismantle national structures and replace them with pan-European rules and regulations, the greater its own authority. But the commission has persuasive arguments on its side.

It reckons that if the EU's service industries employed as many people as those in the US - not too extravagant a comparison, given the similar size of the two economies - that would create an additional 36m jobs, double the number of people out of work in the single market area.

Sweden, which holds the EU presidency, has put employment high on its agenda. Yesterday's report provides a more than useful starting point.

Post modern

What nonsense some chief executives spout. Take yesterday's offering from John Roberts, the country's head postie.

Announcing the decision to rebrand the Post Office as Consignia, Mr Roberts explained that it was a "modern and meaningful" new moniker and that "the new name describes the full scope of what the Post Office does in a way that the words 'post' and 'office' cannot".

Frankly, it really describes the full scope of what a specialist brand consultancy can achieve. The words "money" and "old rope" spring to mind.

Consignia is not meaningful. It is a newly invented word, straight out of the mould of so many other wacky new corporate identities. Where once we had British Gas, National Power, Scottish Power's telecoms division, Tarmac construction, British Steel and Sketchley, we now have the shiny new nameplates of Lattice and Centrica, Innogy, Thus, Carillion, Corus and Semara. Only last week we had the respected Andersen Consulting restyling itself in 21st century gobbledegook as Accenture .

Old names are always jettisoned on the grounds that they no longer reflect the real business of the company. Irrelevant, it seems, that the new ones don't either.

The Post Office did need a new corporate name. The generic term Post Office could not be legally protected, which is crucial as it expands overseas.

But Consignia is artificial, meaningless, unrecognisable and absurd. A corporation with a history stretching back to the reign of Charles I has lost its head. Its new name should be consigned to the dustbin of history.

webTitle: Touchy-feely tough guy rounds on fight-to-lose brigade

fields.headline: Touchy-feely tough guy rounds on fight-to-lose brigade
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Parliament
Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Following the Guardian article yesterday morning, the defence minister John Spellar made a statement about depleted uranium shells and the effect they are having on our soldiers.
fields.body:
Following the Guardian article yesterday morning, the defence minister John Spellar made a statement about depleted uranium shells and the effect they are having on our soldiers.

It appears they aren't having any effect, or at least not anything you need to worry about. Short of curling up with a hot water bottle and a mug of Ovaltine, there's nothing healthier for a soldier than a depleted uranium shell.

I exaggerate, but only slightly. Mr Spellar's statement was a classic example of the New Labour caring and sharing, touchy-feely style, combined with the Mister Mucho Macho pose favoured by defence ministers since the days of Genghis Khan.

I ran Mr Spellar's statement through the new bullshit programme on my computer and came up with a helpful concordance.

"This ammunition provides a battle-winning capacity. Therefore DU will remain part of our arsenal for the foreseeable future. Because, when this country commits our forces to conflict, we fight to win!"

[So, anyone who expresses anxiety about the effects is one of those milktoasts who believes that our boys should fight to lose.]

"The working environment of our forces in the Balkans is already closely monitored because of health and safety and environmental concerns about the theatre."

[New Labour treats a battlefield with the same tender concern as a primary school which might have asbestos in the roofing.]

"I have spelt out the background to DU research because it is important to put some of the inaccurate and inflammatory media coverage in context."

[This remark, greeted with some approval, translates as "we can always blame the papers for flamming things up". If there's one thing MPs dislike more than other MPs, it's the press.]

"These issues are not new, and we must not unduly alarm service personnel or their families."

[Anything which warns soldiers that they might have to face dangers quite apart from the enemy is destroying morale. There just might be an implied reference here to the Guardian, a notorious leader of the fight-to-lose brigade.]

"Our response will be... on the best available science."

[This phrase, which we heard innumerable times in the early days of the BSE crisis, means "on the basis of any scientific research we can drag up which fits what we have decided already".]

"I hope this statement puts the current debate in context."

[Or, "shuts the papers up for a few weeks at least".]

"We are providing battle-winning equipment for our forces and taking seriously our responsibility for their welfare. I am sure the house would agree they deserve no less."

[And the house is really keen on motherhood and apple pie, too.]

Not surprisingly, apart from a sprinkling of "fight-to-lose" MPs who pointed out that some of their constituents who'd fought in the Gulf war and Kosovo were in pretty rough shape, this statement was received with tremendous approval from all round the house, not least from the Tories. Iain Duncan-Smith, their defence spokesman, pointed out that the Italians had threatened, if DU weapons were not banned, to pull out of Nato! This was greeted with great hilarity, and no doubt lots of jokes about the Italian tank with one forward gear and three reverse.

Nicholas Soames was entirely in favour of DU shells. "They inflict the most serious damage on the Queen's enemies!" he thundered.

Oh dear, not another attack on the poor old Guardian.

webTitle: French arms scandal implicates politicians

fields.headline: French arms scandal implicates politicians
fields.trailText: France's widening arms-dealing scandal threatened to embroil more high-ranking figures yesterday as the head of an arms export agency run by the interior ministry claimed his company had for years served as a cover for trafficking.
fields.body:
France's widening arms-dealing scandal threatened to embroil more high-ranking figures yesterday as the head of an arms export agency run by the interior ministry claimed his company had for years served as a cover for trafficking.

Henri Hurand, managing director of Sofremi, the export company controlled by the interior ministry, alleged that the accused arms dealer Pierre Falcone was Sofremi's sole intermediary for foreign arms sales and that he had "showered everyone with bribes for years".

Mr Hurand made no specific accusations against past interior ministers responsible for Sofremi, but he alleged that at least two - the centre-rightist Charles Pasqua and the Socialist Pierre Joxe - had "followed the company's operations extremely closely".

Mr Falcone and his company, Brenco International, are at the centre of a huge money-laundering and arms-trafficking scandal involving the illicit sale to Angola of some £350m-worth of Russian-made helicopters, tanks, weapons and other military equipment in 1993 and 1994.

Besides Mr Falcone, those in jail on suspicion of involvement in the deals are Bernard Poussier, Mr Hurand's predecessor at Sofremi, and Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, the son of the former French president François.

Mr Mitterrand, who was for several years his father's chief adviser on African affairs, has admitted receiving some £1.3m from Brenco in the late 1990s, but denied that the money was related to arms deals. He last night reluctantly paid his Fr5m (£480,000) bail.

Investigators believe that the privileged relations between the late president's elder son and a number of African leaders may have helped Mr Falcone - who was on Sofremi's books as an "adviser" - to win the two Angolan contracts and possibly several others.

Mr Hurand, who has radically overhauled Sofremi and severed its relations with Mr Falcone since his appointment in 1997, said the accused arms dealer was "omnipresent" in the company's activities from 1992 onwards.

"As a general rule, a private intermediary was called on for every deal," he said in an interview with Le Figaro. "In fact, from 1992, Falcone was Sofremi's sole and unique intermediary.

"It was completely abnormal. He received exorbitant commissions on every sale."

Mr Hurand said Sofremi, which was set up by the French government to oversee the export of security-related technology and services, mainly to developing countries, was "quite plainly used by Mr Falcone as a cover for his personal activities".

"...this could not have been done without the approval of the company's bosses", he said, adding "[it was] evident, too, that the managing directors of Sofremi have always had to report to the interior minister".

The name of Mr Pasqua, interior minister from 1986 to 1988 and from 1993 to 1995, had already been linked to the scandal. The investigating magistrate, Phillippe Courroye, has searched Mr Pasqua's home and offices, and last week ordered the seizure of the 1999 European election campaign accounts of his party, Rally for France (RPF).

French media have reported that the magistrate is intrigued by sums paid into RPF's campaign coffers from African donors. Mr Pasqua has insisted that his party's financing is strictly above board and has vehemently denied any improper relationship with Mr Falcone or Brenco.

webTitle: Nazi suspect may face trial

fields.headline: Nazi suspect may face trial
fields.standfirst:
Lithuania wants extradition of man living in UK

Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: Lithuanian officials confirmed yesterday that they plan to seek the extradition of a suspected Nazi war criminal who has been living in Britain since 1947.
fields.body:
Lithuanian officials confirmed yesterday that they plan to seek the extradition of a suspected Nazi war criminal who has been living in Britain since 1947.

Anton Gecas, 85, who runs a guest house in Edinburgh, is alleged to have taken part in the mass murder of Jews by Nazi death squads in Lithuania in 1941.

Eight years ago Mr Gecas was branded a war criminal by a Scottish judge after he lost a libel case against Scottish Television over a documentary that alleged he led atrocities against Jews in his native country and Belarus as the head of a special police battalion during the second world war.

At the time, the judge, Lord Milligan, at the court of session in Edinburgh, said he was "clearly satisfied" Mr Gecas had "committed war crimes against innocent civilians".

The claims were investigated by Scottish prosecution authorities, but no action was taken against Mr Gecas, who denied involvement in the massacres.

Yesterday, the Lithuanian prosecutor general's office said it planned to approach the Home Office to ask for Mr Gecas's extradition, although no date had been set. "The plans are for the nearest future," said Rimvydas Valentukevicius, head of the department of special investigations.

The crown office, the Scottish prosecution service, said it had yet to receive a formal request for extradition, while the Home Office said it could not confirm or deny the details of any request received from other states.

But the moves by Lithuania were welcomed by Lord Janner, secretary of the parliamentary all-party war crimes group. He said he would be surprised if Mr Gecas was not extradited.

webTitle: 400 police join hunt for murderer

fields.headline: 400 police join hunt for murderer
fields.trailText: A huge manhunt was continuing in southern France last night as more than 400 police, accompanied by dogs and helicopters, closed in on a convicted murderer who on Monday shot dead two policemen and two witnesses from his trial.
fields.body:
A huge manhunt was continuing in southern France last night as more than 400 police, accompanied by dogs and helicopters, closed in on a convicted murderer who on Monday shot dead two policemen and two witnesses from his trial.

A police spokesman said several people claimed to have spotted a man fitting the description of Albert Foulcher some 10 miles north of Narbonne. The search was concentrating last night on a small area near the village of St Marcel-sur-Aude, about five miles north-west of Narbonne.

Mr Foulcher, a former insurance agent, has been on the run since April when he was convicted in his absence of the murder of a colleague. He was on foot, the spokesman said, having abandoned two cars stolen in the past 24 hours.

Eluding roadblocks set up along a 70-mile stretch of the A9 Marseilles-Barcelona motorway, and armed with at least one semi-automatic machine pistol, Mr Foulcher had evaded his pursuers throughout the night and early morning, the spokesman said.

"The hunt is being conducted with extreme caution," he added. "This is a clever, resourceful and exceptionally dangerous man who has shown he will stop at nothing. He has nothing left to lose."

The police deaths brought to four the number of French police killed on duty on the past three weeks, prompting an outcry from police unions.

"What we fear we are facing here is the Americanisation of crime in France," said Jean-Claude Gleize of the police union, Alliance.

The deadly chase started with the apparent vengeance killing on Monday afternoon of Pascal Herrero, who had given evidence at Mr Foulcher's trial for the 1993 murder of André Meffray, a fellow insurance agent.

Mr Herrero's wife called the police as soon as she saw Mr Foulcher arrive at the couple's house north of Narbonne, but the killer shot her husband dead as the patrol car arrived before turning his weapon on the two policemen. The driver was killed instantly, hit by four bullets in the head, and his passenger died before reaching hospital.

Mr Foulcher then drove his stolen car to a village near Narbonne, pulling up at the home of Maurice Michaud, another insurance agent who had testified against him.

He mowed the man down as soon as the door was opened and fled in Michaud's silver Mercedes.

webTitle: Battlefield medical services in crisis, official figures show

fields.headline: Battlefield medical services in crisis, official figures show
fields.trailText: Britain's armed forces have a chronic shortage of field hospitals, with the ability to deploy just a third of the number required by the Ministry of Defence, according to figures released today.
fields.body:
Britain's armed forces have a chronic shortage of field hospitals, with the ability to deploy just a third of the number required by the Ministry of Defence, according to figures released today.

The defence minister, Lewis Moonie, admitted in a letter to Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, that the defence medical services could field only five of the 14 hospitals they were obliged to deploy for large-scale warfare.

"These figures are profoundly disturbing," Mr Campbell said last night. "The dedicated and professional men and women who serve as doctors and nurses are severely overstretched."

He warned that Britain's armed forces would have to rely increasingly on the medical services of allied countries. "They are paying the price for the Tory government's ineptitude in the 1990s. But the present government cannot hide behind Tory inadequacy for ever. Urgent action is required."

The shortage of trained medical personnel in the forces was so acute that they could staff only one and half field hospitals, Mr Moonie admitted. The shortfall would have to be made up by territorial army personnel.

The government's 1988 strategic defence review instructed the medical services to provide up to 14 field hospitals - three staffed by regular personnel and 11 by TA reservists. After making up for the shortage of medical staff for the three hospitals staffed by regulars, the TA would have enough staff left for only two out of the remaining 11, Mr Moonie said.

"The manning crisis needs to be addressed as a matter of urgency," Mr Campbell wrote in the latest issue of the Royal United Services Institute's newsletter.

The military's medical services were suffering from a 76% shortage of anaesthetists, 45% of general physicians, 52% of general surgeons, 71% of orthopaedic surgeons, 87% of accident and emergency provision, and 50% of psychiatrists, according to official figures.

The services were losing more than 700 doctors, nurses, and specialists a year, according to Mr Campbell.

Britain's last military hospital, Haslar in Portsmouth, is due to close in April. France recently opened its 15th, Mr Campbell pointed out.

webTitle: Young Turks shake up summer exhibition

fields.headline: Young Turks shake up summer exhibition
fields.standfirst: Invitation to new stars of British art stirs anger at Royal Academy
fields.trailText: Invitation to new stars of British art stirs anger at Royal Academy.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The annual splutter of outrage over the Royal Academy summer exhibition, a fixture in the art calender for more than two centuries, began early this year with news that the curator, Peter Blake, will invite some of the young British artists he admires to rub shoulders with the creators of serried ranks of Lakeland sunsets, flowers on Hampstead window sills and views from Tuscan balconies.

The academy council met yesterday, and despite a rumble of protest from its members, has approved Mr Blake's plans to widen the scope of the show, held annually since 1767 and now the largest open art exhibition in the world.

The summer exhibition is still hugely popular, but there are signs that its regular audience of more than 100,000 is vulnerable. Last summer visitor numbers fell to 80,000, a decline blamed mainly on the success of Tate Modern and other millennium attractions.

It has also been eclipsed in recent years by the success of the academy's two shockers, Sensation in 1997 and last year's Apocalypse, both deliberately provocative exhibitions of contemporary work.

Mr Blake intends to revitalise the show by reorganising it as themed rooms, for the academy members - each entitled to submit six pieces, 480 works if all took up their quota - one devoted to a single major artist, and another to the "send-ins", the miles of unsolicited canvas which are ruthlessly pruned by the hanging committee.

He will also include a gallery of contemporary art, and has hinted at some of the names he would like to see: "Damien [Hirst], Tracey [Emin], Sarah Lucas, Angus Fairhurst, Gary Hume, Gavin Turk - all are friends of mine."

Turk, whose week long installation based on Che Guevara opens next week in a former East End foundry, was intrigued. "We all love Peter," he said. "I'm sure he could twist my arm. I think Tracey and the rest would be up for it too."

Although Mr Blake is finalising his plans and no invitations have been issued, the academy confirmed yesterday that "a handful" of letters of protest had arrived, including one from a former member of staff, Leonard McComb.

Mr McComb, an artist and former keeper of the Royal Academy Schools, and his supporters see Mr Blake's innovations as evidence of "Serota-isation", the sidelining of traditional subjects and techniques by conceptual artists, as championed by Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate galleries and the annual Turner Prize.

Outrage is a fine academy tradition: there were several resignations over Sensation, particularly the notorious portrait of Myra Hindley by Marcus Harvey, constructed from the hand prints of children.

Mr Blake, however, is an improbable bogeyman. The avuncular pop artist is a legend, creator of the Beatles's Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band album cover.

He said cheerfully: "There's always some fuss about the summer exhibition."

Despite the annual display of eyeball searing flower paintings, jelly boned ballerinas and buttoned up portraits, the summer exhibition has been discreetly evolving for several years. For the past three a major contemporary sculptor has been invited to fill the front courtyard: Sir Edward Paolozzi, Antony Gormley and Tony Cragg have already taken up the challenge. An architecture gallery was added five years ago, and in 1999 David Hockney was invited to fill a room with his vast Grand Canyon canvases.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Hamilton case delayed
fields.body:
Hamilton case delayed

Bankruptcy proceedings involving the disgraced former minister Neil Hamilton have been delayed for nearly three weeks after solicitors acting for the Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, served a bankruptcy statutory demand on him, it was announced yesterday.

Man held over dog fights

Police investigating allegations of dog fighting yesterday arrested a 21-year-old man in the Lozells area of Birmingham, in an operation with the RSPCA.

Ex-care worker accused

A former care worker was remanded on bail by Birmingham magistrates yesterday charged with 17 counts of sexual abuse. Terrence Goodhall, 51, of Margate, Kent, is alleged to have carried out the offences between 1976 and 1981 against 15 boys at Tennal assessment centre in Harborne, Birmingham.

TV stand warning

A television model could be in danger of toppling over due to a faulty stand, it emerged yesterday. The safety warning covers owners of Sony TV stand model SU 36FS70. Owners can contact Sony on 0800 169 5263.

Store's advert 'offensive'

French Connection, a clothing store, is criticised by the Advertising Standards Authority today for a newspaper advertisement headed "world's biggest fcuk" promoting a new shop in Oxford Street. The advertisers claimed it was generally understood that "fcuk" referred to French Connection UK. But the ASA found that "fcuk" could be read as an expletive and was likely to cause offence.

Meningitis fear as student dies

An alert was issued yesterday after the death at Sheffield Hallam University of a first-year student, Helen McCadden, 18, from Chester, from suspected meningitis. It was thought she had died from B strain meningitis, for which there is no vaccine.

Firefighters rescue children

Four children aged between three and nine left in the care of a 16-year-old aunt while their mother went to Tenerife on holiday were rescued by firefighters from a burning house in Bewsey, near Warrington, Cheshire, yesterday. A 17-year-old boy has been arrested on suspicion of arson.

Transport aid for disabled

Families of severely disabled children are to be helped to buy specially adapted cars, the social security minister, Hugh Bayley, told the Commons yesterday. The lower age limit for eligibility for mobility payments is being reduced from five to three.

Pay boost for pathology staff

Pathology workers are to get pay rises of up to 13% in an attempt to cure staff shortages that have been blamed for delays in processing hospital test results. It is part of an offer covering 400,000 NHS staff outside the pay review bodies that will trigger inflation-busting awards across the service.

webTitle: Girl band All Saints expected to break up

fields.headline: Girl band All Saints expected to break up
fields.trailText: All Saints, the all-girl group that offered a credible antidote to the excesses of girl power, are expected to split up this week, bringing to an end a career that produced five number one singles and countless tabloid headlines.
fields.body:
All Saints, the all-girl group that offered a credible antidote to the excesses of girl power, are expected to split up this week, bringing to an end a career that produced five number one singles and countless tabloid headlines.

A spokesman for the group yesterday said management was "struggling to hold the thing together", but privately, sources close to the group believed a split would be announced by the end of the week.

Yesterday the band were thought to be discussing how to resolve outstanding commitments, which include a single due for release on Monday and a UK tour planned for May.

The break-up is thought to have come about because founder member Melanie Blatt wants to spend more time with her daughter, Lily.

A source said: "This has been brewing for some time. A lot of this has come from Mel Blatt not really being up for it any more.

"In the past she has made it difficult for the band, storming off TV shows and that sort of thing. She certainly pulled out of the Australia and Japan tour [last November]."

The band was founded by Blatt and the principal song writer, Shaznay Lewis, in 1993. The sisters Natalie and Nicole Appleton joined in 1996.

Reports yesterday suggested that the Appleton sisters had signed a deal with London Records to produce albums as a duo.

Since their first release as a quartet in 1997, all seven of All Saints' singles have made the top 10, with half going straight to the top. Pure Shores, their soundtrack to the Leonardo DiCaprio movie film The Beach, was the second biggest selling single last year, bettered only by Bob the Builder's Can We Fix It?

In contrast to more manufactured acts of the 1990s, All Saints struck a chord with their unshowy tomboy style and soulful, catchy pop, quickly winning popular and critical acclaim.

Before long, however, they were generating less welcome publicity. The Appleton sisters, with a penchant for high profile boyfriends and late nights, became tabloid staples.

Last year Blatt indicated in the Guardian that at some point her family would have to come first: "I'd like there to be a 10th album ... but realistically, with Lily, I can't do this for the rest of my life."

Nicole Appleton meanwhile indicated that the pressures of fame had strained relations between the four: "It's very difficult to be friends and have a business relationship."

webTitle: Eight Britons overstay Olympic visas

fields.headline: Eight Britons overstay Olympic visas
fields.trailText: Three months after the Sydney Olympic Games the search is on for 108 people, including eight Britons, who were issued with Olympic family visas for the event and have failed to leave the country.
fields.body:
Perhaps they want to cling to the memory of the world's greatest sporting event or maybe they just want to linger in the sunshine. Three months after the Sydney Olympic Games the search is on for 108 people, including eight Britons, who were issued with Olympic family visas for the event and have failed to leave the country.

The British Olympic Association insisted yesterday that none of the Britons was an athlete and that all members of the UK team had been accounted for. Only two athletes remain in Australia, one who is visiting his girlfriend and another who is training.

A BOA spokesman said: "None of the Britons who have overstayed their visas are athletes or official team members. A large number of Olympic family visas were issued and this included members of the media, representatives of different sports, umpires, physiotherapists and other officials."

The spokesman added that all British team members were warned that they would have to apply for visa extensions if they wanted to remain in Australia for more than three months. While many who attended the games stayed on for holidays almost all left within the specified time.

The spokesman added: "You can't really blame people who have overstayed, it's an awful lot warmer in Australia. We have checked all records and know the whereabouts of all our Olympic team members."

Australian officials are on the lookout for people from 61 countries who entered on Olympic family visas. Another 30 athletes and individuals, mainly from developing countries, have applied for asylum.

The Australian authorities have refused to release the names of those who have overstayed, despite requests from the BOA and the Foreign Office. They have said that those who have overstayed should come forward so that they can be repatriated. Those who did not give themselves up would be deported.

The Australian authorities have refused to release the names of those who have overstayed, despite requests from the BOA and the Foreign Office. They have said that those who have overstayed should come forward so that they can be repatriated. Those who did not give themselves up would be deported.

webTitle: Audio firm shuts in US

fields.headline: Audio firm shuts in US
fields.trailText: Audio equipment maker Soundtracs said yesterday it would have to close its US trading subsidiary after under-estimating a slowdown in business for the second time in six months.
fields.body:
Audio equipment maker Soundtracs said yesterday it would have to close its US trading subsidiary after under-estimating a slowdown in business for the second time in six months.

The company's share price plummeted to a record low of 22.5p, down 13p on the back of yesterday's profit warning.

Shares dropped 30% in August after Soundtracs, which has supplied systems used by Mark Knopfler, left, and Pete Townsend, announced it had cut its profits forecast because of disappointing sales.

Yesterday, the company said sales had remained "frustratingly low" for longer than expected during the six months to October. The switch from analogue to digital technology has also caused problems for the company, forcing it to change much of its core business over recent years.

webTitle: Nokia hit despite sales rise of 64%

fields.headline: Nokia hit despite sales rise of 64%
fields.trailText: Nokia saw almost a fifth of its stock market value wiped away at one point yesterday when investors reacted in panic to weaker than expected handset sales figures from the world's largest manufacturer of mobile phones.
fields.body:
Nokia saw almost a fifth of its stock market value wiped away at one point yesterday when investors reacted in panic to weaker than expected handset sales figures from the world's largest manufacturer of mobile phones.

Investors rattled by a recent profits warning from rival manufacturer Motorola marked Nokia shares down by as much as 19% in early trading on the Helsinki stock exchange - knocking £25bn from its total value.

The shares regained some lost ground after analysts said the selling had been overdone. They closed down about 9% at €41 (£26).

That valued a firm that for much of last year was Europe's largest at £121bn. Vodafone, at £142bn, now holds the title.

Nokia said it had sold 128m mobile phones in 2000, up 64% on the previous year, but below the expected the 135m-140m most observers were looking for. A lack of any accompanying news on how margins were holding up added to concern that perhaps even the highly rated Nokia was not immune to the downturn in the telecoms sector.

"Clearly the risk has increased, particularly with the current economic condition, however Nokia's superior supply chain management and its ability to reach the end market will keep it ahead of its peers," said Adnaan Ahmad, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. Mr Ahmad remains confident that Nokia will continue to hit targeted sales numbers and increase its market share in 2001.

Investors will get a clearer picture when Nokia reports full-year figures at the end of this month. In the meantime they will nervously await earnings figures from Ericsson, expected later today.

Nokia said that 405m mobile phones were sold worldwide by all manufacturers last year, giving it a market share of 31.6%. Observers are split on whether Nokia will be able to continue its strong growth.

Tony Milbourn, managing director of TTP Communications which manufactures software and designs chips for mobile phone manufacturers such as Siemens and Panasonic, said Nokia faced increasing competition from smaller operators. "People are piling into their market at every point," he said. "Cheap Chinese manufacturers and handheld computer companies want a slice of the action.

"The tier one manufacturers like Nokia are going to see their market share diminish in the long run."

Nokia has instigated a price war in an attempt to squeeze its competitors. It appears prepared to sacrifice short-term profits to reinforce its market leading position but investors are unlikely to remain tolerant of the strategy if sales do not continue to grow.

webTitle: Tension mounts along with Dales couple's 11 years of rubbish

fields.headline: Tension mounts along with Dales couple's 11 years of rubbish
fields.trailText: One of the Yorkshire Dales' less lovely landmarks may at last be removed after one of the longest stand-offs in the history of local government.
fields.body:
One of the Yorkshire Dales' less lovely landmarks may at last be removed after one of the longest stand-offs in the history of local government.

Eleven years of domestic rubbish will be carted through a beauty spot known as "the Switzerland of England" if the health of a couple's toddler grandchild tips the balance against stubborn pride.

The pyramid of sardine tins, cereal packets and teabags has accumulated as a monument to principle since 1989, when architect John Cale and his wife, Margaret, first insisted that "doorstep" collection of refuse should mean what it said.

Harrogate council disagreed, regarding over £100,000 of cumbersome refuse truck as too precious to risk on a rutted track at the head of Nidderdale.

Simon Johnson, head of Harrogate's environmental services, said: "It has been to the ombudsman and we have been upheld.

"It is the same for 180 other very remote residents, and the Cales are the only objectors. It comes up year after year after year."

Mrs Cale yesterday repeated her refusal of the council's decade-old offer to collect the rubbish from the end of the family's half-mile long track, but her granddaughter's health on family visits has now entered the equation.

Nobody is expecting any rapid developments, but the 22ft long pile, which is 10ft wide and 6ft high, will probably have to be moved further from the Cales' isolated farmhouse if it is not finally taken away in a compromise.

"Our goodwill offer stands to send a small van and collect the whole backlog if the Cales will accept lane-end collection," said Mr Johnson.

webTitle: Water deal blocked

fields.headline: Water deal blocked
fields.standfirst: Whitehall departments link up to halt not-for-profit firm taking over Welsh Water
fields.trailText: Whitehall departments link up to halt not-for-profit firm taking over Welsh Water.
fields.body:
An unlikely alliance of three leading Whitehall departments is engaged in a campaign to scuttle plans by a new not-for-profit company to take over Welsh Water, the Guardian has learned.

The trade and industry department (DTI), environment department (DETR) and Treasury are understood to be pressing Philip Fletcher, the new water industry regulator, to reject Glas Cymru's agreed £1.8bn bid to buy Welsh Water from its US owners, WPD.

Mr Fletcher, head of Ofwat, is due to rule on the Glas Cymru plans within the next few days. Critical factors include financing the new company through debt, rather than equity, and outsourcing daily operations and customers to one or several established water companies.

Ofwat's ruling, initially expected to favour Glas Cymru, is eagerly awaited by other water groups seeking to boost earnings and share price through alternative ways of separating assets from operations than the mutual model rejected by Mr Fletcher's predecessor, Sir Ian Byatt, last year.

The Whitehall campaign threatens to open a rift between London and the national assembly for Wales led by first minister Rhodri Morgan. The assembly, the bulk of opinion-leaders and, less strongly, union leaders in Wales, favour the Glas Cymru plans.

Sources close to the sustained negotiations suggested yesterday that an Ofwat ruling against Glas Cymru could open the way for Nomura, the Japanese bank, to take over Welsh Water.

The bank's private equity division, headed by Guy Hands, was pipped at the last minute in the bidding battle for Hyder, Welsh Water's then owners, by WPD. Its final offer was £557m plus debt of £1.9bn - and Welsh sources believe it could now pay considerably less and then sell on for a profit.

The Whitehall trio's alliance masks substantial differences, say insiders. The DTI, closely linked to Ofgem, the energy regulator fiercely opposed to the Glas Cymru, is said to be wedded to the equity model of funding a privatised monopoly industry such as water.

It believes shareholders alone provide the necessary incentives for efficiencies and lower bills for customers and insists the Glas Cymru model of raising capital through bonds is flawed. The not-for-profit company, it insists, may not reach its target of £300m reserves to cover "shock" events such as drought or 5% cuts in bills by 2005.

The Treasury, which scuppered plans to make Scottish water companies mutuals, does not want to be provider of last resort. The DETR opposes the separation of assets from operations - on the basis that this would repeat the disastrous split between Railtrack and the train operators.

Nigel Annett, executive director of Glas Cymru, defended plans to outsource up to 85% of Welsh Water's activities. "Our model is that pursued in France and, increasingly, in America."

webTitle: House price gap likely to narrow

fields.headline: House price gap likely to narrow
fields.trailText: The north-south divide in Britain's housing market is likely to narrow this year as a recovery in the hard-pressed manufacturing sector boosts demand for property in the industrial heartlands, Halifax bank said yesterday.
fields.body:
The north-south divide in Britain's housing market is likely to narrow this year as a recovery in the hard-pressed manufacturing sector boosts demand for property in the industrial heartlands, Halifax bank said yesterday.

Although the past two months saw a widening of the gap between the two halves of the country, the bank said sales in the south would be affected by the explosive rise in prices recently, which had put them beyond the reach of many potential buyers.

Halifax's regional house price survey for the fourth quarter of 2000 found that property was dearer than in the third quarter but the annual pace of growth slowed to 5.7% from a peak of 14.5% in the first three months of last year.

In 2000 as a whole, prices tended to rise fastest in regions south of a line from the Bristol Channel to the Wash, with the fastest rates in East Anglia (13.7%) and the south-west (12.1%). However, house prices also rose by 10% in the West Midlands, despite its reliance on manufacturing. The two regions that saw a fall in prices were the north (-2.2%) and Scotland (-4.3%).

Greater London, where prices were rising at an annual rate of 29.5% early last year, saw the market cooling during 2000 with property inflation down to 8.3% in the final three months of the year. This trend was mirrored in the south-east, where prices fell in the final quarter of 2000. The average cost of a semi-detached house - the Halifax's benchmark of the market - in Greater London (£226,050) is five times that in South Humberside (£46,600). Surrey and Berkshire are the two next most expensive counties.

"The substantial rise in prices in this part of the country during 1999 resulted in affordability becoming an issue in these regions, making it increasingly difficult for buyers to enter the market," Halifax said. "This dampened demand and slowed price growth last year."

It added that the housing market had remained much more subdued outside the south of England, with little evidence of the"ripple effect", where a boom in one part of the country gradually spreads to other regions.

"This again largely reflects less buoyant economic conditions in most parts of Britain compared with the south of England.

"Slower economic growth in these regions has in part been due to their greater dependence on the manufacturing sector, which has continued to face difficult trading conditions."

Prices in the country as a whole rose by 0.9% in the fourth quarter of last year, slightly down on the 1.2% recorded in the third quarter.

webTitle: Interbrew ignored advice to delay flotation

fields.headline: Interbrew ignored advice to delay flotation
fields.trailText: Belgian beer firm Interbrew pressed ahead with its £9bn stock market flotation last month ignoring advice from a leading merchant bank that it should delay the move until a regulatory ruling on its recent purchase of Bass Brewers.
fields.body:
Belgian beer firm Interbrew pressed ahead with its £9bn stock market flotation last month ignoring advice from a leading merchant bank that it should delay the move until a regulatory ruling on its recent purchase of Bass Brewers.

Industry sources have revealed that Lehman Brothers, which advised Interbrew on the Bass deal, had "strong reservations" about the flotation. Lehman was not retained as an adviser for the public offering - Interbrew chose Merrill Lynch instead.

There was considerable surprise in the City that Interbrew proceeded with its flotation despite the risk of regulatory intervention in the £2.3bn acquisition of Bass's beer operations. At the time, Interbrew's chief executive Hugo Powell told investors he was confident that the deal would be cleared.

However, the trade and in dustry secretary, Stephen Byers, last week ordered Interbrew to sell Bass Brewers, which many analysts believe will leave the firm nursing an £800m loss.

Having been placed at €33 (£21) in December, Interbrew's shares jumped to €37. But Mr Byers' decision sent them down by a quarter in one day, and they changed hands for just over €26 yesterday.

Lehman Brothers said it could not comment on the ad vice it gave to clients. However, one source close to the deal said Lehman "expressed concern about doing an IPO at the same time as going through the regulatory process".

The source added that although not an official adviser on the share offering, Lehman was "asked for a view on it".

News of Lehman Brothers' concerns are bound to increase pressure on Mr Powell, who is said to have faced anger from shareholders since Mr Byers blocked the Bass deal. The company is considering a legal challenge to the decision.

Corneel Maes, an Interbrew spokesman, said it was "pure speculation" that Lehman had advised against the flotation. He said a delay would have pushed the share offering back to May. The company wanted to go earlier, in order to raise cash for further acquisitions.

"We weighed the pros and cons of both alternatives," Mr Maes said. "But the beer sector is consolidating fast and we didn't want to miss out on any opportunities."

Interbrew is still controlled by three Belgian families, who have 66% of the shares. Last month's flotation of a 21% stake raised £1.8bn.

The competition commission told Mr Byers that Interbrew's purchase of Bass Brewers would create a duopoly, with the Belgian firm and Scottish & Newcastle dominant in the beer industry.

webTitle: BAE Systems to disclose Nimrod losses

fields.headline: BAE Systems to disclose Nimrod losses
fields.trailText: BAE Systems, the UK's premier defence and aerospace group, is today expected to confirm market fears about losses on a key British military contract and warn that it is also suffering from a slowdown in UK defence orders. Another swingeing round of job cuts is also likely.
fields.body:
BAE Systems, the UK's premier defence and aerospace group, is today expected to confirm market fears about losses on a key British military contract and warn that it is also suffering from a slowdown in UK defence orders. Another swingeing round of job cuts is also likely.

BAE, formed from the £7bn merger of British Aerospace and what was then GEC's Marconi defence electronics arm, is set to accompany the gloomy trading statement with a 10-year plan to restore earnings growth and restructure its military business.

The group, which last September announced a 48% rise in pretax profits for the first half to £507m, was expected by some City analysts to produce full-year profits topping £1bn. But, after peaking in July last year at 453p, shares in BAE fell a further 11p yesterday to close at 356p on fears that delays to a £2bn contract to upgrade 21 Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft for the RAF could result in provisions of up to £450m.

While chief executive John Weston voiced hopes of a better earnings stream in the final six months of the year, the Nimrod debacle is now expected to overshadow the group's profitability through 2003.

Uncertainty about the full scope of any provisions for the Nimrod contract and lack of clarity in company statements have produced an erratic range of analysts' forecasts for BAE's full-year earnings. They range from £651m to £1.3bn.

It is known that BAE was forced to renegotiate the Nimrod contract, with the RAF finally agreeing to take delivery of the planes 23 months late, from 2005 instead of 2003. Last week company sources insisted the programme was back on track.

BAE has also been under siege over an alleged lack of orders for its Hawk trainer aircraft but has recently been named by India as preferred supplier for 66 of these jets.

Last year the group set in train plans to axe 5,300 staff, including 1,500 managers, and is widely expected to announce a further round of redundancies today, especially in the military business which has been hit by declining defence budgets.

But BAE, which has a £37bn order book, is expected to point to future earnings growth - notably once the transformation of Airbus, the European aircraft maker, into a stand-alone company is complete next month.

The UK group holds a 20% stake in the current consortium but is due to win greater returns on sales of the A340-500/600 widebodied jetliner. Its liabilities, linked to interest on state loans to launch new models, including the A380 superjumbo, could be reduced by £300m-400m when Airbus Integrated Company is launched.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Deutsche Börse is expected to raise up to 1bn (£632m) when it floats next month - a move designed to provide the Frankfurt exchange with the financial firepower to play a leading part in the ongoing restructuring of share trading in Europe, writes Mark Milner.
fields.body:
Exchange float may raise €1bn

Deutsche Börse is expected to raise up to €1bn (£632m) when it floats next month - a move designed to provide the Frankfurt exchange with the financial firepower to play a leading part in the ongoing restructuring of share trading in Europe, writes Mark Milner.

The exchange is expected to sell a 30% stake with some of the shares coming from its main shareholder, Deutsche Bank, but the bulk being provided by the exchange issuing new shares. The exchange has not yet put a value on itself but on the basis of existing profits figures and using a similar price/earnings ratio to those of other quoted exchanges it could have an overall value of €3bn.

An extraordinary meeting of shareholders has been called for January 18 to approve the capital increase but more details of the public offering are expected to be made avalaible this week.

Goldman tries to recoup $8m

Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, is asking its rivals each to repay $500,000 it paid them for their help with sales of its shares last year.

Goldman Sachs floated 18 months ago. Its former partners sold 40m shares last summer and up to 16 of its rivals participated in an exercise, regularly undertaken to help stabilise shares after a mass sale. But, Goldman accidentally overpaid them for the role they played and is trying to recover $8m.

Pension funds drop in value

The value of British pension funds fell 1.8% last year, the first decrease since 1994, according to a report yesterday from performance consultants WM Company.

Dragging down performance were investments in UK equities, which make up half of the typical British pension fund. These declined 4.5% last year, compared with a gain of 24.1% in 1999. Overseas equities fell 6.5%. Propping up the funds were bonds, which rose in value by 8.5% last year, and continued strong returns from property investment, up 10.2% during the year.

OECD tax plan under fire

Offshore financial centres in the Caribbean and Pacific yesterday branded crackdown by industrialised nations on tax evasion as an assault on their livelihoods.

Meeting representatives of the OECD in Barbados, the offshore centres complained that wealthy nations were trampling on their sovereignty by threatening sanctions against them without proper consultation.

The two sides agreed on the need for transparency in tax regimes and effective exchange of information but clashed about the way forward.

webTitle: Second wanted man found dead in shame campaign

fields.headline: Second wanted man found dead in shame campaign
fields.trailText: Two men who featured on West Midlands police's controversial 10-strong "most wanted" list have been found dead in unexplained circumstances, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Two men who featured on West Midlands police's controversial 10-strong "most wanted" list have been found dead in unexplained circumstances, it emerged yesterday.

An investigation was launched after a man whose 40sq ft mugshot was beamed on to the side of the force's headquarters was found dead on a Birmingham river bank.

He was the second man from the rogues' gallery to die in two months since their pictures were put on the internet and displayed in public places, including bus stops, billboards and near a motorway exit.

Detectives had been hunting Damian Vernon, 23, since he jumped bail last year while facing five criminal charges. On Monday afternoon his body was found beneath the M6 next to the river Tame in the Bromford area of Birmingham.

An autopsy proved inconclusive and more tests are being carried out on the body, which police said showed evidence of minor injuries.

The matter has been referred to the police complaints authority.

Less than two months ago Glen Foster, a street robber, whose picture also featured in the rogues' gallery, was found stabbed to death in London.

At the launch of Operation Safer Streets, fears were voiced that the campaign could spark vigilante attacks, or lead to cases being thrown out by judges because trials might be prejudiced by the publicity.

The police have vowed to carry on with the project and dismissed local suggestions that vigilantes might be targeting those on the wanted list.

Vernon was one of three suspected street robbers whose photos were projected on to the side of Birmingham police headquarters. Police described the images as the city's "alternative Christmas lights".

Vernon's family has made an official complaint to the police complaints authority about his appearance on the wanted list.

Yesterday police said they had been making inquiries about Vernon in Bromford the previous day. Because of the the force's involvement in the case, they were voluntarily referring the matter to the complaints authority.

A spokesman, Jon Clarke, said: "An outside force will be asked to examine the circumstances of Mr Vernon's death." He added: "This is not currently being treated as a murder inquiry."

Vernon was due to appear before magistrates more than eight months ago to face three counts of robbery and two of theft of a motor vehicle.

The police spokesman said: "Our decision to publicise the names and faces of wanted criminals is not affected. We remain of the view that this is a logical and appropriate tactic."

But Malcolm Fowler of Birmingham's Law Society warned that lawyers defending clients would seek to get cases thrown out. He said: "The Human Rights Act requires that people have a right to privacy which is denied by this scheme. The family may well have a claim because if it can be proved there is a link here, they may well have a very significant civil claim that can be brought against the police."
