webTitle: Shares fuelled buying spree

fields.headline: Shares fuelled buying spree
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US has become a nation of shareholders. Between 1983 and 1999, the number of households owning shares rose by 86% to 78.7m, according to the Investment Company Institute, a trade body.
fields.body:
The US has become a nation of shareholders. Between 1983 and 1999, the number of households owning shares rose by 86% to 78.7m, according to the Investment Company Institute, a trade body. Almost half of all Americans now own shares either directly or indirectly through pension plans and savings.

The euphoria caused by a decade of strong performance by US stock markets was credited with spurring much of the consumer spending frenzy which has driven a large part of the record-breaking US economy over the past decade.

Now economists worry that collapsing share prices will hold back consumer spending and exacerbate the slowdown.

John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investor Services, fears that the downturn could lead to a vicious circle: "Lower stock prices can impact consumer spending, result in downsizing and force companies to stop ordering. Companies could be forced to lay off people to produce better earnings," he said.

The impact is likely to be felt keenly over the next few weeks, when millions of Americans will receive their mutual fund statements for last year. The average mutual fund investing in the US stock market lost 4.51% of its value last year, according to the performance tracking group Lipper.

Of real concern is the high level of debt held by many Americans. In the third quarter of last year, households spent more than they earned for the first time since the 1930s as people borrowed on the back of wealth which has declined as stocks have fallen.

Joshua Feinman, chief economist at Deutsche Bank, says that some of the fall in an individual's net worth is likely to be offset by continuing high house prices in the US.

webTitle: Gulf veterans left in cold

fields.headline: Gulf veterans left in cold
fields.standfirst:
Balkans troops to be screened for uranium

Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: The government yesterday bowed to intense domestic and international pressure by agreeing to screen Balkans veterans for signs of contamination from depleted uranium used in US anti-tank shells.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor and Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
The government yesterday bowed to intense domestic and international pressure by agreeing to screen Balkans veterans for signs of contamination from depleted uranium used in US anti-tank shells.

But the announcement infuriated Gulf war veterans, whose supporters labelled the refusal to offer the tests to troops in previous conflicts a "vicious injustice".

In an embarrassing u-turn, foreshadowed in yesterday's Guardian, John Spellar, the armed forces minister, told MPs that British troops who had served in Kosovo and Bosnia, as well as civilians working there, would be offered what he called "an appropriate voluntary screening programme".

He said Britain would step up its environmental monitoring of the Balkans and pool data collected by the UN and European allies, which have already introduced emergency screening for their troops. Until yesterday, the MoD had repeatedly spurned the need for any screening for DU.

But Mr Spellar insisted there was no evidence linking DU shells to ill health. He did not offer the new tests to troops in the Gulf war even though far more of the controversial weapons were fired there than in the Balkans.

Mr Spellar delivered a robust defence of DU shells, used in British tanks as well as US aircraft, insisting they provided a "battle-winning military capability". He said: "Because of its density and metallurgic properties, depleted uranium isideally suited for use as a kinetic energy penetrator in anti-armour munitions".

At Nato headquarters in Brussels, Britain and the US joined forces to kill off an Italian proposal, backed by Germany, for the alliance's 19 member countries to stop using depleted uranium ammunition until further notice.

Mr Spellar conceded that debris from DU shells might present a "hazard from chemical toxicity" and a "low-level radiological hazard". Those risks, he said, arose from dust created when the weapons hit targets, but as expended rounds or fragments the hazards of DU were "negligible".

He said Gulf veterans - the cause of whose illnesses, he added, had not been discovered - had been offered screening for a "whole body load of uranium". But these tests were derided as inappropriate by Gulf war veterans and their medicaladvisers.

Malcolm Hooper, emeritus professor of medicinal chemistry at Sunderland University, described the Ministry of Defence move as a "cynical betrayal" and "vicious injustice".

The MoD, he said, was testing for high-level exposure to soluble material, rather than long-term, low-level, exposure to radiation inside the body. It was indulging in "Mickey Mouse science".

Terry Gooding of the Gulf War Veterans Association said the MoD had never screened members for DU symptoms. Michael Burrows, senior coordinator of the association, said: "Mr Spellar said there is an insignificant danger posed by radiation from depleted uranium, but what about the dust and the effect it has on the lymphatic system?"

He added: "I can't see that the voluntary screening will have any benefit whatsoever. The screening that he is talking about is for uranium, not depleted uranium."

Ministers are expected to await the publication of a report on DU being prepared by the Royal Society, expected in the summer , before finalising details of the screening programme.

Bruce George, chairman of the Commons defence committee, who had been threatening to mount his own inquiry into the affair, warned it was essential that the research was carried out as quickly as possible. "If it is true that there is a link between depleted uranium and leukaemia cancer, then people are going to die," he said.

The government's announcement - pressed on the MoD by Downing Street - follows a spate of leukaemia cases among Balkan veterans in Italy, France, Portugal and Denmark, though scientists differ over whether the number is exceptional within the total groups.

Professor Eric Wright, an expert on radiation-induced leukaemia at the University of Dundee, said: "The diagnosis of leukaemia in many of these people is very soon after the alleged exposure. Whilst you can never say never in science, this does seems extraordinarily unlikely to be causal."

Norwegian peacekeepers yesterday refused to sign contracts for service in Kosovo, demanding a clarification of the risk from ammunition that included DU.

webTitle: Letters: It's ethical

fields.headline: It's ethical
fields.trailText: We welcome the news that Christian Aid and Oxfam are switching their staff pension plans to ethically screened investments (Charities pull funds out of arms firms, January 8). But one is bound to say: "Not before time!"
fields.body:
We welcome the news that Christian Aid and Oxfam are switching their staff pension plans to ethically screened investments (Charities pull funds out of arms firms, January 8). But one is bound to say: "Not before time!"

Traidcraft's pension plan has had an ethical investment policy for more than a decade, and last year Traidcraft and War on Want jointly secured £136,000 of Lottery funding to provide pension plan trustees and advisers with information about the impact of their investment policies on the "third world"

However, if socially and ethically-aware organisations like Oxfam and Christian Aid have only just announced their switch in policy, how many others have yet to examine how their staff pension plans are invested?
Philip Angier
Traidcraft
Rob Cartridge
War on Want

webTitle: Letters: Spending on our schools

fields.headline: Spending on schools
fields.trailText: Your anonymous correspondent (Letters, January 5) alleges that we have "cleverly linked the violent children with the disabled" in our policies on exclusion and special needs.
fields.body:
Your anonymous correspondent (Letters, January 5) alleges that we have "cleverly linked the violent children with the disabled" in our policies on exclusion and special needs, and goes on to claim that with our exclusion policy the teacher is "protected less and less". Both these characterisations are wholly false.

We have drawn a very clear distinction between children with behavioural difficulties and those with disabilities. By providing extra money for schools access - £50m for the coming year - we can make schools better equipped for children with disabilities. But both David Blunkett and I have always been very clear that special schools have a vital continued role, not least for children with emotional and behavioural difficulties.

Schools continue to be able to exclude violent or disruptive pupils. The difference now is that we have increased by 1,000 the number of places in off-site pupil referral units since 1997 and are moving to a full-time education in them. Previously, they were excluded to the streets. New in-school units enable teachers to get disruptive pupils out of the classroom quickly on a short-term basis. The £174m I announced to curb classroom misbehaviour will permit the funding of more of both types of provision.

There are 7,000 more teachers in the classroom now than two years ago and we have greatly reduced the paperwork from this department and the curriculum authority to schools this year. Since we are spending £450 more per pupil from April 2001 in real terms than was spent in 1997, it is quite absurd to suggest that any of these measures are designed to "save money".
Jacqui Smith MP
Schools standards minister

webTitle: Letters: Battle lines

fields.headline: Battle lines
fields.trailText: Lesley Abdela misses the point about women soldiers (So many male stupidities, January 9). A woman of child-bearing age is more valuable to a country than a man of child-begetting age.
fields.body:
Lesley Abdela misses the point about women soldiers (So many male stupidities, January 9). A woman of child-bearing age is more valuable to a country than a man of child-begetting age.

If most of a country's young men were killed, the population could be restored in one generation, but if most of the young women were killed, the country might never recover. Hence the old tradition of putting men only in the front line of battle.

The tradition is lapsing now, because of the way warfare has changed. With aircraft and ballistic missiles, 90% of war casualties are civilians, and armed forces, even in the front line, are comparatively safe.
Donald Rooum
London

Here in Surrey, we should be delighted even if our libraries were open from Monday to Saturday, and if we did not have to pay a fee to have a book sent to us from another branch of our own library service.

Leatherhead, Surrey

webTitle: Letters: Depleated uranium

fields.headline: Depleted uranium: civilian research is also needed
fields.trailText: The terrible result of the last 10 years of carnage in the Balkans extends beyond its effect on peacekeeping troops.
fields.body:
The terrible result of the last 10 years of carnage in the Balkans extends beyond its effect on peacekeeping troops. Since the Bosnian conflict we have been reviewing aspects of health care in Sarajevo - and disquieting phenomena are appearing. There is substantial anecdotal evidence that there has been a great increase in the number of malignant soft tissue and bone tumours since the end of the war. These are frequently presented to one of us, an orthopaedic surgeon, on his regular visits to Sarajevo. In the last two years the number of tumours has at least equalled those seen in a similar-sized population during 20 years of practice in the UK.

We do not know if the shells landing on Sarajevo contained depleted uranium, but this is surely a matter for investigation. More generally, it is crucial that there are formal epidemiological investigations of diseases in all post-conflict areas - and that we do not confine concern to members of external armed forces.
John Beavis
James Ryan
Leonard Cheshire Centre of Conflict Recovery

 Last February, I attended a seminar at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office in which Derek Plumbly, then head of the Middle East section, said that the FCO was going to cooperate with the Department for International Development and with the World Health Organisation on research into the health effects of depleted uranium in southern Iraq (Climbdown on Gulf war syndrome, January 9).

When I probed Ron White of DfID, he said that it would only support research into the health effects of the Iraqi regime's use of chemical weapons in Halabja in 1988. Subsequent correspondence I received from Peter Hain confirmed that the British government was not interested in research into the impact of DU on the Iraqis.

Now that the cover-up of the dangers to which British soldiers were exposed has been revealed, the government has one less incentive for obstructing research into the military use of contaminated material in Iraq and Kuwait.
Dr Kamil Mahdi
Institute of Arab and Islamic Studies, University of Exeter

 Surely there is a paradox at the heart of the current controversy over the use of depleted uranium armour piercing shells in Kosovo? During its air campaign, Nato was strongly criticised for not allowing its pilots to venture below 15,000ft and, as a result, failing to destroy more than a handful of Serb armoured vehicles.

Given that the real danger from depleted uranium occurs after the warhead strikes armour plate with enough energy to penetrate and fireball - creating ultrafine residues of toxic uranium oxide - the presence of significant uranium oxide contamination in Kosovo would suggest that Nato war planes were flying much lower than 15,000ft and hit many more armoured vehicles than we were led to believe.
Dave Parker
Bishop's Stortford, Herts

Since the Bosnian conflict we have been reviewing aspects of health care in Sarajevo - and disquieting phenomena are appearing. There is substantial anecdotal evidence that there has been a great increase in the number of malignant soft tissue and bone tumours since the end of the war. These are frequently presented to one of us, an orthopaedic surgeon, on his regular visits to Sarajevo. In the last two years the number of tumours has at least equalled those seen in a similar-sized population during 20 years of practice in the UK. We do not know if the shells landing on Sarajevo contained depleted uranium, but this is surely a matter for investigation. webTitle: Letters: The other life sentences

fields.headline: The other life sentences
fields.trailText: As a victim-support volunteer I have met many murder victims' relatives and have no doubt that every one serves a life sentence (Bulger killers granted anonymity for life, January 9).
fields.body:
As a victim-support volunteer I have met many murder victims' relatives and have no doubt that every one serves a life sentence (Bulger killers granted anonymity for life, January 9). There is no punishment that can resolve their grief because it cannot bring back the dead. But a life sentence served in prison is an exception in our criminal justice system. Those who have killed and been punished are released and live among us.

Two young men, when boys, committed the terrible crime of the murder of James Bulger. In order to be considered for parole they will have to have demonstrated that they feel remorse, and as lifers they will be under supervision for the rest of their lives. The energy that would go into hounding Thompson and Venables could be better employed while, we can only hope, they do their best to justify their second chance.
Anne Day
Woodbridge, Suffolk

 Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss was right in her ruling in the Bulger case, and right for more reasons than anyone has yet outlined.

The original purpose of the criminal law, as the earliest surviving English laws illustrate, was to prevent vendettas by putting a stop to private vengeance. It is essential to keeping the peace that the state should defend its monopoly on the use of force. Any threat to that monopoly has potentially anarchist implications.

It is the state's duty to prevent private vengeance by all means in its power.
Lord Russell
House of Lords

 What an appalling indictment of journalism in this country that three major newspaper groups opposed the granting of permanent injunctions to protect the child killers of James Bulger (Precedent warning as judgment promises new lives in secrecy for icons of hate, January 9). How could they imagine that the nation's most senior family judge would give them the green light to pursue two young men for an offence committed when they were troubled youngsters in dire need of professional help?
Bill Jackson
Nottingham

 The crux of Desmond Browne's argument is that the right of papers to print absolutely anything should take precedence over prevention of acts of incitement. There has seldom been a better illustration of the prerogative of the harlot throughout the ages.

I'm sure the papers he represents would throw up their hands in pious horror at people "taking the law into their own hands" and assaulting either of the young men, all the while strenuously denying that publication of the details had anything to do with it - even though they published them in the most lurid manner possible.
Adam Walker
Hatfield

 Fifty years ago, a time-served notorious criminal would doubtless have been ostracised by his local community and received abusive mail from further afield had his whereabouts become public knowledge. But any suggestion that his life was endangered would have been met with incredulous laughter. Now, however, we have baying mobs outside courts and police stations endeavouring to enact the sort of lynching that was once the preserve of America's deep south - along with tabloid journalists inciting such behaviour.
David Lewin
Oxford

 How depressing to realise that the "icons of hate" in this country are a woman and two children.
Julia North
Manchester

webTitle: Leader: Checking on charity

fields.headline: Checking on charity
fields.standfirst: The commission has been too slow to act
fields.trailText: The commission has been too slow to act.
fields.body:
War Child UK, the charity set up to help victims of the Bosnian war, is in serious trouble. Luciano Pavarotti and five other celebrity patrons have walked out of the high-profile overseas aid charity. Eleven trustees have resigned. A joint investigation by the Guardian and Channel 4 News shows that Bill Leeson, one of its co-founders, and Mike Terry, a consultant, took a bribe from contractors building a Bosnian music therapy centre, named after the Italian tenor. Though it was later repaid to the charity,the two men are still involved with the charity. There is also grave concern about high administrative expenses, poor accounting, inadequate management structures.

A spokesman for Mr Pavarotti said yesterday that he did not want to be associated with anything corrupt. He had asked about a Liberian children's project, but had had to wait for a year before he could get the accounts to discover that administration had absorbed much of the expenditure. As a result, he personally directed that all future money from him for former War Child UK projects in Yugoslavia, Liberia and Guatemala should be funded by different charities, following which, when the Kosovo crisis broke, a $1m donation was sent to the United Nations refugee agency.

Nigel Osborne, professor of music at Edinburgh University and former director of music for the centre, described the bribe as "a catastrophical betrayal". It was the revelation of the bribe that prompted patrons to act. They called for the retirement of Mr Leeson, the dissolution of the management committee, and the transfer of the Pavarotti project out of War Child UK's control. But nothing happened, leading to an exodus of patrons and trustees. It was a sad development in a charity that won the support of a new generation of pop stars. Many of the biggest names helped raise money for it in the mid 1990s. Other patrons included Sir Tom Stoppard, the playwright, and Juliet Stevenson, the actor.

What lessons can be learned? The trustees clearly behaved responsibly. Thwarted by the charity's management, they wrote to the charity commissioners in June 1998 about the lack of reports to trustees and the refusal to arrange suitable meetings. They also complained of the "financial impropriety". Two further letters were sent the same year complaining about the lack of financial information, the reluctance of Mr Leeson to cooperate, and the need for a full-time paid trustee to fill in the gaps in their knowledge and to examine whether Mr Leeson could be dismissed. The chairman of the trustees called in an independent auditor and independent solicitors. Yet they were still unable to budge the charity's management. Hence the decision of 11 trustees to resign.

The charity commission is conducting a financial audit but has moved much too slowly. It is 30 months since it was alerted to serious problems in the charity and yet it has still not produced a report or made public any recommendations. The commission's procedures are notorious for being ponderous and antiquated. John Stoker, the chief charity commissioner, is planning to upgrade its monitoring role, helped by a two-year 40% boost to its funding that begins in April 2002. But with a current £20m budget and a staff of 500, it should already be able to move more quickly to deal with a serious complaint. Quite separate from its regulatory role, the commission needs to review the advice it gives trustees. War Child trustees wanted to dismiss their unsatisfactory managers but failed. With better advice, they should have been able to get their way.

webTitle: Letters: Reasons to be cheerful

fields.headline: Reasons to be cheerful
fields.trailText: It may well be that students' depression (The low country, January 9) is caused by poor diet, with stress (and medication) merely aggravating it.
fields.body:
It may well be that students' depression (The low country, January 9) is caused by poor diet, with stress (and medication) merely aggravating it. Many young people would almost certainly find that if they stopped eating junk and/or processed foods and began to eat meals that they prepared themselves from organic food the depression would lift of its own accord.

It is not more expensive to buy organic food, especially if you cook it yourself. It might even be cheaper. It is not only more effective, but also a much safer way of dealing with the problem than taking drugs - prescribed or otherwise.

I say this as a "chronic depressive" who has not had a depressed day since I adopted this way of eating four years ago.
Sara Neill
Tunbridge Wells, Kent
sara.neill@zoom.co.uk

 At the heart of people's experience of depression lie feelings of guilt and self-reproach. This is because the depressed state features fantasies (not necessarily "true") of having damaged or destroyed something that you love. Depression is therefore closely connected with aggression, anger and rage.

Our growing understanding that emotional and social experience are linked is very helpful here. Many groups in society have good reason to feel angry: poor people, ethnic minorities, women (and some men), those with health problems, workers in soul-destroying jobs and citizens appalled at what we are doing to the environment. You don't have to suffer directly to be angry at such collective problems.

While we continue to see depression as a matter for individuals, the incidence of it will continue to rise.
Prof Andrew Samuels
University of Essex

webTitle: Why you should beware of sharks in the jungle

fields.headline: Why you should beware of sharks in the jungle
fields.standfirst: Brazil says conservationists duped into buying swaths of rainforest that did not belong to the seller
fields.trailText: Brazil says conservationists duped into buying swaths of rainforest that did not belong to the seller.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Conservationists in Europe and the US have been conned into buying vast swaths of Amazonian rainforest in order to protect it - by a Brazilian entrepreneur who had no right to sell it - the Brazilian government has claimed.

Felb Saraiva de Farias used the non-government organisation Forever Green - despite its environmentally friendly name - as a cover for peddling false land titles in the world's largest rainforest, it is alleged.

Mr de Farias is said to have sold thousands of hectares he did not own to foreigners with the promise the land would be preserved. The environmental groups allegedly duped by him have not yet been identified.

"He fooled European and US citizens, selling them land that belongs to Brazil," said the agrarian reform minister, Raul Jungmann. "This is a crime that extends abroad. We have asked the Brazilian intelligence service for help in this investigation."

It is not uncommon for environmentalist groups to buy endangered and ecologically rich land. The Amazon rainforest is shrinking at a rate which could destroy 42% of its area within 20 years, according to a recent survey.

The allegations of sustained fraud across the Amazon is bound to raise fears that large areas of forest, which were thought to be protected, remain vulnerable to development and exploitation.

Forever Green was formed in 1991 by a group including Mr de Farias, who donated 50,000 hectares (about 125,000 acres), 500 miles from Manaus, in the centre of the Amazon. By his own estimates, Mr de Farias owns 6m hectares in the Amazon. On legal advice, he refuses to speak to the press.

Alfredo Lopes, Forever Green president, denies his company's involvement in any wrongdoing. He said its aims were to conserve rainforest and study sustainable development. Mr de Farias, however, was asked to leave Forever Green in 1995 when they realised that his only interest was mercenary. It is understood that he continued to offer land for sale to various interested buyers after 1995.

The environmental groups Nature Conservancy and Greenpeace say they had never heard of Forever Green.

"I've never seen a piece of work they've done and I've never seen them at a conference. They are not part of the environmental movement," one Greenpeace Amazon campaigner, Nilo D'Avila, said

The allegations are the result of a continuing governmental investigation into who owns what in the Amazon. Two years ago, the ministry for agrarian reform started a survey of titles and promptly found that 25m hectares were suspect.

Due to Brazil's vast size - the country has a land mass larger than the continental United States - many remote jungle areas go largely unregulated, making it possible to accumulate land titles illegally and without federal knowledge.

Some landowners have titles dating back hundreds of years, handed out by the Portuguese crown. Others falsify documents at local land-register offices.

"It's very easy to commit fraud. In the Amazon the register office might be in a poor town of 2,000 people. If you bribe the registrar, you can get whatever you want," Mr D'Avila said.

He added: "A favourite technique is to divide a territory into smaller parts, and then declare the size of each part as big as the original territory. You have immediately multiplied your land."

The investigation into who owns the Amazon basin has put the spotlight on a few men, such as Mr de Farias, whose property is apparently the size of some countries in Europe.

Mr de Farias had documents which showed him owning land the size of Ireland, but these were cancelled by the Brazilian government.

One of the largest slices of privately held property in Brazil - the size of Portugal and Belgium - was last year registered to one Carlos Madeiros, until it was discovered that Mr Madeiros did not exist. His name was a front.

webTitle: Things can't get better in just one term, says Blair

fields.headline: Things can't get better in just one term, says Blair
fields.standfirst:
Parties fire first electioneering salvoes as Tories launch poster campaign and PM promises new reforms on crime, welfare and schools

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Parties fire first electioneering salvoes as Tories launch poster campaign and PM promises new reforms on crime, welfare and schools.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is set to unveil a 10-year plan to crack down on crime within the next few weeks, swiftly followed by schemes for widespread reform of welfare to work and of secondary education, he revealed yesterday.

The initiatives - to be unveiled before the anticipated May 3 election - are expected to follow the model of the 10-year NHS and transport plans, both announced in July. The reforms were described by Mr Blair as a "massive programme", suggesting Labour's confidence in winning a second term in office.

The commitment came as Mr Blair spoke to Labour members, businessmen, health officials and schoolchildren at a conference centre in Bristol in what was the first serious salvo of the unofficial election campaign. Before fielding questions on renationalisation of the railways, student tuition fees, and inadequate funding of student nurses, Mr Blair admitted that "for 20 years or more, Britain has suffered from chronic underinvestment in our public services - schools, hospitals, police, transport".

He pledged to rectify this by announcing "the largest ever sustained investment in public services Britain has seen".

The prime minister said money would be channelled into schools - particularly secondaries - the rail system, hospitals, and more police officers. But spending was not the only answer, and, as with the NHS plan which highlighted inefficiencies in the system, each area would undergo radical reform, with "steadily higher standards" demanded.

In an upbeat speech, in which he stressed the skill of the government in handling the economy - repeating the mantra "choice not chance" several times - and the importance of not blowing this economic stability, Mr Blair suggested his reforms were prompted by "one big overarching national purpose: to build a Britain in which prosperity spreads to every corner of the land, every party of every city, every family and child.

"It won't happen by chance, but the choices we as a nation make," he said.

As the Tories stepped up their pre-election campaign by unveiling new posters attacking Labour's pledges on public services, Mr Blair argued "20 years of neglect" were "never going to be put right in just one term of office".

He derided the Tories as the "people who doubled the national debt" for "telling us how to spend the surplus", and, "most comic of all, the people who gave us a botched privatisation of the railways, and failed to invest in them, say things would be better if they were in charge again".

But he also told his audience: "The biggest danger we face is apathy and cynicism; those people saying they're all the same - what's the point of voting."

In contrast to his earlier appearance in the day, when he was pelted with tomatoes, the invited questioners were largely appreciative, though there were cries of "shame" when Bristol West MP Valerie Davey tried to bring the session to a close after just nine questions.

Mr Blair faced tough questioning from Susan Lowther, aged 35, a student nurse at the University of the West of England and mother of three, who told him she could barely afford accommodation in Bristol on her meagre £390-a-month student nurse bursary, and was having to work seven days a week "just to make ends meet. Don't you care about us, so we can care about other people?" she asked, her voice breaking.

Mr Blair faced tough questioning from Susan Lowther, aged 35, a student nurse at the University of the West of England and mother of three, who told him she could barely afford accommodation in Bristol on her meagre £390-a-month student nurse bursary, and was having to work seven days a week "just to make ends meet. Don't you care about us, so we can care about other people?" she asked, her voice breaking.

webTitle: Taxman Hector gets early retirement

fields.headline: Taxman Hector gets early retirement
fields.trailText: With his bowler hat, pinstripe trousers and little moustache, he epitomised the stuffy image of the bumbling bureaucrat. But now the inland revenue has finally pensioned off Hector, the cartoon taxman.
fields.body:
With his bowler hat, pinstripe trousers and little moustache, he epitomised the stuffy image of the bumbling bureaucrat. But now the inland revenue has finally pensioned off Hector, the cartoon taxman.

The service thinks few staff will be sorry to see the character go, admitting Hector had become something of a hate figure within the inland revenue as well as among the long suffering public.

Hector was brought in five years ago to front the inland revenue's self assessment campaign. But since then, the creation has grown to represent the service as a whole.

Last night, Claudine Lashley, an inland revenue spokeswoman, said Hector had done a good job in drawing attention to the self assessment campaign. But the nature of the department had changed.

"We want something that represents the diversity of our customers and the people who work for the revenue," she said. "Although everyone recognises who Hector is and he certainly got the message across, we thought that maybe the bowler hat and the pinstripe trousers were not really very appropriate to modern times."

She said the decision was taken by the revenue's new marketing director, Ian Schoolar. There were no immediate plans for a successor to Hector.

webTitle: Gynaecologist 'nearly pulled me off bed' in forceps birth, says mother

fields.headline: Gynaecologist 'nearly pulled me off bed' in forceps birth, says mother
fields.trailText: A mother sobbed yesterday as she told an inquiry that a gynaecologist used such force during a forceps delivery that he left her son with bruising to his head and almost dragged her off the bed.
fields.body:
A mother sobbed yesterday as she told an inquiry that a gynaecologist used such force during a forceps delivery that he left her son with bruising to his head and almost dragged her off the bed.

Nicola Cummins, 30, said Janusz Wszeborowski, 63, was "very forceful and very rough" as he delivered Matthew at the Queen Elizabeth hospital in Gateshead, Tyne and Wear. Two midwives and her husband, Geoffrey, had to cling on to her, she told the hearing of the General Medical Council's professional conduct committee in central London.

Mrs Cummins, a secretary, said: "It was very painful ... I felt myself being pulled down the bed. Geoffrey took hold of my shoulders and pulled me back."

Mr Cummins, 31, told the inquiry he had sobbed as he desperately tried to keep his wife on the bed as Dr Wszeborowski pulled hard on the forceps.

"I expected it to be difficult and hard work, but I wasn't expecting the amount of force he used," Mr Cummins said. "I was holding her down when it felt as though her insides were being ripped out."

Another of Dr Wszeborowski's patients, Joanne Lavin, told the hearing that he was "like a man possessed". She said she felt she was "going to die" as he gave her an episiotomy without enough anaesthetic.

He then tried to deliver her daughter, Emily, with a ventouse suction cap, throwing the cap across the floor "in absolute temper and frustration" when the procedure failed, Mrs Lavin said.

His excessively forceful attempts to deliver the baby with forceps repeatedly dragged her and her 16-stone husband, Paul, who was holding her arms, down the bed, the GMC heard.

Mrs Lavin said she could "feel every stitch" as the gynaecologist sewed up the episiotomy with insufficient anaesthetic, ignoring the protests of a midwife.

"It was like he wasn't a doctor," she said."They could have pulled someone in off the street and it would have been exactly the same."

Lesley Pallister, 30, said she was hysterical as Dr Wszeborowski "yanked" on her baby's head with a ventouse cap. He had then used forceps, pulling so hard that he dragged the bed across the floor, even with the wheel brakes on.

When her son, James, was eventually delivered, his head was swollen to twice its normal size, he had a black eye and a cut to his ear, she added.

Dr Wszeborowski is charged with using excessive force to deliver the three babies, and with treating their mothers in an "inappropriate and insensitive" way. He is also accused of treating a fourth woman in an inappropriate and insensitive way during a gynaecological examination and causing a fifth patient "considerable anxiety and distress" by calling a colleague on his mobile phone to discuss her sensitive case within earshot.

Dr Wszeborowski, of Gateshead, denies serious professional misconduct. The hearing continues today.

webTitle: Bosnia soldier 'reduced to nothing'

fields.headline: Bosnia soldier 'reduced to nothing'
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Kevin Rudland served with the Territorial Army for 18 years and came top in fitness tests.
fields.body:
Kevin Rudland served with the Territorial Army for 18 years and came top in fitness tests.

He used to enjoy hill-walking, abseiling and parachuting and ran three miles a day, but now he has difficulty walking 200 yards without having to stop for a rest.

His life changed soon after he got back from a six-month tour of duty in Bosnia, where he served as a regular army engineer working for the international peacekeeping force.

Stationed in the Bosnian town of Banja Luka between December 1995 and April 1996, his job involved repairing tanks. He was given no protective clothing and believes he was exposed to depleted uranium while servicing tank tracks and gun barrels.

On his return home to the UK he set up his own business as an engineer but within weeks started to suffer ill effects, beginning with sudden and severe hair loss which left him bald by the winter. This was followed by post-traumatic stress disorder, rotting teeth, and osteoarthritis.

Mr Rudland, 41, a father of three who lives near Hull, East Yorkshire, is angry that he was not told of the health risk from depleted uranium.

He said the Ministry of Defence's announcement yesterday: that soldiers will be screened for cancer was "like a dream come true". He added: "I have been reduced to nothing by this illness. I have chronic fatigue and depression and all I want is for this to be recognised by the government."

Mr Rudland has emerged as the first recognised British case of Balkan war syndrome. It was only within the past year that it had come to Mr Rudland's attention that his condition now might be connected with depleted uranium, the former Royal Engineer said.

"This is a big problem that they've got and they need to look into it quickly. I may be the first in this country at the moment but I believe there are more that have not come forward or do not know yet.

"People have already died in Italy. [Five Italian soldiers who served in the Balkans have died of leukaemia.] I don't know what my future holds or whether the symptoms will carry on. I am unemployable.

"I think I am owed an explanation, for my benefit and for that of other servicemen and women."

Europe's response

 Irish soldiers who served in the Balkans are to be screened for signs of exposure to DU. A team of experts will leave Dublin for Kosovo and Bosnia this week to test 700 Irish troops who have served there since 1997.

 Ukrainian president Leonid Kuchma called for a moratorium on the use of DU ammunition when he inspected his country's peacekeepers in Kosovo yesterday.

 France said yesterday a fifth soldier who served in the Balkans had leukaemia but insisted there was nothing to link the illness to DU.

 Italy is to ask Nato to suspend use of DU ammunition until it is sure it is not linked to leukaemia.

 EU medical and scientific experts are to report next month on possible health risks of DU.

 Norwegian soldiers due to join peacekeeping forces in Kosovo this week demanded clarification of the risks from spent DU-tipped shells before leaving for a tour of duty.

webTitle: Pair intended to damage Trident sub, jury told

fields.headline: Pair intended to damage Trident sub, jury told
fields.trailText: A prosecutor told a jury yesterday that it would feel "utter respect and admiration for the strength and integrity" of the beliefs of two defendants accused of conspiring to damage a nuclear submarine.
fields.body:
A prosecutor told a jury yesterday that it would feel "utter respect and admiration for the strength and integrity" of the beliefs of two defendants accused of conspiring to damage a nuclear submarine.

There was "no doubt" that Sylvia Boyes, 57, from Keighley in West Yorkshire, and River (formerly Keith Harold Wright), 45, an Open University tutor from Manchester, "hold very strong opinions as to the evils of nuclear weapons", Elizabeth Nicholls told Manchester crown court.

They were found, dressed in wetsuits and carrying an axe, hammer and other tools, near HMS Vengeance in Barrow-in-Furness docks on November 23 1999, she added.

As members of the direct action group Trident Ploughshares, they planned to damage the Trident submarine at the Cumbrian shipyard, one of four submarines that carry Britain's nuclear deterrent.

Ms Nicholls added: "Both accepted that they had entered the docks with the intention of damaging the submarine."

Boyes was found first, the court heard. She had a hammer and screwdriver attached to her wetsuit belt, bearing anti-nuclear slogans.

River was then found in the water, equipped with hammers, a small axe and wire cutters.

He also had six cans of aerosol varnish.

Ms Nicholls said the pair believed they were acting lawfully because they believed that being in possession of a nuclear submarine was a crime.

She added that the two had read out prepared statements to the police, declaring their intention to "dismantle" the submarine.

Documents found in their possession, she said, included a pamphlet with instructions on how to dismantle a nuclear submarine safely, a CND newsletter, and signed statements of intent to "enter any Trident nuclear facility".

River was carrying a document which said, "Now the time has come to take action myself to do whatever I can", the jury was told.

A security guard, Hugh Crawford, told the court that Boyes told him she "intended to commit criminal damage". She called the submarine - which was at the shipyard for a refit - "a weapon of mass destruction".

Terry Munyard, defending Boyes, told the jury that although the submarine had no warheads on board, it was still "a floating nuclear reactor". The submarine was "very close" to residential areas of Barrow-in-Furness.

Both defendants deny the charge of conspiracy to commit criminal damage.

The trial continues.

webTitle: UN holds back on uranium warnings

fields.headline: UN holds back on uranium warnings
fields.standfirst:
No radiation risk, says official, as fears spread in Kosovo over legacy of bombing

Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: No radiation risk, says official, as fears spread in Kosovo over legacy of bombing.
fields.byline: Nicholas Wood in Klina and Jonathan Steele
fields.body:
The United Nations is resisting calls to protect children and other civilians in Kosovo from the potential health risks from depleted uranium left by British and American shells in contravention of its own expert advice.

On a hastily arranged trip designed to play down growing alarm in Nato countries, Bernard Kouchner, who heads the UN administration in the war torn territory, went to western Kosovo yesterday where most of the Nato shells were fired. He told reporters there was no radiation and he saw no immediate necessity to cordon off sites thought to be contaminated by the heavy metal.

His remarks flew in the face of recommendations from a panel of experts from the UN's own environment programme last autumn that all possible depleted uranium sites be sealed off from public access. On Monday the World Health Organisation also warned that depleted uranium was of potential danger to children in particular playing in contaminated areas.

As Dr Kouchner toured the site of a Nato air strike in the town of Klina, Italian soldiers equipped with white overalls and Geiger counters surveyed the wreckage of a destroyed Yugoslav tank and two armoured personnel carriers. He said no radiation had been detected.

"It might be better to close it because of all the tanks and all the holes, but I trust the soldiers. They are very precise and they did it several times." He added that the UN had not received any requests to close off the site off from the public.

Nearby Valmir Ademaj, 11, told reporters he and his friends had played inside the destroyed military vehicles and nobody had warned them not to go there. Beqir Rracaj, 74, said many people had taken parts of the tanks as souvenirs.

The potential danger from contamination by depleted uranium has been known to western governments for a long time. A month after Nato troops entered Kosovo Britain's government-funded national radiation protection board warned foreigners working in Kosovo, or visiting as journalists or aid staff, to keep clear of war-damaged Yugoslav vehicles.

"If access to potentially contaminated areas is deemed essential, advice should be sought from the Ministry of Defence or the Foreign Office on any protective measures required," it said in a warning posted on its website. But Britain and other western countries did not call for areas to be fenced off.

Most of the anxiety expressed in Nato countries has centred on the risk to their own citizens working as soldiers or police in Kosovo. Several cases of leukemia have prompted alarm. Britain and other countries are now starting a screening campaign for their nationals.

The team from the UN environment programme, which visited 11 potential depleted uranium sites last autumn, is due to publish its findings in February. In the meantime, it said, "where there is an apparent risk of contamination, signs should be put up to forbid public access".

Ironically, the Yugoslav government has taken more precautions since the war than Nato or the UN. It says it marked the eight sites in southern Serbia where up to 5,000 Nato shells landed. It has had no access since the war to the 100 sites in Kosovo where shells fell.

Slobodan Milosevic's government said use of depleted uranium shells "adds a new dimension to the crime Nato perpetrated against the Yugoslav people". The new western-backed government of Vojislav Kostunica has not repudiated this harsh language.

Zoran Stankovic of the Belgrade Military Academy hospital told a Belgrade newspaper this week that about 10% of uranium 238 turns on impact into toxic oxides, and 70% into aerosols, which are often more dangerous than radiation.

He warned that serious lung, kidney and bone disorders caused by toxic uranium particles inhaled or otherwise introduced in the body - with contaminated food or drink - could be expected in Yugoslavia.

The Serbian ecology minister, Dragan Veselinovic, said last week there was a danger of Nato bombs and radioactive ammunition "threatening to turn into live uranium and enter the food chain".

Pleurat Sejdiu, joint head of Kosovo's health department, dismissed the concern as propaganda. "People trust the Nato experts not to harm the population," he said.

Ibrahim Rugova, leader of Kosovo's biggest party, said yesterday that the depleted uranium scare in the Balkans was being misused by those who opposed Nato intervention in Kosovo in the hope that it would lead to withdrawal of the Nato-led peacekeeping force.

webTitle: Teen musical brings together divided inner city areas

fields.headline: Teen musical brings together divided inner city areas
fields.standfirst: The cast of a new musical are mostly unsung teenagers from two of Liverpool's poorest areas.  Deborah Mulhearn  attends rehearsals
fields.trailText: The cast of a new musical are mostly unsung teenagers from two of Liverpool's poorest areas. Deborah Mulhearn attends rehearsals
fields.body:
"And the two words for this evening are?" Sue Lancaster shouts into the jumble of laughing, lolling teenagers. It's a break from rehearsals for a new musical to be performed in a worryingly short time. "Energy and volume" they shout back. "No!" she roars, laughing herself now. "Volume and freeze. We need to sort out exits and when to freeze. Everyone's just flopping around at the end of a scene at the moment."

This is the only time director and choreographer Ms Lancaster does shout, and then only to make herself heard. Despite provocation - people fluffing lines, forgetting stage directions, talking in corners, or just not being there when they should be - she is good humoured throughout. For the most part, these young people are not professional actors, but part of a unique community arts project which is bringing together two very different inner city areas of Liverpool - areas that don't usually mix.

The teenagers will perform The Longest Night Alone later this month at Liverpool's Philharmonic Hall, the city's classical music hall and poshest venue, and they are taking it in their stride. They only started rehearsing a matter of weeks ago, and, despite appearances, only a couple of them knew each other beforehand.

The project has been organised by The Greenhouse, a children's arts and play centre based in Toxteth which grew out of the European year against racism in 1997. The centre's activities were originally aimed at pre-school children, but to stitch together the ever-expanding patchwork quilt of funding, Greenhouse director Debbie Wright found herself extending her own boundaries and ambitions. "This particular project is funded by the Liverpool central urban initiative and the criteria stipulated that we target the four electoral wards deemed to be the poorest," she said. These were the four closest to the city centre: Vauxhall and Everton to the north, and the more racially mixed Abercromby and Granby to the south, all with unemployment rates markedly higher than the national - and Liverpool's - average.

To advertise for participants, Greenhouse dropped flyers through every letterbox in the four wards. "We wanted to attract young adults sitting at home who fancied having a go but had no experience, rather than professionals," Ms Wright said. "Our aim was that it could be the starting point for a professional career, but it's mainly about increasing self-confidence and the motivation to succeed. And of course they are being trained."

The play is not overtly about race issues; rather, it's the existence of the project itself that is challenging preconceptions. Writer Curtis Watt wanted to make an original musical about modern times, using the ubiquitous mobile phone and pager culture to twist and turn events instead of a more traditional narrative. "There is a classical thread running through the story; I wanted a theme of death and rebirth but it's basically one day in the life of an inner city housing estate that's awaiting demolition, and the pressures that throws up," he said. It's a raw look at the issues and choices urban British teenagers and young adults have to face - debt, drugs, death, love and loyalties, on a mobile phone merry-go-round of misunderstandings, malice and misery. And it's a timely reminder of how society is failing them.

Mr Watt, who also wrote the score, was happy to introduce extra characters to showcase as much talent as possible. "We looked at people's skills and juggled them about. For instance we have a girl rapper who performs her own rap, but this moves the story along rather than just being incidental."

The musical style ranges from hip hop to operatic, he explains, because he wanted to reflect the all-inclusiveness of the project. "There aren't many cities in my experience where the natural balance is properly represented in a project like this," he said, though he does point out that it was difficult to persuade boys to audition. "It seems theatre isn't macho at the moment and we need to work on that."

Mr Watt himself joined the local youth theatre at 15 "to stay out of trouble", he says. And it worked. He has been involved in a lot of projects for black and other communities who don't usually access theatre, and he also performs around the country as poet and rapper C Zero.

Michael Ryan, who plays two parts in the play, knows all about the peer pressure that requires you to dismiss something that's not cool. "I was told I had a talent for acting at school but I was put off by my scally mates," he says. "But then I decided to take the stick." At 20, Michael is something of an old pro, having already landed the part of John Lennon's schoolfriend in a new film about the Beatle. He is one of the few members of the cast who has worked professionally. "There are a lot of first-time performers here and it's an excellent project for them because it's so supportive. The script is brilliant and there's a great atmosphere, but we've still got to reach the peaks it's demanding."

Michelle Barrett and Vicki Clarke, at 14 and 15 the youngest members of the cast, picked up the Greenhouse leaflets and braved the bus to the auditions. webTitle: Ethnic equality inquiry to shape social housing agenda

fields.headline: Ethnic equality inquiry to shape social housing agenda
fields.trailText: A shake-up of housing association provision for ethnic minority clients is in the pipeline, following the launch of an inquiry into racial equality in social housing. The investigation, which will also look at recruitment and development of black and Asian staff, aims to establish a new code of practice on race and housing for social landlords.
fields.body:
A shake-up of housing association provision for ethnic minority clients is in the pipeline, following the launch of an inquiry into racial equality in social housing. The investigation, which will also look at recruitment and development of black and Asian staff, aims to establish a new code of practice on race and housing for social landlords.

The inquiry is calling for ideas and evidence of good practice from tenants' groups, government bodies, think tanks and academic institutions, as well as members of the national housing federation (NHF) and the federation of black housing organisations (FBHO).

Set up by the commission for racial equality, the housing corporation and the NHF and FBHO, the inquiry panel will invite some contributors to attend hearings across Britain in April. It will produce a report in July, setting out a three-year action plan for improving racial equality.

Leading the inquiry is Leroy Phillips, who chairs Hexagon housing association. He said that although many registered social landlords (RSLs) have changed their approach to racial equality, good practice has not been consolidated since the watershed inquiry into the death of Stephen Lawrence.

"The Lawrence report did provide a renewed commitment to racial equality," said Mr Phillips, a census area manager for Lambeth, south London.

"It highlighted the need for landlords to do more to support victims of racial harassment and take action against the perpetrators. That is still limited. If we don't put tangible actions in place then we will have lost the moment."

He points to a forthcoming report from De Montfort University, Leicester, which is expected to show that many RSL policies and practices fail to look at the needs and aspirations of black and minority ethnic communities. While racial equality policies have been adopted by 98% of housing associations, only 21% have action plans.

He also cites a Salford University report for the housing corporation, showing that ethnic minorities are seriously under-represented at senior levels in housing associations - 56% of governing bodies have no ethnic minority members and black and Asian staff report discriminatory practices in recruitment, selection and promotion.

"It's what is commonly referred to as a glass-ceiling. Minorities have found that they progress through these organisations before being blocked. The inquiry intends to establish a holistic response to change that," Mr Phillips said.

"We want good, modern examples of practices that have worked in promoting racial equality and I hope we come up with solutions that are not just London-centric. We want far-reaching solutions that have appeal outside the capital."

 Submissions should be sent by March 2 to the Race and Housing Inquiry, c/o National Housing Federation, 175 Gray's Inn Road, London WC1X 8UP. Further information from Helen Williams on 020-7843 2261.

webTitle: Jobs under threat as Marie Curie feels fundraising pressure

fields.headline: Jobs under threat as Marie Curie feels fundraising pressure
fields.trailText: Fundraising review leads to withdrawal of top job offer and threat of redundancies at Marie Curie as high street slump hurts charity shops. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
A leading cancer charity, Marie Curie Cancer Care, is in a state of flux with the threat of up to 50 redundancies and withdrawal at the last minute of a job offer to a new fundraising director.

The developments are thought to represent further evidence of the impact on many top charities of the slump in profits from high street trading. Several are reviewing their fundraising operations.

Mark Astarita was offered the post of Marie Curie's fundraising and marketing director four months ago. He should have started the £65,000-a-year job last week, but the charity pulled out the day before his leaving party from his job as director of fundraising and PR at the National Deaf Children's Society (NDCS).

Marie Curie admits it withdrew the offer, explaining the move as part of a general review of fundraising operations. Community fundraising staff around the country are having to reapply for jobs.

Chris Dainty, spokesman for the charity, said: "Wherever possible, those staff affected by the changes are being offered redeployment or job shares, but there are likely to be a maximum of 50 redundancies.

"As part of the review, it was decided the vacant post of director of marketing, fundraising, PR and shops would cease to exist. This was absolutely no reflection on the considerable abilities of the successful candidate."

Marie Curie had, however, already issued a contract to Mr Astarita and he had attended a two-day conference. The whole exercise is likely to have cost the charity several thousand pounds in compensation and other expenditure.

The NDCS was also forced to waste a considerable sum, as it had already recruited a replacement for Mr Astarita. Its job advertisement in the Guardian had boasted that Mr Astarita was moving on to Marie Curie. By chance, the woman chosen was persuaded by her current employer to stay on, so Mr Astarita was able to keep his job, which was advertised at £36,000-£40,000.

Mr Astarita said: "I am very disappointed with what happened. I think there is a lot I could have done [at Marie Curie], but I am delighted to be staying at NDCS."

The new chief executive of Marie Curie, 46-year-old Tom Hughes-Hallet, is understood to have decided to take personal charge of fundraising. He joined the charity last autumn, leaving the lucrative post of chairman of merchant banker Fleming Private Asset Management.

His work managing the finances of the charity will be cut out, however. In the financial year to March 2000, its expenditure outstripped income by £1.4m, compared with a surplus of £900,000 in the previous year. The charity has said in a statement: "We are determined not to be in that situation again."

Marie Curie was founded in 1948 and has an annual income of some £63m. It employs more than 4,000 staff, including its famous Marie Curie nurses. It is also the biggest provider of hospice beds outside the NHS.

Andrew Watt, head of policy at the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers, said: "Income from charity shops played a major part in the fundraising mix of Marie Curie and I'm sure this general decline in income is a significant factor in their need to restructure. Oxfam is also restructuring to a degree, to take up the slack from charity shop income, but there is not enough evidence to point to a general trend towards restructuring."

webTitle: Why poverty figures are out of date

fields.headline: Why poverty figures are out of date
fields.standfirst: Large numbers have been lifted out of poverty but this May the statistics will still be showing the poor got poorer under Labour
fields.trailText: Comment: Large numbers have been lifted out of poverty but this May the statistics will still be showing the poor got poorer under Labour, predicts Malcolm Dean
fields.body:
An election approaches. Yet, almost unbelievably for a government which prides itself on its presentational skills, one of Labour's best achievements - particularly in the eyes of its most loyal supporters - will remain clouded in obscurity. Large numbers have been lifted out of poverty but this May the statistics will still be showing the poor got poorer under Labour.

What is wrong? Blame the statisticians. Key poverty figures (known in the trade as HBAI - households below average income) are drawn from the family resources survey. The latest figures, published last November, are drawn from the financial year ending March 1999. Thus they were already 18 months out of date on publication and will be more than two years out of date by the expected election date, May 3.

They ignore a succession of major anti-poverty initiatives that began after March 1999, including working families' tax credits, national minimum wage and minimum income guarantee for pensioners that are lifting 1.2m children and more than 800,000 adults out of poverty.

Do not doubt much malicious interpretation will be made by the Tory party and Tory press with the dated figures. Just look at last month's headlines greeting New Policy Institute's poverty audit, which rightly warned its statistics were old: "More people living in poverty under Labour" (Telegraph) and "Poor have risen by 500,000 under Labour" (Times). Tory spokesman David Willetts said it was "devastating evidence of the gap between Labour's rhetoric on poverty and the grim reality."

If unemployment stats can be published within two months and the Labour survey within three months, why does it take 18 months to produce poverty figures? Even in arcane statistical circles, it seems the poor come at the bottom of the queue.

Ministerial interference will be difficult. Labour has rightly made the statistical service more independent. What happened under the Tories must never be repeated - they destroyed public trust in official statistics with 20 different changes to unemployment data (all but one reducing the numbers), emasculated Social Trends, and malignly manipulated poverty figures.

Statisticians still feel beleaguered and defensive. But no one is asking for a change in accounting methods. All that is wanted is a more prompt response to collected facts. The analytical services division of the Department of Social Security proudly boasts on its website of 140 specialists and 285 staff. If the professionals have any pride, they won't need ministerial prompting to improve their promptness. They'll do it themselves.

webTitle: User consultation nets praise for care staff

fields.headline: User consultation nets praise for care staff
fields.standfirst: Home care managers in Bradford have been asking pensioners, in their own homes, how they rate services. As  Kendra Inman  reports, they got a pleasant surprise
fields.trailText: Home care managers in Bradford have been asking pensioners, in their own homes, how they rate services. As Kendra Inman reports, they got a pleasant surprise
fields.body:
Like many bosses, Bradford home care manager Jenny Hardy usually comes face to face with service users only when things have gone wrong and she's dealing with complaints. So when she left her office to visit elderly community care users in their own homes, she expected the pensioners to use the opportunity to list the service's shortcomings. To her surprise, however, many of them took the chance to say how much they appreciated the home help staff.

Unexpected praise was just one of the surprises to emerge from a ground-breaking experiment in user consultation when Ms Hardy and 10 fellow managers were sent "back to the floor" to find out what some of the city's most elderly citizens think of home care, day centres and other services on offer. The move came out of a joint project between Bradford social services and York University's social policy research unit (Spru), part of a department of health programme looking at service outcomes.

Charles Patmore, Spru research fellow, believes the Bradford experiment is a first for social services. Involving community care recipients in service development has become a key management goal, but tried and tested methods such as questionnaires and focus groups are less appropriate for the oldest clients. When asked by researchers for the trial scheme, many of this group said they would much rather give feedback from the comfort of their own homes and would like to do so direct to those in charge of the services.

Their reasons were straight-forward, says Mr Patmore, in that they wanted to show the decision-makers the problems they faced in everyday life. "They also believed that the involvement of senior managers would prove the consultation was more than a token gesture."

For their part, the managers overcame reservations about how much time the exercise would take and 11 managers, from two area offices, interviewed 30 randomly selected home care clients (half of whom were over 85) using an interview script drawn up by Spru.

It had been 10 years since John Howarth, area service manager for older people in the south of the Bradford district, had worked directly with clients (although his managerial duties include regular visits to care homes on his patch). He said the visits helped him get a more rounded view of clients' lives: "You get to see them not just in terms of being a service user but as a person. You see how the service fits in with their overall needs and aspirations."

The interviews helped the team learn the importance of recognising clients' previous lifestyles, said Mr Howarth, whose varied brief includes a large council estate and a small Pennine village. "If someone lived as part of a close family unit, there may be fundamental issues about the emotional support they need alongside help with daily tasks. Others may have had a lifestyle where they had been fairly self-sufficient and may not need or want the same level of support."

Celia Waller, who runs the care management team in the town of Keighley, said the interviews reminded her of the need for staff to communicate effectively. "You forget how important it is to service users to be told if someone such as a home help or meal deliverer is delayed. If they're housebound, they get terribly anxious if someone's late."

Mr Patmore admits that some managers feared meeting dissatisfied clients. And although the latter may have been fewer and less fierce than the managers feared, they still had plenty to say about where the service fell short of their expectations. Many of the elderly people Ms Hardy visited wanted a more thorough cleaning service, rather than the basic "hygiene clean" on offer now owing to spending constraints.

"They said no one dusts in out of the way places such as along the tops of pictures," she said. "I've been in the service for a long time and I remember when we could provide that level of domestic help. Help with the lighter tasks can be important psychologically. Frustration at not being able to maintain your home can make users depressed."

Some problems could be fixed, though, and the researchers found the managers took swift action to rectify a problem identified in an interview - something less senior personnel would probably have struggled to do. Mr Patmore recalled: "One interviewer was struck by how depressed someone was by their arthritis, a condition that was aggravated by a badly-designed flat. So they had them moved."

In another case, an interviewer met a man who relied heavily for company upon a failing television. The manager arranged for the set to be fixed. And the researchers found that some of the interventions, such as improving a day centre's activity programme, benefited many clients, not just the interviewees who prompted the moves.

Ms Waller found that interviewees sometimes disagreed about service shortcomings, however. "Some people said they wanted to see the same home help every visit; others said they liked a variety of helpers. Some said they liked the day centre activities; others said there weren't enough. The important thing is to respond to individual need," she said.

The interview programme resulted in 16 recommendations for change, some relating to the care of specific individuals, others pertaining more broadly to the direction the service should take. The department is in the process of integrating the recommendations into service plans.

The Spru researchers concluded that manager interviewers were a promising means of reaching older community care clients. And for at least some of the managers, "the fundamental purpose and value of their work was confirmed".

But it is being stressed that these interviews are something to be deployed occasionally - not an alternative to monitoring services through a review system - although there may be room to develop interviews by senior staff generally as a routine management tool.

Ms Hardy said the interviews taught her a great deal. "I started out at the bottom in home care," she said. "It was fascinating to go back to see how the service has altered and grown - and to see what has dropped off the end in the process."

Mr Howarth also found the experience rewarding. "Ideally it is something we could do on an annual basis," he said, "linking it into development and business planning." Ms Waller warns that departments may struggle to marry the clients' agenda with that of the social services department, driven by government. But even she agrees that going back to the floor was an exercise well worth repeating.

It had been 10 years since John Howarth, area service manager for older people in the south of the Bradford district, had worked directly with clients (although his managerial duties include regular visits to care homes on his patch). He said the visits helped him get a more rounded view of clients' lives: "You get to see them not just in terms of being a service user but as a person. You see how the service fits in with their overall needs and aspirations." The interviews helped the team learn the importance of recognising clients' previous lifestyles, said Mr Howarth, whose varied brief includes a large council estate and a small Pennine village. "If someone lived as part of a close family unit, there may be fundamental issues about the emotional support they need alongside help with daily tasks. Others may have had a lifestyle where they had been fairly self-sufficient and may not need or want the same level of support." Celia Waller, who runs the care management team in the town of Keighley, said the interviews reminded her of the need for staff to communicate effectively. "You forget how important it is to service users to be told if someone such as a home help or meal deliverer is delayed. If they're housebound, they get terribly anxious if someone's late." Mr Patmore admits that some managers feared meeting dissatisfied clients. And although the latter may have been fewer and less fierce than the managers feared, they still had plenty to say about where the service fell short of their expectations. Many of the elderly people Ms Hardy visited wanted a more thorough cleaning service, rather than the basic "hygiene clean" on offer now owing to spending constraints. "They said no one dusts in out of the way places such as along the tops of pictures," she said. "I've been in the service for a long time and I remember when we could provide that level of domestic help. Help with the lighter tasks can be important psychologically. Frustration at not being able to maintain your home can make users depressed." Some problems could be fixed, though, and the researchers found the managers took swift action to rectify a problem identified in an interview - something less senior personnel would probably have struggled to do. Mr Patmore recalled: "One interviewer was struck by how depressed someone was by their arthritis, a condition that was aggravated by a badly-designed flat. So they had them moved." In another case, an interviewer met a man who relied heavily for company upon a failing television. The manager arranged for the set to be fixed. And the researchers found that some of the interventions, such as improving a day centre's activity programme, benefited many clients, not just the interviewees who prompted the moves. Ms Waller found that interviewees sometimes disagreed about service shortcomings, however. "Some people said they wanted to see the same home help every visit; others said they liked a variety of helpers. Some said they liked the day centre activities; others said there weren't enough. The important thing is to respond to individual need," she said. The interview programme resulted in 16 recommendations for change, some relating to the care of specific individuals, others pertaining more broadly to the direction the service should take. The department is in the process of integrating the recommendations into service plans. The Spru researchers concluded that manager interviewers were a promising means of reaching older community care clients. And for at least some of the managers, "the fundamental purpose and value of their work was confirmed". But it is being stressed that these interviews are something to be deployed occasionally - not an alternative to monitoring services through a review system - although there may be room to develop interviews by senior staff generally as a routine management tool. Ms Hardy said the interviews taught her a great deal. "I started out at the bottom in home care," she said. "It was fascinating to go back to see how the service has altered and grown - and to see what has dropped off the end in the process." Mr Howarth also found the experience rewarding. "Ideally it is something we could do on an annual basis," he said, "linking it into development and business planning." Ms Waller warns that departments may struggle to marry the clients' agenda with that of the social services department, driven by government. But even she agrees that going back to the floor was an exercise well worth repeating.

webTitle: Call for new guidelines as contact visits cause concern

fields.headline: Call for new guidelines as contact visits cause concern
fields.trailText: Foster carers should not be required to host contact between foster children and their birth parents, according to a study which found that most carers did not like contact sessions in their homes.
fields.body:
Foster carers should not be required to host contact between foster children and their birth parents, according to a study which found that most carers did not like contact sessions in their homes.

Carers reported difficulties in getting birth parents to leave; awkward silences with nobody knowing what to say; and cases where birth parents had been aggressive or even arrived drunk. Most foster children, too, said they would rather go out on contact visits. One foster child told researchers: "It felt funny seeing my mum and my sisters in my foster home; it made me feel funny and tingly and ticklish inside."

The study was carried out by Birmingham Foster Care Association (BFCA), in response to a growing number of disputes over contact visits. Some carers mentioned such problems as reasons for giving up fostering; some potential fosterers were deterred by the contact issue. Seven of the BFCA's committee members, trained by the centre for social action at De Montfort University, Leicester, interviewed 22 foster carers, 16 of their own children, 14 foster children and nine birth parents.

A majority of carers said contact visits were negative experiences. One recalled a birth parent "opening the stereo and putting on records and coming in the kitchen and picking out what she liked". The carer said: "OK, I was looking after her child but not her as well."

One single carer told the researchers she felt particularly vulnerable during contact visits, while others cited resentment on the part of their own and other foster children at the intrusion. "We do find it quite difficult as we all sit there waiting for the visit to end," said one. Birth parents were more positive, often stressing the importance of being able to see where their children were living. But some spoke of feeling awkward or "inadequate" and were resentful in cases where the carer was required to supervise them.

Some foster children were happy with contact visits in the home, but a majority - where they felt safe with their relatives - said they would prefer to go out. One said: "It's all right at home, but it gets boring. I prefer to go out skating."

In a report on its research, the BFCA is calling for new guidelines on contact, appointment of contact workers, creation of special venues and the lifting of carers' contractual obligations to host visits. Steve Holloway, who chairs the association, said: "Too often the children and young people we are looking after are not experiencing the contact with their relatives that they need to develop and thrive."

 The research report is available at £5 inc. p&p from BFCA, Underwood Centre, Underwood Close, Erdington, Birmingham, B23 7HD
