webTitle: Fairer care charge plan gets muted welcome

fields.headline: Fairer care charge plan gets muted welcome
fields.standfirst: Plans to tackle glaring differences in charges for home care unveiled last week have been greeted with only limited and grudging approval by welfare groups, writes David Brindle
fields.trailText: Plans to tackle glaring differences in charges for home care unveiled last week have been greeted with only limited and grudging approval by welfare groups, writes David Brindle
fields.body:
Ever clearer become the government's problems in rejecting the idea of free personal care for elderly people. The latest fallout is a less than enthusiastic reception for plans to tackle glaring differences in charges for home care.

With ending all kinds of "postcode lotteries", one of Labour's great campaign themes, the consultative plans ought to have been a winner. But their publication last week has been greeted with only limited and grudging approval by welfare groups.

More than 500,000 elderly and disabled people in England and Wales receive home care services and charges vary widely. An audit commission survey found that charges for similar services in similar circumstances could range from nothing to £100 a week, with 30% of councils even charging people on income support. The government's proposals, to be introduced as statutory guidance by May for implementation in England no later than April next year, seek to eliminate the greatest - but not all - variation.

Main points include that charges should on no account reduce an individual's income below income support levels; that where disability benefits are taken into account in assessing a person's income, any charge should be "reasonable"; and that a maximum 55% of an individual's earnings should be taken into account as income, to ensure people are not discouraged from working.

The consultation paper, which commends as a model the approach of Torbay council in Devon, says the guidance should not result in any net loss of income to local authorities. "While some users will pay lesser charges, or cease to pay charges, better-off users may reasonably be expected to pay higher charges."

Had ministers accepted the full recommendations of the royal commission on long-term care, all personal care for elderly people would have been free. According to charity Age Concern, the draft guidance on charging proves it is "almost impossible" to devise a fair system of charging for personal care.

The charity is concerned that the guidance suggests strongly that "intermediate" care - for older hospital patients ready for discharge from an acute environment but not yet ready to go home - will be charged for. The consultation paper says that "separate guidance is being issued about charging arrangements."

Anxiety over this is also being expressed by the Association of Directors of Social Services, which has "broadly welcomed" the guidance but warned that it "does not address the continuing underlying differential between health and social care costs."

Other concerns about the guidance focus on the degree of discretion being left to councils; the continued charging of people receiving both income support and disability benefits; and the taking into account of as much as 55% of a disabled person's earnings. Alison Tarrant, who chairs the Coalition on Charging, representing almost 200 user groups, said: "Overall, the guidance is a real disappointment to older and disabled people."

Published simultaneously with the guidance was a further consultation paper on the government's supporting people reforms, by which means-tested council grants will replace housing benefit funding for services in supported and sheltered housing. This paper makes plain that while tenants on income support will not be charged for services, those on housing benefit will have only a three-year respite when the new scheme starts in 2003. From 2006, they will face a single means test for support services and home care.

 Consultation on both the home care and supporting people proposals is open until March 30.

webTitle: Government disabled scheme may mean job losses

fields.headline: Government disabled scheme may mean job losses
fields.standfirst: A new government scheme is meant to make life better for the 23,000 disabled people in supported employment but, as  Emma Lindsey  reports, there are fears that it may also lead to job losses
fields.trailText: A new government scheme is meant to make life better for the 23,000 disabled people in supported employment but, as Emma Lindsey reports, there are fears that it may also lead to job losses
fields.body:
When the bent spines and exhausted covers of battered library books need repair, the Remploy book-binding factory in Newcastle-under-Lyme is one of the places they are sent. Here in the unit's low-rise blocks, 80 or so partially-sighted, deaf and wheelchair-using staff work by hand, stitching together the pages of rare works, or use machines to glue and press hardback covers.

They are engaged in supported employment where devices such as wheelchair ramps, wide doors, induction loops and Braille signs have been used to make working life easier. But under a new government scheme called Workstep, supported employment is due for a radical shake-up from April. Its architects hail the restructuring as a long overdue modernisation of a neglected area.

Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, said: "For years we have accepted that disabled people should be included in mainstream education. We've accepted care in the community instead of people being locked up in Victorian institutions, but no one has yet tackled disabled people in the workplace. There is an ethos that disabled people shouldn't work alongside the able-bodied, which is outrageous."

At the moment, the government gives a £156m subsidy to supported employment, enabling employers such as Remploy, Mencap and local authorities to compete on a level playing field with mainstream outfits. Remploy, Britain's largest supported employer, was established in 1945 to provide work for returning war veterans who had lost limbs in combat.

Today, a total of 10,358 - nearly half the 23,000 disabled people in supported employment - work either in the company's 87 factories, with 7,397 assembling mobile phones, car parts for Rover, furniture and textiles, or on its Interwork scheme, where it acts as an agent contracting out a further 2,961 disabled people to host companies such as Asda and Tesco, while contributing one third of their salary.

Under the government's new plans, the Interwork scheme would be further developed. Proponents of Workstep argue that it will "progress" disabled people through extensive training in supported employment and out into the mainstream where they may take on meaningful work in callcentres and supermarkets. "At the moment we have a static workforce in disabled people because no one has offered them opportunities to move on and develop," said an employment department spokesperson. "Our aim is to get 5,000 people progressed within three years and, as an incentive, payments will be made to companies based on the number of progressions they have. Obviously if people are severely disabled and want to stay within a supported environment we won't force them to move. We are simply providing opportunities to do more interesting work for people who can use them."

Among those with physical and mental impairments, however, there is concern that progression is simply a byword for turfing them on to the scrapheap and anger at the subtext that Remploy is thought to be merely an expensive form of social service. They feel that the government stance of treating the future of disabled employment as a civil rights issue is far wide of the mark.

The GMB general union calls it "insulting" to imply that disabled people have nothing commercially viable to offer. "Remploy's Clydebank factory produces radiation suits," said a union official. "The Ministry of Defence started using a company in Scandinavia because of cost, but in the end sent the suits back to Clydebank because the quality was better."

Pam Tinsley, 56, works at Remploy's Newcastle-under-Lyme factory. Severe osteoarthritis and a damaged spine from a work-related accident 10 years ago mean that she has to wear surgical shoes and she uses a wheelchair to move herself over distances.

She sent off 385 job applications and had 182 interviews before arriving at Remploy. "Before I came here I thought Remploy was just a place full of badly disabled people sitting doing nothing and getting pocket money," said Ms Tinsley, who was awarded an MBE in 1999 for services to disabled people. "But apart from the serious work that goes on, it's actually a lifeline for many of the people here who wouldn't speak to anyone outside their home from one month to the next otherwise. Remploy employs people with a whole range of disabilities who can care for each other in practical ways that might never occur to an able-bodied person."

Ms Tinsley's other hat is mother of chapel for the Graphical Paper and Media Union (GPMU), which means some of her time is spent helping other employees figure out what benefits they are entitled to and how to claim them. "Some of the forms are so complicated you need a degree to fill them in - and the person who can most help someone with a disability, is someone else with a disability," she said. "There is a sense of community within many of the factories. All too often in mainstream factories the disabled employee will be treated like the village idiot."

The fear is that the Workstep scheme is simply a backdoor means to cut jobs at the factories instead of a route to fulfilling work. People joining the new scheme will be moved on after two years, which could mean the commercial viability of the factories will be gradually undermined. There is also the suspicion that employers, when given the choice of someone with a disability and someone without, will choose the easiest option. Further, those employers who do take up the challenge may do so only because employing someone at a subsidised rate will make them a cheap source of labour, without having the burden of responsibility for them.

Phil Davies, chairman of the Remploy consortium of trade unions, said: "This is all being done in the name of desegregation, but what's wrong with disabled people working together? If you are profoundly deaf, and there are no other signers around and you can't lip read, you're in an alien world. Assimilation can be progression into isolation. We're not against integration, but there is a requirement for both. Disabled people are entitled to a choice and to the dignity of working in a safe environment. If a working business like Remploy can supply both, then why not?"

Ms Tinsley is dead against the move. She said: "The people within the Remploy system want to stay there. It is a nice idea that we should be integrated into mainstream industry, but the harsh fact is, it doesn't want us. There are too many able-bodied people out of work. We need sheltered employment and protection. There are some working here who would never get a job anywhere else because their disabilities are too severe."

Ms Hodge counters that the needs of the 400,000 disabled people ready to work but unable to find it, would be best served by restructuring companies such as Remploy to develop their agency function and put greater emphasis on skills training.

"Nobody likes change and if you're coping with a disability it's even harder," the minister said. "We have to make sure that new people come into a properly defined programme. This is all about reconfiguring to create greater opportunities."

Part of the government's supported employment review will take on the task of changing perceptions about disability among employers. A recent initiative, called Dining with a Difference, involved getting together a group of owners of small businesses for dinner and making them feel disabled by supplying forks but no knives, and having chairs at an awkward height.

However, those within and working on behalf of supported employment would like to see recruitment of disabled people into senior management positions. It is a source of continuing grievance that none of Remploy's current paid board members has a disability. "It creates a culture of able bodies saying they know best," said Mr Davies. "We want to see active recruitment of disability throughout the hierarchy. At the moment there is a glass ceiling where if you come in as a shop floor worker, you may get to the level of supervisor but progress stops there. What disabled people want are quality, long-term jobs. If we're not going to have a charitable attitude towards them then what are we saying?"

Disability and the job market
David Brindle

Disabled people are almost seven times as likely as others to be out of work and claiming benefits, according to official figures.

More than 6.6m people of working age are defined as "long-term disabled"in the government's labour force survey. This represents 19% of the workforce.

A smaller number, almost 5.4m or 15% of the workforce, are said to have a "work-limiting" disability. Of these, only 40% are in work, compared to 82% of non-disabled people of working age.

Workers with a limiting disability are more likely to be self-employed (14%, as against 10% of non-disabled workers) and typically earn less (an average £7.64 an hour, compared to £8.84). But they stay longer in their jobs, having completed an average 8.3 years in their current positions in contrast to 7.4 years among the non-disabled.

Among all long-term disabled people of working age, 52% are out of work and 40% are receiving state benefits. But 17% - more than 1.1m - say they would like to work and 6% - almost 400,000 - say they are available.

Employment rates vary considerably according to type of disability, being lowest for people with mental illness (17%) or learning disability (24%) and highest for those with diabetes (68%), skin conditions and allergies (also 68%) or hearing difficulty (65%).

The government is introducing nationally the New Deal for disabled people, by which "job brokers" will help find training and work for claimants of incapacity benefit. One pilot scheme in part of Wales found jobs for 750 people.

One pilot scheme in part of Wales found jobs for 750 people.

webTitle: Surprise expressed at home care rating

fields.headline: Down your way
fields.standfirst: Home care managers in Bradford have been asking pensioners, in their own homes, how they rate services. As  Kendra Inman  reports, they got a pleasant surprise
fields.trailText: Home care managers in Bradford have been asking pensioners, in their own homes, how they rate services. As Kendra Inman reports, they got a pleasant surprise
fields.body:
Like many bosses, Bradford home care manager Jenny Hardy usually comes face to face with service users only when things have gone wrong and she's dealing with complaints. So when she left her office to visit elderly community care users in their own homes, she expected the pensioners to use the opportunity to list the service's shortcomings. To her surprise, however, many of them took the chance to say how much they appreciated the home help staff.

Unexpected praise was just one of the surprises to emerge from a ground-breaking experiment in user consultation when Hardy and 10 fellow managers were sent "back to the floor" to find out what some of the city's most elderly citizens think of home care, day centres and other services on offer. The move came out of a joint project between Bradford social services and York University's social policy research unit (Spru), part of a department of health programme looking at service outcomes.

Charles Patmore, Spru research fellow, believes the Bradford experiment is a first for social services. Involving community care recipients in service development has become a key management goal, but tried and tested methods such as questionnaires and focus groups are less appropriate for the oldest clients. When asked by researchers for the trial scheme, many of this group said they would much rather give feedback from the comfort of their own homes and would like to do so direct to those in charge of the services.

Their reasons were straight-forward, says Patmore, in that they wanted to show the decision-makers the problems they faced in everyday life. "They also believed that the involvement of senior managers would prove the consultation was more than a token gesture."

For their part, the managers overcame reservations about how much time the exercise would take and 11 managers, from two area offices, interviewed 30 randomly selected home care clients (half of whom were over 85) using an interview script drawn up by Spru.

It had been 10 years since John Howarth, area service manager for older people in the south of the Bradford district, had worked directly with clients (although his managerial duties include regular visits to care homes on his patch). He says the visits helped him get a more rounded view of clients' lives. "You get to see them not just in terms of being a service user but as a person. You see how the service fits in with their overall needs and aspirations."

The interviews helped the team learn the importance of recognising clients' previous lifestyles, says Howarth, whose varied brief includes a large council estate and a small Pennine village. "If someone lived as part of a close family unit, there may be fundamental issues about the emotional support they need alongside help with daily tasks. Others may have had a lifestyle where they had been fairly self-sufficient and may not need or want the same level of support."

Celia Waller, who runs the care management team in the town of Keighley, says the interviews reminded her of the need for staff to communicate effectively. "You forget how important it is to service users to be told if someone such as a home help or meal deliverer is delayed. If they're housebound, they get terribly anxious if someone's late."

Patmore admits that some managers feared meeting dissatisfied clients. And although the latter may have been fewer and less fierce than the managers feared, they still had plenty to say about where the service fell short of their expectations. Many of the elderly people Hardy visited wanted a more thorough cleaning service, rather than the basic "hygiene clean" on offer now owing to spending constraints.

"They said no one dusts in out of the way places such as along the tops of pictures," she says. "I've been in the service for a long time and I remember when we could provide that level of domestic help. Help with the lighter tasks can be important psychologically. Frustration at not being able to maintain your home can make users depressed."

Some problems could be fixed, though, and the researchers found the managers took swift action to rectify a problem identified in an interview - something less senior personnel would probably have struggled to do. Patmore recalls: "One interviewer was struck by how depressed someone was by their arthritis, a condition that was aggravated by a badly-designed flat. So they had them moved."

In another case, an interviewer met a man who relied heavily for company upon a failing television. The manager arranged for the set to be fixed. And the researchers found that some of the interventions, such as improving a day centre's activity programme, benefited many clients, not just the interviewees who prompted the moves.

Waller found that interviewees sometimes disagreed about service shortcomings, however. "Some people said they wanted to see the same home help every visit; others said they liked a variety of helpers. Some said they liked the day centre activities; others said there weren't enough. The important thing is to respond to individual need," she says.

The interview programme resulted in 16 recommendations for change, some relating to the care of specific individuals, others pertaining more broadly to the direction the service should take. The department is in the process of integrating the recommendations into service plans.

The Spru researchers concluded that manager interviewers were a promising means of reaching older community care clients. And for at least some of the managers, "the fundamental purpose and value of their work was confirmed."

But it is being stressed that these interviews are something to be deployed occasionally - not an alternative to monitoring services through a review system - although there may be room to develop interviews by senior staff generally as a routine management tool.

Hardy says the interviews taught her a great deal. "I started out at the bottom in home care," she says. "It was fascinating to go back to see how the service has altered and grown - and to see what has dropped off the end in the process."

Howarth also found the experience rewarding. "Ideally it is something we could do on an annual basis," he says, "linking it into development and business planning." Waller warns that departments may struggle to marry the clients' agenda with that of the social services department, driven by government. But even she agrees that going back to the floor was an exercise well worth repeating.

 Further information is available in a short report, Learning from Older Community Care Clients, obtainable free from Lindsey Myers, Social Policy Research Unit, University of York, York YO10 5DD, tel: 01904-433608. Also published on Spru's website: www.york.ac.uk/inst/spru

webTitle: Call for new guidelines as contact visits cause carers concern

fields.headline: Fostering good relations
fields.standfirst: Call for new guidelines as contact visits cause carers concern
fields.trailText: Call for new guidelines as contact visits cause carers concern
fields.body:
Foster carers should not be required to host contact between foster children and their birth parents, according to a study which found that most carers did not like contact sessions in their homes.

Carers reported difficulties in getting birth parents to leave; awkward silences with nobody knowing what to say; and cases where birth parents had been aggressive or even arrived drunk. Most foster children, too, said they would rather go out on contact visits. One foster child told researchers: "It felt funny seeing my mum and my sisters in my foster home; it made me feel funny and tingly and ticklish inside."

The study was carried out by Birmingham Foster Care Association (BFCA), in response to a growing number of disputes over contact visits. Some carers mentioned such problems as reasons for giving up fostering; some potential fosterers were deterred by the contact issue. Seven of the BFCA's committee members, trained by the centre for social action at De Montfort University, Leicester, interviewed 22 foster carers, 16 of their own children, 14 foster children and nine birth parents.

A majority of carers said contact visits were negative experiences. One recalled a birth parent "opening the stereo and putting on records and coming in the kitchen and picking out what she liked." The carer said: "OK, I was looking after her child but not her as well."

One single carer told the researchers she felt particularly vulnerable during contact visits, while others cited resentment on the part of their own and other foster children at the intrusion. "We do find it quite difficult as we all sit there waiting for the visit to end," said one. Birth parents were more positive, often stressing the importance of being able to see where their children were living. But some spoke of feeling awkward or "inadequate" and were resentful in cases where the carer was required to supervise them.

Some foster children were happy with contact visits in the home, but a majority - where they felt safe with their relatives - said they would prefer to go out. One said: "It's all right at home, but it gets boring. I prefer to go out skating."

In a report on its research, the BFCA is calling for new guidelines on contact, appointment of contact workers, creation of special venues and the lifting of carers' contractual obligations to host visits. Steve Holloway, who chairs the association, says: "Too often the children and young people we are looking after are not experiencing the contact with their relatives that they need to develop and thrive."

 The research report is available at £5 inc. p&p from BFCA, Underwood Centre, Underwood Close, Erdington, Birmingham, B23 7HD

webTitle: Charity urges official protocols on care home closures

fields.headline: Seeking protection
fields.standfirst: Charity urges official protocols on care home closures
fields.trailText: Charity urges official protocols on care home closures
fields.body:
The growing number of care home closures has prompted charity Counsel and Care to call for official protocols on what happens when a home faces shutdown.

Many recent home closures have taken place in "unseemly haste", the charity says. In an otherwise highly regulated sector, there is nothing to protect the interests of vulnerable elderly and disabled residents. Counsel and Care, which provides advice on residential and nursing care, says 800 closures have taken place over the past year.

Given the "low" level of fees offered by local authorities for residents funded by the community care system, it warns, the attrition looks likely to continue. Les Bright, the charity's deputy director, argues that lack of closure protocols makes the care sector the poor relation.

School closures take place only after lengthy consultation, and council housing stock transfers depend on a vote among tenants, he says, adding: "If a home is earmarked for closure, residents and patients should be protected and their views sought to ensure that the anxiety and distress they experience is minimised."

Protocols would delay closure so that every other possibility was examined, especially in the interests of residents and patients without close family. "In the past, there have been deaths among patients transferred from homes in which they have lived for many years," says Bright. "It seems not only practical but humane that the Department of Health should consider that closure protocols should be put in place."

The charity's call is being backed by Unison, the public services union, which blames the rash of closures on the fact that the care home sector has become dominated by for-profit operators. Malcolm Wing, the union's national secretary for local government, says: "Local authorities were forced to dispose of the majority of homes because the private sector said it could run them cheaper and better. The sight of elderly people being, in effect, evicted because they were no longer making a profit for their home owners is a scandal which should not be allowed to continue."

fields.trailText: Frosty response
fields.body:
Frosty response An academic at Birmingham University has criticised the building of snowmen because she claims they reinforce traditional gender stereotypes that man's territory is the outdoors.
Metro North East, 21.12.00 (Heath Gould, Newcastle upon Tyne)

Cut-throat business One of the few barbers in Britain still to give traditional shaves with a cut-throat razor has set up a website to advertise his shop in Telford.
Shropshire Star, 12.12.00 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Slippery customers A couple from Diss, Norfolk, were left with a bill for £500 when mechanics had to rip apart their car to find a snake that escaped while they were taking it to be sold to a pet shop.
Worcestershire Evening Mail, 20.12.00 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

With the light on A zoologist from Croydon, Surrey, has applied for funding to work on his theory that street lighting is affecting the body clocks of badgers, owls and foxes, causing them to mate out of season.
Croydon Advertiser, 22.12.00 (J Jessup, London SE19)

Credit overdue A 67-year-old man has just been sent the geography certificate for the A-level exam he passed at a Norwich school 48 years ago.
Eastern Evening News, 20.12.00 (Glenys Wise, Norwich)

Called to serve A barmaid planning to become a curate believes the skills she developed listening to customers at a pub in Cheltenham will help in her studies.
East Anglian Daily Times, 19.12.00 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Piping hot A degree course to study bagpipes in Glasgow has attracted five times more applicants than can be accommodated.

Manchester Evening News 27.12.00 (Gillian Oakes, Cheadle)

It's a stick-up Police in Kidsgrove, Staffordshire, have issued a warning about a conman selling free crime prevention stickers for £1 each.
Staffordshire Sentinel, 12.12.00 (Chris Thomes, Stoke-on-Trent)

Donkey work Therapeutic visits to cheer up people in nursing homes and hospitals are being made by donkeys from a sanctuary in Sidmouth, Devon.
Sunday Independent, 24.12.00 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

Howls of pain Doctors at a Bradford hospital's accident and emergency unit have noted an increase in the number of cases of people being bitten by animals when there is a full moon.
Telegraph and Argus, 22.12.00 (C Frail, Bradford)

Close call Firefighters in Totnes, Devon, drove to the hospital a few yards across the road from their station, only to discover that the fire alarm was caused by a piece of burnt toast.
Western Morning News, 18.12.00 (C Philip, Tavistock)

Not too clever A member of Mensa was arrested by police in Cardiff after leaving a trail of muddy footprints to his front door from the neighbour's house he had burgled.
Metro, 22.12.00 (A Lamont, Smethwick)

Inside knowledge The barrister representing a Southampton man guilty of causing actual bodily harm asked the judge to send his client to prison for at least 15 months so he would have time to learn carpentry and bricklaying skills while inside.
Southern Daily Echo 18.12.00 (L Napier, Winchester)

Going loco Commuters who took to their cars to avoid delays on the railways were stuck in a traffic jam at Harrogate, north Yorkshire, when a 59-tonne locomotive fell off the low-loader truck on which it was being transported.
Newcastle Journal, 20.12.00 (Anne Liddon, Tynemouth)

webTitle: Malcolm  Dean: Old statistics and more damn jibes

fields.headline: Old statistics and more damn jibes
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Large numbers have been lifted out of poverty but this May the statistics will still be showing the poor got poorer under Labour
fields.body:
An election approaches. Yet, almost unbelievably for a government which prides itself on its presentational skills, one of Labour's best achievements - particularly in the eyes of its most loyal supporters - will remain clouded in obscurity. Large numbers have been lifted out of poverty but this May the statistics will still be showing the poor got poorer under Labour.

What is wrong? Blame the statisticians. Key poverty figures (known in the trade as HBAI - households below average income) are drawn from the family resources survey. The latest figures, published last November, are drawn from the financial year ending March 1999. Thus they were already 18 months out of date on publication and will be more than two years out of date by the expected election date, May 3.

They ignore a succession of major anti-poverty initiatives that began after March 1999, including working families' tax credits, national minimum wage and minimum income guarantee for pensioners that are lifting 1.2m children and more than 800,000 adults out of poverty.

Do not doubt much malicious interpretation will be made by the Tory party and Tory press with the dated figures. Just look at last month's headlines greeting New Policy Institute's poverty audit, which rightly warned its statistics were old: "More people living in poverty under Labour" (Telegraph) and "Poor have risen by 500,000 under Labour" (Times). Tory spokesman David Willetts said it was "devastating evidence of the gap between Labour's rhetoric on poverty and the grim reality."

If unemployment stats can be published within two months and the Labour survey within three months, why does it take 18 months to produce poverty figures? Even in arcane statistical circles, it seems the poor come at the bottom of the queue.

Ministerial interference will be difficult. Labour has rightly made the statistical service more independent. What happened under the Tories must never be repeated - they destroyed public trust in official statistics with 20 different changes to unemployment data (all but one reducing the numbers), emasculated Social Trends, and malignly manipulated poverty figures.

Statisticians still feel beleaguered and defensive. But no one is asking for a change in accounting methods. All that is wanted is a more prompt response to collected facts. The analytical services division of the Department of Social Security proudly boasts on its website of 140 specialists and 285 staff. If the professionals have any pride, they won't need ministerial prompting to improve their promptness. They'll do it themselves.

Statisticians still feel beleaguered and defensive. But no one is asking for a change in accounting methods. All that is wanted is a more prompt response to collected facts. The analytical services division of the Department of Social Security proudly boasts on its website of 140 specialists and 285 staff. If the professionals have any pride, they won't need ministerial prompting to improve their promptness. They'll do it themselves.

webTitle: The problem of suicide on psychiatric wards

fields.headline: Matter of life or death
fields.standfirst: Linda Hart has twice tried to commit suicide on a psychiatric ward.  Wendy Moore  looks at the dilemmas faced by the NHS in reducing the risks to patients
fields.trailText: Linda Hart has twice tried to commit suicide on a psychiatric ward. Wendy Moore looks at the dilemmas faced by the NHS in reducing the risks to patients
fields.body:
Nobody was watching when Linda Hart went to her room, took the cord from her dressing gown, stuffed it up her jumper, then went to the bathroom. Nobody saw her tie the cord around her neck, throw the other end around a waste pipe then stand on a box. And nobody saw her jump.

Yet Linda was a patient on an NHS psychiatric ward, compulsorily detained for her own safety because she was known to be suicidal and supposedly under constant supervision by staff. She is one of the lucky ones. Her absence, at least, was noted and she was cut down and eventually revived.

"It was quite easy," says Linda, 53, who is diagnosed psychotic but now lives at home in the midlands. Nurses supervising her were chatting about their holidays when she made the suicide attempt seven years ago. She survived a further attempt last summer, on the same ward, when she drank bath cleaner she had smuggled to her room.

Others are not so lucky. About 180 psychiatric in-patients commit suicide each year. Almost half the suicides happen on the ward itself, or in hospital grounds, and the rest while patients are on leave, according to the national confidential inquiry into suicide and homicide by people with mental illness. Hanging, usually from shower or curtain rails, is the most common method. A quarter of wards where suicides happen have nursing shortages. One in five patients is under special observation - 3% "constantly" - at the time they kill themselves.

One of them was a friend of Linda's, a 56-year-old man who hanged himself in 1999 from the same pipe Linda had used. The pipe has finally, says Linda, been boxed in.

Psychiatric services appear slow to learn the lessons. Since 1971 repeated reports have recommended wards could reduce suicides at a stroke by replacing fixed curtain and shower rails with collapsible versions. Yet data to the ongoing confidential inquiry reveal such deaths are still happening. At the same time, other means of committing suicide are readily available while obvious preventive measures are ignored.

Now the government wants all suicides by hanging from non-collapsible rails eliminated by March next year. Mental health lobby groups would like to go further and prevent all suicides on the wards. So is the NHS doing enough to stop psychiatric patients taking their lives? Louis Appleby, director of the confidential inquiry, thinks not. And now, as the recently appointed mental health tsar, he is in the unusual position of implementing his own recommendations.

They include removing from wards all structures which could be used for hanging, eliminating obstructions to observing patients and ensuring staff in contact with suicidal patients are trained in recognising, assessing and managing that risk. He finds it "staggering" that one in 25 of all suicides takes place on a psychiatric ward - almost twice the rate of suicides in prisons, although these receive far more publicity.

And although many psychiatric wards have already removed obvious hanging points, he says reports of deaths from fixed rails continue. Services could do more to reduce suicides through more training, increased vigilance, improved ward design and better assessment of risk, he believes. But eliminating suicides entirely is "unrealistic". He says: "Admission is often because people are suicidal so we are already dealing with a very high risk group. A completely risk-free environment would be stark and oppressive. You always have to balance these issues of safety against the dignity of the surroundings for people."

Margaret Clayton, who chairs the mental health act commission, agrees, adding: "Unless you have constant one-to-one observation, which would be totally unacceptable to the patients, it is impossible completely to rule out suicides." She backs the inquiry's recommendations, which have been echoed in commission reports. An audit by the commission in 1999 found that 31 people detained under the Mental Health Act, supposedly for their own or others' safety, hanged themselves in the 12 months up to February 1998 and 20 had had ready access to belts or dressing gown cords, as well as the means, such as rails, from which to hang themselves.

The key factor - highlighted in a repeat audit out shortly - is assessing risk, argues Clayton. "If you have more and better trained staff that always helps, but you have to draw a balance somewhere between almost harassing the patient," she says.

Leading psychiatrists also regard some suicides as inevitable. "There is always a tension between being oppressive and being safe," says Geoff Searle, consultant psychiatrist at St Ann's hospital, Poole. Leaving fixed rails in place is "stupidity", he says. But removing all means of committing suicide - including door knobs, pictures and crockery - would turn psychiatric wards into prisons.

"You can end up with an incredibly arid environment," he says. Truly determined patients will still find ways to kill themselves. He recalls a patient on a locked ward who propped up his bed, tied a sheet to the rungs and dropped to his knees to hang himself.

Tony Maden, professor of forensic psychiatry at Imperial College, London, says all suicides are theoretically preventable but the emotional cost can be too high. While suicides could be stopped through one-to-one, arms-length observation by staff, this would be extremely intrusive.

But lobby groups condemn the attitude that suicide is unavoidable on psychiatric wards. "It should not be seen as an outcome of mental illness. It is not inevitable," says Gary Hogman, head of policy at the National Schizophrenic Fellowship, which has been campaigning since 1993 to reduce suicide rates.

An estimated one in 10 people with schizophrenia kill themselves - far more than kill anyone else, despite the media circus this generates. "Many families think their son is in hospital and they can sleep at night then two days later he has managed to kill himself," says Hogman. He blames a combination of factors, including increased pressure on wards from over-occupied beds, under-staffing, more violence and more detained patients. Poor ward conditions also do not help.

Research last autumn by the mental health charity, Mind, concluded that depressing ward conditions were hindering patients' recovery. Its survey found that more than one in two ex-patients described wards as "untherapeutic" with complaints about dirty bathrooms, insufficient food and drink, lack of contact with staff and sexual harassment.

Angela Hampton (not her real name) has been in and out of hospital for the past eight years with various mental health problems. The 45-year-old has attempted suicide four times in the past year, the last time after being sent home when refused a bed at her local unit because it was full.

When she is admitted, she says staff are demoralised and overworked. "We are left on our own to sit around and smoke," she says. Last time she smuggled in scissors, a penknife, a mirror and sewing needles which she kept hidden until discharged three weeks later. "I used the penknife to scratch myself and I did think about committing suicide." Talk among patients frequently centres on means to commit suicide, she says. "We are like prisoners learning about crime."

Taking their lives in their hands

 A quarter of the 2,370 people who committed suicide in England and Wales between April 1996 and March 1998 had had contact with mental health services in the previous year.

 Of these 16% - about 180 a year - were psychiatric in-patients.

 A third of suicides took place on the wards, 13% on hospital premises and just over half on leave.

 Hanging was the means of suicide in 68% of ward deaths.

 Nursing shortages and difficulties observing patients were reported in a quarter of in-patient suicides.

 Mental health teams believed that one in five suicides could have been prevented.

 Linda Hart has written a book describing her experiences on a psychiatric ward. Phone at Nine Just to Say You're Alive is published by Pan at £6.99.

webTitle: Blowing life back into the valleys

fields.headline: Blowing life back into the valleys
fields.standfirst: Villagers go to the polls over first non-profit community-owned wind farm
fields.trailText: Villagers go to the polls over first non-profit community-owned wind farm
fields.body:
Villagers in one of the most economically deprived parts of south Wales are being asked to vote in a referendum next month to help determine whether their area should become home to Britain's first community-owned wind farm.

In a unique departure from other wind farm projects, any profits generated by the proposed scheme would be channelled into a charitable trust and used for a variety of regeneration initiatives in the hard-up communities of the upper Swansea and upper Amman valleys.

Emily Hinshelwood, research coordinator for Awel Aman Tawe, a community group set up to take the project forward, says: "The whole focus is on community regeneration."

Working from a small rented office at the village school in Gwaun-Cae-Gurwen, the group has spent almost a year carrying out an extensive consultation exercise with residents, supported by around £75,000 of funding from the DTI and other bodies such as the Prince's Trust.

The scheme will not go ahead unless there is majority support in the community referendum taking place over a three-week period from the end of next month.

The bilingual postal and telephone ballot, in which more than 8,000 people will be entitled to vote, will be overseen by the independent Electoral Reform Society. Everyone aged 16 and over living in the 14 villages closest to the proposed site is being encouraged to express a view in what will be a significant exercise in local democracy.

In the face of inevitable opposition to the project from some residents, Awel Aman Tawe has spent recent months seeking to raise awareness of the proposed scheme by sending leaflets to homes and arranging public meetings.

Coach trips have also been organised to take people to Britain's biggest wind farm, the 56-turbine operation at Carno, mid-Wales, and a smaller farm near Bridgend in an effort to address the concerns often raised about such projects.

The group says many of the worries arise through lack of information, so to help counter that it has launched its own website.

"The more people understand the issue of renewable energy and climate change and the more people are exposed to wind farms, the more likely they are to support the project," says Hinshelwood.

"We have had an overwhelmingly positive response from people coming back from the farms. Nobody has come back saying they think it is a bad idea and most have returned saying they think it is a good one."

As part of its research, Awel Aman Tawe - the name translates literally as Amman Swansea breeze or wind - sent a member of its steering group to Europe to look at a cooperatively-owned wind farm project in Denmark.

Hinshelwood says the main lesson learned from the trip was that such projects can be done and that communities can and do support wind farms elsewhere.

The proposal being worked on involves the construction of four or five turbines, each up to 50 metres tall, on windswept common land on top of Mynydd Uchaf. The site is close to an open cast coal mine due to close later this year.

The farm would be about two miles from Gwaun-Cae-Gurwen and just over a mile from the small village of Tairgwaith, where several residents have come out strongly against the project fearing visual and noise impact and possible TV interference. One local school would be just under a mile from the site.

Those behind the project say it could produce a profit of up to £350,000 a year by selling the electricity it generates to the national grid or to a local end user such as an industrial estate. The money would be used to support local community projects and businesses in the area.

The farm would be owned and managed by local people. Those living in the area would be entitled to membership for a payment of just £1, giving them the right to elect trustees and make essential decisions about the farm. Those investing more than £1 would not be entitled to more than one vote.

If the project gets the go-ahead in the community referendum, Awel Aman Tawe will need to steer the proposals through the full planning process, including the preparation of an environmental impact assessment, before embarking on the task of raising the £4m needed to turn the dream into reality.

Supporters of the scheme are confident they will be able to tap into the European Objective 1 funds earmarked for west Wales and the valleys, as well as other sources of finance designed to promote renewable energy and others that aim to help former coalfields communities.

For more information see: www.awelamantawe.co.uk

webTitle: Will the principles of organic farming be lost in mass markets?

fields.headline: Snouts in the trough
fields.standfirst: Organic farming is fashionable but, asks  John Vidal, will the principles be forgotten as the mass market moves in?
fields.trailText: Organic farming is fashionable but, asks John Vidal, will the principles be forgotten as the mass market moves in?
fields.body:
If anyone doubted British farming was in deep mire, they need only have dropped into the Oxford farming conference last week. The mood at this gathering of the country's leading conventional farmers was bleak. In the past year more than 22,000 farmworkers have been made unemployed, following 18,000 in 1999. Incomes are down, many farms are trading at a record loss, and thousands more are expected to founder. When Graham Wynne, the head of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, called on the delegates to be more "environmentally conscious", he was heckled. "Never mind the birds, what about the farmers," was the angry cry from the hall.

Meanwhile, 450 of Britain's 3,000 organic famers were meeting at the Soil Association's bi-annual conference near Circencester. The contrast could not have been greater. The organic market, which just six years ago was barely measurable, has been growing exponentially by up to 40% a year since 1993, and is not slowing. British farmers can barely keep up with demand, 80% of shoppers have at some time bought organic foods, it is widely associated with quality and health, it attracts the young and next year UK sales should reach £500m.

On the surface all is well in the fields where food is grown and animals are reared without pesticides, where land is rotated and manures are heavily used to increase soil fertility. Some 3.5m acres have now been converted, and as much again is in the pipeline.

Politically, too, organic farming is on Downing Street's radar as something positive, radical and popular, to be supported if not with targets and cash then with vague promises of more research and enthusiasm. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and Michael Meacher, the environment minister, together with trade unions, are in favour, and groups like the RSPB, with its one million members, are warming. Joan Ruddock's proposed private members' bill, which would commit Britain to convert 30% of all farmland to organics within 10 years, has attracted more than 200 MPs.

But organic food is now a global industry. It may have been pioneered here after the war, but like wave and wind power, we have been overtaken by others. The Nordic countries, Austria and Italy, Holland, the US, Australia and others are all pouring research, conversion and support money into organics and the EU is debating how to get behind it. In Germany, where the first three BSE cases have been found in recent weeks, Chancellor Schröder has declared that "industrial agriculture in the country must end", and next week Germany is expected to set a target of 20% organic within 10 years. Denmark, with an eye on the export market, has gone organic ballistic.

More than that, organic farming, from being a system practised by and sold to a few cranks and foodies, has become fashionable to the point of being seen as utopian. "To be in favour of organic farming is now the same as wanting a better health service or education system", Radio 4 presenter John Humphrys told delegates. So what could possibly be wrong with a popular "sustainable" farming system which employs more people, leads to better management of the land, helps conservation, and is regarded as healthier for humans and animals?

Plenty. The widespread fear is that "organic" could become no more than a global "brand" and that the philosophy behind it, which implied small-scale, local production and support for local economies, will collapse as the mass market is unleashed and if everyone gets their snout in the trough.

Organic farmers can be just as gloomy as conventional ones and there are real fears that standards are starting to be eroded, the quality of the foods will drop, and that the hope of a more locally-based farming system to underpin rural regeneration will founder. And because the foodstuffs are bought by a small group (62% of all sales in Britain by just 7% of the population), the fear is that fashion may turn.

The problems concentrate around the role of the supermarkets. On the one hand, organic farming has depended on them to reach a mass market, but their strength also threatens to wound the grassroots who have developed the farming system. With prices high and demand outstripping supply, as now, there is room for everyone to profit, but when the market becomes flooded, as it will, so the supermarkets will dictate price, production methods and standards.

"As ever, it will mean the small producers will not be able to compete," said one delegate at Cirencester. Like others, he fears that unless organic farmers group together into co-operatives or associations to counter the supermarkets, they will go the same way as almost every small, conventional farm in the land.

Robert Duxbury of Sainsbury's, shares the fears. He sees pressure building to lower standards as farmers flock to organics in the hope of saving their livelihoods and inter- national food groups with no commitment to the founding principles move in. "Pressure to lower standards is increasing all the time," he said. "Newcomers do not always understand why you have strict standards, or that if you lose the philosophy, you lose the integrity. Customers buy organic on trust."

But Sainsbury's, which predicts its sales will rise 65% in the next year, mostly fears that Asda/Walmart and Iceland will undermine the market by trying to drive prices down to the same as conventional food by squeezing the small growers and importing massively. "Customers should be aware of the full cost of organic food", said Duxbury "The worst scenario is that that Asda will overwhelm [small farmers]. We sense a real danger to the integrity of organic foods."

But Sainsbury's, Tesco and Waitrose, who dominate the British market, are themselves accused of "stealing the story" of the grass roots and taking over the £65m market of local organic sales from box schemes, farmers' markets and specialist organic and farm shops. Box schemes, which led the organics surge before the supermarkets got in on the act, are now levelling off or contracting by 15%. "People are going down the road to get their organics at a supermarket", said Guy Watson, who runs one of Britain's largest schemes.

Most worrying for some of the greener growers is that the market is becoming an end in itself and consumers are being given the wrong message. Organic food has the cachet of being healthy and environmentally benign, but because the food is increasingly processed into convenience foods, or sent halfway round the world at massive hidden environmental expense, there is little or no social, nutritional, or ecological benefit and it is only a matter of time before people cotton on. "How can you call swedes flown in from Australia, or long-life milk from Sweden 'organic'? How can organic tobacco or organic pineapples grown by giant multinationals in the third world countries by people just above starvation wages be seen as beneficial?" asked one delegate. Another stressed: "Organics was always about more than the food or produce itself. It must have a social content, too."

Whether organic standards should be linked to "food miles" or social or environmental standards, as with fair trade, divides the Soil Association and its 15,000 members. It is a fraught argument and hard to see how to resolve except by education of consumers. Patrick Holden, director of the Soil Association, warned: "Unless there is education into organics, much of the potential wider benefits for society and the development of local economies will be lost. It would be a tragedy."

In Germany, where the first three BSE cases have been found in recent weeks, Chancellor Schröder has declared that "industrial agriculture in the country must end", and next week Germany is expected to set a target of 20% organic within 10 years. Denmark, with an eye on the export market, has gone organic ballistic. More than that, organic farming, from being a system practised by and sold to a few cranks and foodies, has become fashionable to the point of being seen as utopian. "To be in favour of organic farming is now the same as wanting a better health service or education system", Radio 4 presenter John Humphrys told delegates. So what could possibly be wrong with a popular "sustainable" farming system which employs more people, leads to better management of the land, helps conservation, and is regarded as healthier for humans and animals? Plenty. The widespread fear is that "organic" could become no more than a global "brand" and that the philosophy behind it, which implied small-scale, local production and support for local economies, will collapse as the mass market is unleashed and if everyone gets their snout in the trough. Organic farmers can be just as gloomy as conventional ones and there are real fears that standards are starting to be eroded, the quality of the foods will drop, and that the hope of a more locally-based farming system to underpin rural regeneration will founder. And because the foodstuffs are bought by a small group (62% of all sales in Britain by just 7% of the population), the fear is that fashion may turn. The problems concentrate around the role of the supermarkets. On the one hand, organic farming has depended on them to reach a mass market, but their strength also threatens to wound the grassroots who have developed the farming system. With prices high and demand outstripping supply, as now, there is room for everyone to profit, but when the market becomes flooded, as it will, so the supermarkets will dictate price, production methods and standards. "As ever, it will mean the small producers will not be able to compete," said one delegate at Cirencester. Like others, he fears that unless organic farmers group together into co-operatives or associations to counter the supermarkets, they will go the same way as almost every small, conventional farm in the land. Robert Duxbury of Sainsbury's, shares the fears. He sees pressure building to lower standards as farmers flock to organics in the hope of saving their livelihoods and inter- national food groups with no commitment to the founding principles move in. "Pressure to lower standards is increasing all the time," he said. "Newcomers do not always understand why you have strict standards, or that if you lose the philosophy, you lose the integrity. Customers buy organic on trust." But Sainsbury's, which predicts its sales will rise 65% in the next year, mostly fears that Asda/Walmart and Iceland will undermine the market by trying to drive prices down to the same as conventional food by squeezing the small growers and importing massively. "Customers should be aware of the full cost of organic food", said Duxbury "The worst scenario is that that Asda will overwhelm [small farmers]. We sense a real danger to the integrity of organic foods." But Sainsbury's, Tesco and Waitrose, who dominate the British market, are themselves accused of "stealing the story" of the grass roots and taking over the £65m market of local organic sales from box schemes, farmers' markets and specialist organic and farm shops. Box schemes, which led the organics surge before the supermarkets got in on the act, are now levelling off or contracting by 15%. "People are going down the road to get their organics at a supermarket", said Guy Watson, who runs one of Britain's largest schemes. Most worrying for some of the greener growers is that the market is becoming an end in itself and consumers are being given the wrong message. Organic food has the cachet of being healthy and environmentally benign, but because the food is increasingly processed into convenience foods, or sent halfway round the world at massive hidden environmental expense, there is little or no social, nutritional, or ecological benefit and it is only a matter of time before people cotton on. "How can you call swedes flown in from Australia, or long-life milk from Sweden 'organic'? How can organic tobacco or organic pineapples grown by giant multinationals in the third world countries by people just above starvation wages be seen as beneficial?" asked one delegate. Another stressed: "Organics was always about more than the food or produce itself. It must have a social content, too." Whether organic standards should be linked to "food miles" or social or environmental standards, as with fair trade, divides the Soil Association and its 15,000 members. It is a fraught argument and hard to see how to resolve except by education of consumers. Patrick Holden, director of the Soil Association, warned: "Unless there is education into organics, much of the potential wider benefits for society and the development of local economies will be lost. It would be a tragedy."

webTitle: Readers' letters

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Letters
fields.body:
Laud Nelson

Mary Thomson (Letters, January 3) prompts me to recall my own experience of the warmth of the people of Nelson, Lancashire.

On May 5 1939, aged 14, I arrived in England with a children's transport from Danzig, organised by the Society of Friends. A home had been found for me in Nelson and I was put on a train at Euston station, knowing virtually no English and having no idea where Nelson was or when I would get there.

In Burnley, an extended family of mill workers got into my compartment and it took them no time at all to find out where I was going. Their own destination was Colne, but they got out of the train with me at Nelson, carried my suitcase and, having located my adoptive family on the platform, escorted us to the family's house. Some months later, two of them saw me walking in the road and ran after me, shook me by the hand and told me how pleased they were to see me again.

What could have been a sad and miserable year for me in a strange country, without parents or family, was made one of the happiest periods of my life by the universal warmth, kindness and sympathy from everybody I met - at home, at school, in shops, church and everywhere else.

In fact, the kindness shown to me was wonderful. In Nelson, where unemployment and hardship had been rife until the cotton mills opened again shortly before the war, there was a wonderful spirit of community and sharing. There was also a burning desire for knowledge among families where fathers and mothers had sometimes had to start work at age 12 because their earnings were so badly needed. The majority of pupils in my class at school were the children of mill workers on a scholarship, and their determination to do well was an eye-opener to me.

I have often regretted that I could not thank the people of Nelson, but I am so happy to see that their spirit of tolerance and compassion is alive and well. I feel sure that the young asylum seekers who are beneficiaries from it today will remember their stay with as much gratitude and affection as I do.

Karl Roome

London

Playing for time

The requirement to submit complaints within 12 months (A fatal flaw, January 3) applies to local government as well as the NHS.

My past experience as a councillor asked, often after considerable delay, for help in the presentation of such cases, is that council officers - like their health service counterparts - are frequently (and I believe deliberately) slow in answering complaints and supplying reliable, relevant information.

This can make it virtually impossible to prepare a case for presentation to the ombudsman within the prescribed time limit. I believe that the specified period within which unresolved complaints can be referred to an ombudsman should be extended to two years and that the authorities concerned be required, at an early stage, to notify complainants of this regulation.

Bob Heys

Halifax

Missing a point

Rodney Hedley made a number of thought-provoking points in his article about homelessness (Home begins at charity, December 20) but did not touch on a major issue which would help thousands of young people avoid life on the streets Ñ greater access to educational opportunities.

Half of all homeless young people have no qualifications at all. Does this mean they lack potential? No, rather that when their contemporaries were completing course work and sitting exams, they were often already preoccupied with finding somewhere to sleep for the night. Without financial backing or connections into the world of work from their family, homeless young people struggle to achieve a normal adult lifestyle. Getting worthwhile qualifications is one of the few routes off the street and out of poverty. So why does a government committed to reducing rough sleeping make it well nigh impossible for homeless young people to gain these qualifications after age 19?

Young people over 19 are no longer allowed to study full time while claiming housing benefit. Yet research we carried out recently showed a wide range of reasons - ill health, substance dependency, emotional and family conflicts, or plain lack of confidence and motivation - why many homeless young people are past their teens before they feel ready to return to studying.

I'm not sure whether the Foyer Federation is one of the homelessness charities alluded to in Hedley's article, but we will continue to drive home the message that when you are young and homeless you need more than a roof over your head, crucial though this is.

Carolyn Hayman

Chief executive, Foyer Federation

Stepping in

Malcolm Dean calls for "more systematic auditing of accounts" and asks for the charity commission to "please step in" when a charity's fundraising costs are higher than average (Cheques and balances, January 3).

We have done just that on 3,289 occasions in response to unusually high fundraising costs since we started routine monitoring of charities' annual returns more than three years ago. Our new accountancy framework makes charities' accounts and returns more transparent, and requires trustees to clarify and explain the cost and benefits of fundraising activities. Charities receiving more than £10,000 a year have to submit annual returns and accounts to us by law. More than 90% have, increasing to 97% among larger charities.

We intend shortly to publish the names of charities which have persistently failed in this duty.

Simon Gillespie

Director of operations, Charity Commission

 Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@theguardian.com. Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited

webTitle: Liverpool opens up acting opportunities to all

fields.headline: Play for today
fields.standfirst: The cast of a new musical are mostly unsung teenagers from two of Liverpool's poorest areas.  Deborah Mulhearn  attends rehearsals
fields.trailText: The cast of a new musical are mostly unsung teenagers from two of Liverpool's poorest areas. Deborah Mulhearn attends rehearsals
fields.body:
"And the two words for this evening are?" Sue Lancaster shouts into the jumble of laughing, lolling teenagers. It's a break from rehearsals for a new musical to be performed in a worryingly short time. "Energy and volume" they shout back. "No!" she roars, laughing herself now. "Volume and freeze. We need to sort out exits and when to freeze. Everyone's just flopping around at the end of a scene at the moment."

This is the only time director and choreographer Lancaster does shout, and then only to make herself heard. Despite provocation - people fluffing lines, forgetting stage directions, talking in corners, or just not being there when they should be - she is good humoured throughout. For the most part, these young people are not professional actors, but part of a unique community arts project which is bringing together two very different inner city areas of Liverpool - areas that don't usually mix.

The teenagers will perform The Longest Night Alone later this month at Liverpool's Philharmonic Hall, the city's classical music hall and poshest venue, and they are taking it in their stride. They only started rehearsing a matter of weeks ago, and, despite appearances, only a couple of them knew each other beforehand.

The project has been organised by The Greenhouse, a children's arts and play centre based in Toxteth which grew out of the European year against racism in 1997. The centre's activities were originally aimed at pre-school children, but to stitch together the ever-expanding patchwork quilt of funding, Greenhouse director Debbie Wright found herself extending her own boundaries and ambitions. "This particular project is funded by the Liverpool central urban initiative and the criteria stipulated that we target the four electoral wards deemed to be the poorest," she says. These were the four closest to the city centre: Vauxhall and Everton to the north, and the more racially mixed Abercromby and Granby to the south, all with unemployment rates markedly higher than the national - and Liverpool's - average.

To advertise for participants, Greenhouse dropped flyers through every letterbox in the four wards. "We wanted to attract young adults sitting at home who fancied having a go but had no experience, rather than professionals," Wright says. "Our aim was that it could be the starting point for a professional career, but it's mainly about increasing self-confidence and the motivation to succeed. And of course they are being trained."

The play is not overtly about race issues; rather, it's the existence of the project itself that is challenging preconceptions. Writer Curtis Watt wanted to make an original musical about modern times, using the ubiquitous mobile phone and pager culture to twist and turn events instead of a more traditional narrative. "There is a classical thread running through the story; I wanted a theme of death and rebirth but it's basically one day in the life of an inner city housing estate that's awaiting demolition, and the pressures that throws up," he says. It's a raw look at the issues and choices urban British teenagers and young adults have to face - debt, drugs, death, love and loyalties, on a mobile phone merry-go-round of misunderstandings, malice and misery. And it's a timely reminder of how society is failing them.

Watt, who also wrote the score, was happy to introduce extra characters to showcase as much talent as possible. "We looked at people's skills and juggled them about. For instance we have a girl rapper who performs her own rap, but this moves the story along rather than just being incidental."

The musical style ranges from hip hop to operatic, he explains, because he wanted to reflect the all-inclusiveness of the project. "There aren't many cities in my experience where the natural balance is properly represented in a project like this," he says, though he does point out that it was difficult to persuade boys to audition. "It seems theatre isn't macho at the moment and we need to work on that."

Watt himself joined the local youth theatre at 15 "to stay out of trouble", he says. And it worked. He has been involved in a lot of projects for black and other communities who don't usually access theatre, and he also performs around the country as poet and rapper C Zero.

Michael Ryan, who plays two parts in the play, knows all about the peer pressure that requires you to dismiss something that's not cool. "I was told I had a talent for acting at school but I was put off by my scally mates," he says. "But then I decided to take the stick." At 20, Ryan is something of an old pro, having already landed the part of John Lennon's schoolfriend in a new film about the Beatle. He is one of the few members of the cast who has worked professionally. "There are a lot of first-time performers here and it's an excellent project for them because it's so supportive. The script is brilliant and there's a great atmosphere, but we've still got to reach the peaks it's demanding."

Michelle Barrett and Vicki Clarke, at 14 and 15 the youngest members of the cast, picked up the Greenhouse leaflets and braved the bus to the auditions. They didn't know each other before but are now friends. "You have to get on with each other here and there's no bitching,' says Barrett. Clarke adds: "You have to cope with getting to rehearsals and you have to leave your social life and your problems at home. This isn't the place for that because it affects everybody."

Two older girls, Samira Saeed, 19, and Ruth Cullen, 18, are both unemployed after completing performing arts diplomas. They felt slightly disillusioned after college until they got parts in The Longest Night Alone. "My confidence was knocked a bit; we weren't getting any parts," says Cullen. Both girls learned to sing and dance as well as act because they believed it would enhance their career prospects. Now with renewed confidence and energy they can't wait to get to rehearsals. "It's the best part of the day," says Saeed.

Watt thinks one of the hardest things has been instilling a sense of commitment into the cast. But only a couple of people have dropped out.

The actors are not paid, though they can claim expenses, and the writer, director and choreographer team of Watt, Lancaster and her partner Stephen Mulrooney, have all been touched by the energy, attitude and dedication the cast has brought to the project. Lancaster says: "I knew a couple of people had the discipline of college performances behind them but not the exposure, and some had been in small shows or dance sketches but all had to learn how to take direction."

"I wanted to create a safe environment so they could express themselves, and they've been amazing. They may live in two totally separate communities but the issues they have to face as teenagers and young adults, and which the play addresses, are the same. They all believe in what they are doing, they understand that they are only as strong as the weakest link, and that they alone are responsible for getting the story across, and also to entertain the audience. And if it furthers their acceptance of one another's race, culture or background then it's all to the good. And," she adds with a grin, "it's bringing a whole new audience to the Phil."

 The Longest Night Alone plays at the Liverpool Philharmonic Hall on January 23

webTitle: Muted welcome for government plans for fairer care charges

fields.headline: Home truths for ministers
fields.standfirst: Muted welcome for government plans for fairer care charges
fields.trailText: Muted welcome for government plans for fairer care charges
fields.body:
Ever clearer become the government's problems in rejecting the idea of free personal care for elderly people. The latest fallout is a less than enthusiastic reception for plans to tackle glaring differences in charges for home care.

With ending all kinds of "postcode lotteries", one of Labour's great campaign themes, the consultative plans ought to have been a winner. But their publication last week has been greeted with only limited and grudging approval by welfare groups.

More than 500,000 elderly and disabled people in England and Wales receive home care services and charges vary widely. An audit commission survey found that charges for similar services in similar circumstances could range from nothing to £100 a week, with 30% of councils even charging people on income support. The government's proposals, to be introduced as statutory guidance by May for implementation in England no later than April next year, seek to eliminate the greatest - but not all - variation.

Main points include that charges should on no account reduce an individual's income below income support levels; that where disability benefits are taken into account in assessing a person's income, any charge should be "reasonable"; and that a maximum 55% of an individual's earnings should be taken into account as income, to ensure people are not discouraged from working.

The consultation paper, which commends as a model the approach of Torbay council in Devon, says the guidance should not result in any net loss of income to local authorities. "While some users will pay lesser charges, or cease to pay charges, better-off users may reasonably be expected to pay higher charges."

Had ministers accepted the full recommendations of the royal commission on long-term care, all personal care for elderly people would have been free. According to charity Age Concern, the draft guidance on charging proves it is "almost impossible" to devise a fair system of charging for personal care.

The charity is concerned that the guidance suggests strongly that "intermediate" care - for older hospital patients ready for discharge from an acute environment but not yet ready to go home - will be charged for. The consultation paper says that "separate guidance is being issued about charging arrangements."

Anxiety over this is also being expressed by the Association of Directors of Social Services, which has "broadly welcomed" the guidance but warned that it "does not address the continuing underlying differential between health and social care costs."

Other concerns about the guidance focus on the degree of discretion being left to councils; the continued charging of people receiving both income support and disability benefits; and the taking into account of as much as 55% of a disabled person's earnings. Alison Tarrant, who chairs the Coalition on Charging, representing almost 200 user groups, says: "Overall, the guidance is a real disappointment to older and disabled people."

Published simultaneously with the guidance was a further consultation paper on the government's Supporting People reforms, by which means-tested council grants will replace housing benefit funding for services in supported and sheltered housing. This paper makes plain that while tenants on income support will not be charged for services, those on housing benefit will have only a three-year respite when the new scheme starts in 2003. From 2006, they will face a single means test for support services and home care.

 Consultation on both the home care and Supporting People proposals is open until March 30. The home care consultation document and draft guidance can be found at www.doh.gov.uk/ ; the Supporting People paper is at www.supporting-people.detr.gov.uk or from 0870-1226 236.
