Main points include that charges should on no account reduce an individual's income below income support levels; that where disability benefits are taken into account in assessing a person's income, any charge should be "reasonable"; and that a maximum 55% of an individual's earnings should be taken into account as income, to ensure people are not discouraged from working. The consultation paper, which commends as a model the approach of Torbay council in Devon, says the guidance should not result in any net loss of income to local authorities. "While some users will pay lesser charges, or cease to pay charges, better-off users may reasonably be expected to pay higher charges." Had ministers accepted the full recommendations of the royal commission on long-term care, all personal care for elderly people would have been free. According to charity Age Concern, the draft guidance on charging proves it is "almost impossible" to devise a fair system of charging for personal care. The charity is concerned that the guidance suggests strongly that "intermediate" care - for older hospital patients ready for discharge from an acute environment but not yet ready to go home - will be charged for. The consultation paper says that "separate guidance is being issued about charging arrangements." Anxiety over this is also being expressed by the Association of Directors of Social Services, which has "broadly welcomed" the guidance but warned that it "does not address the continuing underlying differential between health and social care costs." Other concerns about the guidance focus on the degree of discretion being left to councils; the continued charging of people receiving both income support and disability benefits; and the taking into account of as much as 55% of a disabled person's earnings. Alison Tarrant, who chairs the Coalition on Charging, representing almost 200 user groups, says: "Overall, the guidance is a real disappointment to older and disabled people." Published simultaneously with the guidance was a further consultation paper on the government's Supporting People reforms, by which means-tested council grants will replace housing benefit funding for services in supported and sheltered housing. This paper makes plain that while tenants on income support will not be charged for services, those on housing benefit will have only a three-year respite when the new scheme starts in 2003. From 2006, they will face a single means test for support services and home care.  Consultation on both the home care and Supporting People proposals is open until March 30. webTitle: Acts of courage remembered

fields.headline: Fit for heroes
fields.standfirst: As the Royal Humane Society next week presents its latest awards for bravery,  Janet Smith  looks at acts of courage over the past 200 years
fields.trailText: As the Royal Humane Society next week presents its latest awards for bravery, Janet Smith looks at acts of courage over the past 200 years
fields.body:
Ray Cochrane will be presented on Tuesday with a Royal Humane Society silver medal, its top domestic award, for saving the life of his friend and fellow jockey, Frankie Dettori, when their light aircraft crashed on June 1 just after take-off at Newmarket.

Despite suffering burns to his head, Cochrane dragged the injured Dettori out of the plane and also tried, unsuccessfully, to save the pilot. When Cochrane's name is added to the distinguished roll of award winners, it will mark the first silver medal the society has given for more than two years, but it has a tradition going back more than two centuries.

The most famous of these remarkable volunteers is probably Grace Darling who, in 1838 at age 22, rowed through the North Sea with her father to rescue nine survivors of a shipwreck. Both Darlings won specially struck gold medals.

It was a desire to save life, rather than reward bravery, that brought the Royal Humane Society (RHS) into being in 1774. Two young London doctors, William Hawes and Thomas Cogan, were convinced that too many people were wrongly presumed dead and consigned to an early grave. Supported by a group of medical friends, the pair formed The Institution for Affording Immediate Relief to Persons Apparently Dead from Drowning. This soon became the more manageable Humane Society and, in 1787 under the patronage of George III, the RHS.

The new institution offered financial rewards, paid for initially by Hawes but later by public subscription, to anyone producing a body - dead or alive. The top rate was a generous four guineas (about £250 in today's money). This tantalising offer, however, led to a widespread scam: down-and-outs in London started working in pairs - one claiming to have rescued the other and both sharing the prize money. Largely because of this, awards gradually replaced rewards.

The society did not rely solely on passers-by to help their fellow citizens, however. It organised a team of medical assistants - doctors and apothecaries - who were effectively on 24-hour call. They were not paid, but from time to time were awarded honorary medals. The society also built up a network of "receiving houses" in and around London, where the half-dead could be taken for treatment. The most famous of these was in Hyde Park, central London. Otherwise, publicans were encouraged to open their doors to those in need of more than just a drink and each time they did so, they were paid a guinea.

From the outset, the society offered advice on what we now call first aid. Some of it still holds good: mouth-to-mouth resuscitation and keeping the body warm, for instance (though in 1774, "the skin of a sheep fresh killed" was thought ideal for this purpose). Other recommended techniques today sound more life-threatening than life-saving. "The smoke of tobacco thrown up the fundament [rectum] should be ranked among the earliest applications," said the society, and "if a fumigator should not be at hand, the common pipe will answer the purpose of applying this vapor to the bowels."

The treatment went beyond first aid. The pioneering doctors advised that it was "to be continued with spirit for two hours, or upwards, although there should not be the least symptoms of returning life." Nowadays, St John Ambulance recommends that first aid should be administered only until medical help arrives.

From the beginning, many of those rescued were people attempting to commit suicide. Their "black designs" and the welfare of their souls were a matter of great concern to the Christian founders of the society, who decided to give every saved person "approved books of piety and devotion." In 1830, the British and Foreign Bible Society made an annual gift of 50 Bibles. Sadly, attempted suicide still features prominently in the RHS cases.

By the time of its centenary in 1874, the society reckoned it had helped save 38,056 lives - in other words, more than one person every day since its foundation. Salvation in the 20th century continued at much the same rate - Cochrane's award will be logged as case number 84,081.

Cochrane, who raced again after the crash but has now retired to be Dettori's agent, is as modest about his bravery as are many of the society's winners. "I just happened to be there," he says. "One man was unconscious and the other injured, so I had to do something." And his pleasure at the award is tempered by the death of the pilot, Patrick Mackey. "It's hard to be enthusiastic when somebody you know lost his life," he says.

While Cochrane acted to try to save two friends, many RHS award winners intervene to help total strangers. From its inception, the society has encouraged people to be aware of the needs of their fellow men - an aim that today chimes with government plans for lessons in citizenship.

Bernard Crick, who chaired the cross-party committee advising the government, thinks the society's cases are "good examples of practical citizenship and civic spirit" although he stresses that children should not be coerced into taking unnecessary risks.

Metropolitan police assistant commissioner Ian Johnston sees no incompatibility in rewarding bravery and, at the same time, advising caution. "Everybody obviously has to make their own choices in particular situations," he says, "but I think we should always celebrate the courage of those who put their own lives at risk in an effort to help others in distress." A view that Frankie Dettori would undoubtedly endorse.

Prompt action that saved a life

One drizzly evening in January 1998, Trudi Plumb, 36, was driving along a country lane in Essex on her way to an evening class.

Plumb, who comes from Burnham-on-Crouch, noticed that the car ahead was being driven erratically and, a little further on, she found it in a ditch on the opposite side of the road. Flames were rising from the bonnet and the male driver was slumped at the wheel.

After calling the emergency services on her mobile phone, Plumb scrambled into the ditch and, with what she calls "popping and hissing noises" coming from the car, opened the driver's door to free the unconscious man who was strapped in by his seat belt.

With flames coming through the windscreen, she managed to release the belt and pull the man partially on to the bank. But his feet were still trapped under the pedals and, with the flames now forcing their way through the dashboard, she leaned in once more to push his feet clear. This time, with the help of another passerby, she dragged him to the top of the bank. Below, she saw the car engulfed in flames and smoke.

For this act of bravery, Plumb was awarded an RHS bronze medal. "I knew if I hadn't pulled him out, he would have burned in the car," she says. "And I would always have regretted not doing it."

webTitle: Government disabled scheme may mean job losses

fields.headline: Willing and able
fields.standfirst: A new government scheme is meant to make life better for the 23,000 disabled people in supported employment but, as  Emma Lindsey  reports, there are fears that it may also lead to job losses
fields.trailText: A new government scheme is meant to make life better for the 23,000 disabled people in supported employment but, as Emma Lindsey reports, there are fears that it may also lead to job losses
fields.body:
When the bent spines and exhausted covers of battered library books need repair, the Remploy book-binding factory in Newcastle-under-Lyme is one of the places they are sent. Here in the unit's low-rise blocks, 80 or so partially-sighted, deaf and wheelchair-using staff work by hand, stitching together the pages of rare works, or use machines to glue and press hardback covers.

They are engaged in supported employment where devices such as wheelchair ramps, wide doors, induction loops and Braille signs have been used to make working life easier. But under a new government scheme called Workstep, supported employment is due for a radical shake-up from April. Its architects hail the restructuring as a long overdue modernisation of a neglected area.

Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, says: "For years we have accepted that disabled people should be included in mainstream education. We've accepted care in the community instead of people being locked up in Victorian institutions, but no one has yet tackled disabled people in the workplace. There is an ethos that disabled people shouldn't work alongside the able-bodied, which is outrageous."

At the moment, the government gives a £156m subsidy to supported employment, enabling employers such as Remploy, Mencap and local authorities to compete on a level playing field with mainstream outfits. Remploy, Britain's largest supported employer, was established in 1945 to provide work for returning war veterans who had lost limbs in combat.

Today, a total of 10,358 - nearly half the 23,000 disabled people in supported employment - work either in the company's 87 factories, with 7,397 assembling mobile phones, car parts for Rover, furniture and textiles, or on its Interwork scheme, where it acts as an agent contracting out a further 2,961 disabled people to host companies such as Asda and Tesco, while contributing one third of their salary.

Under the government's new plans, the Interwork scheme would be further developed. Proponents of Workstep argue that it will "progress" disabled people through extensive training in supported employment and out into the mainstream where they may take on meaningful work in callcentres and supermarkets. "At the moment we have a static workforce in disabled people because no one has offered them opportunities to move on and develop," says an employment department spokesperson. "Our aim is to get 5,000 people progressed within three years and, as an incentive, payments will be made to companies based on the number of progressions they have. Obviously if people are severely disabled and want to stay within a supported environment we won't force them to move. We are simply providing opportunities to do more interesting work for people who can use them."

Among those with physical and mental impairments, however, there is concern that progression is simply a byword for turfing them on to the scrapheap and anger at the subtext that Remploy is thought to be merely an expensive form of social service. They feel that the government stance of treating the future of disabled employment as a civil rights issue is far wide of the mark.

The GMB general union calls it "insulting" to imply that disabled people have nothing commercially viable to offer. "Remploy's Clydebank factory produces radiation suits," says a union official. "The Ministry of Defence started using a company in Scandinavia because of cost, but in the end sent the suits back to Clydebank because the quality was better."

Pam Tinsley, 56, works at Remploy's Newcastle-under-Lyme factory. Severe osteoarthritis and a damaged spine from a work-related accident 10 years ago mean that she has to wear surgical shoes and she uses a wheelchair to move herself over distances.

She sent off 385 job applications and had 182 interviews before arriving at Remploy. "Before I came here I thought Remploy was just a place full of badly disabled people sitting doing nothing and getting pocket money," says Tinsley, who was awarded an MBE in 1999 for services to disabled people. "But apart from the serious work that goes on, it's actually a lifeline for many of the people here who wouldn't speak to anyone outside their home from one month to the next otherwise. Remploy employs people with a whole range of disabilities who can care for each other in practical ways that might never occur to an able-bodied person."

Tinsley's other hat is mother of chapel for the Graphical Paper and Media Union (GPMU), which means some of her time is spent helping other employees figure out what benefits they are entitled to and how to claim them. "Some of the forms are so complicated you need a degree to fill them in - and the person who can most help someone with a disability, is someone else with a disability," she says. "There is a sense of community within many of the factories. All too often in mainstream factories the disabled employee will be treated like the village idiot."

The fear is that the Workstep scheme is simply a backdoor means to cut jobs at the factories instead of a route to fulfilling work. People joining the new scheme will be moved on after two years, which could mean the commercial viability of the factories will be gradually undermined. There is also the suspicion that employers, when given the choice of someone with a disability and someone without, will choose the easiest option. Further, those employers who do take up the challenge may do so only because employing someone at a subsidised rate will make them a cheap source of labour, without having the burden of responsibility for them.

Phil Davies, chairman of the Remploy consortium of trade unions, says: "This is all being done in the name of desegregation, but what's wrong with disabled people working together? If you are profoundly deaf, and there are no other signers around and you can't lip read, you're in an alien world. Assimilation can be progression into isolation. We're not against integration, but there is a requirement for both. Disabled people are entitled to a choice and to the dignity of working in a safe environment. If a working business like Remploy can supply both, then why not?"

Tinsley is dead against the move. She says: "The people within the Remploy system want to stay there. It is a nice idea that we should be integrated into mainstream industry, but the harsh fact is, it doesn't want us. There are too many able-bodied people out of work. We need sheltered employment and protection. There are some working here who would never get a job anywhere else because their disabilities are too severe."

Hodge counters that the needs of the 400,000 disabled people ready to work but unable to find it, would be best served by restructuring companies such as Remploy to develop their agency function and put greater emphasis on skills training.

"Nobody likes change and if you're coping with a disability it's even harder," the minister says. "We have to make sure that new people come into a properly defined programme. This is all about reconfiguring to create greater opportunities."

Part of the government's supported employment review will take on the task of changing perceptions about disability among employers. A recent initiative, called Dining with a Difference, involved getting together a group of owners of small businesses for dinner and making them feel disabled by supplying forks but no knives, and having chairs at an awkward height.

However, those within and working on behalf of supported employment would like to see recruitment of disabled people into senior management positions. It is a source of continuing grievance that none of Remploy's current paid board members has a disability. "It creates a culture of able bodies saying they know best," says Davies. "We want to see active recruitment of disability throughout the hierarchy. At the moment there is a glass ceiling where if you come in as a shop floor worker, you may get to the level of supervisor but progress stops there. What disabled people want are quality, long-term jobs. If we're not going to have a charitable attitude towards them then what are we saying?"

Disability and the job market

David Brindle

Disabled people are almost seven times as likely as others to be out of work and claiming benefits, according to official figures.

More than 6.6m people of working age are defined as "long-term disabled"in the government's labour force survey. This represents 19% of the workforce.

A smaller number, almost 5.4m or 15% of the workforce, are said to have a "work-limiting" disability. Of these, only 40% are in work, compared to 82% of non-disabled people of working age.

Workers with a limiting disability are more likely to be self-employed (14%, as against 10% of non-disabled workers) and typically earn less (an average £7.64 an hour, compared to £8.84). But they stay longer in their jobs, having completed an average 8.3 years in their current positions in contrast to 7.4 years among the non-disabled.

Among all long-term disabled people of working age, 52% are out of work and 40% are receiving state benefits. But 17% - more than 1.1m - say they would like to work and 6% - almost 400,000 - say they are available.

Employment rates vary considerably according to type of disability, being lowest for people with mental illness (17%) or learning disability (24%) and highest for those with diabetes (68%), skin conditions and allergies (also 68%) or hearing difficulty (65%).

The government is introducing nationally the New Deal for disabled people, by which "job brokers" will help find training and work for claimants of incapacity benefit. One pilot scheme in part of Wales found jobs for 750 people.

Among all long-term disabled people of working age, 52% are out of work and 40% are receiving state benefits. But 17% - more than 1.1m - say they would like to work and 6% - almost 400,000 - say they are available. Employment rates vary considerably according to type of disability, being lowest for people with mental illness (17%) or learning disability (24%) and highest for those with diabetes (68%), skin conditions and allergies (also 68%) or hearing difficulty (65%). The government is introducing nationally the New Deal for disabled people, by which "job brokers" will help find training and work for claimants of incapacity benefit. One pilot scheme in part of Wales found jobs for 750 people.

webTitle: High street slump hurts charity shops

fields.headline: Curie job shock
fields.standfirst: High street slump hurts charity shops
fields.trailText: High street slump hurts charity shops
fields.body:
A leading cancer charity, Marie Curie Cancer Care, is in a state of flux with the threat of up to 50 redundancies and withdrawal at the last minute of a job offer to a new fundraising director.

The developments are thought to represent further evidence of the impact on many top charities of the slump in profits from high street trading. Several are reviewing their fundraising operations.

Mark Astarita was offered the post of Marie Curie's fundraising and marketing director four months ago. He should have started the £65,000-a-year job last week, but the charity pulled out the day before his leaving party from his job as director of fundraising and PR at the National Deaf Children's Society (NDCS).

Marie Curie admits it withdrew the offer, explaining the move as part of a general review of fund-raising operations. Community fundraising staff around the country are having to reapply for jobs.

Chris Dainty, spokesman for the charity, says: "Wherever possible, those staff affected by the changes are being offered redeployment or job shares, but there are likely to be a maximum of 50 redundancies.

"As part of the review, it was decided the vacant post of director of marketing, fundraising, PR and shops would cease to exist. This was absolutely no reflection on the considerable abilities of the successful candidate."

Marie Curie had, however, already issued a contract to Astarita and he had attended a two day conference. The whole exercise is likely to have cost the charity several thousand pounds in compensation and other expenditure.

The NDCS was also forced to waste a considerable sum, as it had already recruited a replacement for Astarita. Indeed, its job advertisement in the Guardian had boasted that Astarita was moving on to Marie Curie. By chance, the woman chosen was persuaded by her current employer to stay on, so Astarita was able to keep his job, which was advertised at £36,000-£40,000.

Astarita says: "I am very disappointed with what happened. I think there is a lot I could have done [at Marie Curie], but I am delighted to be staying at NDCS."

The new chief executive of Marie Curie, 46-year-old Tom Hughes-Hallet, is understood to have decided to take personal charge of fundraising. He joined the charity last autumn, leaving the lucrative post of chairman of merchant banker Fleming Private Asset Management.

His work managing the finances of the charity will be cut out, however. In the financial year to March 2000, its expenditure outstripped income by £1.4m, compared to a surplus of £900,000 in the previous year. The charity has said in a statement: "We are determined not to be in that situation again."

Marie Curie was founded in 1948 and has an annual income of some £63m. It employs more than 4,000 staff, including its famous Marie Curie nurses. It is also the biggest provider of hospice beds outside the NHS.

Andrew Watt, head of policy at the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers, says: "Income from charity shops played a major part in the fundraising mix of Marie Curie and I'm sure this general decline in income is a significant factor in their need to restructure. Oxfam is also restructuring to a degree, to take up the slack from charity shop income, but there is not enough evidence to point to a general trend towards restructuring."

webTitle: Shareholders meet to discuss ITN flotation

fields.headline: Shareholders meet to discuss ITN flotation
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Shareholders in ITN, the news provider, will meet this month to discuss whether to press ahead with the stock market flotation of the business. reports David Teather.
fields.body:
Shareholders in ITN, the news provider, will meet this month to discuss whether to press ahead with the stock market flotation of the business.

A board meeting has been set for January 24. Investment bank ABN Amro and financial public relations firm Financial Dynamics were appointed at the end of last year to begin preparations for flotation.

The agenda for the meeting is expected to include the possibility of an early renewal of ITN's main contract to supply news to ITV - seen as an important block to be put in place before approaching potential investors. The current five-year contract, which accounts for about 45% of the group's revenues, finishes at the end of next year. Carlton Communications and Granada Media, which own the bulk of ITV, are shareholders in ITN.

The news provider last year renewed its Channel 5 contract and yesterday announced the extension of its supply agreement to Channel 4 by another 2 years.

ITN has annual revenues of about £100m and profits of about £10m, which it generates primarily from contracts to supply news services to television and radio. The business has been valued at £300m.

As well as the prevailing market conditions, the flotation of ITN has been delayed by the consolidation of ITV into Carlton and Granada. The two companies are discussing ways of working more closely together and may be keen to increase their stakes in ITN.

The same discussions have held up the flotation of ONdigital, the pay-television platform owned jointly by Granada and Carlton.

The communications white paper last month said it would consider relaxing the 20% limit on any one shareholder in ITN. The two possible sellers among the five shareholders are Lord Hollick's United Business Media which is in the process of exiting television, and Daily Mail & General Trust, though insiders said they would be reluctant to sell while valuations are not at their peak.

webTitle: A charity caught up in chaos

fields.headline: A charity caught up in chaos
fields.standfirst: Unique projects in ravaged areas hid the financial mess of a dream that turned sour
fields.trailText: Unique projects in ravaged areas hid the financial mess of a dream that turned sour.
fields.body:
It started as a daring and innovative charity that was prepared to give practical help in places where no-one else would go. War Child was set up in 1993 by two friends, David Wilson, a former teacher and art agent, and Bill Leeson, a film maker. The rock musician Brian Eno describes both as "heroic figures" for being brave enough to go to Bosnia when bullets and bombs were flying and ethnic cleansing was at its height. It was launched at the Royal Festival Hall, London, during a three-day event at which the playwright Sir Tom Stoppard, its first patron, gave a reading.

The charity's first big project was a mobile bakery in Bosnia that was feeding 15,000 people a week in east Mostar and frontline villages.

Stoppard also describes their work as heroic: "Here it was a bakery in the centre of the war zone - feeding people whether they were Muslims or orthodox Christians. It was a tremendous thing to do - when it was really needed in an area where nobody would go."

The success of the bakery also led to their first contact with the world of pop. A radio report of the work of the mobile bakery persuaded Eno's partner, Anthea Norman-Taylor, to take a £2,000 cheque to War Child's office.

From those small beginnings, the charity's development snowballed. The music business became increasingly alarmed at the unfolding crisis in war-torn former Yugoslavia which led to the launch of a fundraising CD, Help.

Brian Eno persuaded his megastar friends, like U2's Bono and the Edge, to stage a concert to raise money to get musical instruments and tapes to Sarajevo. But his biggest breakthrough was to convince the world-famous tenor, Luciano Pavarotti, to sing in the same concert as Bono at Modena in Italy in 1995. It was the first of three Modena concerts inspired by War Child.

War Child's plans were upgraded. Instead of supplying musical instruments to Sarajevo, the charity decided to build a £3m music therapy centre. "It was like a dream come true," said David Wilson.

But as the dream was realised, the problems began. The charity began to lose control of its new-found wealth. Money began pouring in from CD royalties and one of the co-founders, Bill Leeson, accepted a gift from the contractors of the music centre.

The taking of the bribe - detailed on page one - shocked trustees. One, Elizabeth Huhne, said: "It was anathema for me. I know this happens sometimes in business but we are running a charity. We must be completely above board."

Berry Ritchie, a former chairman of trustees, said: "I was appalled. It staggered me that anybody involved in a charitable exercise, particularly one of the founders, should actually consider that he was justified in taking the money."

The fall-out was worse. After agreeing that Mr Leeson could stay, the trustees found themselves increasingly kept out of the picture. War Child UK was becoming increasingly ambitious, with sister organisations established in Holland, West Africa, Italy and the United States.

Mr Ritchie said: "It took us some time to realise we didn't know how much money was coming in. We certainly didn't know how much was being spent."

Mrs Huhne said: "It concerned me that at every meeting we had, we didn't have full financial reports. We could see the costs going up and up. It was like uncovering a can of worms every time you heard something."

There were complaints about Lynne Kuschel - then a member of the management committee and now chief executive - taking trips to Sarajevo and flying club class to attend an embassy cocktail party, and Mike Terry, a consultant to the charity's Mostar music centre, flying club class to meet the Croatian deputy prime minister. War Child said its policy for both aid and fundraising trips has always been to spend as little as possible on flights and accommodation.

The biggest row broke out over plans to send 19 employees to a concert for Liberian children organised by Pavarotti at Modena in 1998. Khawar Qureshi, a barrister in the chambers of Lord Neill (later to become chairman of the committee for standards in public life) who had taken over as chairman of trustees, warned at the time that this was excessive. "We are working with public money for the public and are accountable to the public," he said in a memo sent on June 2 to Bill Leeson. War Child eventually sent 11 people and yesterday defended their role there.

The trustees became increasingly unhappy. Mr Ritchie wrote to the charity commission on June 15 1998 on behalf of the trustees asking for "urgent advice" on handling the problem, disclosing the "financial impropriety" and asking for guidance on the "flouting of our authority."

Mr Qureshi says he called in independent accountants and solicitors to sort out the charity's finances and reform procedures but met resistance from the directors until he resigned in January 1999.

Problems were exacerbated when the patrons were belatedly informed in 1999 about the bribe and demanded action. Pavarotti demanded to see how much money had been spent on the Liberian project and accounts of all the money that had been ringfenced for the Mostar project. He was not happy and neither was Brian Eno.

Figures supplied by Amela Saric, the music centre's present director in Mostar might explain why. They show that between 1996 and September 1999 when War Child UK officially severed its link with Mostar some £2.190m was handed over. This compares with£3.209m raised for the centre and a further DM432,000 (£144,000) since then.

Some specific sums including money earmarked by Island records - a cheque for £133,259, royalties from a single called Miss Sarajevo, and £7,961 from profits on the Passengers single - have not reached the centre, according to the director.

The chairman, Peter Smith, last night released figures showing that the money from the Island cheques and other sums had reached the charity but had been used to cover their management fees in London. Altogether, he said £4,395,578 had been spent on the centre, including a management fee for War Child UK of £343,789.

There have also been disputes over the Liberian project. War Child's accounts show £287,464 was spent on the project. Yet according to Myrtle Gibson, the Liberian government senator in charge of the project: "The only thing we have seen on the ground is a Range Rover."

"We believe that between $300,000 (£198,000) and $500,000 (£330,000) does not seem to have reached us from the Modena concert in 1998." War Child UK said they had not had anything to do with the project since March 1999. They had passed the money to War Child Italy.

The charity's failure to sort out its problems led to Pavarotti withdrawing his money from Mostar, Liberia and another project in Guatemala. Most of the patrons also left. All the then trustees also quit - a new group chaired by businessman Peter Smith and including the editor of the Daily Express, Rosie Boycott, took their place. Ms Boycott said: "We all understood that the charity had been in trouble in recent years, but we all felt that War Child is an important organisation with a great deal to contribute to world poverty and the trauma caused to children in the aftermath of the conflict."

The projects have been saved by action taken by the patrons. The Mostar centre and Liberian children's village are being funded by Future Trust, a new charity set up by David Wilson and backed by Brian Eno and Pavarotti. Liberia also receives support from War Child Italy, now called Music for Peace, and War Child USA supports Guatemala.

webTitle: Leader: Will Lazio's loss be England's gain?

fields.headline: Sven in doubt...
fields.standfirst: Will Lazio's loss be England's gain?
fields.trailText: Will Lazio's loss be England's gain?
fields.body:
Just 10 weeks ago, Sven Goran Eriksson was on top of the world. In the 1999-2000 season he had steered Lazio to the Italian football championship, his 16th trophy in a career of 24 years. And here, proffered as if on a silver salver, was the sought-after (though not, to be truthful, by many) job of coach to England's national team - an honour never before bestowed on a foreigner. On November 1, he said yes.

And then, back in Rome, things began to go wrong. On November 5, Lazio had a good win over Bologna. Next week their result was defensible - a draw at Juventus. A week later they were disappointingly held at home by Milan. On November 26 they lost to Parma. December 2 saw them defeating Reggina, but then everyone beats Reggina. And on December 5 they were crushed at home by Leeds. The relief of a 4-1 win at Vicenza was swiftly nullified when Lazio then lost at home to their local rivals, Roma. Very soon in the bars and piazzas, one sentence must have been on everyone's lips: "Questo poveraccio sta soffrendo della grave malattia degli allenatori inglesi!" (this poor chap must have caught England manager's disease).

The final blow came last weekend when Lazio went down 2-1 to struggling Napoli. That left them at the foot of their group in the Champions' League, out of the Italian cup, and 11 points adrift of top-of-the-table Roma. "The players still had Christmas cake in their feet," said Lazio's chairman. This is the Italian equivalent of the time-honoured and usually lethal British formula: "The board has given the manager a vote of confidence." Yesterday Sven Goran quit. And so, before we have even agreed how to pronounce his name, he is free to take up his duties here. For his sake, as well as England's, let us hope he is in for a change of luck, and will soon resume the managerial form that brought him all those championships in the past. Meanwhile, doesn't that Terry Venables seem to be doing well at Middlesbrough?

webTitle: Looking to Lewisham for the mayoral model

fields.headline: Looking to Lewisham for the mayoral model
fields.standfirst: The London borough that can't wait to implement directly elected mayors
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's proposals for directly elected city mayors are about as popular as measles with most councillors, but in Lewisham the idea has taken hold, writes Paul Richards
fields.body:
Tony Blair's proposals for directly elected city mayors are about as popular as measles with most councillors, but in some corners the idea has taken hold. Lewisham council in south-east London has been run by a "new" Labour administration since 1998 and has shown enthusiasm for every initiative to emerge from the government. This council has more pilots than British Airways, and if the council were a consumer, it would be dubbed an "early adopter".

Lewisham has been preparing for the transition to a directly elected mayor for more than two years. It hopes to be among the first to hold a referendum and elections. But it has not wasted time hanging around - the building blocks are already in place.

Lewisham gives us some idea of what life under a mayor might be like for councils, their officers, councillors and voters. The first thing the council did was abolish the old-style committee system and establish a new Westminster-style cabinet, including seats for the opposition party leaders. The Tories took their seat; the Liberal Democrats did not. An independent inquiry recommended a new system of allowances for councillors reflecting responsibility rather than attendance at meetings. Local politicians will increasingly become professional rather than amateur players.

Lewisham replaced the post of council leader with the post of mayor. Dave Sullivan was appointed, a respected political operator who was chosen to lead the council for the second time. His dynamic leadership style lends itself to the mayoral model - he works five days a week or more for Lewisham and his office resembles that of a government minister. He leads on decision making, chairs the weekly cabinet meeting and appoints its members. The senior officers - the directors of services - are accountable to him and are called in for regular meetings, like a secretary of state would with his or her senior civil servants.

Lewisham's leadership did not introduce these changes without opposition. The reduced number of committee meetings left many members feeling left out. The need to refocus council activities away from the town hall and into the community, from "backbench" to "frontline", was not supported by all members. Many felt their scrutiny role was undermined and the leadership was steaming through decisions. This led to resentment, and the administration has had to work hard to establish a credible scrutiny function.

When mayors are in place, new council structures will have to ensure that the role of the councillor - already held in fairly low regard - is not made redundant altogether.

Council officers will find they are directly accountable - face to face with the political leader, instead of being shielded by the committee system and chief executive. The job of chief executive in councils will change - perhaps to one of chief operating officer - as many senior officer functions, particularly those involved with policy making, will be taken by the mayor. The strict lines between officers and politicians will blur, as mayors employ aides and spin doctors. Britain's town halls will not be a million miles away from the TV series Spin City.

There is some confusion in Lewisham about the title "mayor", which may be replicated in other towns and cities. The title traditionally refers to the ceremonial office familiar to most people - a mayor who opens fetes, wears the official chains of office, but lacks any executive authority. By renaming the leader as mayor, Lewisham created a hybrid post. The mayor still wears the chain on official business and attends community events, but also holds the senior political position within the council. So there is a danger some in the community will expect to see more of their mayor once they have directly elected them. Instead, the mayor will spend much of his or her time locked away in management meetings and political activity inside the town hall.

Lewisham's experience shows directly elected mayors will change the structure and culture of local government in fundamental ways, with new challenges for officers and members alike. But the true test of the new political system will be whether the tenant with the broken window, the library user wanting longer opening hours, or the dog walker wanting a graffiti-free park, will notice any difference.

This council has more pilots than British Airways, and if the council were a consumer, it would be dubbed an "early adopter". Lewisham has been preparing for the transition to a directly elected mayor for more than two years. It hopes to be among the first to hold a referendum and elections. But it has not wasted time hanging around - the building blocks are already in place. Lewisham gives us some idea of what life under a mayor might be like for councils, their officers, councillors and voters. The first thing the council did was abolish the old-style committee system and establish a new Westminster-style cabinet, including seats for the opposition party leaders. The Tories took their seat; the Liberal Democrats did not. An independent inquiry recommended a new system of allowances for councillors reflecting responsibility rather than attendance at meetings. Local politicians will increasingly become professional rather than amateur players. Lewisham replaced the post of council leader with the post of mayor. Dave Sullivan was appointed, a respected political operator who was chosen to lead the council for the second time. His dynamic leadership style lends itself to the mayoral model - he works five days a week or more for Lewisham and his office resembles that of a government minister. He leads on decision making, chairs the weekly cabinet meeting and appoints its members. The senior officers - the directors of services - are accountable to him and are called in for regular meetings, like a secretary of state would with his or her senior civil servants. Lewisham's leadership did not introduce these changes without opposition. The reduced number of committee meetings left many members feeling left out. The need to refocus council activities away from the town hall and into the community, from "backbench" to "frontline", was not supported by all members. Many felt their scrutiny role was undermined and the leadership was steaming through decisions. This led to resentment, and the administration has had to work hard to establish a credible scrutiny function. When mayors are in place, new council structures will have to ensure that the role of the councillor - already held in fairly low regard - is not made redundant altogether. webTitle: Sonner's helping hand gives Ipswich advantage

fields.headline: Sonner's helping hand gives Ipswich advantage
fields.standfirst:
Sonner's helping hand gives Ipswich the advantage
Preview: Jordan rebuilds fragile Palace
fields.trailText:
Ipswich 1 - 0 Birmingham
First leg Danny Sonner's helping hand gives Ipswich the advantage.
fields.body:
Ipswich will trust that the qualities which have marked their performances away from home this season in the Premiership suffice to take them to their first League Cup final. In the meantime Birmingham will cling to the thought that only a controversial penalty separated the sides in an often scrappy opening leg to the first Worthington semi-final here last night.

It came at the end of a first half which, if the football seldom held the attention, had at least held out the promise of a scoreless draw for Trevor Francis's disciplined if artless City. On a linesman's say-so the referee, Clive Wilkes, ruled that Danny Sonner had handled a hard-driven centre from Jim Magilton, and Marcus Stewart's penalty, his 15th goal of the season, proved enough.

Sonner had two full seasons at Ipswich before leaving in late 1998 and claimed, a little optimistically, that the ball had caught him on the chest. "I was very, very surprised the penalty was given," said Francis. "There was no reason that Danny Sonner would deliberately handle in that position."

Had Ipswich accepted their chances before and after the goal there would surely have been less for City to grumble about. But the Nationwide side were entitled to go home feeling hard done by because, even though the penalty decision was probably correct, tactics designed to stifle the opposition's natural passing game had looked like working.

It was never going to be in City's interest merely to contain Ipswich, off whom they had taken four points in the First Division last season. Close Town down in midfield, then get the ball forward quickly to Peter Ndlovu and Dele Adebola: that was the plan.

Thus Matt Holland and Magilton, the gearbox and clutch of George Burley's side, had to work hard to create the space they needed to open up the wings for Ipswich and stretch the defence to leave openings for the in-form Stew art. But, with Birmingham frequently withdrawing eight men behind the ball, this was never going to be easy.

"Give Birmingham credit," said Burley, "they'd done their homework and tried to stop us playing through the midfield."

But his team's patience and persistence inevitably created chances. Two arrived around the half-hour, Ian Bennett flinging himself hard right to keep out a header from James Scowcroft and then Jermaine Wright slicing a shot wide after Magilton's quick through-pass caught the defence on the wrong foot. Those apart, Ipswich's attacks struggled against solid defending.

From an Ipswich viewpoint the penalty could hardly have been better timed, Sonner getting himself booked for protesting that the ball had not hit his forearm. Once the hubbub had died down Stewart calmly sent Bennett the wrong way.

Hermann Hreidarsson might have made it 2-0 seven minutes into the second half when he met a cross from Mark Venus with a superb header which beat Bennett but rebounded from the far post. Then a Fabian Wilnis centre evaded everyone before reaching an unmarked Stewart at the far post. Like Wright earlier, Stewart miscued his shot wide.

Birmingham's attack never amounted to much, given the authority of Venus and Titus Bramble in the middle of the defence, and Francis's side will have to find more subtlety near goal to turn this semi-final around at St Andrews.

"Ipswich must still be the favourites to go through," said Francis. Said Burley: "We've got to be confident, given our away record this season."

Both may be right and, with all due respect to Birmingham and Crystal Palace, there is much to commend the idea of Ipswich and Liverpool inaugurating the Cardiff Millennium stadium's spell as host for English finals on February 25.

webTitle: Business: Equitable ponders deal to cap liabilities

fields.headline: Equitable ponders deal to cap liabilities
fields.trailText: A deal that would put a cap on Equitable Life's £1.5bn-plus liability bill and increase its chances of being sold could be just days away, according to a policyholders' action group that took part in a frantic round of meetings yesterday.
fields.body:
A deal that would put a cap on Equitable Life's £1.5bn-plus liability bill and increase its chances of being sold could be just days away, according to a policyholders' action group that took part in a frantic round of meetings yesterday.

The group yesterday submitted proposals to the company's management aimed at putting a ceiling on the total cost of meeting promises made to 90,000 holders of so-called guaranteed annuities. The Equitable Life Guaranteed Annuity Rate Action Group's idea was endorsed by the National Association of Pension Funds, which also met Equitable yesterday and will discuss the issue at a meeting with the financial services authority today.

Stuart Bayliss of the action group reportedly said the two sides were negotiating the level of the cap and a deal could be reached within days.

However, sources close to the negotiations were still unable to confirm the size of the "black hole" at Equitable Life, estimated at £1.5bn.

The company played down speculation that a deal was imminent, saying of the capping idea: "It is quite complex. We have got 90,000 people all of whom have got individual contracts. In practical terms it is not simple."

The action group has suggested a one-off payment might be made to the guaranteed annuity holders in return for which they would forgo their rights to higher returns. But the group is thought unlikely to accept a total payout of less than £1.5bn. Concern that the total cost of meeting these guarantees could reach several billion pounds frightened off a number of potential buyers late last year.

The FSA is trying to broker a sale and with Equitable is talking to several companies in the hope of reviving interest. But it is far from certain that even if a sale were engineered the insurer would remain intact. Equitable is talking to a number of parties about three parts of its business: its asset management division, sales force and administration business.

webTitle: Slow trains put brake on Selfridges' sales

fields.headline: Slow trains put brake on Selfridges' sales
fields.standfirst: Christmas produces cheers and jeers
fields.trailText: Christmas produces cheers and jeers.
fields.body:
Selfridges department store group yesterday spelled out the impact of the rail crisis on central London retailers.

In the six weeks to January 6, as Railtrack's speed limits more than doubled journey times into London from many destinations, Selfridges' sales at its Oxford Street store rose just 1%. The trading period includes the busiest Christmas shopping weeks and the height of the subsequent sale season.

In the same period the group's Manchester store recorded sales ahead 22% on last year.

Selfridges said it had experienced a marked downturn in London trade after 6pm, when most London commuters turn up to shop. "People who work in London decided not to come in after work because of the problems getting home", said finance director Peter Williams. People living outside London also abandoned shopping trips to the capital because of the delays.

West End retailers warned before Christmas that the rail delays were hitting trade as customers chose to shop locally. Mr Williams said yesterday: "We want the rail system back to normal as soon as possible."

Over the 23 weeks to January 6, Selfridges' London sales were up 5% on last year. Over 49 weeks to the same date they were up 6%. In Manchester sales were up 22% over 23 weeks and 23% over 49 weeks.

The group said that it had increased its margins on own-bought goods - rather than those sold through concessions - and new systems meant stock levels had been kept lower than previously, leaving less merchandise to be cleared at sale prices.

Chief executive Vittorio Radice said that while sales had been hit by Railtrack's problems "the effect has been offset by margin and cost improvements and by the performance of Manchester".

Its best performing departments over Christmas were womenswear, cosmetics and perfumery. Champagne and eveningwear sales, which had been specially bouyant last new year, were the most disappointing.

While many mid-market retailers have been facing tough trading conditions, Selfridges' upmarket "house of brands" philosophy has been paying off.

It is to open a new store in Birmingham in 2003 and is looking for sites in Glasgow, Leeds, Newcastle and the south-west.

A further 100,000sq ft expansion of the London store is planned, along with a landmark "Selfridges Tower" at the rear of the Oxford Street store.

webTitle: Review: Roustern Saitkoulov

fields.headline: The devil in Stravinsky's detail
fields.standfirst:
Roustem Saitkoulov
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Roustem Saitkoulov
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
When an aspiring pianist announces himself with a programme that begins with Beethoven's A flat Sonata Op 110 and ends with Stravinsky's Three Movements from Petrushka - and tales in Schumann's Etudes Symphoniques and Scriabin's Op 42 Studies along the way - he is certainly making a confident statement. The Russian-born Roustem Saitkoulov is now 29; in Moscow he was a pupil of Elisso Virssaladze and spent much of the 1990s picking up prizes on the European piano competition circuit. His Wigmore recital on Monday was his London debut, neatly coinciding with the release of his CD in EMI's Debut series.

His playing does not lack self-assurance. There was nothing half-hearted about the way he set about the Beethoven or the Etudes Symphoniques; it was take-it-or-leave-it stuff. I would rather have left most of it, or more positively have encouraged Saitkoulov to ponder late Beethoven for a bit longer before exploring it so publicly. After a nicely poised opening, the sonata fell apart, lacking a grasp of structure and any real comprehension of what the music is doing; the scherzo proceeded in disjointed flurries, the finale simply prosaically. There were no insights, original or second hand. The Schumann was equally unprepossessing - confined to a narrow dynamic range between mezzo-forte and fortissimo, and often muddled by over-pedalling.

There were hopes that the Russian second half would be more idiomatic, and Saitkoulov's best playing of the evening did come in a couple of the Scriabin Studies, where he caught the febrile flickering perfectly, though in others he failed to give the floating, Chopin-esque lines full weight.

But even here, and more pertinently in Stravinsky's Four Studies from 1908 - fascinating, rarely heard pre-Firebird pieces - the lack of a grip on tempo and how the speed of one section should relate to another was a serious flaw. In the Petrushka pieces that proved disastrous, as each of these magnificent showpieces was dismembered. One wonders whether Saitkoulov has heard Stravinsky's original orchestral score - had he done so he might have realised that some of the details he consigned to near inaudibility are actually important, and that getting round the notes (which was not convincingly achieved either) is not enough, especially when other considerations of phrasing, texture and coherence are ignored.

webTitle: Review: McCabe

fields.headline: McCabe
fields.standfirst:
Borderline, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Borderline, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Almost at the bottom of the pile are McCabe, based around the Warwick University dropouts Jill Jones and Matt Booth. Without a record deal since their only single, the well-regarded Nothing, failed to breach radio playlists last summer, they have expanded into a quintet about whom something of a groundswell is developing. It is not hard to see why and, in their only moment of hubris, they elect not to play their sole familiar song.

Always thoughtful, McCabe's other songs are endearingly frail, with well-toned melodies to the fore. Stepping Stones carries the weight of a less murky 4AD band and Complete Yourself could be the work of the late-1980s artpoppers Frazier Chorus. But the lovelorn 24-7, Only In Love (with its heavenly "la-la" interlude) and Nostalgia Rules, the first encore, are distinct.

Jones performs the latter accompanied only by Booth's piano and looks terrified at having to present it in so unadorned a setting, but the quality of this tricky tale of life-ruining lost love carries her through. It all goes a little T'Pau on the floor-clearing Truth or Dare, but the defiant I'm Not Sorry is the sort of song Aimee Mann has been aspiring to since Whatever.

Rather gauche, Jones has something of the nervous presence of Hazel O'Connor about her. Between songs she is lost, creating the awkward silences of the unpolished. Before Truth or Dare, she stands and sucks her thumb for want of something to do.

Indeed, she never seems to relax until the final song, the anthemic No One's No One. Then she stops hunching and begins to soar, and the songs finally get the performance they deserve. Perhaps it should be their first song.

Jones gets little visual help from her four backers (although the guitarist Sam Lewis would relish the opportunity to extend himself); having the rhythm section slouching at the back when their services are not called upon is as unfortunate as the synth-drums that dominate Complete Yourself.

Still, these are early days for McCabe. The songs are there, the performances will evolve and with the right producer they will sell a lot of records.

webTitle: Review: Dean Street Underground Orchestra

fields.headline: Tim Garland's big, bold, brassy band
fields.standfirst:
Dean Street Underground Orchestra
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Dean Street Underground Orchestra
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The Dean Street Underground Orchestra is a biggish band aiming to be a regular presence at Dean Street's Pizza Express Jazz Club, with a repertoire of originals by its members and some jazz classics. It has the makings of a creative collective, but a big band (even a nine-piece such as this one) is a big boulder to push uphill, and at the moment the Underground Orchestra's de facto leader is Tim Garland, the fine UK saxophonist and composer who joined Chick Corea last year and now spends much of his working life out of the country.

Garland's high profile, vision of jazz and long history as an inventive bandleader have made him a strong candidate to get this kind of a venture on the road. The Underground Orchestra's (so far) monthly Monday-night shows are still too heavily weighted toward Garland's own music, but the spiritedness of the playing and the blue-chip pedigree of the performers suggest that much more of a workshop feel could emerge over time, with composers inside and outside the band using it as a springboard for new work.

This Monday's line-up imposingly included Winston Clifford on drums, Gareth Williams on piano, Andy Panayi on reeds, and Jamiroquai's Martin Shaw and the former Jazz Warrior Kevin Robinson on trumpets. The band also brought out a large and expectant audience with a good many classy musicians in it, so there has certainly been a buzz on the wires.

An eclectic Loose Tubes echo is sometimes distantly apparent in Garland's ensemble writing, in pieces that enmesh orthodox jazz elements with materials drawn from all over contemporary music and traditional folk forms. A richly harmonised uptempo piece peppered with tempo changes preceded Panayi's light and liquid flute account of Garland's Little Serafina, with the notes of the soloists fluttering lightly down onto yielding pillows of brass chords.

On the quicker Gentle Nemesis, a typical, lyrical Garland melody, Shaw's flugelhorn solo mingled lustrous long sounds with nimble and elegant double-time figures as Clifford's cymbal beat began to lean on him. Will Vincent, a young American altoist Garland was introducing to London, delivered a superb solo of rugged, leathery sounds turning into rounded, mellifluous high notes, his secure control and storming energy occasionally reminiscent of Bobby Watson.

But the real potential of the band as a powerhouse inter preter of strong composition burst out on Made by Walking - a headlong contrapuntal swinger of pumping chords going every which way, with the horns winding conversationally between them and around each other, and Garland, Williams and Robinson breaking out with telling solos. Definitely a space to watch.

It has the makings of a creative collective, but a big band (even a nine-piece such as this one) is a big boulder to push uphill, and at the moment the Underground Orchestra's de facto leader is Tim Garland, the fine UK saxophonist and composer who joined Chick Corea last year and now spends much of his working life out of the country. Garland's high profile, vision of jazz and long history as an inventive bandleader have made him a strong candidate to get this kind of a venture on the road. The Underground Orchestra's (so far) monthly Monday-night shows are still too heavily weighted toward Garland's own music, but the spiritedness of the playing and the blue-chip pedigree of the performers suggest that much more of a workshop feel could emerge over time, with composers inside and outside the band using it as a springboard for new work. This Monday's line-up imposingly included Winston Clifford on drums, Gareth Williams on piano, Andy Panayi on reeds, and Jamiroquai's Martin Shaw and the former Jazz Warrior Kevin Robinson on trumpets. The band also brought out a large and expectant audience with a good many classy musicians in it, so there has certainly been a buzz on the wires. An eclectic Loose Tubes echo is sometimes distantly apparent in Garland's ensemble writing, in pieces that enmesh orthodox jazz elements with materials drawn from all over contemporary music and traditional folk forms. A richly harmonised uptempo piece peppered with tempo changes preceded Panayi's light and liquid flute account of Garland's Little Serafina, with the notes of the soloists fluttering lightly down onto yielding pillows of brass chords. On the quicker Gentle Nemesis, a typical, lyrical Garland melody, Shaw's flugelhorn solo mingled lustrous long sounds with nimble and elegant double-time figures as Clifford's cymbal beat began to lean on him. Will Vincent, a young American altoist Garland was introducing to London, delivered a superb solo of rugged, leathery sounds turning into rounded, mellifluous high notes, his secure control and storming energy occasionally reminiscent of Bobby Watson. But the real potential of the band as a powerhouse inter preter of strong composition burst out on Made by Walking - a headlong contrapuntal swinger of pumping chords going every which way, with the horns winding conversationally between them and around each other, and Garland, Williams and Robinson breaking out with telling solos. Definitely a space to watch.

webTitle: Review: Brian Griffiths/Kenji Yanobe

fields.headline: Brian Griffiths/Kenji Yanobe
fields.standfirst:
Brian Griffiths/ Kenji Yanobe
Curve, Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Brian Griffiths/ Kenji Yanobe
Curve, Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
There could hardly be a better place to see art that mourns the death of the future, or at least the one dreamed in 20th-century science fiction, than the Barbican. Here, in what you might describe as a site like the wheel of a space station but more accurately as a gallery in a curved corridor, two young artists have a laugh at all those sci-fi utopias and dystopias of yesteryear.

Atom cars, atom suits and alien planets even less convincing than the ones in Star Trek represent a tatty celebration of 2001's failure to live up to technocratic expectations. Kenji Yanobe has constructed Atom Cars, the size of bumper cars but sealed and fitted with Geiger counters, as protective transport through a post-nuclear wasteland. He has also made a space suit for walking through the irradiated apocalyptic world. He appears in it photographed against the backdrop of the 1970s Osaka expo site, a spaceman alone.

This atomic fantasia is a jokily painful reading of post-war Japanese culture; the memory of nuclear devastation comes courtesy of Godzilla, who appears as a blue gargoyle. He is meant to blow bubbles, but this was not working when I was there. Perhaps this breakdown was fitting in an art that mocks modern dreams. Yanobe's sci-fi props are funny, but no funnier than their source material.

The three tableaux made by Brian Griffiths out of cardboard, paper and polythene are more mysterious. These bold structures, in which tube-headed aliens pose in cheesy yet magnificent landscapes, are Blue Peter modelling on the scale of civic art. If they speak of the future, they also revel in art history. These are sculptural settings in the style of Renaissance gardens; the first has a Neptune-like figure, standing over a pool, made of blue and black shiny plasticky stuff. If the materials are cheap, the aspiration is that of a Giambologna fountain.

Beyond is a rocky crag of brown paper; you wonder at how crumpled paper can imitate the folds and ridges of rock. Paper flowers sprout down one side, paper moss hangs off a ledge and on top looms another tube-headed figure. The final setting is inside a spaceship, a flying saucer or perhaps the planet Krypton; white cubist patterns carved out of polystyrene announce this is The Future. Griffiths's constructions get at the pleasure of science fiction's ability to create convincing and detailed imaginary landscapes. He transforms this odd gallery into a concrete grotto, a setting for ornate pastoral fantasy. His art, hamfisted and sublime, has a touch of magic.

 Ends Sunday. Details: 020-7638 4141.

webTitle: Working lives: Tricks of the trade

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
36. How to negotiate the contract you want

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 36. How to negotiate the contract you want.
fields.body:
Emily King, 36
IT consultant

I always apply for advertised jobs where the salary is negotiable, and I always ask for more money. I've learned that you can lie about your current or last salary because nobody ever checks. I changed jobs recently because I felt undervalued, so I should have been on more money anyway. I didn't feel guilty about lying.

When I'm negotiating a contract it always helps to be a chirpy, relaxed person about the process rather than a hard-nosed negotiator. You get much further if you take it in a relaxed way. And accept defeat. If you can't negotiate the salary you want then it's probably not the job for you, so you shouldn't accept it.

Alison Parker, 39
Chief executive

In the late stages of negotiation in a previous job, a parking space was allocated to me. It wasn't on the contract and when I went to ask for it after I joined the company, I was told there was a nine-month waiting list and nothing could be done. What had happened was that the person I had negotiated with was not in a position to give me what he promised. Make sure you are negotiating with the person who can get what you want.

You have to ask them, "Are you in a position to offer me this, or do I have to ask somebody else?" Sometimes in large organisations people want you to come and work for them but they don't have the kind of clout to get you the deal you want.

Anthony Lewis, 48
Marketing director

People can get locked into the financial side of contract negotiating. It's easy to forget about all the other areas you can consider. Before you start discussions, think about other things in your life that are important but aren't specifically related to salary. Flexible working hours and the option to work at home can be worth more in quality-of-life terms. Good holiday allowance is important, particularly as you get older and need more space from your job.

When I moved to my current job, my pension was very important to me and I managed to reach an agreement that suited, even though the salary wasn't a huge amount. When you are negotiating it is important to look at your own circumstances and work out what is really best for you. People get too excited about salary over and above everything else.

Judith Hughes, 35
Chief executive

From an employer's point of view, you have to be honest when you are negotiating a contract. I offered someone a job a few years ago and when she didn't get back to me I tracked her down. She then mentioned she had a child and that the hours weren't flexible enough for her. During our discussions she had negotiated her holidays and her salary but she hadn't told me the full story.

If she had been upfront I would have negotiated a more flexible package because I thought she was that good. As it was, she lied to me, so I decided that I didn't want her as an employee. My tip? If you are good, an organisation worth joining will take every step to make sure you are happy. Good people are always at a premium.

Joanna Haysworth, 28
Financial manager

When you're discussing a contract, it helps if you have another job in the offing because that gives you real leverage in terms of negotiation. And think about the money you'll need in a year or two's time. The only real chance you get to negotiate your salary is when you join. After that you get pay rises in line with inflation or bonuses, but your basic salary will remain proportionally the same - so get the highest rate of pay you can.

webTitle: Working lives: Corporate espionage

fields.headline: Spies in suits
fields.standfirst:
UK firms have never been more desperate for their rivals' trade secrets - and the growing number of corporate intelligence agents will go to almost any lengths to obtain them, says Esther Addley

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: UK firms have never been more desperate for their rivals' trade secrets - and the growing number of corporate intelligence agents will go to almost any lengths to obtain them, says Esther Addley.
fields.body:
It was 11.30pm on a cold Sunday evening when the phone rang. It had been a long shift, and the lone warehouse security guard was glad to hear a friendly voice. "Hello, mate. What time do you open in the morning for deliveries?" Just an HGV driver, obviously, probably working for himself. The security guard gave him directions to the warehouse.

"Is it better to get there early to beat the queue," asked the caller, "or are there enough loading bays to cope with demand?" The two fell into friendly conversation. "I suppose things get busy in the mornings. How many loading bays have you got? And just out of interest, who else delivers to the warehouse?"

After a few more minutes of idle chat the caller hung up, and the security guard returned to his cup of tea and his newspaper. And in a small office in north London, the delivery driver replaced the receiver with satisfaction. Bingo.

It is unlikely that the security guard ever realised the significance of the chat, or the value of the information he had so casually given away. Because the "delivery driver" was no such thing: he was, instead, an operative from Aware, an investigative consultancy hired by a competitor of the warehouse firm to find out its loading-bay capacity and the names of its major clients.

The firm knew that demand for warehouse space in the area was likely to increase, but wanted to find out its competitors' capabilities before building an extension to its own premises. And all it took was one brief, friendly chat with a junior employee.

Forget market research, strategic planning, supply chain management or whatever it was you thought made your company successful. Chances are - particularly if you work in telecommunications, or pharmaceuticals, or manufacturing, or just about any competitive environment - that your company is increasingly pinning its success on trying to work out exactly what its rivals are up to. And a growing number of consultants skilled in getting hold of that information are ready and willing to offer their services to give your company the competitive edge, by fair means or - occasionally - foul.

This is the world of competitive intelligence, once seen as a rather shady side to corporate affairs, but increasingly viewed as a legitimate tool to help firms steal a march on their rivals. Most big American companies now have an internal CI unit, dedicated to analysing the competitive marketplace; they are likely also to use external investigators to complement this function. Fuld and Co, one of the oldest CI consultancies in the US, says it has advised more than half the Fortune 500 companies.

The once whispered-about world of CI is increasingly overground and - like all good American innovations - over here. The Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals (SCIP) now has 200 members in the UK - a fraction of its global membership of 7,000, but a figure which is steadily on the increase. Most major telecoms and pharmaceuticals companies in Britain are now believed to have their own intelligence departments, while smaller firms in a competitive marketplace are likely to have a lone CI worker who keeps an eye on what other players are up to.

In the knowledge economy, information is the commodity that really matters. "The fundamental is that there are huge amounts at stake when you make business decisions these days," says Bill Waite, managing director and senior counsel at the Risk Advisory Group, which claims to be the biggest CI consultancy in Europe.

"The more you know, not only about your own strengths but about your competitors', the more likely it is that you will reach a positive business transaction rather than a negative one. So the pressure to obtain good information is increasing. It is becoming a very big business. More and more companies are starting to do this kind of work, including the major consultancy firms, who wouldn't have touched this area five years ago."

There are good reasons why respected firms thought twice about developing intelligence-gathering wings, since activities falling into the broad category of competitive intelligence have not always earned the practice the most honourable of reputations.

In May last year an executive from car giant General Motors was indicted on charges that in 1996 he stole secret GM documents, including plans for new car models, supplier prices and details of a new assembly operation called "Plant X", and turned them over to Volkswagen. The German manufacturer paid GM $100m in compensation three years ago.

An employee working for a Canadian distributor of Gillette also paid heavily for sharing confidential information: he sold plans for Gillette's Mach-3 razor to arch-rivals Bic - and was jailed for 27 months for his efforts.

CI practitioners scramble to distance themselves from this kind of behaviour, more accurately described as corporate espionage and unequivocally illegal in most countries. Nonetheless, they are still called upon frequently to defend themselves against charges that the practice inhabits the slightly grubby margins of ethical business dealings.

This is doubtless because the juiciest examples of corporate information warfare - the ones that hit the headlines - invariably involve a level of intrigue that most chief executives would be embarrassed to admit to their shareholders. In the late 1980s, for instance, British Airways commissioned Kroll Associates, one of the biggest US-based corporate investigators, to look into rivals Air Europe as part of their well-documented "dirty tricks" against Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic. The larger airline was later forced to pay record libel damages to the entrepreneur.

Larry Ellison, the chairman of software giant Oracle, felt no compunction in admitting in June that his company had used private detectives to snoop on contractors working for Microsoft. Ellison argued that it had been his "civic duty" to set investigators rummaging through the rubbish of the lobby group the Association for Competitive Technology, looking for evidence that Microsoft was paying the lobby group to influence its antitrust case. The practice, known as "dumpster diving", is frowned upon by those who try to gather information from more ethical sources.

"We always seek to distance ourselves from the less ethical kind of practice," says Ted Howard-Jones, business development manager at Current Analysis, a consultancy firm specialising in the telecoms industry. "In the UK, people cannot put into perspective the tiny minority of cases where illegal or unethical conduct takes place." He points to SCIP's code of ethics, to which all members sign up, and insists that the vast majority of CI work involves collating information already in the public domain.

Arthur Weiss, a managing partner at Aware, agrees. "It is not in my interests to lie in order to get information, and I'm going to be found out if I do. And if I call back I would have to remember who I said I was. There will be times that I won't get the information and someone who follows a different ethical rule will. But I prefer to be able to sleep at night."

But surely masquerading as someone else to get hold of sensitive information, or at least allowing them to believe that you are an innocent caller, is a bit ethically suspect? "We wouldn't identify the client - we never identify the client - but we will always identify ourselves. I would say I was calling from a research company. Certainly if I was asked." Talking to someone who doesn't appreciate the value of the information is often the best way to get hold of sensitive facts and figures, he admits.

SCIP insists that the worst excesses of rogue CI practitioners are a thing of the past, particularly since the US introduced the Economic Espionage Act in 1996, under which the FBI is believed to be investigating 800 cases of corporate misbehaviour. Howard-Jones argues that the Data Protection Act is an even more rigid constraint on the activities of information gatherers in this country.

But with the demand for corporate investigations booming at an exponential rate, it is inevitable that companies and consultants will continue to dance round the more precarious limits of the law in order to get hold of that crucial figure.

"It's the speed of change. Look at the product life cycle. You now want a new mobile phone every six months, not every three years, and it's going to get faster. Many of the old-fashioned methods of planning that companies once used are now completely redundant. Five-year plans do not exist any more.

"Businesses don't make serious plans more than a year, or at most 18 months ahead. That's why you need to react so quickly, and that's why it is vital that you have information about what your competitor is up to. If you get it wrong, you don't have the time to catch up."
