webTitle: Pick of the week

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: This week, a surreal interview double-hander, a scary time with a first-time flyer, an ambitious film project for January, and the Biotic Baking Brigade
fields.trailText: This week, a surreal interview double-hander, a scary time with a first-time flyer, an ambitious film project for January, and the Biotic Baking Brigade
fields.body:
Let Go
(www.hypnotic.com)
This crisp black-and-white comedy about a nervous job applicant is deftly played and directed, but it's Gilbert Girion's smart script that keeps all the balls in the air. He weaves a cat's cradle of dialogue which is both horribly believable and increasingly surreal, as two men wrestle for control of an interview. A dry martini of a movie to be savoured while your boss is safely out of the office. (KS)
 View the film (14mins)

Coming of Age
(Atom Film)
Little Jim finds the fellow passenger from hell on his first plane trip in this movie which features a 360 degree picture that allows - in fact demands - that the viewer swivel the camera to follow the action. Just put your screen pointer in the video window and sweep it (gently) in the direction of the dialogue to follow Jim's nightmare journey. Try and have a second viewing too, to catch the frantic playlets being enacted elsewhere on the screen. We chose to be charitable about the weak ending, which has a twist-in-the-tail that isn't up to the standard of The New Arrival, Atom's first experiment with storytelling in the round. (KS)
 View the film (7.35mins)

Stop for a Minute
Stop for a Minute is a month long short-film-on-the web project offering 31 films in 31 days. A single, one-minute film is being released each day throughout January and an impressive team of film-makers and artists, including acclaimed animator Simon Pummey, Pussyfoot Records supremo Howie B and REM frontman Michael Stipe, has been assembled. The films themselves range in quality and subject matter. On one end you have Katie Hill's Two Artist's Piss on Duchamp's Urinal, which is little more than raw, unedited video feed of, well the title says it all. At the other end you have a heavily filtered performance piece by artist Adam Chodzko. Most of the films are worth a butcher's and the whole thing is wrapped up in some lovely interface design. As the song says, it only takes a minute, unless you're on a dial-up at home that is. (SD)
 View the film

Pies the Limit
(www.regenerationtv.com)
An overripe tomato may be the dissenter's weapon of choice this side of the Atlantic, but in the States the good old custard pie still rules. This 30-minute documentary follows the work of the Biotic Baking Brigade as they ask the question: "How wealthy and powerful will you look with pie dripping from your face?" Unfortunately the film soon becomes a little undigestible as it opts for a heavy handed and partisan approach that eschews much of the joyous situationism that flan-flinging offers up. Still, scenes of economist Milton Friedman and Monsanto chief Robert Shapiro wiping custard pie from their face are priceless. (SD)

He weaves a cat's cradle of dialogue which is both horribly believable and increasingly surreal, as two men wrestle for control of an interview. A dry martini of a movie to be savoured while your boss is safely out of the office. Just put your screen pointer in the video window and sweep it (gently) in the direction of the dialogue to follow Jim's nightmare journey. Try and have a second viewing too, to catch the frantic playlets being enacted elsewhere on the screen. We chose to be charitable about the weak ending, which has a twist-in-the-tail that isn't up to the standard of The New Arrival, Atom's first experiment with storytelling in the round. A single, one-minute film is being released each day throughout January and an impressive team of film-makers and artists, including acclaimed animator Simon Pummey, Pussyfoot Records supremo Howie B and REM frontman Michael Stipe, has been assembled. The films themselves range in quality and subject matter. On one end you have Katie Hill's Two Artist's Piss on Duchamp's Urinal, which is little more than raw, unedited video feed of, well the title says it all. webTitle: Review: Juan Diego Florez

fields.headline: Has Peru produced the next Pavarotti?
fields.standfirst:
Juan Diego Florez
St John's Smith Square, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Juan Diego Florez
St John's Smith Square, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
It would seem that the 21st century has found the first of its great tenors. When Juan Diego Florez finished his solo recital at St John's Smith Square, something akin to pandemonium broke out, as everyone rose to their feet clamouring for more. The elegant young Peruvian, who has already wowed audiences at Covent Garden in Rossini's Otello and La Cenerentola, is now very much a star.

One hopes it won't go to his head, for a certain innocence, a quality of guileless naivety and an unselfconscious ability to communicate the pleasure he takes in singing, are all part of his style and appeal. It could be catastrophic if he started giving himself airs, as tenors are wont to do.

A specialist in the bel canto repertory, he opted for a taxing programme of arias and songs that included the daring and the reputedly impossible. Most tenors junk Almaviva's second act scena from Rossini's The Barber of Seville on the grounds that it is unsingable. Florez closed the first half of his recital with it, spinning out its protracted phrases with an exquisite ease, the coloratura flashing and twinkling with spontaneous accuracy and expressive warmth.

He also chose A Mes Amis from Donizetti's La Fille du Régiment, with its infamous nine top Cs. One was vaguely conscious of a gauntlet being thrown down, for it was Luciano Pavarotti's singing of the aria 35 years ago at Covent Garden that made him famous. Riotously exuberant, Florez sang it in Italian rather than French, the high Cs pinging with thrilling accuracy.

Throughout, it was the liquidity of Florez's voice - the sumptuous ease and swiftness with which it moves and the generous ebb and flow of golden tone - that took your breath away, even when he chose material that avoids the consciously spectacular. He tackled songs by Tosti, infusing them with a limpidity and a passionate intensity that cut away all the usual associations with Victorian stuffiness.

A group of Peruvian songs by Rosa Ayarza de Morales found him exulting in their catchy Afro-Hispanic cross-rhythms and syncopations. During the first of these, When the Turtledove Cries, he suddenly stopped. "I've got lost," he giggled. It is one of those moments in a recital that could cause a singer to lose nerve. "As you know, I should know this song by heart. Do you mind if I start again?" No one did, and his second rendition - complete this time - was different from his first, with an inward, innate stillness replacing mercurial wit and flickering irony. It would be wrong to say the evening was without its flaws. He took a while to warm up, in a couple of Mozart arias in which you were conscious of a lack of warmth in tone during some of his soft singing. His pianist, Vincenzo Scalera, was occasionally heavy-handed and indelicate. None of this ultimately mattered as everyone was swept away by the beauty and the joy of it all.
